('71', 0, 0, 1, 0) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 1
('71', 0, 1, 2, 41) 1. INTERVIEW TO DR.
('71', 0, 2, 3, 61) [February 25, 1937] 2
('71', 0, 3, 4, 83) GANDHIJI: I shall certainly give you my reaction to Christianity.
('71', 0, 3, 5, 149) Even when I was 18 I came in touch with good Christians in London.
('71', 0, 3, 6, 216) Before that I had come in touch with what I used then to call ‘beef and beer bottle Christianity’, for these were regarded as the indispensable criteria of a man becoming a Christian, with also a third thing, namely, adoption of a European style of dress.
('71', 0, 3, 7, 472) Those Christians were parodying St. Paul’s teaching—‘Call thou nothing unclean’.
('71', 0, 3, 8, 553) I went to London, therefore, with that prejudice against Christianity.
('71', 0, 3, 9, 624) I came across good Christians there who placed the Bible in my hands.
('71', 0, 3, 10, 694) Then I met numerous Christians in South Africa, and I have since grown to this belief that Christianity is as good and as true a religion as my own.
('71', 0, 3, 11, 843) For a time I struggled with the question, ‘which was the true religion out of those I know?
('71', 0, 3, 12, 935) But ultimately I came to the deliberate conviction that there was no such thing as only one true religion, every other being false.
('71', 0, 3, 13, 1067) There is no religion that is absolutely perfect.
('71', 0, 3, 14, 1116) All are equally imperfect or more or less perfect, hence the conclusion that Christianity is as good and true as my own religion.
('71', 0, 3, 15, 1246) But so also about Islam or Zoroastrianism or Judaism.
('71', 0, 3, 16, 1300) I therefore do not take as literally true the text 3 that Jesus is the only begotten Son of God.
('71', 0, 3, 17, 1397) God cannot be the exclusive father and I cannot ascribe exclusive divinity to Jesus.
('71', 0, 3, 18, 1482) He is as divine as Krishna or Rama or Mahomed or Zoroaster.
('71', 0, 3, 19, 1542) Similarly I do not regard every word of the Bible as the inspired word of God even as I do not regard every word of the Vedas or the Koran as inspired.
('71', 0, 3, 20, 1694) The sum total of each of these books is certainly inspired, but I miss that inspiration in many of the things taken individually.
('71', 0, 3, 21, 1824) The Bible is as much a book of religion with me as the Gita and the Koran.
('71', 0, 3, 22, 1899) Therefore I am not interested in weaning you from Christianity and making you a Hindu, and I would not relish your designs upon
('71', 0, 4, 23, 2027) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('71', 0, 4, 24, 2077) Dr. Crane was a clergyman from America, who had given up active service in the midst of World War I in disgust for its violence.
('71', 0, 4, 25, 2206) He wanted to know Gandhiji’s attitude towards Christianity and also religion in general.
('71', 0, 4, 26, 2295) 2 From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary 3 St. John, III 16
('71', 1, 0, 1, 2361) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 1, 1, 2, 2401) me, if you had any, to convert me to Christianity!
('71', 1, 1, 3, 2452) I would also dispute your claim that Christianity is the only true religion.
('71', 1, 1, 4, 2529) It is also a true religion, a noble religion, and along with other religions it has contributed to raise the moral height of mankind.
('71', 1, 1, 5, 2663) But it has yet to make a greater contribution.
('71', 1, 1, 6, 2710) After all what are 2,000 years in the life of a religion?
('71', 1, 1, 7, 2768) Just now Christianity comes to yearning mankind in a tainted form.
('71', 1, 1, 8, 2835) Fancy Bishops supporting slaughter in the name of Christianity.
('71', 1, 2, 9, 2899) CRANE: But, when you say that all religions are true, what do you do when there are conflicting counsels?
('71', 1, 3, 10, 3005) G. I have no difficulty in hitting upon the truth, because I go by certain fundamental maxims.
('71', 1, 3, 11, 3100) Truth is superior to everything and I reject what conflicts with it.
('71', 1, 3, 12, 3169) Similarly that which is in conflict with non violence should be rejected.
('71', 1, 3, 13, 3243) And on matters which can be reasoned out, that which conflicts with Reason must also be rejected.
('71', 1, 4, 14, 3341) C. In matters which can be reasoned out?
('71', 1, 5, 15, 3382) G. Yes, there are subjects where Reason cannot take us far and we have to accept things on faith.
('71', 1, 5, 16, 3480) Faith then does not contradict Reason but transcends it.
('71', 1, 5, 17, 3537) Faith is a kind of sixth sense which works in cases which are without the purview of Reason.
('71', 1, 5, 18, 3630) Well then, given these three criteria, I can have no difficulty in examining all claims made on behalf of religion.
('71', 1, 5, 19, 3746) Thus to believe that Jesus is the only begotten son of God is to me against Reason, for God can’t marry and beget children.
('71', 1, 5, 20, 3870) The word ‘son’ there can only be used in a figurative sense.
('71', 1, 5, 21, 3931) In that sense everyone who stands in the position of Jesus is a begotten son of God.
('71', 1, 5, 22, 4016) If a man is spiritually miles ahead of us we may say that he is in a special sense the son of God, though we are all children of God.
('71', 1, 5, 23, 4150) We repudiate the relationship in our lives, whereas his life is a witness to that relationship.
('71', 1, 6, 24, 4246) C. Then you will recognize degrees of divinity.
('71', 1, 6, 25, 4294) Would you not say that Jesus was the most divine?
('71', 1, 6, 26, 4344) G. No, for the simple reason that we have no data.
('71', 1, 6, 27, 4395) Historically we have more data about Mahomed than anyone else because he was more recent in time.
('71', 1, 6, 28, 4493) For Jesus there are less data and still less for Buddha, Rama and Krishna; and when we know so little about them, is it not preposterous to say that one of them was more divine thananother?
('71', 1, 6, 29, 4683) In fact even if there were a great deal of data available, no judge should shoulder the burden of sifting all the evidence, if only for the reason that it requires a highly spiritual person to guage
('71', 2, 0, 1, 4882) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 3
('71', 2, 1, 2, 4923) the degree of divinity, of the subjects he examines.
('71', 2, 1, 3, 4976) To say that Jesus was 99 per cent divine, and Mahomed 50 per cent, and Krishna 10 per cent, is to arrogate to oneself a function which really does not belong to man.
('71', 2, 2, 4, 5142) C. But, let us take a debatable point.
('71', 2, 2, 5, 5181) Supposing I was debating between whether violence is justified or not.
('71', 2, 2, 6, 5252) Mahomedanism would say one thing, Christianity another.
('71', 2, 3, 7, 5308) G. Then I must decide with the help of the tests I have suggested.
('71', 2, 4, 8, 5375) C. But does not Mahomed prescribe the use of the sword in certain circumstances?
('71', 2, 4, 9, 5456) G. I suppose most Muslims will agree.
('71', 2, 4, 10, 5494) But I read religion in a different way.
('71', 2, 4, 11, 5534) Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan derives his belief in non violence from the Koran, and the Bishop of London derives his belief in violence from the Bible.
('71', 2, 4, 12, 5687) I derive my belief in non violence from the Gita, Whereas there are others who read violence in it.
('71', 2, 4, 13, 5787) But if the worst came of the worst and if I came to the conclusion that the Koran teaches violence, I would still reject violence, but I would not therefore say that the Bible is superior to the Koran or that Mahomed is inferior to Jesus.
('71', 2, 4, 14, 6026) It is not my function to judge Mahomed and Jesus.
('71', 2, 4, 15, 6076) It is enough that my non violence is independent of the sanction of scriptures.
('71', 2, 4, 16, 6156) But the fact remains that religious books have a hold upon mankind which other books have not.
('71', 2, 4, 17, 6251) They have made a greater impression on me than Mark Twain or, to take a more appropriate instance, Emerson.
('71', 2, 4, 18, 6359) Emerson was a thinker.
('71', 2, 4, 19, 6382) Jesus and Mahomed were through and through men of action in a sense Emerson would never be.
('71', 2, 4, 20, 6474) Their power was derived from their faith in God.
('71', 2, 5, 21, 6523) C. I will take a concrete instance now to show what I mean.
('71', 2, 5, 22, 6583) I was terribly shocked on Monday.
('71', 2, 5, 23, 6617) I counted 37 cows slain on the streets by Muslims in the name of religion, and in offence to the Hindu sentiment.
('71', 2, 5, 24, 6731) I asked the Hindu friend who travelled with me why the Muslims did so.
('71', 2, 5, 25, 6802) He said it was part of their religion.
('71', 2, 5, 26, 6841) ‘Is it part of their spiritual growth?’ I asked him.
('71', 2, 5, 27, 6894) He said it was.
('71', 2, 5, 28, 6910) I met a Mussalman who said, ‘We both please God and ourselves’.
('71', 2, 5, 29, 6974) Now here was a Mussalman revelling in a thing that outrages you and me too.
('71', 2, 5, 30, 7050) Do you think all this is counter to the Koran?
('71', 2, 5, 31, 7097) G. I do indeed 1. Just as many Hindu practices, e.g., untouchability—are no part of Hindu religion, I say that cow slaughter is no part of Islam.
('71', 2, 5, 32, 7243) But I do not wrestle with the Muslims who believe that it is part of Islam.
('71', 2, 6, 33, 7319) 1 Here Gandhiji referred the interviewer to the article “Need for Tolerance”, 13 3 1937
('71', 3, 0, 1, 7407) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 3, 1, 2, 7447) C. What do you say to the attempts to convert?
('71', 3, 2, 3, 7494) G. I strongly resent these overtures to utterly ignorant men.
('71', 3, 2, 4, 7556) I can perhaps understand overtures made to me, as indeed they are being made.
('71', 3, 2, 5, 7634) For they can reason with me and I can reason with them.
('71', 3, 2, 6, 7690) But I certainly resent the overtures made to Harijans.
('71', 3, 2, 7, 7745) When a Christian preacher goes and says to a Harijan that Jesus was the only begotten son of God, he will give him a blank stare.
('71', 3, 2, 8, 7875) Then he holds out all kinds of inducements which debase Christianity.
('71', 3, 3, 9, 7945) C. Would you say a Harijan is not capable of reason?
('71', 3, 4, 10, 7998) G. He is.
('71', 3, 4, 11, 8008) For instance, if you try to take work out of him without payment, he will not give it.
('71', 3, 4, 12, 8095) He also has a sense of ethical values.
('71', 3, 4, 13, 8134) But when you ask him to understand theological beliefs and categories he will not understand anything.
('71', 3, 4, 14, 8237) I could not do so even when I was 17 and had a fair share of education and training.
('71', 3, 4, 15, 8322) The orthodox Hindus have so horribly neglected the Harijan that it is astonishing how he adheres to the Hindu faith.
('71', 3, 4, 16, 8439) Now I say it is outrageous for others to shake his faith.
('71', 3, 5, 17, 8497) C. What about a man who says he is commanded by God to do violence?
('71', 3, 6, 18, 8565) G. There you would not put another God before him.
('71', 3, 6, 19, 8616) You need not disturb his religion, but you will disturb his reason.
('71', 3, 7, 20, 8684) C. But take Hitler.
('71', 3, 7, 21, 8704) He says he is carrying out God’s behest in persecuting the Jews and killing his opponents.
('71', 3, 8, 22, 8795) G. You will not pit one word of God against another word of God.
('71', 3, 8, 23, 8860) But you will have to bear down his reason.
('71', 3, 8, 24, 8903) For him you will have to produce a miracle which you will do when Christians will learn the art of dying without killing in defence of what they hold dearer then religion.
('71', 3, 8, 25, 9075) But we can go on arguing like this endlessly.
('71', 3, 8, 26, 9121) And then I may tell you that you are talking against time.
('71', 3, 9, 27, 9180) And with this Gandhiji looked at the watch.
('71', 3, 10, 28, 9224) C. Just one question, then.
('71', 3, 10, 29, 9252) Would you say then that your religion is a synthesis of all religions?
('71', 3, 11, 30, 9323) G. Yes, if you will.
('71', 3, 11, 31, 9344) But I would call that synthesis Hinduism, and for you the synthesis will be Christianity.
('71', 3, 11, 32, 9434) If I did not do so, you would always be patronizing me, as many Christians do now, saying, ‘How nice it would be if Gandhi accepted Christianity,’ and Muslims would be doing the same, saying, ‘How nice it would be if Gandhi accepted Islam!’ That immediately puts a barrier between you and me.
('71', 3, 11, 33, 9727) Do you see that?
('71', 4, 0, 1, 9744) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 5
('71', 4, 1, 2, 9785) C. I do.
('71', 4, 1, 3, 9794) Just one last question.
('71', 4, 1, 4, 9818) In your Hinduism do you basically include the caste system?
('71', 4, 2, 5, 9878) G. I do not.
('71', 4, 2, 6, 9891) Hinduism does not believe in caste.
('71', 4, 2, 7, 9927) I would obliterate it at once.
('71', 4, 2, 8, 9958) But I believe in varnadharma, which is the law of life.
('71', 4, 2, 9, 10014) I believe that some people are born to teach and some to defend and some to engage in trade and agriculture and some to do manual labour, so much so that these occupations become hereditary.
('71', 4, 2, 10, 10205) The law of varna is nothing but the law of conservation of energy.
('71', 4, 2, 11, 10272) Why should my son not be a scavengar if I am one?
('71', 4, 3, 12, 10322) C. Indeed?
('71', 4, 3, 13, 10333) Do you go so far?
('71', 4, 3, 14, 10351) G. I do, because I hold a scavenger’s profession in no way inferior to a clergyman’s.
('71', 4, 4, 15, 10437) C. I grant that, but should Lincoln have been a wood chopper rather than President of the U.S.A.?
('71', 4, 5, 16, 10535) G. But why should not a wood chopper be a President of the United States?
('71', 4, 5, 17, 10609) Gladstone used to chop wood.
('71', 4, 6, 18, 10638) C. But he did not accept it as his calling.
('71', 4, 6, 19, 10682) G. He would not have been worse off if he had done so.
('71', 4, 6, 20, 10737) What I mean is, one born a scavenger must earn his livelihood by being a scavenger, and then do whatever else he likes.
('71', 4, 6, 21, 10857) For a scanvenger is as worthy of his hire as a lawyer or your President.
('71', 4, 6, 22, 10930) That, according to me, is Hinduism.
('71', 4, 6, 23, 10966) There is no better communism on earth, and I have illustrated it with one verse from the Upanishads which means: God pervades all—animate and inanimate.
('71', 4, 6, 24, 11119) Therefore renounce all and dedicate it to God and then live.
('71', 4, 6, 25, 11180) The right of living is thus derived from renunciation.
('71', 4, 6, 26, 11235) It does not say, ‘When all do their part of the work I too will do it’.
('71', 4, 6, 27, 11307) It says, ‘Don’t bother about others, do your job first and leave the rest to Him’.
('71', 4, 6, 28, 11390) Varnadharma acts even as the law of gravitation.
('71', 4, 6, 29, 11439) I cannot cancel it or its working by trying to jump higher and higher day by day till gravitation ceases to work.
('71', 4, 6, 30, 11553) That effort will be vain.
('71', 4, 6, 31, 11579) So is the effort to jump over one another.
('71', 4, 6, 32, 11622) The law of varna is the antithesis of competition which kills.
('71', 4, 6, 33, 11685) Harijan, 6 3 1937
('71', 4, 7, 34, 11703) 2. LETTER TO KAMALNAYAN BAJAJ
('71', 4, 8, 35, 11733) SEGAON, February 26, 1937
('71', 4, 9, 36, 11759) KAMALNAYAN, I got your letter.
('71', 4, 9, 37, 11790) You are getting more and more involved and here everybody is talking of calling you back soon.
('71', 4, 9, 38, 11885) Your father in 
('71', 5, 0, 1, 11901) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 5, 1, 2, 11941) law wants it to be early.
('71', 5, 1, 3, 11967) So does Jankibehn.
('71', 5, 1, 4, 11986) Father also is practically of the same view.
('71', 5, 1, 5, 12031) I am neutral, though I don’t believe that you will bring home much from there.
('71', 5, 1, 6, 12110) But I wouldn’t approve of calling you back so long as you are eager to continue there.
('71', 5, 1, 7, 12197) If you wish to take up business, you should give up your desire for a degree.
('71', 5, 1, 8, 12275) What will you do after becoming a barrister?
('71', 5, 1, 9, 12320) Or a graduate?
('71', 5, 1, 10, 12335) As I understand you, you wish to earn money.
('71', 5, 1, 11, 12380) You do not wish to live on Father’s money or to become a sannyasi.
('71', 5, 1, 12, 12447) If I am right, business is the proper field for you endeavour.
('71', 5, 1, 13, 12510) If you agree with this, give up the desire to be a barrister or to get a degree.
('71', 5, 1, 14, 12591) Your English must have improved sufficiently by now.
('71', 5, 1, 15, 12644) If, however, you are keen on a degree and on going to Oxford or Cambridge, you may see Deenbandhu Andrews.
('71', 5, 1, 16, 12751) Those whom I know at Oxford and Cambridge, I know through him.
('71', 5, 1, 17, 12814) Please, therefore, see him.
('71', 5, 1, 18, 12842) He will make the necessary arrangement for you.
('71', 5, 1, 19, 12890) He lives at Cambridge.
('71', 5, 1, 20, 12913) You know him, of course, but I am writing to him all the same.
('71', 5, 1, 21, 12976) He will, therefore, remember when you write to him.
('71', 5, 1, 22, 13028) His address is: Master’s Lodge, Pembroke College, Cambridge.
('71', 5, 1, 23, 13089) Do whatever you do after full deliberation.
('71', 5, 1, 24, 13133) Keep writing to me.

('71', 5, 3, 28, 13264) 3. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('71', 5, 4, 29, 13292) February 26, 1937
('71', 5, 5, 30, 13310) KRISHNACHANDRA, Your letter.
('71', 5, 5, 31, 13339) What I meant was that if nothing is settled about you till then, you should do in July whatever you want to do.
('71', 5, 5, 32, 13451) I shall also help you to the best of my ability.
('71', 5, 5, 33, 13500) I hardly know anything about Ramana Maharshi.

('71', 5, 7, 36, 13661) 4. OUR CATTLE WEALTH
('71', 5, 8, 37, 13682) This is being written on Bakr Id day—a day of rejoicing for Mussalmans and grief for Hindus.
('71', 5, 8, 38, 13775) It is day of grief for Hindus because their Mussalman brethern slaughter cows for sacrifice though
('71', 6, 0, 1, 13874) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 7
('71', 6, 1, 2, 13915) they know that the cow is an object of worship and veneration for Hindus.
('71', 6, 1, 3, 13989) Though I hold the cow as much in veneration as any Hindu and am responsible for bringing into being the— in my opinion— only scientific society for effectively protecting the cow, I have never sympathized with the Hindu grief and the implied anger against Mussalmans on Bakr Id.
('71', 6, 1, 4, 14268) The latter are undoubtedly foolish and obstinate in that they slaughter the cow and needlessly wound Hindu susceptibility.
('71', 6, 1, 5, 14391) For there is no religious obligation on the part of Mussalmans to kill the cow on Bakr Id or any other day.
('71', 6, 1, 6, 14499) I have heard some Mussalmans arguing that Hindus by their worship of the cow make it obligatory on them to kill the cow.
('71', 6, 1, 7, 14620) This borders on compulsion.
('71', 6, 1, 8, 14648) But if the Mussalman is foolish and obstinate, the Hindu is criminally ignorant and indirectly becomes party to the slaughter of the cow by the Mussalman.
('71', 6, 1, 9, 14803) For cows are sold by Hindus as a rule.
('71', 6, 1, 10, 14842) Hindu grief and anger are uncalled for.
('71', 6, 1, 11, 14882) Hindu ignorance is responsible for many more deaths of cows than the deaths casused by the Mussalmans’ slaughter of the cow for one day in the year.
('71', 6, 1, 12, 15031) Be it noted that Hindus are apparently quite reconciled to cow slaughter on days other than Bakr Id.
('71', 6, 1, 13, 15132) I have in my possession startling authentic figures showing the annual slaughter of cattle and deaths from natural causes.
('71', 6, 1, 14, 15255) According to the livestock census of 1935 about 80 per cent die naturally and 20 per cent are slaughtered.
('71', 6, 1, 15, 15362) The percentage of natural death, however, varies according to locality.
('71', 6, 1, 16, 15434) Where grazing conditions are good and cultivation careful, natural deaths fall as low as 7 per cent, and in famine zones they rise to 30 per cent.
('71', 6, 1, 17, 15581) In the Bombay Presidency (British) it is estimated that there were, in 1935, 74.5 lakhs of cattle.
('71', 6, 1, 18, 15680) Of these 9 lakhs died naturally against 2 lakhs by slaughter, i.e., 12 per cent against 3 per cent.
('71', 6, 1, 19, 15780) In 1935 in British India, including Bengal and Bihar and Orissa, there were over eight crores of cows against just under three crores of buffaloes.
('71', 6, 1, 20, 15928) Comparison between the census of 1935 and 1930 shows that buffalo wealth is on the increase three times that of the cow.
('71', 6, 1, 21, 16049) Now it is common knowledge that the cow is generally owned by Hindus.
('71', 6, 1, 22, 16119) If they removed their unpardonable ignorance, they could easily prevent many deaths from natural causes.
('71', 6, 1, 23, 16224) I reproduce immediately below this note two extracts 1 showing why so many cattle die annually and what can and should be done to prevent this
('71', 6, 2, 24, 16367) 1 These are not reproduced here.
('71', 7, 0, 1, 16400) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 7, 1, 2, 16440) tremenduous waste of wealth.
('71', 7, 1, 3, 16469) Time was when the number of cows was the measure of man’s wealth.
('71', 7, 1, 4, 16535) Today the cows are a drag on a man’s possessions.
('71', 7, 1, 5, 16585) It is almost like depreciation of currency.
('71', 7, 1, 6, 16629) The only difference is that prevention of depreciation of cattle or rather cow currency is possible by internal effort.
('71', 7, 1, 7, 16749) The effort is threefold: (1) No waste of energy over persuading Mussalmans to give up cow slaughter, whether for sacrifice or food.
('71', 7, 1, 8, 16881) They must be put on their own honour.
('71', 7, 1, 9, 16919) (2) Exclusive concentration on improvement of the cow and therefore giving up of buffalo milk and ghee.
('71', 7, 1, 10, 17023) (3) Exclusive use of dead cattle hide and free use other than for food of all the parts of carcasses, and improvement in tanning.
('71', 7, 1, 11, 17153) The material for improvement is ready at hand in the numerous pinjarapoles and goshalas covering the whole land.
('71', 7, 1, 12, 17266) The only thing needful is to remove certain prejudices and to conduct these institutions on sound scientific lines.
('71', 7, 1, 13, 17382) Harijan, 27 2 1937
('71', 7, 2, 14, 17401) 5. VISIBLE AND INVISIBLE VICES
('71', 7, 3, 15, 17432) A khadi worker writes: 1
('71', 7, 4, 16, 17457) It is good question.
('71', 7, 4, 17, 17478) There should be no comparison of vices.
('71', 7, 4, 18, 17518) As for me, I look upon untruth as the root cause of all sins.
('71', 7, 4, 19, 17580) No institution which tolerates untruth can serve the community or survive for long.
('71', 7, 4, 20, 17664) But when a man resorts to untruthfulness, it assumes various forms.
('71', 7, 4, 21, 17732) It is a kind of immorality.
('71', 7, 4, 22, 17760) Untruth rarely parades itself in naked form.
('71', 7, 4, 23, 17805) An immoral person commits three sins.
('71', 7, 4, 24, 17843) He is guilty of untruthfulness because he hides his misbehaviour.
('71', 7, 4, 25, 17909) The misbehaviour itself is a sin.
('71', 7, 4, 26, 17943) And thirdly, it demoralizes the other person with whom he misbehaves.
('71', 7, 4, 27, 18013) All other vices which the correspondent has mentioned are abstract.
('71', 7, 4, 28, 18081) We can neither see them nor catch them.
('71', 7, 4, 29, 18121) They can be discussed only when they become manifest in action.
('71', 7, 4, 30, 18185) Then only is it possible to think of remedies for them.
('71', 7, 4, 31, 18241) Suppose a man hates another.
('71', 7, 4, 32, 18270) As long as that hatred does not lead to some action, the hatred cannot be criticized nor can the jealous person be improved.
('71', 7, 4, 33, 18395) But when that
('71', 7, 5, 34, 18409) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('71', 7, 5, 35, 18446) The correspondent had asked whether vices like untruth, jealousy and hatred were not more harmful than sexual lapses.
('71', 8, 0, 1, 18564) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 9
('71', 8, 1, 2, 18605) hatred causes any harm to another, then it can be condemned and the person deserves punishment.
('71', 8, 1, 3, 18701) The fact is, sexual immorality is given a long rope in the social as well as the legal code, although it causes great harm to society.
('71', 8, 1, 4, 18836) The thief gets stringent punishment and the poor fellow is almost ostracized by society.
('71', 8, 1, 5, 18925) But the fashionable debauchee moves freely and goes scot free.
('71', 8, 1, 6, 18988) The law turns a blind eye to him.
('71', 8, 1, 7, 19022) I am convinced that an institution pledged to the service of millions should have no room for debauchees, just as it has no place for thives and rowdies.
('71', 8, 1, 8, 19176) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 27 2 1937
('71', 8, 2, 9, 19214) 6. WHY SHOULD THREE ANNAS BE PAID?
('71', 8, 3, 10, 19249) I am discussing here a difficulty which I am faced with in Segaon in trying to put into practice to some extent the ideas which I had expressed regarding the rate of wages earned by women spinners for yarn spun by them.
('71', 8, 3, 11, 19469) I engage in, or permit, as little discussion as possible on the experiments which I am carrying on in Segaon and the hopes which I am entertaining because my experiments are still at a preliminary stage.
('71', 8, 3, 12, 19673) I neither show definite results nor see any myself.
('71', 8, 3, 13, 19725) I regard myself as an extremely cautious worker.
('71', 8, 3, 14, 19774) I work out each task in a scientific spirit.
('71', 8, 3, 15, 19819) A devotee of truth cannot function in any other way.
('71', 8, 3, 16, 19872) While working in that manner, I feel it would be thought improper for me to write anything at this stage about my experiments in Segaon.
('71', 8, 3, 17, 20009) But there can be nothing improper in saying what I have been unable to accomplish to this day.
('71', 8, 3, 18, 20104) Now, in my opinion, anyone who puts in one hour of diligent work should get one anna.
('71', 8, 3, 19, 20190) So that a woman who spins skilfully for an hour should also be paid one anna.
('71', 8, 3, 20, 20268) I have been unable to make any experienced person put this into effect; and that is as it should be.
('71', 8, 3, 21, 20369) If crores of Indians start earning an anna an hour, India would become an economically prosperous country.
('71', 8, 3, 22, 20476) Today, the average annual income of an Indian is fifty to sixty rupees; this is not the minimum income.
('71', 8, 3, 23, 20580) If instead, the minimum income becomes one hundred and eighty rupees no one would starve.
('71', 8, 3, 24, 20670) However, in Segaon, to this day, I have not been able to pay three annas for eight hours’ work to any unemployed person.
('71', 8, 3, 25, 20791) In Segaon the rate for a man is three annas and for a woman five to six pice.
('71', 8, 3, 26, 20869) Children of fifteen or sixteen earn something in between.
('71', 9, 0, 1, 20927) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 9, 1, 2, 20968) could have my way, I would see to it that women are paid the same wages as men.
('71', 9, 1, 3, 21048) But I have been unable to do even this little bit.
('71', 9, 1, 4, 21099) And I have been unable to pay, or make others pay, the same rate to the unemployed as is paid to labourers in Segaon.
('71', 9, 1, 5, 21217) This is because the rate I have mentioned applies to those who do not ordinarily remain unemployed.
('71', 9, 1, 6, 21317) What I desire is the capacity to pay three annas for eight hours’ labour to whosover comes in search of work.
('71', 9, 1, 7, 21427) I have not been able to achieve that or make much progress.
('71', 9, 1, 8, 21487) I cannot accept that I alone am to blame for this.
('71', 9, 1, 9, 21538) Partly no doubt my own failing is responsible.
('71', 9, 1, 10, 21585) But it is for this reason that I have proved for myself and others like me the necessity for living in village.
('71', 9, 1, 11, 21697) It is not true that a few months’ stay in the villages enables one to solve all its problems.
('71', 9, 1, 12, 21791) I have never imagined it can.
('71', 9, 1, 13, 21821) One can have a grasp of rural problems and find solutions for them only when one stays in a village like a true villager from three to five years.
('71', 9, 1, 14, 21968) Here I have merely noted the difficulties experienced in paying even the unemployed the wage of three annas.
('71', 9, 1, 15, 22077) At the root of this difficulty I see our inveterate idleness.
('71', 9, 1, 16, 22139) The unemployed are so indifferent that if entrusted with some work of which they have no experience, they are not even prepared to consider it.
('71', 9, 1, 17, 22283) They have formed the habit of agreeing to everything, so they will nod their heads in assent to any suggestion but will do nothing beyond that.
('71', 9, 1, 18, 22427) However, by mentioning these difficulties I have by no means expressed my despondency.
('71', 9, 1, 19, 22514) I have expressed my sympathy towards other colleagues who experience similar difficulty.
('71', 9, 1, 20, 22603) Idleness which has persisted for years cannot be got rid of all at once.
('71', 9, 1, 21, 22676) Patience is what is required.
('71', 9, 1, 22, 22706) We do not wish to give three annas or even more for eight hours’ work by way of a gift, but we wish to create conditions where people can earn this amount.
('71', 9, 1, 23, 22862) In trying to achieve this lies the education and the test of social workers as well as villagers.
('71', 9, 1, 24, 22960) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 28 2 1937
('71', 9, 2, 25, 23001) 7. DEFINITION OF POVERTY
('71', 9, 3, 26, 23026) While discussing the question of providing work to the poor living in villages, a gentleman writes to say:
('71', 9, 4, 27, 23133) You had once said that those who engaged labourers to plough their fields could not be called poor.
('71', 9, 4, 28, 23233) But that is not enough.
('71', 9, 4, 29, 23257) Can it be said that those who do not suffer from want of food and clothing and do not have to incur debts are not poor?
('71', 10, 0, 1, 23377) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 11
('71', 10, 1, 2, 23419) This question may be answered in the affirmative as well as in the negative.
('71', 10, 1, 3, 23496) If we consider the matter from the standpoint of health, few persons in the Indian climate suffer from want of clothes.
('71', 10, 1, 4, 23616) This is because innumerable persons can do with loincloths, and it may be said that it does not harm the health.
('71', 10, 1, 5, 23729) But even persons said to belong to the middle class do not get a proper diet from the nutritional standpoint.
('71', 10, 1, 6, 23839) Except for a few wealthy people, all others are unable to get sufficient milk, ghee, vegetables and fruit.
('71', 10, 1, 7, 23946) They may well afford a drop of dirty milk adulterated with water, and a small quantity of vegetables, but they never get fruit.
('71', 10, 1, 8, 24074) And because of the want of these three things, crores of people in India, including those of the middleclass, can never maintain good health.
('71', 10, 1, 9, 24216) Hence, if we examine the matter from the standpoint of health, the number of poor people increases greatly.
('71', 10, 1, 10, 24324) This however is not the standpoint of the correspondent.
('71', 10, 1, 11, 24381) For him the question of poverty has arisen in the context of the problem of a minimum wage.
('71', 10, 1, 12, 24473) My definition of poverty, if considered from that standpoint would run as follows: Those who, despite working the whole day, cannot earn even three annas are all poor, because the correspondent has before him only the problem of providing work to the unemployed in the villages.
('71', 10, 1, 13, 24752) Although this is an imperfect definition, it is of importance to workers.
('71', 10, 1, 14, 24826) The reason being that if poverty is considered from the standpoint of health, etc., all villagers and many city dwellers also would be regarded as poor—and actually, they are so.
('71', 10, 1, 15, 25005) But such a definition confuses the workers.
('71', 10, 1, 16, 25049) This does not mean that such persons should not be served.
('71', 10, 1, 17, 25108) The village worker is constantly faced with problems of sanitation, health and economic betterment.
('71', 10, 1, 18, 25208) He is constantly faced with problems of how people should get pure milk and butter milk in their own villages, how they can obtain vegetables and fruit, how those who do not get sufficient coverings for the winter can do so.
('71', 10, 1, 19, 25433) And his skill lies in solving these.
('71', 10, 1, 20, 25470) But no one can solve all problems at once.
('71', 10, 1, 21, 25513) It is for this very reason that I have given a working definition of poverty so that everyone can realize that it is their dharma to serve the maximum number of poor people and make a beginning in that direction.
('71', 10, 2, 22, 25726) [From Gujarati]
('71', 10, 3, 23, 25742) Harijanbandhu, 28 2 1937
('71', 11, 0, 1, 25767) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('71', 14, 7, 18, 31629) 17. LETTER TO SHARDABEHN C. SHAH
('71', 14, 8, 19, 31662) SEGAON, WARDHA, March 2, 1937
('71', 14, 9, 20, 31692) SHARDA, Received your letter.
('71', 14, 9, 21, 31722) There is no reason at all to be scared of hip baths.
('71', 14, 9, 22, 31775) The secret is that you should not feel cold while sitting in the tub and the body should be sufficiently warm after coming out of the tub.
('71', 14, 9, 23, 31914) For this, you should bring warmth to the body either by walking or by covering yourself up in bed or by pouring over yourself a few mugs of hot water after the hip bath.
('71', 15, 0, 1, 32084) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 15, 1, 2, 32125) Friction bath can be taken .
('71', 15, 1, 3, 32154) 1 The bather should perch on a stool, with the private parts kept away from the edge of the stool.
('71', 15, 1, 4, 32253) They should then be rubbed with a piece of cloth repeatedly soaked in the tub water.
('71', 15, 1, 5, 32338) This is what is called friction bath.
('71', 15, 1, 6, 32376) The idea behind it is as follows: there is a complex of nerves at the opening of the organ.
('71', 15, 1, 7, 32468) The effect on them spreads throughout the body with lightning speed.
('71', 15, 1, 8, 32537) This effect is quite the opposite of that produced by masturbation and other bad habits.
('71', 15, 1, 9, 32626) And this checks many diseases and cures many others.
('71', 15, 1, 10, 32679) Garlic should not be chewed.
('71', 15, 1, 11, 32708) It should be ground and mixed with vegetables like a sauce.
('71', 15, 1, 12, 32768) Some people take it with curds.
('71', 15, 1, 13, 32800) If youcan get fresh garlic it is better than dry garlic.
('71', 15, 1, 14, 32857) If sweet limes and oranges are available no other fruits are required.
('71', 15, 1, 15, 32928) If you can get good palm gur, you can carry on well with it.
('71', 15, 1, 16, 32989) You must get good milk.
('71', 15, 1, 17, 33013) A person like you cannot stay where good milk is not available.
('71', 15, 1, 18, 33077) Garlic never gives a cold, rather it cures a cold.
('71', 15, 1, 19, 33128) I can say without hesitation that the increase in Chimanlal’s weight is due to his taking earth treatment.
('71', 15, 2, 20, 33235) Blessings from BAPU

('71', 17, 1, 2, 35732) 20. INTERVIEW TO AN EGYPTIAN DEPUTATION 1
('71', 17, 2, 3, 35774) March 3, 1937
('71', 17, 3, 4, 35788) “It was impossible to come to India and go away without seeing you”, they said to Gandhiji, to which Gandhiji jokingly said: And yet you come here at the fag end of your visit.
('71', 17, 4, 5, 35965) With Gandhiji the only topic they discussed was that of cementing the relation between India and Egypt.
('71', 17, 5, 6, 36069) GANDHIJI: I should heartily welcome the co operation.
('71', 17, 6, 7, 36123) SHEIKH IBRAHIM EL GIBALI: We hope the day will not be far off when India regains her past glory and revives her ancient civilization.
('71', 17, 6, 8, 36257) We have many things in common, climate, colour, food, and we are orientals.
('71', 17, 6, 9, 36333) The time has come for us to come closer together.
('71', 17, 7, 10, 36383) HABIB AHMED : We have discovered it is not good fot both the countries to rely on their older generations.
('71', 17, 7, 11, 36490) They should rely more on the younger generations.
('71', 17, 7, 12, 36540) Our youths should go to India and yours should come to Egypt as sportsmen.
('71', 17, 8, 13, 36615) G. Not only may we have an exchange and a mixing together in the field of sport but we should have it in the field of education.
('71', 17, 8, 14, 36744) We should invite professors from Egypt and you should invite those from India, so that we may develop cultural contacts.
('71', 17, 9, 15, 36865) SHEIKH IBRAHIM EL GIBALI: This end can be attained if there is an intellectual fusion of blood between both countries.
('71', 17, 9, 16, 36984) G. That is true, and to reach some kind of solution I would suggest your making a public declaration of this kind.
('71', 17, 9, 17, 37099) I make an offer.
('71', 17, 9, 18, 37116) If you kindly send an Egyptian lad of intelligence and resourcefulness, we will welcome him and adopt him here.
('71', 17, 9, 19, 37228) You will see the maker of this place, Jamnalal Bajaj.
('71', 17, 9, 20, 37282) There is not a public institution here which does not owe its existence to him.

('71', 18, 9, 19, 39077) SURENDRA, I am having consultations about the date of your marriage.
('71', 18, 9, 20, 39146) I gather that you desire the marriage to take place in proper style.
('71', 18, 9, 21, 39215) You are even thinking of a gathering of friends.
('71', 18, 9, 22, 39264) If that is so, please let me know your reason.
('71', 18, 9, 23, 39311) One reason I have understood.
('71', 18, 9, 24, 39341) You feel that all of us elders have enjoyed celebrations of marriages in our time andnow we are out to stop persons like you from doing that, and you ask why.
('71', 18, 9, 25, 39500) This is a pure misconception.
('71', 18, 9, 26, 39530) If, according to our custom, we regard marriage as a festive occasion, a person can enjoy the celebration only once.
('71', 18, 9, 27, 39647) Now as regards myself, I may tell you that whatever happened when I was only twelve years of age.
('71', 18, 9, 28, 39745) My parents did not ask for my consent in regard to anything.
('71', 18, 9, 29, 39806) If anybody had enjoyed the celebrations, it was they and the other relatives.
('71', 18, 9, 30, 39884) I am not aware of having enjoyed the occasion.
('71', 18, 9, 31, 39931) Whatever fun I may have had at that time was much in the same way as children enjoy play.
('71', 18, 9, 32, 40021) I had no sense at all of the responsibility of the occasion.
('71', 18, 9, 33, 40082) This is how I enjoyed the
('71', 18, 10, 34, 40108) 1 The subscription is in Urdu.

('71', 19, 1, 2, 40180) celebration.
('71', 19, 1, 3, 40193) I do not know anything of Kishorelal.
('71', 19, 1, 4, 40231) You need not, therefore, envy my enjoyment.
('71', 19, 1, 5, 40275) What I wish is that on the day fixed you should come alone.
('71', 19, 1, 6, 40335) I will get all the religious ceremonies performed and, after they are over, you may take away Manu on the very same day.
('71', 19, 1, 7, 40456) If you want to have a gathering of friends, you may have one at Akola or Bombay.
('71', 19, 1, 8, 40537) I have no zest at all for such things.
('71', 19, 1, 9, 40576) I am not talking about renunciation but only about common duty.
('71', 19, 1, 10, 40640) Nowadays some thinkers have elevated sensual enjoyment to the position of a dharma.
('71', 19, 1, 11, 40724) I have not been able to accept this view.
('71', 19, 1, 12, 40766) In my opinion marriage is a means of observing self control.
('71', 19, 1, 13, 40827) It is desirable that men and women should have only one connection and not many.
('71', 19, 1, 14, 40908) This is their duty.
('71', 19, 1, 15, 40928) Marriage should be for service, not for self indulgence.
('71', 19, 1, 16, 40985) The relationship of man and woman is only for progeny and should have no other purpose.
('71', 19, 1, 17, 41073) This is the ideal.
('71', 19, 1, 18, 41092) Certainly one cannot say that this ideal is wrong simply because it cannot be attained.
('71', 19, 1, 19, 41180) But if it is right, it is one’s duty to follow it in practice to the best of one’s ability.
('71', 19, 1, 20, 41272) And if such is indeed one’s duty, then the marriage ceremony should be made as religious, quiet and austere as possible.
('71', 19, 1, 21, 41393) If you understand this, then you and Manu should look upon marriage as a new birth and should enter it with a sense of duty.
('71', 19, 1, 22, 41518) Do not regard marriage as a festive occasion but enter the householder’s estate with the blessings of elders and with full understanding of the meaning of marriage.
('71', 19, 1, 23, 41683) If you have understood this, you will give up insisting on inviting anybody.
('71', 19, 1, 24, 41760) If I can I will stop even Nanabhai, Neelkanth and others from coming and wasting money on travelling.
('71', 19, 1, 25, 41862) Notwithstanding these views of mine, however, I do not wish to hurt you.
('71', 19, 1, 26, 41935) You may, therefore, unhesitatingly let me know whatever you desire.

('71', 21, 6, 17, 44408) 27. DISCUSSION WITH R. R. KEITHAHN 1
('71', 21, 7, 18, 44445) [March 5, 1937] 2
('71', 21, 8, 19, 44463) Mr. Keithahn...
('71', 21, 8, 20, 44479) was not quite sure what was at the back of Gandhiji’s mind when he said that all religions were not only true but equal.
('71', 21, 8, 21, 44600) Scientifically, he felt, it was hardly correct to say that all religions are equal.
('71', 21, 8, 22, 44684) People would make comparisons between animists and theists.
('71', 21, 8, 23, 44744) “I would say,” said Mr. Keithahn, “it is no use comparing religions.
('71', 21, 8, 24, 44813) They are different ways.
('71', 21, 8, 25, 44838) Do you think we can explain the thing in different terms?
('71', 21, 9, 26, 44896) GANDHIJI: You are right when you say that it is impossible to compare them.
('71', 21, 9, 27, 44972) But the deduction from it is that they are equal.
('71', 21, 9, 28, 45022) All men are born free and equal, but one is much stronger or weeker than another physically and mentally.
('71', 21, 9, 29, 45128) Therefore superficially there is
('71', 21, 10, 30, 45161) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('71', 21, 10, 31, 45211) R.R. Keithahn was an American missionary.
('71', 21, 10, 32, 45253) 2 From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary
('71', 22, 0, 1, 45300) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 23
('71', 22, 1, 2, 45342) noequality between the two.
('71', 22, 1, 3, 45370) But there is an essential equality: in our nakedness.
('71', 22, 1, 4, 45424) God is not going to think of me as Gandhi and you as Keithahn.
('71', 22, 1, 5, 45487) And what are we in this mighty universe?
('71', 22, 1, 6, 45528) We are less than atoms, and as between atoms there is no use asking which is smaller and which is bigger.
('71', 22, 1, 7, 45634) Inherently we are equal.
('71', 22, 1, 8, 45659) The differences of race and skin and of mind and body and of climate and nation are transitory.
('71', 22, 1, 9, 45755) In the same way essentially all religions are equal.
('71', 22, 1, 10, 45808) If you read the Koran, you must read it with the eye of the Muslim; if you read the Bible, you must read it with the eye of the Christian; if you read the Gita, you must read it with the eye of a Hindu.
('71', 22, 1, 11, 46011) Where is the use of scanning details and then holding up a religion to ridicule?
('71', 22, 1, 12, 46092) Take the very first chapter of Genesis or of Matthew.
('71', 22, 1, 13, 46146) We read a long pedigree and then at the end we are told that Jesus was born of a virgin.
('71', 22, 1, 14, 46235) You come up against a blind wall.
('71', 22, 1, 15, 46269) But I must read it all with the eye of a Christian.
('71', 22, 2, 16, 46321) K. Then even in our Bible, there is the question of Moses and Jesus.

('71', 22, 3, 18, 46421) G. Yes.
('71', 22, 3, 19, 46429) All prophets are equal.
('71', 22, 3, 20, 46453) It is a horizontal plane.
('71', 22, 4, 21, 46479) K. If we think in terms of Einstein’s relativity all are equal.
('71', 22, 4, 22, 46543) But I cannot happily express that equality.
('71', 22, 5, 23, 46587) G. This is why I say they are equally true and equally imperfect.
('71', 22, 5, 24, 46653) The finer the line you draw, the nearer it approaches Euclid’s true staight line, but it never is true straight line.
('71', 22, 5, 25, 46771) The tree of religion is the same, there is not that physical equality between the branches.
('71', 22, 5, 26, 46863) They are all growing, and the person who belongs to the growing branch must not gloat over it and say, ‘Mine is the superior one’.
('71', 22, 5, 27, 46994) None is superior, none is inferior, to the other.

('71', 22, 6, 29, 47063) 28. DISCUSSION WITH A ROMAN CATHOLIC PRIEST 1
('71', 22, 7, 30, 47109) [March 5, 1937] 2
('71', 22, 8, 31, 47127) A Roman Catholic Father who saw Gandhiji the other day asked how Gandhiji proposed to break the caste.
('71', 22, 9, 32, 47230) GANDHIJI: It is already breaking.
('71', 22, 9, 33, 47264) All it requires is education, and under the education that is being imparted for some time it is breaking.
('71', 22, 9, 34, 47371) But by education I do not mean literary education but
('71', 22, 10, 35, 47425) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” 2 From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary
('71', 23, 0, 1, 47521) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 23, 1, 2, 47562) thespread of true knowledge.
('71', 23, 1, 3, 47591) Caste has no religious basis, but it is certainly regarded as bound up with religion, though it is not derived from the scriptures.
('71', 23, 1, 4, 47723) Untouchability is the last word on caste, and as soon as untouchability goes, caste goes.
('71', 23, 1, 5, 47813) The outcaste has been all over the world.
('71', 23, 1, 6, 47855) In Europe the Jews were outcastes and confined to the ghettos where life was much worse than in the untouchables’ quarters.
('71', 23, 1, 7, 47979) The degradation to which the outcastes in India are reduced is bad enough, but what one knew of ghettos from Israel Zangwill’s works, which years ago I read at the instance of a friend, was something blood curdling.
('71', 23, 1, 8, 48195) Such a thing cannot happen in India, because of the non violence of a sort that we are practising.
('71', 23, 1, 9, 48294) However, though we have no ghettos, there is nothing to choose between them and untoucha bility.
('71', 23, 1, 10, 48391) Take untouchability out and the fabric of caste is destroyed.
('71', 23, 2, 11, 48453) And here Gandhiji explained the distinction between caste and varna, which
('71', 23, 3, 12, 48528) was not only a law for the Hindus but a universal law, to which we confirm, with or
('71', 23, 4, 13, 48612) without knowledge, and if we do not, we do so at our peril.
('71', 23, 4, 14, 48672) Caste had been the best
('71', 23, 5, 15, 48696) target for missionaries to assail Hinduism with, and rightly, but caste in the sense of
('71', 23, 6, 16, 48784) varna and trade guilds, as Sir W. W. Hunter 1 described it, will live forever.
('71', 23, 6, 17, 48863) CATHOLIC FATHER: If Hinduism became monotheistic, Christianity and Hinduism can serve India in co operation.
('71', 23, 7, 18, 48972) G. I would love to see the co operation happen, but it cannot if the present day Christian mission persist in holding up Hinduism to ridicule and saying that no one can go to Heaven unless he renounces and denounces Hinduism.
('71', 23, 7, 19, 49198) But I can conceive a good Christian, silently working away, and shedding the sweet aroma of his life on Hindu communities, like the rose which does not need any speech to spread its fragrance but spreads it because it must.
('71', 23, 7, 20, 49422) Even so a truly spiritual life.
('71', 23, 7, 21, 49454) Then surely there would be peace on earth and goodwill among men.
('71', 23, 7, 22, 49520) But not so long as there is militant or ‘muscular’ Christianity.
('71', 23, 7, 23, 49585) This is not to be found in the Bible, but you find it in Germany and other countries.
('71', 23, 8, 24, 49671) R.C.F. But if Indians begin to believe in one God and give up idolatry, don’t you think the whole difficulty will be solved?
('71', 23, 9, 25, 49796) G. Will the Christians be satisfied with it?
('71', 23, 9, 26, 49841) Are they all united?
('71', 23, 10, 27, 49862) R. C .F. Of course all the Christian sects are not united.
('71', 23, 11, 28, 49921) 1 A member of the Viceroy’s Council, he directed the statistical survey of Indian Empire (1869 81), whose reports were later condensed in The Imperial Gazetteer of India.
('71', 24, 0, 1, 50092) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 25
('71', 24, 1, 2, 50134) G. Then you are asking only a theoretical question.
('71', 24, 1, 3, 50186) And may I ask you, is there any amalgamation between Islam and Christianity, though both are said to believe in one God?
('71', 24, 1, 4, 50307) If these two have not amalgamated, there is less hope of amalgamation of Christians and Hindus along the lines you suggest.
('71', 24, 1, 5, 50431) I have my own solution, but the first instance I dispute the description that Hindus believe in many gods and are idolators.
('71', 24, 1, 6, 50556) They do say there are many gods, but they also declare unmistakably that there is One God, God of gods.
('71', 24, 1, 7, 50660) It is therefore not proper to suggest that Hindus believe in many gods.
('71', 24, 1, 8, 50732) They certainly believe in many worlds.
('71', 24, 1, 9, 50771) Just as there is a world inhabited by men and another by beasts, so also is there one inhabited by superior beings called gods, whom we do not see but who nevertheless exist.
('71', 24, 1, 10, 50946) The whole mischief is created by the English rendering of the words deva or devta for which you have not found a better term than ‘god’.
('71', 24, 1, 11, 51083) But god is Ishwara, Devadhideva, God of gods.
('71', 24, 1, 12, 51129) So you see it is the word ‘god’, used to describe different divine beings, that has given rise to such confusion.
('71', 24, 1, 13, 51243) I believe that I am a thorough Hindu but I never believe in many gods.
('71', 24, 1, 14, 51314) Never even in my childhood did I hold that belief, and no one ever taught me to do so.
('71', 24, 1, 15, 51401) As for idol worship, you cannot do without it in some form or other.
('71', 24, 1, 16, 51470) Why does a Mussalman give his life for defending a mosque which he calls a house of God?
('71', 24, 1, 17, 51559) And why does a Christian go to a church and when he is required to take an oath swear by the Bible?
('71', 24, 1, 18, 51659) Not that I see any objection to it.
('71', 24, 1, 19, 51695) And what is it if not idolatry to give untold riches for building mosques and tombs?
('71', 24, 1, 20, 51780) And what do the Roman Catholics do when they kneel before Virgin Mary and before saints—quite imaginary figures in stone or painted on canvas or glass?

('71', 24, 2, 23, 52054) When I worship God, I acknowledge Him as Creator and greater than any human being.
('71', 24, 3, 24, 52137) G. Even so, it is not the stone we worship but it is God we worship in images of stone or metal however crude they may be.
('71', 24, 4, 25, 52260) R. C .F. But villagers worship stones as God.
('71', 24, 5, 26, 52306) G. No, I tell you they do not worship anything that is less than God.

('71', 25, 9, 27, 54115) We are all born equal, but we have all these centuries resisted the will of God.

('71', 25, 9, 29, 54342) The human breast does not lend itself to that means.
('71', 25, 10, 30, 54395) R. C. F. When Hinduism comes to power, will it not make a united front against Christianity?

('71', 26, 1, 2, 54892) destruction of Mussalmans too!

('71', 27, 1, 2, 57021) 29. AS OTHER SEE US
('71', 27, 2, 3, 57041) Here is a letter 1 which has been lying on my file for some time:
('71', 27, 3, 4, 57107) Your attitude towards religious conversion and particularly the hope
('71', 27, 4, 5, 57176) you entertain for the Depressed Classes within the fold of Hinduism,
('71', 27, 5, 6, 57245) overlooks the prevalent practices of Hinduism as it exists in India today...
('71', 27, 6, 7, 57322) Any religion is judged by its fruits.
('71', 27, 6, 8, 57360) Here is a contrast.
('71', 27, 6, 9, 57380) Take the case of the Christian religion, whether Roman Catholic or Protestant.
('71', 27, 6, 10, 57459) The funds that are collected from the rich and poor are carefully accounted for and repaid in the form of medical and educational service.
('71', 27, 6, 11, 57598) Religious worship is open to all alike.
('71', 27, 6, 12, 57638) The number of schools, colleges, dispensaries, hospitals and orphanges admirably served by their religious institution bear eloquent testimony to the quality of faith that is in them.
('71', 27, 6, 13, 57822) It is not a theology and philosophy which they possess but the self sacrificing service which they render in abundant measure towards all that is a contrast to the service rendered by the temples and mutts.
('71', 27, 6, 14, 58029) What are the uses of the wealth of temples and mutts?
('71', 27, 6, 15, 58083) Are not these weapons of superstition and oppression?
('71', 27, 6, 16, 58137) The heads of these mutts live princely lives with vast endowments,.
('71', 27, 6, 17, 58205) I am informed that there are regular lawyers to collect dues and serve the interests of these religious heads, swamis and gurus.
('71', 27, 6, 18, 58334) This state of affairs is an oppression worse than popery in its worst days.
('71', 27, 6, 19, 58410) Not merely the accumulated wealth and the annual collections, which in all these mutts must amount to several crores, are never properly accounted for, but this gigantic system of ghastly exploitation continues to be supported by the most intellectual leaders of the people as if Hindu society will break up by questioning it.
('71', 27, 6, 20, 58737) This is practical Hinduism.
('71', 27, 6, 21, 58765) Why should there be any surprise that the Depressed Classes alone should revolt against a system which denies them equal rights to worship the Deity but keeps them also in perpetual social excommunication?
('71', 27, 6, 22, 58971) Why is it that no one ventures to question the priestly oppression, this draining away annually the wealth of the people without any service whatever?
('71', 27, 7, 23, 59122) It is exploitation by religious heads that has crushed the people,
('71', 27, 8, 24, 59189) and the money lender and the State combined have finished the process.
('71', 27, 9, 25, 59260) not more work and harder work, and the variety of cottage industries that
('71', 27, 10, 26, 59334) thesehalf dead half living masses require, but more vocational schools and
('71', 27, 11, 27, 59409) dispensaries, maternity and child welfare centres and better food.
('71', 27, 12, 28, 59476) State is not moved very easily by your Herculean endeavours, Hinduism
('71', 27, 13, 29, 59546) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('71', 28, 0, 1, 59583) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 29
('71', 28, 1, 2, 59625) requires a far more drastic purge as it has been established some thousands of
('71', 28, 2, 3, 59704) years longer than this alien Government.
('71', 28, 3, 4, 59745) Bishops and priests of the Christian religion, in spite of the fierce criticism levelled against them in this land and every other country, render humanitarian service unequalled by any other class of human beings who follow any other faith or no faith, and are approachable to all people.
('71', 28, 3, 5, 60035) It is good to see ourselves as others see us.
('71', 28, 3, 6, 60081) Try as we may, we are never able to know ourselves fully as we are, especially the evil side of us.
('71', 28, 3, 7, 60181) This we can do only if we are not angry with our critics but will take in good part whatever they might have to say.

('71', 28, 3, 9, 60380) The grave limitations of Hinduism as it is seen today in practice must be admitted.
('71', 28, 3, 10, 60464) Many mutts and their administration are undoubtedly a disgrace to Hinduism.
('71', 28, 3, 11, 60540) The money that is poured into some of them does not return to the worshippers in the form of service.

('71', 28, 3, 13, 60688) Humanitarian work done by Christian missions must also be admitted.
('71', 28, 3, 14, 60756) But these admissions of mine must not be interpreted to mean endorsement of the deductions of the writer.
('71', 28, 3, 15, 60862) Economic and educational relief is required by most poor Indians in common with Harijans.
('71', 28, 3, 16, 60952) But the latter suffer from special disabilities.
('71', 28, 3, 17, 61001) It is not a question of what disabilities they resent.
('71', 28, 3, 18, 61056) It is the duty of the so called superior Hindus to break the chains that bind the Harijans even though they may hug them.The admission by the writer of the sublimity of Hinduism as expounded by Vivekanand and Radhakrishanan should have led to his discovery of its percolation down to the masses.
('71', 28, 3, 19, 61352) I make bold to say that in spite of the crudeness which one sees among the villagers, class considered, in all that is good in human nature they compare favourably with any villagers in the world.
('71', 28, 3, 20, 61549) This testimony is borne out by the majority of travellers who from the times of Huen Tsang down to the present times have recorded their impressions.
('71', 28, 3, 21, 61699) The innate culture that the villagers of India show, the art which one sees in the homes of the poor, the restraint with which the villagers conduct themselves, are surely due to the religion that has bound them together from time immemorial.
('71', 28, 3, 22, 61942) In his zeal to belittle Hinduism, the writer ignores the broad fact that Hinduism has produced a race of reformers who have successfully combated prejudices, superstitions and abuses.
('71', 28, 3, 23, 62126) Without any drum beating Hinduism has devised a system of relief of the poor which has been the envy of many foreign admirers.
('71', 28, 3, 24, 62253) I myself feel that
('71', 29, 0, 1, 62272) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 29, 1, 2, 62313) it leaves much to be desired.
('71', 29, 1, 3, 62343) It has its evil side.
('71', 29, 1, 4, 62365) But from the philanthropic standpoint it has wholly justified itself.
('71', 29, 1, 5, 62435) It is not the Indian habit to advertise charities through printed reports and the like.
('71', 29, 1, 6, 62523) But he who runs may see the free kitchens and free medical relief given along indigenous lines.
('71', 29, 1, 7, 62619) The writer belittles village work.
('71', 29, 1, 8, 62654) It betrays gross ignorance.
('71', 29, 1, 9, 62682) If the mutts and the revenue offices were extinguished and free schools were opened, the people would not be cured of their inertia.

('71', 29, 1, 11, 62937) But starvation will not disappear because people pay no revenue and mutts are destroyed and schools spring up in every village.
('71', 29, 1, 12, 63065) The greatest education in the villages consists in the villagers being taught or induced to work methodically and profitably all the year round whether it be on the land or at industries connected with the villages.
('71', 29, 1, 13, 63281) Lastly, my correspondent seems to resent acceptance by us of humanitarian services by missionaries.

('71', 31, 4, 6, 66554) 32. HOW TO BEGIN 2
('71', 31, 5, 7, 66573) My invitation in these columns some time back to such khadi workers as may be anxious to become adepts in the various processes relating to the production of Khadi, 3 has evoked a wide reponse and I have already received several communications on the subject.
('71', 31, 5, 8, 66833) The object of the following remarks is to set forth a few practical hints for the guidance of these friends.
('71', 31, 5, 9, 66942) The first essential condition for anyone who wants to become master of any subject is to have a living faith in it.
('71', 31, 5, 10, 67058) He must next have the eagerness to learn and readiness to make the necessary sacrifice for its sake.
('71', 31, 5, 11, 67159) Books, teachers and other accessories of education are of course necessary in a more or less degree, but passion for knowledge and eagerness to learn are the most essential of all.
('71', 31, 5, 12, 67340) Given these, the other things will follow of themselves.
('71', 31, 5, 13, 67397) I would therefore suggestto these intending students of the khadi science that they can at once make a begining by finiding out what processes relative to khadi production are being carried out in their immediate neighbourhood and picking up all the useful information with regard to them available there.
('71', 31, 5, 14, 67703) The main task that faces a student of the khadi science today is collation and co ordination of personal experience.
('71', 31, 5, 15, 67820) A number of different processes relating to the production of khadi are today in vogue in different parts of the country.
('71', 31, 5, 16, 67942) But there is no single person today who fully knows all of them.
('71', 31, 5, 17, 68007) And yet complete, detailed knowledge of all these different processes is necessary before the science of khadi can be developed.
('71', 31, 5, 18, 68136) The task is obviously beyond the compass of a single individual.
('71', 31, 5, 19, 68201) But if there are a number of persons
('71', 31, 6, 20, 68238) 1 Vide “Letter to Chimanlal N. Shah”, 6 2 1937 2 The Gujarati original of this was published in the Harijanbandhu, 7 3 1937. The translation is by Pyarelal.
('71', 31, 6, 21, 68395) 3 Vide“What Khadi Workers Should Know”, 13 2 1937
('71', 32, 0, 1, 68445) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 33
('71', 32, 1, 2, 68487) who are truly fired by a scientific spirit of research and they apply themselves to the task in a systematic manner, they will, by pooling their talents and experience, be able to evolve a living, growing science of khadi in a short time.
('71', 32, 1, 3, 68726) But before they can do that, they will need to have themselves collectively mastered all the processes of khadi production that are in vogue in the country today.
('71', 32, 1, 4, 68889) To take a concrete instance, several varieties of khadi are produced in different parts of Andhra today, employing different methods of carding.
('71', 32, 1, 5, 69034) Now any khadi worker in Andhra who is anxious to acquire the science of khadi can begin by mastering all these various methods.
('71', 32, 1, 6, 69162) For this he need not quit his province.
('71', 32, 1, 7, 69202) Let him by way of a start pick up the process which is current in his immediate neighbourhood.
('71', 32, 1, 8, 69297) A scientific study of carding would, of course, include a knowledge of the construction of the carding bow on the part of the student.
('71', 32, 1, 9, 69432) He would further need to know the materials from which the gut string and other component parts of a carding bow are made and how; what exactly the length of a carding bow should be in order to yield the best results, and the effects of departure from the standard length; where precisely the stroke on the bow string should be delivered and the reason why, and so on in respect of a host of other questions about which even the best of our professional carders today know little and care even less.
('71', 32, 1, 10, 69932) Similarly, with regard to cotton a worker who takes up a study of carding as a science would need to know all about the different varieties of cotton; the length, strength and fineness of their respective fibres, the various processes through which it has to pass before it reaches his hands; where it is grown; what is the yield per acre and the total money value of the crop; what is the extent of the area under cotton; what was the crop grown there previously which has been displaced, or was the area under question lying fallow before; what difference it would make to the cultivator if another crop were substituted in place of cotton; etc.
('71', 32, 1, 11, 70580) Thus his practical experience will be illumined by scientific knowledge and give him such a firm grip of his subject and an insight into its intricacies that to master the other processes of carding prevailing in different parts of Andhra will become comparatively an easy thing for him and take but little time.
('71', 32, 1, 12, 70893) If, further, he keeps regular notes of his experiments and experiences, they will in time take the place of an authoritative treatise on the science of carding.
('71', 32, 1, 13, 71054) It will be thus seen that no khadi worker need leave his field of work in order to learn the science of khadi.
('71', 32, 1, 14, 71165) If he is fired by the spirit
('71', 33, 0, 1, 71194) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 33, 1, 2, 71235) of inquiry and has patience and capacity for concentrated application in a sufficient measure, he will , by applying himself to an intensive study of the processes for which his neighbourhood offers special facilities, not only become a specialist in those particular processes but also gradually widen the scope of his knowledge so as to deserve the name science.
('71', 33, 1, 3, 71600) Harijan, 10 4 1937

('71', 37, 8, 27, 77923) NARANADAS, You of course read what I have been writing about khadi these days.
('71', 37, 8, 28, 78002) And you have also read Maganlal’s book 1. Will you, taking that book as your guide or according to any other plan you like, write

('71', 38, 1, 5, 78497) You must have read my questionnaire and Lakshmidas’s article.

('71', 38, 1, 8, 78662) I read your printed programme.
('71', 38, 1, 9, 78693) I didn’t like it as well as I did your statement.
('71', 38, 1, 10, 78743) The portion in dialogue form is certainly excellent, but it can’t be said to have been artistically interwoven with the rest.
('71', 38, 1, 11, 78869) That, however, is a minor defect.
('71', 38, 1, 12, 78903) I notice spelling mistakes too.
('71', 38, 1, 13, 78935) The Vidyapith dictionary is an authority for us.
('71', 38, 1, 14, 78984) I don’t know if it contains the words peen, reeban, chipia, etc.
('71', 38, 1, 15, 79049) If it, you should look them up.
('71', 38, 1, 16, 79081) Now the dictionary does not at all give the word pin.
('71', 38, 1, 17, 79135) In English the vowel is short and we should spell the word accordingly.
('71', 38, 1, 18, 79207) I went through the rules about spelling and there also it is stated that words borrowed from foreign languages should be spelt in conformity with their spellings in those languages.
('71', 38, 1, 19, 79389) Moreover, the word peen has a definite meaning in Gujarati.
('71', 38, 1, 20, 79449) The dictionary explains it as “thick”, “wellfed”, “rounded”.
('71', 38, 1, 21, 79510) At first sight I didn’t get the meaning of peen, but I made it out as I proceeded further.
('71', 38, 1, 22, 79601) In the dialogue you have spelt the word as cheepeeo.
('71', 38, 1, 23, 79654) It should be cheepio.
('71', 38, 1, 24, 79676) It is followed in the same sentence by reeban 1. In English the word is pronounced as“riban” and that is how it should be spelt according to the rule given in the dictionary.
('71', 38, 1, 25, 79851) The word is not given in the dictionary, though there is no harm in using it all the same.
('71', 38, 1, 26, 79942) You will find many more of similar other spelling mistakes.
('71', 38, 1, 27, 80002) I see no poetry in the bhajan or song “He is the witless man”.
('71', 38, 1, 28, 80065) The language jars on the ear and the thought also is none too pleasant.
('71', 38, 1, 29, 80137) The very first syllable augurs ill.
('71', 38, 1, 30, 80173) There is no such word as murakh.
('71', 38, 1, 31, 80206) The word is moorakh.
('71', 38, 1, 32, 80227) The thought in the line “feeds the foreigner lovingly” is indicative of ill will.
('71', 38, 1, 33, 80309) It does not befit a follower of non violence.
('71', 38, 1, 34, 80355) And if a foreigner is hungry, why should not one feed him lovingly?
('71', 38, 1, 35, 80423) Of course the meaning in the author’s mind is different, but the reader is not concerned with the meaning in an auther’s mind if it is not expressed in his language.
('71', 38, 1, 36, 80589) In the phrase, deshana dukkhne tane, the syllable “na”, should be nasalized.
('71', 38, 1, 37, 80666) The expression “to serve the stones of unemployment” lacks moderation.
('71', 38, 1, 38, 80737) The metaphor also is not happy.
('71', 38, 1, 39, 80769) The thought in “The fine noose of
('71', 38, 2, 40, 80803) 1 Ribbon

('71', 40, 6, 18, 83436) I could not agree with your argument.

('71', 40, 6, 20, 83567) In my opinion, good lies in implementing all these ideas gradually.
('71', 40, 6, 21, 83635) How can a person whom we would not like to keep in our house be permitted to stay in a temple?
('71', 40, 6, 22, 83730) A temple should never be allowed to be a shelter for vagabonds.
('71', 40, 6, 23, 83794) Only holy men are a worthy sight in a temple compound.
('71', 40, 6, 24, 83849) If you brothers cherish the idea of making the temple God’s abode, then it is desirable that you do not transform it into a place of self seeking.
('71', 40, 6, 25, 83996) If your ideas are carried out, God will suffocate in that place although it may be called a temple.
('71', 40, 6, 26, 84096) I would personally wish that you should never copy the failings of the Hindus who consider themselves as belonging to the upper castes.
('71', 40, 6, 27, 84232) I may remind you that Bhangi friends twice took an oath before me that they would give up drinking and twice broke it.
('71', 40, 6, 28, 84351) But I too am made of ordinary clay as you are.
('71', 40, 6, 29, 84398) So we need not put a high value on the knowledge that you may be able to gain from me, but, if you desire to make the temple a true abode of God, then do not make it a shelter for persons of doubtful worth and a place for storing utensils of use to the community.
('71', 40, 6, 30, 84662) Instead, the moment the temple is opened you should take before the deity

('71', 41, 5, 7, 85218) 47. THE COW
('71', 41, 6, 8, 85230) The cow is an object of worship and veneration to millions in India.
('71', 41, 6, 9, 85299) I count myself among them.
('71', 41, 6, 10, 85326) The cow shed in Segaon is in front of me.
('71', 41, 6, 11, 85368) I cannot escape its inmates even if I would.
('71', 41, 6, 12, 85413) And when I was arguing the question of the masses of Harijans with Christian friends, I said, ‘The majority of Harijans can no more understand the presentation of Christianity than my cows.’ This comparision shocked my friends so much that the shock has travelled to America and I have begun to receive letters from America telling me how my comparision is being used to discredit me and my claim to serve Harijans.
('71', 41, 6, 13, 85829) The critics seem to say, ‘You can have little regard for Harijans if you compare them to the cow.’ Nevertheless I am unrepentant.
('71', 41, 6, 14, 85959) My American credit will be little worth if it can be demolished on the very first shock however trivial it might be.
('71', 41, 6, 15, 86076) But I hold that my comparison was as innocuous as it was appropriate.
('71', 41, 6, 16, 86146) It was innocuous because of the unique place the cow occupies in India.
('71', 41, 6, 17, 86218) It was appropriate because in the matter of understanding the presentation of Christianity the ordinary Harijan can no more take it in than the cow.
('71', 41, 6, 18, 86367) That the dullest Harijan can be trained to understand it in course of time, whereas the cow never can, is irrelevant for the simple reason that the discussion related to the present condition, not to future possibility.
('71', 41, 6, 19, 86587) My point would be better understood if I extend the comparision and say that my five year old grandson or my sixty eight year old wife can no more understand the presentation than my cow, though both my wife and my grandson are objects of tender care and attention.
('71', 41, 6, 20, 86853) I could say of myself that I can no more read the Chinese alphabet today than my worshipful cow.
('71', 42, 0, 1, 86950) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 43
('71', 42, 1, 2, 86992) The truth of this last statement is not in any way altered by the fact that if someone began to teach my cow and me the difficult alphabet, I should beat the cow hollow, if the poor venerable mother ever consented to enter the competition.
('71', 42, 1, 3, 87232) Let my critics and credulous friends understand that apart from the comparison, I stand on unassailable ground when I assert that it is a travesty of religion to seek to uproot from the Harijans’ simple minds such faith as they have in their ancestral religion and to transfer their allegiance to another, even though that other may be as good as and equal to the original in quality.
('71', 42, 1, 4, 87617) Though all soils have the same predominantcharaterstics, we know that the same seeds do not fare equally well in all soils.
('71', 42, 1, 5, 87741) I have some excellent tree cotton seeds which thrive excellently in certain parts of Bengal.
('71', 42, 1, 6, 87834) But Mirabehn has not succeeded as yet in getting the same result from the same seeds in the Varoda soil.
('71', 42, 1, 7, 87939) But I should be unable to subscribe to the formula, if the attempt was made to advance it, that the Varoda soil is inferior to the Bengal soil.
('71', 42, 1, 8, 88083) But my fear is that though Christian friends nowadays do not say or admit that Hindu religion is untrue, they must harbour in their breasts the belief that Hinduism is an error and that Christianity as they believe it is the only true religion.
('71', 42, 1, 9, 88328) Without some such thing it is not possible to understand, much less to appreciate, the C.M.S. appeal from which I reproduced in these columns some revealing extracts the other day.
('71', 42, 1, 10, 88509) 1 One could understand the attack on untouchability and many other errors that have crept into Hindu life.
('71', 42, 1, 11, 88616) And if they would help us to get rid of the admitted abuses and purify our religion, they would do helpful constructive work which would be gratefully accepted.
('71', 42, 1, 12, 88777) But so far as one can understand the present effort, it is to uproot Hinduism from the very foundation and replace it by another faith.
('71', 42, 1, 13, 88913) It is like an attempt to destroy a house which though badly in want of repair appears to the dweller quite decent and habitable.
('71', 42, 1, 14, 89042) No wonder he welcomes those who show him how to repair it and even offer to do so themselves.
('71', 42, 1, 15, 89136) But he would most decidedly resist those who sought to destroy the house that had served well him and his ancestors for ages, unless he, the dweller, was convinced that the house was beyond repair and unfit for human habitation.
('71', 42, 1, 16, 89365) If the Christian world entertains that opinion about the Hindu house, ‘Parliament of Religions’ and ‘International Fellowship’ are empty phrases.
('71', 42, 1, 17, 89511) For both the terms presuppose
('71', 42, 2, 18, 89541) 1 Vide “A Christian Letter”, 30 1 1937
('71', 43, 0, 1, 89580) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 43, 1, 2, 89621) equality of status, a common platform.
('71', 43, 1, 3, 89660) There cannot be a common platform as between inferiors and superiors, or the enlightened and the unenlightened, the regenerate and the unregenerate, the high born and the low born, the caste man and the outcaste.
('71', 43, 1, 4, 89873) My comparison may be defective, may even sound offensive.
('71', 43, 1, 5, 89931) My reasoning may be unsound.
('71', 43, 1, 6, 89960) But my proposition stands.
('71', 43, 1, 7, 89987) Harijan, 13 3 1937

('71', 43, 3, 9, 90032) Deenbandhu Andrews writes:
('71', 43, 4, 10, 90059) The arrival of each new number of Harijan is one of the exciting events
('71', 43, 5, 11, 90131) of the week in my old college rooms at Cambridge, where I have been busy

('71', 43, 10, 18, 90509) gone down into Travancore at your request—both to Vaikom, where I
('71', 43, 11, 19, 90575) witnessed the great Satyagraha struggle, and also to Kottayam.
('71', 43, 11, 20, 90638) Outside Kottayam, in the country district, multitudes of the avarnas had come to meet
('71', 43, 12, 21, 90724) me and to receive your message.

('71', 43, 13, 23, 90794) collected.
