('71', 43, 24, 41, 91718) From all I hear, the Proclamation is being worked so effectively that the economic salvation which Deenbandhu wants to hear of is bound to come and that sooner than one may expect.
('71', 43, 24, 42, 91899) For, addressing a meeting of Pulayas, Pariahs and others on the Ist instant at
('71', 44, 0, 1, 91978) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 45
('71', 44, 1, 2, 92020) Trivandrum, the Dewan Sir C.P. Ramaswami Aiyar is reported to have said:
('71', 44, 2, 3, 92093) The Maharaja regarded the Temple entry Proclamation not as an end in itself, but as the first step in the rehabilitation of the State.
('71', 44, 2, 4, 92228) What was needed was educational upliftment, economic upliftment and social integration.
('71', 44, 2, 5, 92316) For this, the co operation of the Ruler and the people was necessary.
('71', 44, 2, 6, 92386) Out of consi deration for the class of people who were being lifted up, it had been decided to omit the word ‘depressed’ from Government documents and publications.
('71', 44, 2, 7, 92551) He ventured to say the time would come when the Depressed Classes would forget that name.
('71', 44, 3, 8, 92641) Harijan, 13 3 1937
('71', 44, 4, 9, 92660) 49. MARRIED BRAHMACHARYA 1
('71', 44, 5, 10, 92687) A friend writes:
('71', 44, 6, 11, 92704) I have long since held with you that self control is the only sovereign method for attaining birth control.
('71', 44, 6, 12, 92812) That the sexual act is meant for procreation only, and apart from it, in any shape or form , would amount to unnatural gratification of lust, needs no proof.
('71', 44, 6, 13, 92970) But sometimes this brings one up against a grave dilemma.
('71', 44, 6, 14, 93028) Supposing that the sexual act, once or twice, fails to lead to conception, what is one to do then?
('71', 44, 6, 15, 93127) Where is one to draw the limit?
('71', 44, 6, 16, 93159) It is hard finally to give up all hope of begetting offspring.
('71', 44, 6, 17, 93222) On the other hand, unlimited indulgence in the sexual act must result in the man being drained of all vitality.
('71', 44, 6, 18, 93334) Again, should such a person be told to regard his failure to beget progeny on the first or the second chance, as a mark of adverse fate and on that score to abstain from having any further intercourse thereafter?
('71', 44, 6, 19, 93547) But that would require an exceptional degree of self possession and spiritual strength on the part of the person concerned.
('71', 44, 6, 20, 93671) Instances of people begetting progeny in their declining years after repeated failure during the years of manhood and youth are by no means either unknown or rare.
('71', 44, 6, 21, 93835) That makes the observance of complete abstinence still more difficult, and the position becomes further complicated when the parties happen to be otherwise healthy and free from any physical defect.
('71', 44, 6, 22, 94034) I admit the difficulty, but the difficulty is inherent in the problem itself.
('71', 44, 6, 23, 94112) The road to any progress is strewn with such difficulties and the story of man’s ascent in the scale of evolution is co extensive with the history of the successful overcoming of these
('71', 44, 7, 24, 94297) 1 The Hindi original of this was published in Harijan Sevak, 13 3 1937. The translation is by Pyarelal.
('71', 45, 0, 1, 94401) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 45, 1, 2, 94442) difficulties.
('71', 45, 1, 3, 94456) Take the story of the attempts to conquer the Himalayas.
('71', 45, 1, 4, 94513) The higher you go the steeper becomes the climb, the more difficult the ascent, so much so that its highest peak still remains unvanquished.The enterprise has already exacted a heavy toll of sacrifice.
('71', 45, 1, 5, 94715) Yet every year sees fresh attempts made only to end in failure like their predecessors.
('71', 45, 1, 6, 94803) All that has, however, failed to damp the spirit of the explorers.
('71', 45, 1, 7, 94870) If that is the case with the conquest of the Himalayas, what about the conquest of self, which is a harder job by far, even as the reward is richer?
('71', 45, 1, 8, 95019) The scaling of the the Himalayas can, at best, give a temporary feeling of elation and triumph.
('71', 45, 1, 9, 95115) But the reward of the conquest of self is a spiritual bliss that knows no waning and grows ever more and more.
('71', 45, 1, 10, 95226) It is a welll known maxim of the science of brahmacharya that insemination in the case of a man who has properly kept the rules of brahmacharya cannot, ought not to, fail to lead to conception.
('71', 45, 1, 11, 95420) And this is just as it should be.
('71', 45, 1, 12, 95454) When a man has completely conquered his animality, involuntary incontinence becomes impossible, and the desire for sexual gratification for its own sake ceases altogether.
('71', 45, 1, 13, 95626) Sexual union then takes place only when there is a desire for offspring.
('71', 45, 1, 14, 95699) This is the meaning of what has been described as ‘married brahmacharya’.
('71', 45, 1, 15, 95773) In other words, a person who obeys this rule, though leading a married life, attains the same state as, and is equal in merit to, one who completely abstains from the sexual act, which is only a means for procreation, never for self indulgence.
('71', 45, 1, 16, 96018) In practice, it is true, this ideal is seen to be rarely realized in its completeness.
('71', 45, 1, 17, 96105) But in shaping our ideals we cannot think in terms of our weaknesses or the possible lapses.
('71', 45, 1, 18, 96198) The present tendency, however, is to take a complete swing round, and the protagonists of contraceptives have almost set up self indulgence as their ideal.
('71', 45, 1, 19, 96354) Self indulgence obviously can never be an ideal.
('71', 45, 1, 20, 96403) There can be no limit to the practice of an ideal.
('71', 45, 1, 21, 96454) But unlimited self indulgence, as everybody would admit, can only result in certain destruction of the individual or the race concerned.
('71', 45, 1, 22, 96591) Hence self control alone can be our ideal, and it has been so regarded from the earliest times.
('71', 45, 1, 23, 96687) Therefore we have to explore the means of its attainment, not to circumvent it.
('71', 45, 1, 24, 96767) It has become my settled conviction that most of the difficulties that are experienced in connection with the practice of brahmacharya are due to our ignorance about its laws and would of themselves disappear if we discovered them.
('71', 45, 1, 25, 96999) Let us, for instance, examine the poser propounded by our correspondent in the ideal light.
('71', 45, 1, 26, 97091) In the ideal state, in the first place, such a contingency will never arise, because in a normally healthy couple, who have from their childhood upward observed the rules of brahmacharya, sexual union can never prove
('71', 46, 0, 1, 97308) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 47
('71', 46, 1, 2, 97350) infertile.
('71', 46, 1, 3, 97361) In practice, however, anomalies do arise.
('71', 46, 1, 4, 97403) The only rule that can be laid down in such instances is that coitus may be permittedonce at the end of the monthly period till conception is established.
('71', 46, 1, 5, 97558) If its object is achieved it must be adjured forthwith, for mere sensual gratification should never be its object.
('71', 46, 1, 6, 97673) It is my faith based on my experience that bodily and mental health increases in the same ratio as bodily and mental chastity.
('71', 46, 1, 7, 97800) Nor is it to be wondered at.
('71', 46, 1, 8, 97829) A substance that is capable of producing such a wounderful being as man, cannot but be transmuted into matchless energy and strength.
('71', 46, 1, 9, 97963) Anyone can test for himself the truth of this observation of the Shastras for himself by personal experience.
('71', 46, 1, 10, 98073) And the rule holds good in respect of woman no less than man.
('71', 46, 1, 11, 98135) The real difficulty, however, is that we vainly expect to be free from outward manifestations of lust, while harbouring it in our minds, with the result that physically and mentally we become utter wrecks, and our lives, in the words of the Gita become a living lie or hypocrisy personified.
('71', 46, 1, 12, 98427) Harijan, 20 3 1937

('71', 47, 4, 8, 99223) 52. LETTER TO PARIKSHITLAL L. MAJUMDAR
('71', 47, 5, 9, 99262) SEGAON, March 13, 1937
('71', 47, 6, 10, 99285) BHAI PARIKSHITLAL, I got your letter.
('71', 47, 6, 11, 99323) The description of the Harijan school at Edarpura appears to be good but I refrain from publishing it.
('71', 47, 6, 12, 99426) There have been instances in the past when, after a favourable description about a school or an institution was received and published, our subsequent experience of it was bitter.
('71', 47, 6, 13, 99606) Either we do not have the courage to publish such experience or it seems improper to do so.
('71', 47, 6, 14, 99698) If, however, one occasionally comes across a description like the one you have given, one may derive what joy one can from it and then forget about it.
('71', 47, 6, 15, 99850) One would then be saved from the kind of embarrassing situation mentioned above.
('71', 47, 6, 16, 99931) If it is a really good school, it will surely go on progressing.
('71', 47, 6, 17, 99996) Such a school cares for no praise.
('71', 47, 6, 18, 100031) I have not seen many reasons to hope that because of our description of a school others will immediately copy its example.
('71', 47, 6, 19, 100154) However, I have not made it a rule in my mind that such descriptions should never be published.
('71', 47, 6, 20, 100250) Whenever, therefore, you feel it very necessary to publish a particular description, please write to me.
('71', 47, 6, 21, 100355) Blessings from BAPU

('71', 48, 2, 3, 100520) The following figures represent the aggregate out turn of handlooms using both inigenous and foreign mill yarn up to 1934: YEAR AVERAGE OUT TURN OF CLOTH
('71', 48, 3, 4, 100674) IN HUNDRED THOUSAND YARDS 1911 14 ..

('71', 48, 5, 6, 100722) 1925 28 ..
('71', 48, 6, 7, 100733) 1930 ..
('71', 48, 7, 8, 100741) 1931 ..
('71', 48, 8, 9, 100749) 1932 ..
('71', 48, 9, 10, 100757) 1933 ..
('71', 48, 10, 11, 100765) 1934 ..
('71', 48, 10, 12, 100773) 170 It is difficult to say how far these figures are reliable.
('71', 48, 10, 13, 100836) But I think it may safely be assumed that if they err at all it is on the side of understatement.
('71', 48, 10, 14, 100934) The actual production of the handlooms is probably higher.
('71', 48, 10, 15, 100993) We ought to be able to convert all these handlooms to the use of hand spun yarn, but we are powerless to do that today.
('71', 48, 10, 16, 101113) Our charkha yarn today is neither of sufficient strength nor is it produced in sufficient quantity.
('71', 48, 10, 17, 101213) So long as we cannot produce hand spun yarn that will stand comparison with the mill yarn in strength and uninformity, the handloom weaver will refuse to handle it and for very good reason too.
('71', 48, 10, 18, 101407) In the first place, the employement of weak and uneven yarn reduces the quantity of cloth that he can turn out in a given time and thus affects his earning capacity.
('71', 48, 10, 19, 101573) Secondly, the handloom weaver today has specialized more or less in higher lines of production while our output of hand spun yarn of fine count is extremely meagre and that too is confined mostly to Andhra.
('71', 48, 10, 20, 101780) The solution of the difficulty involves a complete mastery of the khadi science.
('71', 48, 10, 21, 101861) But I am not asking anybody to tackle this problem today.
('71', 48, 10, 22, 101919) It can for the present wait.
('71', 48, 10, 23, 101948) There are a number of other problems whichwill have to be successfully tackled before we can cope with the question of the handloom.
('71', 48, 10, 24, 102081) Only let it be borne in mind that this

('71', 53, 2, 3, 106617) DELHI, March 16, 1937 The A. I. C. C. endorses and confirms the resolutions of the Working Committee passed at Wardha on February 27 and 28, 1937, on the extra parliamentary activities of Congress members of the Legislatures, mass contact and the Congress policy in the Legislatures and calls upon all Congressmen in the Legislatures and outside to work in accordance with the directions contained in them.
('71', 53, 2, 4, 107024) And on the pending question of office acceptance and in pursuance of the policy summed up in the foregoing paragraph, the A. I. C. C. authorizes and permits the acceptance of the Ministerial offices in Provinces where the Congress commands majority in the Legislature; provided that Ministerships shall not be accepted unless the Leader of the Congress Party in the Legislature is satisfied and is able to state publicly that as long as he and his Cabinet act within the Constitution, the Governor will not use his special powers of interference or set aside the advice of Ministers.

('71', 55, 1, 2, 109830) 64. LETTER TO LILAVATI ASAR March 17, 1937
('71', 55, 2, 3, 109873) LILAVATI, I have written to Ba, but it is you who will have to prepare the thing.
('71', 55, 2, 4, 109955) You will have always to give to Kanu 1 the bread which he will take with him and eat in the evening.
('71', 55, 2, 5, 110056) If it is necessary to prepare something else also, do it yourself.
('71', 55, 2, 6, 110123) Keep an account of each minute of yours.
('71', 55, 2, 7, 110164) If possible, form the habit of getting up at 4 o’clock without fail.

('71', 58, 1, 2, 114577) 69. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('71', 58, 2, 3, 114604) DELHI, March 19, 1937
('71', 58, 3, 4, 114626) Asked for his comments on the resolution 1 of the A. I. C. C., Gandhiji said: This is not now within my province.
('71', 58, 3, 5, 114740) I being now aloof from the day to day activities of the Congress, it is not for me to forecast how the resolution would work out in the actualities of provincial politics.
('71', 58, 3, 6, 114912) My interest at present is confined to that of tendering advice and assisting in drafting 2.
('71', 58, 4, 7, 115004) Denying very firmly any intention to make office acceptance virtually impossible, he said: The resolution is a downright honest resolution, without the slightest mental reservation but it must be read as an indivisible whole.
('71', 58, 4, 8, 115230) If Governors want Congressmen to take office, I can see nothing in the resolution to make it even awkward to them to give the fullest satisfaction to the Congress leaders in their representative Provinces– this of course within the very limited sphere in which Provincial Governors have discretion and the resolution has asked for nothing more.
('71', 58, 4, 9, 115576) Any leader summoned by the Governor in terms of the Act to form his Cabinet will naturally use the Congress resolution by way of illustration and he will ask for an assurance in cases covered by the resolution.
('71', 58, 5, 10, 115787) Asked if he would indicate some of the details of the plan of work of Congress Ministries, Gandhiji said that that could be best done by those who were likely to be in office themselves.
('71', 58, 5, 11, 115974) The Hindustan Times, 20 3 1937
('71', 58, 6, 12, 116005) 70. ENFORCED WIDOWHOOD
('71', 58, 7, 13, 116028) Pyarelal has unearthed the following instructive extract on the suttee and widowhood from the treatise on universal histroy by Diodorus the Sicilian who lived in the age of Julius Caesar.
('71', 58, 8, 14, 116216) Now it was an ancient law among the Indians that when young men and maidens were minded to wed they did not marry according to the judgment of the parents, but by mutual consent.
('71', 58, 8, 15, 116395) But when espousals were made between
('71', 58, 9, 16, 116432) 1 Vide Appendix Resolution Passed at A.I.C.C. Meeting, Delhi”, 16 3 1937. 2 Vide “Extract from A. I. C. C. Resolution”, 16 3 1937
('71', 59, 0, 1, 116562) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 59, 1, 2, 116603) persons of immature age, mistakes of judgment were of frequent occurrence, and when both sides repented their union, many of the women became depraved, and through incontinence fell in love with other men, and when at last they wished to leave the husbands they had first chosen, but could not in decency do so openly, they got rid of them by poison, a means of destroying life which they could readily procure in their country which produces in great quantity and variety drugs of fatal potency, some of which cause death if merely introduced as powder into food and drink.
('71', 59, 1, 3, 117178) But when this nefarious practice had become quite prevalent, and many lives had been sacrificed, and when it was found that the punishment of the guilty had no effect in deterring other wives from their career of iniquity, they passed a law ordaining that a wife, unless she was pregnant or had already borne children, should be burned along with the deceased husband, and that if she did not choose to obey the law she sould remain a widow to the end of her life, and be for ever excomm unicated from the sacrifices and other solemnities as being an impious person.
('71', 59, 1, 4, 117745) If these extracts give a faithful account of the origin of the two inhuman customs, we have reason to thank Heavens for the suppression of the suttee by law imposed upon us.
('71', 59, 1, 5, 117919) No outside impo sition can cure Hindu society of the enforced widowhood of girls who don’t even know what marriage is.
('71', 59, 1, 6, 118038) The reform can come first by the force of enlightened public opinion among Hindus, secondly by parents recognizing the duty of marrying their girl widows.
('71', 59, 1, 7, 118193) This they can do, where the girls’ consent is lacking, by educating their minds to the correctness of their marrying.
('71', 59, 1, 8, 118311) Naturally this refers to girls under age.
('71', 59, 1, 9, 118353) Where the so called widows have grown to maturity and they do not desire to marry, nothing is necessary save to tell them that they are free to marry precisely as if they were maidens unmarried.
('71', 59, 1, 10, 118548) It is difficult to break the chains of prisoners who hug them, mis taking them as ornaments, as girls and even grown up women do regard their silver or golden chains and rings as ornaments.
('71', 59, 1, 11, 118738) Harijan, 20 3 1937
('71', 59, 2, 12, 118757) 71. AN ILLUSION
('71', 59, 3, 13, 118773) I received this letter 1 last November.
('71', 59, 3, 14, 118813) But owing to pressure of work I could not write anything up till now.
('71', 59, 3, 15, 118883) The writer is a scholar of
('71', 59, 4, 16, 118910) 1 Not translated here.
('71', 59, 4, 17, 118933) The correspondent had said that caste Hindus ill treated Harijans because they were poor and suggested that unless their economic conditions were improved, anti untouchability activities would bear no fruit.
('71', 60, 0, 1, 119141) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 61
('71', 60, 1, 2, 119183) Lahore.
('71', 60, 1, 3, 119191) It is surprising that he should be labouring under such a grave misapprehension.
('71', 60, 1, 4, 119272) Perhaps the recent miracle of Travancore has removed his misapprehension.
('71', 60, 1, 5, 119346) Still there are many people who harbour such misconceptions.
('71', 60, 1, 6, 119407) So, it would be better to reply to his letter.
('71', 60, 1, 7, 119454) In Travancore the Harijans behind the strong movement for temple entry were not wanting in money.
('71', 60, 1, 8, 119552) Their leader was, and still is, Shri Govindan, an ex judge of Travancore.
('71', 60, 1, 9, 119626) Money brought them no peace.
('71', 60, 1, 10, 119655) Temple entry has brought them peace; we witness it for ourselves.
('71', 60, 1, 11, 119721) They are very pleased with the Maharaja and Maharani.
('71', 60, 1, 12, 119775) Even if the Maharaja had bestowed half his kingdom on them, it would not have achieved what temple entry has achieved.
('71', 60, 1, 13, 119894) This miracle shows that man values many things more than wealth.
('71', 60, 1, 14, 119959) Man sacrifices his all for self respect.
('71', 60, 1, 15, 120000) People have suffered many hardships in the cause of religion, and have even embraced death for it.
('71', 60, 1, 16, 120099) When Hindus observe untouchability towards non Hindus, there is certainly hatred in it.
('71', 60, 1, 17, 120187) But as the non Hindus are strong, they do not feel it as much as the Harijans do, who in spite of belonging to the same religion are considered untouchables.
('71', 60, 1, 18, 120345) It is also not right to say that there are restrictions in the matter of eating and drinking even among the four castes.
('71', 60, 1, 19, 120466) The difference between this and untouchability is like that between an elephant and an ant.
('71', 60, 1, 20, 120558) Untouchables are outcastes.
('71', 60, 1, 21, 120586) However rich they may be, if they do anything outside their custom they are flogged.
('71', 60, 1, 22, 120671) It is my firm belief that Hindus alone are responsible for the grievances of the Harijans.
('71', 60, 1, 23, 120762) They have made injustice their dharma.
('71', 60, 1, 24, 120801) To describe their problem as an economic one is tantamount to denying their present situation.
('71', 60, 1, 25, 120896) From the way this correspondent writes it appears that though he is a Hindu, he keeps himself a little outside the Hindu society.
('71', 60, 1, 26, 121026) There are no Brahmins who are hated by Rajputs or any other caste Hindus.
('71', 60, 1, 27, 121100) On the other hand, we find that a Brahmin or any other caste Hindu is worshipped even by the rich if he embraces poverty.
('71', 60, 1, 28, 121222) In the end, even after having read the correspondent’s letter with due care and courtesy, I do not regret anything I have said or done regarding untouchability.
('71', 60, 1, 29, 121383) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 20 3 1937

('71', 61, 8, 19, 122810) It is a matter for rejoicing that interest can be created in this way in khadi amongst girls and boys.

('71', 62, 0, 1, 123598) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 63
('71', 62, 1, 2, 123640) for a balanced diet also prepared there.
('71', 62, 1, 3, 123681) If these activities are properly developed and the boys and girls are taught in the skills needed for them in a manner which they would understand, their minds would truly develop.
('71', 62, 1, 4, 123862) It is an illusion to believe that a child’s intellect develops by cramming it with facts which have no relevance to his life.
('71', 62, 1, 5, 123988) These may well provide entertainment to the intellect, they cannot develop it, because their intellect will not be able to discriminate.
('71', 62, 1, 6, 124125) But whenever a boy or a girl has to perform some activity and that activity is not taught to him in a mechanical fashion but the reason behind each activity is explained, in such cases the child’s intellect develops readily, he acquires self awareness, self respect and self reliance.

('71', 62, 2, 8, 124451) 74. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('71', 62, 3, 9, 124478) [DELHI , On or before March 22, 1937] 2
('71', 62, 4, 10, 124518) Question: It is all right that you teach us tailoring and high class shoe making.

('71', 63, 1, 2, 125938) A. Not by asking you to give up the occupation of your forefathers but by doing it ourselves.

('71', 67, 6, 7, 132876) 82. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('71', 67, 7, 8, 132906) SEGAON, March 25, 1937
('71', 67, 8, 9, 132929) KANTI 1, I could not write to you earlier.
('71', 67, 8, 10, 132972) I had a talk with Devdas.
('71', 67, 8, 11, 132998) If you wish to go to Mysore, you may do so.
('71', 67, 8, 12, 133042) If the expenses increase by your going there, Devdas will earn the money or raise it.
('71', 67, 8, 13, 133128) It is, therefore, not necessary for you to join Wilson [College, Bombay] for want of money or Devdas’s consent.
('71', 67, 8, 14, 133240) You may go to Trivandrum if you like.
('71', 67, 8, 15, 133278) If you get a cargo ship and desire to go by it, there is no objection.
('71', 67, 8, 16, 133349) It is certainly good to travel thus.
('71', 67, 8, 17, 133386) Devdas will bear the expense of the voyage, but if he does not, then you may ask me for it.
('71', 67, 8, 18, 133478) It would not be proper to take it from me if he can bear it.
('71', 67, 8, 19, 133539) I know Devdas could not see you.
('71', 67, 8, 20, 133572) On my asking him he told me that he had tried to see you but could not.
('71', 67, 8, 21, 133644) He did not send for you because his programme was uncertain.
('71', 67, 8, 22, 133705) One should not mind such things.
('71', 67, 8, 23, 133738) And in any case one should never be suspicious.
('71', 67, 8, 24, 133786) You may take from Nimu or Ramdas whatever money you immediately need.
('71', 67, 8, 25, 133856) We, i.e., Ba, Manu, Kanu (Junior), Mahadev, Pyarelal and I are leaving for Madras today.
('71', 67, 8, 26, 133945) We shall be there for three days, and shall be back on the 31st.
('71', 67, 8, 27, 134010) It has almost been decided to have Manu’s wedding 2 in Hudli.
('71', 67, 9, 28, 134072) 1 Son of Harilal Gandhi 2 With Surendra Mashruwala on April 18; vide “Advice to Newly married Couples”, 18 4 1937.
('71', 68, 0, 1, 134187) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 69
('71', 68, 1, 2, 134229) Did you cancel your proposed trip to Rajkot?
('71', 68, 1, 3, 134274) Do you wish to have Amtul Salaam with you?
('71', 68, 1, 4, 134317) She thinks that you do, but Devdas’s impression and mine is that you do not.
('71', 68, 1, 5, 134394) If that is the case, please write to her frankly.
('71', 68, 1, 6, 134444) She is making herself needlessly unhappy.
('71', 68, 1, 7, 134486) She was with me in Delhi as long as I was there.
('71', 68, 1, 8, 134535) My language need not be considered mathematical just because I use mathematical terms.
('71', 68, 1, 9, 134622) But if it is as exact as mathematics, that is, if its successive steps in reasoning are logical and exact, it may be described as mathematical.
('71', 68, 1, 10, 134766) If my language has that quality, it is because of my worship of truth.
('71', 68, 1, 11, 134837) One who wants to learn only a subject of intellectual study can very well do so from a person without character, and such a person may certainly be intelligent also.
('71', 68, 1, 12, 135003) For instance, a craftsman without character may be highly proficient in his craft.
('71', 68, 1, 13, 135086) But the highest intelligence or craftsmanship without good character can never do good to the world or serve it.
('71', 68, 1, 14, 135199) The effect of such service will be temporary.
('71', 68, 1, 15, 135245) That is why the Gita says: “Worship me and I will give you intelligence and whatever else you need”.
('71', 68, 1, 16, 135346) “Worship me”means ‘serve me–my creation’.
('71', 68, 1, 17, 135388) After writing these sheets I went to the ‘library’ and after returning I am now drinking milk and am dictating this while doing so.
('71', 68, 1, 18, 135520) I had taken your letter to the ‘library’, just to see whether I had omitted to reply to any point.
('71', 68, 1, 19, 135619) I am replying in brief to what has been left out.
('71', 68, 1, 20, 135669) A self controlled man should be busy in service for all the twenty four hours.
('71', 68, 1, 21, 135748) If it is merely doing anything even a demon can do it.
('71', 68, 1, 22, 135803) This is in the character of a Ravana.
('71', 68, 1, 23, 135841) But such a person cannot be regarded as a self controlled man.
('71', 68, 1, 24, 135904) Activity is threefold: of body, mind and soul.
('71', 68, 1, 25, 135951) In pure service there is a combination of the three.
('71', 68, 1, 26, 136004) I do know that it is not an easy task to interpret ahimsa in mathematical language.
('71', 68, 1, 27, 136088) I am trying to do that.
('71', 68, 1, 28, 136112) And what is true of ahimsa is also true of all other things, e.g., spinning, village industries, etc.
('71', 68, 1, 29, 136214) But perhaps you will understand all this on your own if you start reading the three journals 1. I am expecting from you work of that level.
('71', 68, 1, 30, 136354) I have torn up your letter.
('71', 68, 1, 31, 136382) Nothing from it will pass to Delhi.
('71', 68, 1, 32, 136418) If you decide to go to Trivandrum, and if you do not take a ship and if you can free yourself from there, then why not join us in Madras?
('71', 68, 2, 33, 136556) Blessings from BAPU

('71', 69, 1, 2, 136731) 83. SPEECH AT DAKSHIN BHARAT HINDI PRACHAR SABHA, MADRAS 1
('71', 69, 2, 3, 136790) March 26, 1937
('71', 69, 3, 4, 136805) Mahatmaji expressed his intention to speak in Hindi and .
('71', 69, 3, 5, 136863) said: It is not my purpose to hear my own voice.
('71', 69, 3, 6, 136912) I would like that you should all hear it and, what is more important, understand it; for otherwise there can be neither pleasure nor profit in speaking.
('71', 69, 3, 7, 137065) So kindly raise your hands, those who understand me–partially or fully.
('71', 69, 4, 8, 137137) A good number of hands went up.
('71', 69, 4, 9, 137169) And now those who cannot understand me, please put up your hands.
('71', 69, 5, 10, 137235) Gandhiji looked round at those with lifted hands and seeing Mr. G. A. Natesan among them cried out: Shame, shame!
('71', 69, 6, 11, 137349) “It is a shame,”Mr. Natesan agreed and added, “and I am very sorry indeed.” Gandhiji at once took the opportunity to impress upon those present the need for learning Hindi: You understand on whom I have just now cried shame.
('71', 69, 6, 12, 137574) It is my good old friend, Mr. Natesan.
('71', 69, 6, 13, 137613) Of course, I would not take that liberty with others.
('71', 69, 6, 14, 137667) I have known him since 1915 when I came here from South Africa and he and I understand each other.
('71', 69, 6, 15, 137766) He is a great publisher and editor.
('71', 69, 6, 16, 137802) He has also brought out translations of great Sanskrit works.
('71', 69, 6, 17, 137864) He has enthusiasm and youthfulness for such work.
('71', 69, 6, 18, 137914) But what has he done in regard to Hindi?
('71', 69, 6, 19, 137955) He may say, ‘Oh I am old.’ Perhaps, he is, in body.
('71', 69, 6, 20, 138007) But let not the mind get old.
('71', 69, 6, 21, 138037) Let it go on adding to its store of knowledge.
('71', 69, 6, 22, 138084) For, one whose mind has not become old can do great good to himself and to his fellowmen.
('71', 69, 6, 23, 138174) There are still some persons–happily, they are very few–who seem to consider it a sin to look upon Hindi Hindustani as the national language and a greater sin to study it.
('71', 69, 6, 24, 138346) I can say from my experience that those who recognize the place of Hindi as the national language will take to its study with enthusiasm and earnestness, whether it be their mother tongue or not.
('71', 69, 6, 25, 138542) Otherwise, they may not be able to contribute to its growth as the national language.
('71', 69, 6, 26, 138628) Hindi cannot take the place of the different provincial languages nor is that the aim of Hindi prachar.
('71', 69, 6, 27, 138732) On the other hand, the spread of the national
('71', 69, 7, 28, 138778) 1 Gandhiji presided over the convocation of the Sabha.
('71', 70, 0, 1, 138833) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 71
('71', 70, 1, 2, 138875) language will accelerate the growth of the provincial languages and vice versa.
('71', 70, 1, 3, 138955) A strong and virile national language requires healthy development of the provincial languages.
('71', 70, 1, 4, 139051) If the latter be weak and anaemic, how can the former at all grow?
('71', 70, 2, 5, 139118) Gujarati, I said to myself, cannot be the language.
('71', 70, 2, 6, 139170) Not more than a thirtieth part of the people of the country speaks it.
('71', 70, 2, 7, 139241) How am I to find Tulsi Ramayana therein?
('71', 70, 2, 8, 139282) What about Marathi, then, I wondered.
('71', 70, 2, 9, 139320) I love Marathi.
('71', 70, 2, 10, 139336) I claim among the Marathi speaking people some staunch co workers.
('71', 70, 2, 11, 139403) I know the Maharastrians’ efficiency, capacity for self sacrifice, and their learning.
('71', 70, 2, 12, 139490) And yet I did not think Marathi–the language that Lokamanya Tilak wielded so wonderfully well–could be our rashtrabhasha.
('71', 70, 2, 13, 139612) When I was thus reasoning this out, let me tell you that I did not know the actual number of people speaking Hindi, and yet I instinctively felt that only Hindi could take that place, and no other.
('71', 70, 2, 14, 139810) Did I not appreciate Bengali?
('71', 70, 2, 15, 139840) I did, and I thought highly of it as the language of Chaitanya, Ram Mohun Roy, Ramakrishna, Vivekananda and Rabindranath Tagore.
('71', 70, 2, 16, 139969) And yet I felt that we could not make even Bengali the language of inter provincial intercourse.
('71', 70, 3, 17, 140066) I was convinced long ago, and my conviction has grown stronger since from experience, that if any Indian language can ever become India’s national language–and some one must become the national language if Indians are to become a nation–that language was only Hindi, and I have always directed my efforts in its cause.
('71', 70, 3, 18, 140385) No doubt, in the South we are up against a great problem in this matter.
('71', 70, 3, 19, 140458) But we cannot see how a language of the South, Tamil or Telugu or any other, can serve as the national language.
('71', 70, 3, 20, 140571) I honestly tried to learn Telugu and Tamil.
('71', 70, 3, 21, 140615) Indeed there was a time when I could speak in Tamil quite as well as I am now speaking Hindi.
('71', 70, 3, 22, 140709) I had sufficient material when I was in South Africa to assist me in this, because I had to work in the midst of Tamils.
('71', 70, 3, 23, 140830) but I must confess, to my regret and shame, that I have not kept up touch with it and have forgotten what little I knew of that language.
('71', 70, 3, 24, 140968) I am not wholly responsible for it.
('71', 70, 3, 25, 141004) The blame for it rests partly on my Tamil friends.
('71', 70, 3, 26, 141055) I have taken a girl 2 from Tamil Nad into my household as my daughter in law.
('71', 70, 3, 27, 141133) But instead of compelling me to keep touch with Tamil, she has learnt Hindi and Gujarati and speaks and writes in
('71', 70, 4, 28, 141247) 1 Vide also “Speech at Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad, Madras II”, 28 3 1937
('71', 70, 5, 29, 141320) 2 Lakshmi, Devdas Gandhi’s wife, daughter of C. Rajagopalachari
('71', 71, 0, 1, 141384) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 71, 1, 2, 141425) What can I do?
('71', 71, 1, 3, 141440) How can I hope to refresh my knowledge of Tamil when Tamilians let me down in this manner?
('71', 71, 1, 4, 141531) Nor is my Hindi particularly good.
('71', 71, 1, 5, 141566) My friends behind, who are all proficient in Hindi, laugh at my Hindi pronunciation and grammar.
('71', 71, 1, 6, 141663) I know both are erratic for I have not studied either.
('71', 71, 1, 7, 141718) It will do for my purpose if I am able to express my thoughts so as to be understood.
('71', 71, 1, 8, 141804) If I attempt to be grammatical, I am afraid the results will not be very complimentary to me.
('71', 71, 1, 9, 141898) I must, on this occasion, express my regret at the absence of any book to help Hindi speaking people to learn Tamil.
('71', 71, 1, 10, 142015) If they want to learn Tamil, they have to do it through English.
('71', 71, 1, 11, 142080) We have not shown the zeal in this cause which some Western Missionaries have evinced.
('71', 71, 1, 12, 142167) I would appeal to Tamils and also my North Indian friends to remedy this defect.
('71', 71, 1, 13, 142248) I am thankful to my South Indian friends for the enthusiasm they have shown in learning Hindi but I must say it is not sufficient.
('71', 71, 1, 14, 142379) It is a unique event that the session of the All India Sahitya Sammelan is being held in Madras, where Tamil is the chief language.
('71', 71, 1, 15, 142511) Tamil, of all the Dravidian languages, has borrowed least from Sanskrit.
('71', 71, 1, 16, 142584) This, no doubt, is a handicap to Tamilians in learning Hindi.
('71', 71, 1, 17, 142646) But still they have striven to learn the language.
('71', 71, 2, 18, 142697) I certainly congratulate you on what you have achieved.
('71', 71, 2, 19, 142753) But I should be satisfied only when distinguished people like my friend G. A. Natesan, member of the Council of State, give half an hour each day to the study of Hindi.
('71', 71, 2, 20, 142922) Let him not plead old age.
('71', 71, 2, 21, 142949) If he is not too old to edit the Indian Review, if he is not too old to study Sanskrit and issue Sanskrit publications one after another, if he is not too old to go to the Council of State, why should he be too old to learn Hindi?
('71', 71, 2, 22, 143180) What I mean to say is this.
('71', 71, 2, 23, 143208) Up till now only the middleclass people have taken up the study of Hindi.
('71', 71, 2, 24, 143282) When will our distinguished leaders take it up?
('71', 71, 2, 25, 143330) When will the Advocate General find half an hour to leave his briefs aside and devote it to Hindi?
('71', 71, 2, 26, 143429) I want men and women among the most distinguished of the South to study Hindi.

('71', 72, 1, 2, 143626) 84. SHAMEFUL IF TRUE
('71', 72, 2, 3, 143647) A correspondent in British Malabar writes: 1
('71', 72, 3, 4, 143692) I desire you kindly to comment on the following incident which has
('71', 72, 4, 5, 143759) agitated me considerably.
('71', 72, 4, 6, 143785) A public procession was organized by the
('71', 72, 5, 7, 143826) Congress workers of our village on the eve of the General Elections to the
('71', 72, 6, 8, 143901) Assembly.
('71', 72, 6, 9, 143911) A Harijan boy of the place wished to go along with the
('71', 72, 7, 10, 143966) procession.
('71', 72, 7, 11, 143978) But the organizers requested him to keep away, mildly saying to
('71', 72, 8, 12, 144042) him, ‘Of course, as you know, we are in full sympathy with you.
('71', 72, 8, 13, 144106) But the
('71', 72, 9, 14, 144114) procession has to go through by lanes along which you people are not
('71', 72, 10, 15, 144183) generally allowed.
('71', 72, 10, 16, 144202) Then again, we fear that the orthodox may make this a
('71', 72, 11, 17, 144256) plea for voting against the Congress.
('71', 72, 11, 18, 144294) We, therefore, consider it prudent
('71', 72, 12, 19, 144329) that you do not accompany us.’ The poor boy returned with a heavy
('71', 72, 13, 20, 144395) This ill treatment of the noble Harijan lad, if the report is true, deserves severe condemnation, and victory at elections or in other matters is not worth anything if it is bought with the suppression of Harijan liberty.
('71', 72, 13, 21, 144617) The prohibition against Harijans making use of the roads in the place mentioned is an illegal act and ought not to be tolerated for a single day.
('71', 72, 13, 22, 144763) Workers should reason with the objectors, and if they do not listen, a test case should be made by taking a few Harijans through the prohibited streets.
('71', 72, 13, 23, 144916) One would have thought that in Malabar at least such things as are described by the correspondent would not happen.
('71', 72, 13, 24, 145032) Harijan, 27 3 1937
('71', 72, 14, 25, 145051) 85. A VOICE IN THE WILDERNESS
('71', 72, 15, 26, 145081) Just lately I read a review of your conference 2 with Mrs. Sanger, the
('71', 72, 16, 27, 145152) birth control advocate.
('71', 72, 16, 28, 145176) I was so deeply moved that I am writing you to express
('71', 72, 17, 29, 145231) my appreciation for your stand.
('71', 72, 17, 30, 145263) God bless you for your courage.
('71', 72, 18, 31, 145295) I realize it will take centuries to educate the public to higher ideals, but
('71', 72, 19, 32, 145372) there is no time like the present to begin.
('71', 72, 19, 33, 145416) I fear she mistakes passion for love,
('71', 72, 20, 34, 145454) for love is of the spirit and never born of lust.
('71', 72, 21, 35, 145504) 1 Only an extract is reproduced here.
('71', 72, 21, 36, 145542) 2 Vide “Interview to Margaret Sanger”, 3/4 12 1935
('71', 73, 0, 1, 145593) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 73, 1, 2, 145634) Dr. Alexis Carrel agrees with you, in that sex control is not harmful
('71', 73, 2, 3, 145704) except to those who feed their passions and are already unbalanced.
('71', 73, 3, 4, 145772) Sanger is wrong in saying that most doctors believe abstinence is harmful.
('71', 73, 4, 5, 145847) find many leading doctors and scientists belonging to the American Social
('71', 73, 5, 6, 145921) Hygiene Association hold that control is beneficial.
('71', 73, 6, 7, 145974) You are doing a noble work.
('71', 73, 6, 8, 146002) You are one of the few who have this
('71', 73, 7, 9, 146039) higher spiritual viewpoint on the sex question.
('71', 73, 8, 10, 146087) Let us keep up the good work so that youth may know the truth, for the hope of the future is in their hands.
('71', 73, 9, 11, 146196) I add a quotation from one of my talks to boys: “.
('71', 73, 9, 12, 146247) Creation– physical, mental and spiritual–is joy and life.
('71', 73, 9, 13, 146305) If you are merely seeking the sensations of the flesh with no thought of creating, or even trying to avoid the aim of creation you are perverting nature and killing your spiritual powers.
('71', 73, 10, 14, 146493) I know this is like a prophet crying in the wilderness, but I am convinced of the truth of it, and I can but point the way.
('71', 73, 10, 15, 146617) This is one of the letters 1 which I occasionally get from America in condemnation of the use of contraceptives.
('71', 73, 10, 16, 146730) Current literature that India imports weekly from the Far West would have us believe that in America none but idiots and imbeciles oppose the use of this modern method of deliverance from the bondage of the superstition which imprisons the body and crushes it by denying it its supreme enjoyment.
('71', 73, 10, 17, 147027) That literature produces as much momentary intoxication as the act which it teaches and incites us to perform without incurring the risk of its oridinary result.
('71', 73, 10, 18, 147189) I do not put before the readers of Harijan merely letters of individual condemnation received from the West.
('71', 73, 10, 19, 147298) They have their use for me as a seeker but very little for the general reader.
('71', 73, 10, 20, 147377) This letter, however, from a teacher of boys with thirty years’ experience behind him has a definite value.
('71', 73, 10, 21, 147485) It should serve as a guide for Indian teachers and the public–men and women–who are carried away by the overwhelming tide.
('71', 73, 10, 22, 147608) The use of contraceptives is infinitely more tempting than the whisky bottle.
('71', 73, 10, 23, 147686) But it is not more lawful than the sparkling liquid for its fatal temptation.

('71', 74, 2, 10, 148910) 86. THE MEANING OF IT I have a wire from Gwalior saying that the notice board in Mahakaleshwar temple in Ujjain, prohibiting the entry into it of Harijans and those who may be associating with or working with them, has been withdrawn by the Maharaja.
('71', 74, 2, 11, 149161) Before one can pronounce an opinion on the notice it is necessary to know its full meaning.
('71', 74, 2, 12, 149253) If the prohibition is not withdrawn but only the offending notice board is, the withdrawal brings no relief to the insulted Harijans and their caste associates.
('71', 74, 2, 13, 149414) It may even bring punishment to the unwary who seeing the notice board withdrawn may venture to enter the temple.
('71', 74, 2, 14, 149528) If it means withdrawal of the prohibition itself, one would expect a notification to that effect.
('71', 74, 2, 15, 149626) And if the prohibition is withdrawn from one temple, why not from all State owned temples of which I am informed there are nearly fifty in Gwalior State?
('71', 74, 2, 16, 149780) I hope, therefore, that the State authorities will clear the point and tell the public what the withdrawal of the notice board means.
('71', 74, 2, 17, 149914) Indeed there seems to be a timidity on the part of the Princes and their advisers on this matter of doing elementary justice to the poorest and the neediest of their people, and that, too, in a matter which has first class religious value but which costs them nothing materially.
('71', 74, 2, 18, 150194) The most striking example of Travancore should have shown them that if they threw open their temples to Harijans there would be no resentment.
('71', 74, 2, 19, 150337) But it may be that the Princes are afraid of the middle class Hindus with whom they come in daily contact and that they are not concerned about the silent sufferers–the bulk of the poorest–whether they be Harijans or others.
('71', 74, 2, 20, 150562) Save for a few Princes who may be counted on the fingers of one’s hands the vast majority have themselves no religious scruples about untouchability.
('71', 74, 2, 21, 150712) Must the
('71', 75, 0, 1, 150721) 76 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 75, 1, 2, 150762) Hindu Princes who are supposed to be custodians of the faith, as is shown by the titles they assume, continue to neglect this obvious duty of throwing open their temples to Harijans?
('71', 75, 1, 3, 150945) I drew attention the other day 1 to the title of the Maharaja of Travancore.
('71', 75, 1, 4, 151022) Now I learn from D. B. Har Bilas Sarda that the Maharajas of Oodeypore 2 are entitled Diwans inasmuch as they are ministers of the deity of their clan, and that whenever they visit their temples in Oodeypore they officiate like priests for the deity.
('71', 75, 1, 5, 151273) I would therefore respectfully urge the Princes and their advisers boldly and unequivocally to throw open the temples in their respective States and prove themselves worthy trustees of their faith.

('71', 76, 9, 14, 153758) March 27, 1937 The Mahamahopadhyaya’s speech has whetted my appetite for a study of Tamil, which neither age nor desire would deter me from undertaking, but only the want of time makes difficult.
('71', 76, 9, 15, 153954) The object of this conference is to collect gems from all provincial literatures and to make them available through Hindi.
('71', 76, 9, 16, 154077) For this purpose I would make an appeal to you.
('71', 76, 9, 17, 154125) Of course everyone must know his own language thoroughly well, and he should also know the great literature of other Indian languages through Hindi.

('71', 77, 1, 4, 154675) But to this end a common script is quite essential.
('71', 77, 1, 5, 154727) It is not difficult to achieve in Tamil Nad.
('71', 77, 1, 6, 154772) For look at this simple fact: over 90 per cent of our people are illiterate.

('71', 77, 1, 9, 154970) In Europe they have tried the experiment of a common script quite successfully.
('71', 77, 1, 10, 155050) Some people even go the length of saying that we might adopt the Roman script from Europe.
('71', 77, 1, 11, 155141) After a good deal of controversy there is a consensus of opinion that the common script can be Devnagari and none else.
('71', 77, 1, 12, 155261) Urdu is claimed as a rival, but I think neither Urdu nor Roman has the perfection and phonetic capacity of Devnagari.

('71', 80, 3, 4, 161659) If the Congress went on as usual while we passed resolutions in support of Hindi as the common language, our work would be painfully slow.
('71', 80, 3, 5, 161798) This resolution appeals to the Congress to exclude the use of English as a language of inter provincial communication.
('71', 80, 3, 6, 161917) English, it says, should not be allowed to take either the place of the provincial languages or of Hindi.
('71', 80, 3, 7, 162023) If English had not ousted the languages of the people, the provincial languages would have been wonderfully rich today.
('71', 80, 3, 8, 162143) If England had adopted French as the language of her national deliberations we should have had no English literature today.
('71', 80, 3, 9, 162267) French was the language there after the Norman conquest.
('71', 80, 3, 10, 162324) But then the tide turned in favour of ‘English undefiled’.
('71', 80, 3, 11, 162383) That created the great English literature we know.
('71', 80, 3, 12, 162434) What Yakub Hussain Saheb said was quite right.
('71', 80, 3, 13, 162481) The Mussalman contact had a great influence on our culture and civilization, so much so that there were men like the late Pandit Ajodhyanath who were perfect scholars in Persian and Arabic.
('71', 80, 3, 14, 162671) If they had given to their mother tongue all the time that they gave to the study of Arabic and Persian, the mother tongue would have made great progress.
('71', 80, 3, 15, 162826) Then English came to occupy the unnatural position it does until this day.
('71', 80, 3, 16, 162901) University professors can wax eloquent in English but will not be able to express their thoughts in their own mother tongue.
('71', 80, 3, 17, 163026) Sir C. V. Raman’s researches are all contained in his papers in English.

('71', 81, 1, 2, 164162) Russia.

('71', 81, 1, 4, 164274) That really prepared the way for Lenin’s Revolution.

('71', 81, 3, 7, 164770) It is not that I am making a fetish of language.
('71', 81, 3, 8, 164819) It is not that I would refuse to have swaraj if I could have it at the cost of our language, as indeed I should refuse to have it at the cost of Truth and Non violence.

('71', 81, 5, 15, 165721) Yakub Hussain Saheb asked me why I insisted so much on ‘Hindi Hindustani’ and was not content with having simple ‘Hind ustani’ as the common language.
('71', 81, 5, 16, 165872) I must take you through the genesis of the whole thing.
('71', 81, 5, 17, 165928) It was as early as 1918 that as President of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan I suggested 1 to the Hindi speaking world to broaden their definition of Hindi to include Urdu.
('71', 81, 5, 18, 166096) When I presided over the Sammelan once again in 1935 2 I had the word Hindi properly defined as a language that was spoken both by Hindus and Mussalmans and written in Devnagari or Urdu script.
('71', 81, 5, 19, 166290) My object
('71', 81, 6, 20, 166300) 1 Vide “Statement of Transvaal Indian Case”, 16 7 1909 2 Vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 29 9 1909 and “London”, 1 10 1909
('71', 82, 0, 1, 166424) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 83
('71', 82, 1, 2, 166466) in doing so was to include in Hindi the high flown Urdu of Maulana Shibli and the high flown Hindi of Pandit Shyamsunderdas.
('71', 82, 1, 3, 166591) Then came the Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad, also an off shoot of the Sammelan.
('71', 82, 1, 4, 166668) At my suggestion the name Hindi Hindustani was adopted in the place of Hindi.
('71', 82, 1, 5, 166746) Abdul Huq Saheb stoutly opposed me there.
('71', 82, 1, 6, 166788) I could not accept his suggestion.
('71', 82, 1, 7, 166823) I should have done violence to myself and to the Sammelan if I had given up the word ‘Hindi’ which was the word of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan and which I had persuaded them to define so as to include Urdu.
('71', 82, 1, 8, 167029) We must remember that the word Hindi is not of Hindu coinage, it was coined after the Muslim advent to describe the language which Hindus of the North spoke and studied.
('71', 82, 1, 9, 167199) So many Mussalman writers of note have described their language as Hindi.
('71', 82, 1, 10, 167273) And why now this quarrel over words when Hindi is defined to include the variations spoken and written by Hindus and Mussalmans?
('71', 82, 1, 11, 167402) Than there is another factor to be considered.
('71', 82, 1, 12, 167449) So far as South Indian languages are concerned it is only Hindi with a large number of Sanskrit words that can appeal to them, for they are already familiar with a certain number of Sanskrit words and the Sanskrit sound.
('71', 82, 1, 13, 167670) When the two—Hindi and Hindustani or Urdu—amalgamate and really become the all India language, daily augmented by the introduction of provincial words, we shall have a vocabulary richer even than the English vocabulary.
('71', 82, 1, 14, 167890) I hope you now understand why I insist on Hindi Hindustani.
('71', 82, 1, 15, 167950) And then I would give a tip to such of you as dread the advent of Hindi Hindustani as the only language of the Congress.
('71', 82, 1, 16, 168071) Invest in a Hindi daily or a good book, read aloud part of it regularly even for five minutes, select passages from well known Hindi writings andspeeches and repeat them to yourselves, for correct intonation, make a point of learning a few Hindi words every day, and I assure you that such regular practice will be enough to enable you to express yourselves well in Hindi Hindustani in six months’ time and without putting an undue strain on your memory.

('71', 83, 1, 2, 168585) 92. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU” 1
('71', 83, 2, 3, 168616) MADRAS, March 28, 1937 Representative: As the reputed co author of the resolution 2 of the A. I. C. C. on office acceptance, can you throw some light on the position as it has emerged today?
('71', 83, 2, 4, 168807) GANDHIJI: It is definite that I am not saying anything about politics.
('71', 83, 2, 5, 168878) That must be understood.
('71', 83, 2, 6, 168903) R. Are you aware that an opinion has been expressed that each side has but tried to put the other in the wrong and that that opinion seems to be held by responsible public men?
('71', 83, 2, 7, 169080) G. I do not know about it.
('71', 83, 2, 8, 169107) I have not yet seen this evening’s papers.
('71', 83, 2, 9, 169150) The interviewer had to switch on to other topics and he sought Gandhiji’s views on the progress of Hindi in South India with particular reference to the resolution 3 adopted by the All India Sahitya Sammelan that day urging the exclusive use of Hindi in Congress deliberations.
('71', 83, 2, 10, 169428) G. The progress made in the matter of Hindi is comparatively speaking good.
('71', 83, 2, 11, 169504) Whereas some years back there was hardly anybody who knew Hindi, today there is a big establishment looking after the training in Hindi of several thousands of boys and girls and men and women.
('71', 83, 2, 12, 169698) That is a sign of progress.
('71', 83, 2, 13, 169726) But I cannot say I am satisfied with the response from all the four Provinces of the South so far as the leaders of public opinion are concerned.
('71', 83, 2, 14, 169872) I very much fear they have not taken up the study of Hindi seriously so as to be able to carry on conversation in Hindi or to understand what is going on in the Hindi Press or to be able to speak to the multitude in northern Provinces.
('71', 83, 2, 15, 170108) It is therefore a happy thing that for the first time in the history of a southern Province, the Hindi Sammelan was invited and had its sittings in Madras.
('71', 83, 2, 16, 170264) I hope and believe the prejudice that Hindi was intended to supplant the provincial languages has by this time been set at rest.
('71', 83, 2, 17, 170393) Indeed the effort of the Sammelan is to strengthen the provincial
('71', 83, 3, 18, 170459) 1 The interview was granted to its representative “immediately after Gandhiji’s evening prayers”.
('71', 83, 3, 19, 170557) 2 Vide “Extract from A.I.C.C. Resolution”, 16 3 1937 3 Vide footnote 1, “Speech at Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad, Madras II
('71', 84, 0, 1, 170678) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 85
('71', 84, 1, 2, 170720) languages also.
('71', 84, 1, 3, 170736) If the provincial languages are not strong, Hindi as a language of inter provincial intercourse would not be able to thrive.
('71', 84, 1, 4, 170861) Love of Hindi as the rashtrabhasha must go hand in hand with love of provincial languages.
('71', 84, 1, 5, 170952) It was indeed a great thing that with unanimous consent, this resolution asking the Working Committee of the Congress to stop the use of English in all India proceedings has been passed.
('71', 84, 1, 6, 171139) I have no doubt that English has enjoyed a status and importance in public affairs which it should never have enjoyed.
('71', 84, 1, 7, 171258) He who runs can see that this usurpation by English of the place that belongs to Hindi or Hindustani has to that extent delayed the progress of Hindi and also of the vernaculars.
('71', 84, 1, 8, 171437) It is not a very flattering admission on our part that the riches and discoveries of physical sciences cannot be accurately described in the provincial languages or in Hindi.
('71', 84, 1, 9, 171612) I am convinced that it is sheer laziness on our part which makes us say so.
('71', 84, 1, 10, 171688) These two conferences, the Sammelan and the Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad, will have rendered a useful service if the eyes of leaders of opinion in the South are opened to this obvious fact.
('71', 84, 1, 11, 171876) R. If, as you say, the fear that the spread of Hindi may be prejudicial to the growth of provincial languages is dying down, is not the suggestion for the adoption of a common script for all Indian languages likely to be a disturbing factor?
('71', 84, 2, 12, 172118) G. That is a question very well put.
('71', 84, 2, 13, 172155) It should be most unfortunate if the suggestion that we should have a common script for the provincial languages disturbs in any way the provincial mind that it is an attempt directly or indirectly to undermine the importance of provincial languages.
('71', 84, 2, 14, 172406) I can say without fear of contradiction that nothing was farther from my thoughts than that by the adoption of a common script the chances of provincial languages should be reduced.
('71', 84, 2, 15, 172588) On the other hand, a common script would remove a great difficulty from the path of persons wanting to learn languages of India other than their own and would thereby facilitate the study of those languages.
('71', 84, 2, 16, 172796) My observation was based on personal experience and that of the experience of co workers.
('71', 84, 2, 17, 172886) We are an illiterate nation, illiterate in the sense that hardly seven per cent of the people of India can trace their own alphabet.
('71', 84, 2, 18, 173019) What are you going to do to the other ninety or ninety three per cent?
('71', 84, 2, 19, 173090) Should the seven or ten per cent of literates, because they are associated with a particular form of script and because they have associated the provincial sound with those signs, impose those signs on the ninety or
('71', 85, 0, 1, 173306) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 85, 1, 2, 173347) ninetythree per cent and make it difficult for them to learn other provincial languages?
('71', 85, 1, 3, 173436) A little care for the illiterate masses and a little thought about all India should convince the seven per cent of provincial literates of the necessity of adopting a common script.
('71', 85, 1, 4, 173618) Has the adoption of a common script in Europe prevented the growth of different European languages in any shape or form?
('71', 85, 2, 5, 173739) Conversation then turned on the rural uplift work which was being carried on in Segaon village and Gandhiji sat up and said: You can talk to me freely of it.
('71', 85, 2, 6, 173897) You can talk to me of khadi, the Charkha, basket making and paper making.
('71', 85, 3, 7, 173971) R. Had paper making made great progress in your Segaon reconstruction scheme?
('71', 85, 3, 8, 174049) G. If I get a contract for paper from newspapers, I hope to be able to supply their requirements, though I am not just now competing with the paper mills.
('71', 85, 3, 9, 174204) For, were I to enter into that competition just now, I must needs neglect the anti malaria work.
('71', 85, 4, 10, 174301) Speaking of malaria, Gandhiji said that preventive measures and diet were the most important items in anti malaria work.
('71', 85, 4, 11, 174422) Administration of quinine, he said, was of no avail unless food was given to the people at the same time.
('71', 85, 4, 12, 174528) Gandhiji added: I have got to give them milk or buttermilk in all cases without exception and advise the adoption of a diet which would enable them to survive the disease.
('71', 85, 4, 13, 174700) I am convinced that diet is more important than drugs and good food better than constant drugging.
('71', 85, 5, 14, 174799) An interesting piece of information which Gandhiji gave out in this connection was that he had hardly taken drugs except on two occasions.
('71', 85, 6, 15, 174938) R. Would you suggest a six month plan for Congress members of the Legislatures on these lines of rural work as the Legislatures, apparently, will have a holiday for the period?
('71', 85, 7, 16, 175115) G. Jawaharlal can prescribe one.
('71', 85, 8, 17, 175148) Gandhiji then answered a few questions about khadi.
('71', 85, 8, 18, 175200) At first, he said, he was inclined to think that enthusiasm for it had abated.
('71', 85, 8, 19, 175279) But the monthly increases in the sales of khadi made him hesitate to pronounce any opinion that love of khadi had abated.
('71', 85, 8, 20, 175401) It was certainly true, he said, that whereas formerly “a forest of khadi caps” was visible, one did not see such demonstrations now.
('71', 85, 8, 21, 175534) That, however, was no test of the real love of khadi.
('71', 85, 8, 22, 175588) Gandhiji added: I do notice this happy result of the increase in the wages of spinners that it has not affected the demand for khadi, as some workers feared it might affect and I should be surprised if, at a date not very distant, we do not adopt a further rise in the spinners’ wages.
('71', 86, 0, 1, 175874) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 87
('71', 86, 1, 2, 175916) Whilst therefore Gandhiji had absolutely no sense of despair about the progress of khadi, he could not, he said, conceal from himself or from the Press and the public his desire for much greater progress than what made so far.
('71', 86, 1, 3, 176143) Conceived as a supplementary occupation for the millions of underfed villagers of India, Gandhiji said: Khadi should command the sympathy and support of town dwellers and others who required a certain amount of clothing for covering themselves.
('71', 86, 1, 4, 176388) The Hindu, 29 3 1937
('71', 86, 2, 5, 176409) 93. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('71', 86, 3, 6, 176436) MADRAS, March 30, 1937 Having brooded over the refusal of the Governors to give the assurances asked for by invited Congress leaders in the Majority Provinces, I feel that I must give my opinion on the situation that has arisen in the country.
('71', 86, 3, 7, 176680) I have had three cables from London shown to me asking for my opinion.
('71', 86, 3, 8, 176751) Friends in Madras too have pressed for its publication.
('71', 86, 3, 9, 176807) Though it is departure from my self imposed rule, I can no longer withstand the pressure especially as I am the sole author of the office acceptance clause of the Congress resolution 1 and the originator of the idea of attaching a condition to office acceptance.
('71', 86, 3, 10, 177070) My desire was not to lay down any impossible condition.
('71', 86, 3, 11, 177126) On the contrary, I wanted to devise a condition that could be easily accepted by the Governors.
('71', 86, 3, 12, 177222) There was no intention whatsoever to lay down a condition whose acceptance would mean any the slightest abrogation of the Constitution.
('71', 86, 3, 13, 177358) Congressmen were well aware that they could not and would not ask for any such amendment.
('71', 86, 3, 14, 177448) The Congress policy was and is not to secure an amendment, but an absolute ending of the Constitution which nobody likes.
('71', 86, 3, 15, 177570) Congressmen were and are also aware that they could not end it by mere acceptance of office, even conditional.
('71', 86, 3, 16, 177681) The object of that section of the Congress which believed in office acceptance was, pending the creation, by means consistent with the Congress creed of non violence, of a situation that would transfer all power to the people, to work the offices so as to strengthen the Congress which has been shown predominantly to represent mass opinion.
('71', 86, 3, 17, 178023) I felt that this object could not be secured unless there was a gentlemanly understanding between the Governors and their Congress Ministers that they would not exercise their special powers of
('71', 86, 4, 18, 178217) 1Vide “Extract from A.I.C.C. Resolution”, 16 3 1937
('71', 87, 0, 1, 178269) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 87, 1, 2, 178310) interference so long as the Ministers acted within the Constitution.
('71', 87, 1, 3, 178379) Not to do so would be to court an almost immediate deadlock after entering upon office.
('71', 87, 1, 4, 178467) I felt that honesty demanded that under standing.
('71', 87, 1, 5, 178517) It is common cause that the Governors have discretionary powers.
('71', 87, 1, 6, 178582) Surely there was nothing extra constitutional in their saying that they would not exercise their discretion against Ministers carrying on constitutional activities.
('71', 87, 1, 7, 178747) It may be remembered that the understanding was not to touch the numerous other safeguards over which the Governors had no power.
('71', 87, 1, 8, 178877) A strong party with the decisive backing of the electorate could not be expected to put itself in the precarious position of being in dread of interference at the will of the Governors.
('71', 87, 1, 9, 179063) The question may be put in another way.
('71', 87, 1, 10, 179103) Should the Governors be courteous to the Ministers or discourteous?
('71', 87, 1, 11, 179171) I hold that it would be distinctly discourteous if they interfered with their Ministers in matters over which law gave the latter full control and with which the Governors were under no legal obligation to interfere.
('71', 87, 1, 12, 179388) A self respecting Minister conscious of an absolute majority at his back could not but demand the assurance of non interference.
('71', 87, 1, 13, 179517) Have I not heard Sir Samuel Hoare 1 and other Ministers saying in so many words that ordinarily the Governors would not use their admittedly large powers of interference?
('71', 87, 1, 14, 179688) I claim that the Congress formula has asked for nothing more.
('71', 87, 1, 15, 179750) It has been claimed on behalf of the British Government that the Act gives autonomy to the Provinces.
('71', 87, 1, 16, 179852) If that is so, it is not the Governors but the Ministers who are during their period of office responsible for the wise adminstration of their Provinces.
('71', 87, 1, 17, 180006) Responsible Ministers sensible of their duty could not submit to interference in the pursuance of their daily duty.
('71', 87, 1, 18, 180122) It does therefore appear to me that once more the British Government has broken to the heart what it has promised to the ear.
('71', 87, 1, 19, 180248) I doubt not that they can and will impose their will on the people till the latter develop enough strength from within to resist it, but that cannot be called working provincial autonomy.
('71', 87, 1, 20, 180436) By flouting the majority obtained through the machinery of their creation, they have in plain language ended the autonomy which they claim the Constitution has given to the Provinces.
('71', 87, 1, 21, 180620) The rule
('71', 87, 2, 22, 180629) 1 Secretary of State for Home Affairs
('71', 88, 0, 1, 180667) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 89
('71', 88, 1, 2, 180709) therefore will now be the rule of the sword, not of the pen, nor of the indisputable majority.
('71', 88, 1, 3, 180804) Anyway that is the only interpretation which with all the goodwill in the world, I can put upon Government action.
('71', 88, 1, 4, 180919) For I believe in the cent per cent honesty of my formula whose acceptance might have prevented a crisis and resulted in a natural, orderly and peaceful transference of power from the bureaucracy to the largest and fullest democracy known to the world.
('71', 88, 1, 5, 181171) The Hindu, 30 3 1937
('71', 88, 2, 6, 181192) 94. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR ON THE TRAIN, March 30, 1937
('71', 88, 3, 7, 181246) MY DEAR IDIOT, This is being written in the moving train.
('71', 88, 3, 8, 181304) You must have had the letter I asked Mahadev to write to you.
('71', 88, 3, 9, 181366) In Madras I had no time for anything but the work before me.
('71', 88, 3, 10, 181427) And I worked to the breaking point.
('71', 88, 3, 11, 181463) The reason was a discovery of great impurity in the Secretary of the Sabha–Pandit Harihar Sharma.
('71', 88, 3, 12, 181561) Ammu Swaminathan was not in Madras.
('71', 88, 3, 13, 181597) You did well in sending me the wire about your foot for your letter was alarming.
('71', 88, 3, 14, 181679) I hope you are now completly free.
('71', 88, 3, 15, 181714) You should discover the cause of it.
('71', 88, 3, 16, 181751) Yes, I would like you to give up even the spoonful of dal and equally give up vegetable or anything cooked or fried in ghee or oil.
('71', 88, 3, 17, 181883) I know you do not touch oil.
('71', 88, 3, 18, 181912) Do take raw onion with raw garlic, tomatoes and some green leaf.
('71', 88, 3, 19, 181977) Increase the quantity of milk.
('71', 88, 3, 20, 182008) If you have a good cow, once during the day try raw milk.
('71', 88, 3, 21, 182066) I evidently forgot to send you Dinshaw Mehta’s address.
('71', 88, 3, 22, 182122) It is Dr. Dinshaw Mehta, Healthatorium, near City Station, Poona City.
('71', 88, 3, 23, 182193) Did you ever get from him the steaming kettle?
('71', 88, 3, 24, 182240) I have asked him to send it to you per V. P. P. Jullundur City address.
('71', 88, 3, 25, 182312) Heat has commenced in these parts.
('71', 88, 3, 26, 182347) But it is not unbearable as yet.
('71', 88, 3, 27, 182380) Mira says they had a bad storm in my absence.
('71', 88, 3, 28, 182426) Wardha weather seems to have changed.
('71', 88, 3, 29, 182464) Your Hindi attempt was good.
('71', 88, 3, 30, 182493) With the Hindi Sammelan Ambujam 1 had got up a Mahila Parishad.
('71', 88, 3, 31, 182557) Ba was nominally President.
('71', 88, 4, 32, 182585) 1 Daughter of S. Srinivasa Iyengar
('71', 89, 0, 1, 182620) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('71', 89, 1, 3, 182712) It would be good excercise for you.
('71', 89, 1, 4, 182748) It has a few mistakes which you should be able to detect.

('71', 89, 3, 8, 182905) ON THE TRAIN, March 30, 1937
('71', 89, 4, 9, 182934) PRABHA, I have your letter.
('71', 89, 4, 10, 182962) I am writing this in a train that is carrying me to Wardha.
('71', 89, 4, 11, 183022) Amtul Salaam has gone to her home in Patiala.
('71', 89, 4, 12, 183068) Navin had come to Madras.
('71', 89, 4, 13, 183094) Paparamma 1 also had come.
('71', 89, 4, 14, 183121) But Saraswati could not.
('71', 89, 4, 15, 183146) The work in Madras was quite heavy.
('71', 89, 4, 16, 183182) Do you know Kamalabai of Madras who was doing publicity work?
('71', 89, 4, 17, 183244) She is here.
('71', 89, 4, 18, 183257) Anna 2 has fallen with her.
('71', 89, 4, 19, 183285) So for the time being she has to give up publicity work 3. Most probably she and Gomatibehn will stay with me.
('71', 89, 4, 20, 183396) I will test her then.
('71', 89, 4, 21, 183418) A man falls if he is a little careless.
('71', 89, 4, 22, 183458) You don’t have to think much about staying with Mridula.
('71', 89, 4, 23, 183515) When you get sufficient self confidence to be able to work in Bihar independently, you can take up such work.
('71', 89, 4, 24, 183625) If you have such self confidence now, you needn’t go to Mridula.
('71', 89, 4, 25, 183690) There is, thus, nothing to worry about.
('71', 89, 4, 26, 183730) If one does thework that comes to one unsought, without worrying about things and with single minded attention, one is bound to be at peace with oneself.

('71', 90, 1, 2, 184091) 96. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('71', 90, 2, 3, 184116) March 31, 1937
('71', 90, 3, 4, 184131) MY DEAR REBEL, Still on the train.
('71', 90, 3, 5, 184166) I wrote 1 yesterday but forgot to tell you that when I saw the cartoon 2 I felt what you felt.
('71', 90, 3, 6, 184261) The joke was quite innocent.
('71', 90, 3, 7, 184290) Only a suspicious mind could find a sinister purpose behind the cartoon.
('71', 90, 3, 8, 184363) But the suspicion is there and has to be taken account of.
('71', 90, 3, 9, 184422) Therefore you were wholly right in drawing Devdas’s attention to the cartoon.
('71', 90, 3, 10, 184500) Yesterday’s letter was posted in the train without late fee.
('71', 90, 3, 11, 184561) Mahadev thinks that therefore it will be delivered to you a day later.
('71', 90, 3, 12, 184632) This is being posted with the late fee.
('71', 90, 3, 13, 184672) You will tell me if this reaches you earlier.
('71', 90, 3, 14, 184718) Hope the toe is in order and you are having your walks.
('71', 90, 3, 15, 184774) No dal at all and no ghee in cooking vagetables, no fried things, as much milk as you can possibly take, raw onion and raw garlic.
('71', 90, 3, 16, 184905) Dr. Dinshaw Mehta, Nature Cure, 6 Toddiwala Road, near City Station, Poona City.
('71', 90, 3, 17, 184986) That is Mehta’s address.
('71', 90, 3, 18, 185011) The latter part is a summary of yesterday’s letter.

('71', 91, 1, 2, 185872) 97. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR SEGAON, April 1, 1937 MY DEAR IDIOT, I got your two letters, one yesterday and one today.

('71', 91, 1, 4, 186038) You should go into it thoroughly and let me know the result of your enquiry.

('71', 91, 1, 13, 186527) Bare foot walking will do good to the toe.
('71', 91, 1, 14, 186570) Of course if you had been with me the toe would have been set right without difficulty.

('71', 91, 1, 17, 186746) Of course it has rained here outside the season.

('71', 91, 4, 23, 186929) April 1, 1937
('71', 91, 5, 24, 186943) BHAI MOOLCHANDJI, I do remember having quoted quite a number of sayings from Satyarth Prakash but I do not desire any public discussion now.
('71', 91, 5, 25, 187084) Even when I wrote them, it resulted in considerable harm and the Arya Samaj suffered some injustice.
('71', 91, 5, 26, 187185) If you send me a copy of Satyarth Prakash, I shall certainly be able to extract the remarks in support of my contention.
('71', 91, 5, 27, 187306) My opinion has undergone no change.
('71', 91, 5, 28, 187342) Still it does in no way imply that my reverence for Swami Dayanand has lessened, only it is not blind.

('71', 92, 1, 2, 187620) 99. LETTER TO BRIJKRISHNA CHANDIWALA
('71', 92, 2, 3, 187657) April 1, 1937
('71', 92, 3, 4, 187671) BRIJKRISHNA, I got your letter yesterday on my return from Madras.
('71', 92, 3, 5, 187738) It is unworthy of you to hold that I discourage you from joining me because of your faults: moreover, it is unjust to me.
('71', 92, 3, 6, 187860) I have forbidden you from coming simply because I think living with me would be an idle waste of time.
('71', 92, 3, 7, 187963) But if you have no peace otherwise, you may certainly come here and stay as long as you deem it fit.
('71', 92, 3, 8, 188064) What would happen if your health suffered?
('71', 92, 3, 9, 188107) Even this point may be overlooked for the time being.
('71', 92, 3, 10, 188161) This much then for your living with me.
('71', 92, 3, 11, 188201) Now for your predicament.
('71', 92, 3, 12, 188227) I think you should get married.
('71', 92, 3, 13, 188259) There is no grave error attached to marrying; every widower does it, which is certainly better than continually harbouring lustful thoughts.
('71', 92, 3, 14, 188400) It is difficult to pronounce any opinion on wealth.
('71', 92, 3, 15, 188452) I would only say this much that even the earning of wealth can be a mode of service, and in that too some ethical restraints must be observed and the prescribed rule should be applied to money making and the wealth should be as far as possible used for the benefit of society.
('71', 92, 3, 16, 188729) Your anguish increases as you try to work beyond your strength.
('71', 92, 3, 17, 188793) Ethics should not be misinterpreted in any way.
('71', 92, 3, 18, 188841) The rest on meeting you.
('71', 92, 3, 19, 188866) Your letter is being returned.
