('71', 94, 6, 10, 191534) 103. HINDI PRACHAR AND PURITY
('71', 94, 7, 11, 191564) On the 26th ultimo there was the convocation of the Hindi Prachar University for giving certificates to those young men and women who had passed its final examination.
('71', 94, 7, 12, 191732) I was invited 1 to present the certificates to the graduates.
('71', 94, 7, 13, 191794) They had to take a threefold vow which pledged them to the spread of Hindi Hindustani, service of the motherland and personal purity for the good name of the University.
('71', 94, 7, 14, 191964) I drew the special attention of the graduates to the last two parts of the pledge.
('71', 94, 7, 15, 192047) The authors of the pledge, however, had a special intention in inserting the clauses about service and personal purity.
('71', 94, 7, 16, 192167) They were evidently of opinion that if the young men and women who passed through the institution spread Hindi in the spirit of service, and if their personal purity was assured, these two factors would enhance the prestige of the graduates and they would themselves be the best advertising media for popularizing Hindi Hindustani.
('71', 94, 7, 17, 192499) I therefore reminded them of the pledge that they had just taken.
('71', 94, 7, 18, 192565) In order to enforce my argument, I quoted to the graduates the instance of the reported fall of a Hindi teacher who had already damaged the cause of Hindi prachar.
('71', 94, 7, 19, 192729) When I referred to this report I had little thought of what was in store for me.
('71', 94, 7, 20, 192810) For the morning following I had a letter placed in my hands giving detailed information of the fall from purity of Pandit Harihar
('71', 94, 8, 21, 192940) 1 Vide “Speech at Dakshin Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha, Madras”, 26 3 1937
('71', 95, 0, 1, 193013) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 95, 1, 2, 193054) Sharma, 1 the prime author of the pledge and the Secretary of the Sabha.
('71', 95, 1, 3, 193127) He is also a member of the Satyagraha Ashram from its foundation.
('71', 95, 1, 4, 193193) He and his wife qualified themselves for Hindi prachar work.
('71', 95, 1, 5, 193254) He has been for years the soul of the Hindi movement in the South.
('71', 95, 1, 6, 193321) At the Ashram he was held in high esteem.
('71', 95, 1, 7, 193363) He was easily among those who were always regarded above suspicion, above reproach.
('71', 95, 1, 8, 193447) I could not therefore believe the letter.
('71', 95, 1, 9, 193489) I spoke to him the next morning; and though he resisted the imputation for a while, the concealment became too unbearable for him and he confessed everything.
('71', 95, 1, 10, 193648) According to the Ashram code he gave me permission to refer to the sin in public.
('71', 95, 1, 11, 193730) I at once broke the news to the executive.
('71', 95, 1, 12, 193773) They were unprepared for the stunning news.
('71', 95, 1, 13, 193817) Pandit Sharma tendered resignation on the ground of the fall.
('71', 95, 1, 14, 193879) The executive will have accepted the resignation and the administration will have been overhauled.
('71', 95, 1, 15, 193978) Kakasaheb stayed in Madras to advise the executive of the Hindi Prachar Sabha.
('71', 95, 1, 16, 194057) But for me the matter does not end there.
('71', 95, 1, 17, 194099) It may be thought that events like this do not need publicity.
('71', 95, 1, 18, 194162) Those who think so evidently do not know the full facts.
('71', 95, 1, 19, 194219) The institution with which I am intimately connected have to deal with masses of mankind, both men and women.
('71', 95, 1, 20, 194329) They work through hundreds of volunteers.
('71', 95, 1, 21, 194371) These have no authority but the moral.
('71', 95, 1, 22, 194410) The volunteer workers inspire confidence because purity of personal life is assumed about them.
('71', 95, 1, 23, 194506) Their influence will wane immediately they lose credit for purity.
('71', 95, 1, 24, 194573) Publicity has never harmed the institutions or the persons involved in sin.
('71', 95, 1, 25, 194649) It behoves the workers throughout India to learn the lesson from Pandit Sharma’s fall that they must be ever watchful of themselves and not be found napping and unready to resist when the enemy assails them.
('71', 95, 1, 26, 194857) This remark applies perhaps with greater force to Hindi teachers in the South than to others.
('71', 95, 1, 27, 194951) There is no purdah there.
('71', 95, 1, 28, 194977) Girls there have been found to be more interested in Hindi than boys.
('71', 95, 1, 29, 195047) Teachers by reason of their very occupation exercise over their pupils a moral authority which disarms suspicion and creates a confidence which would ordinarily be wanting.
('71', 95, 1, 30, 195220) Indeed a suggestion has already been made to the effect that in order to be fool proof the Hindi Prachar Sabha should stop private
('71', 95, 2, 31, 195351) 1 Vide also “Letter to Prabhavati”, 30 3 1937
('71', 96, 0, 1, 195397) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 97
('71', 96, 1, 2, 195439) tuition of girls altogether.
('71', 96, 1, 3, 195468) I have not been able to subscribe to the view.
('71', 96, 1, 4, 195515) Lapses will take place no matter how careful one is.
('71', 96, 1, 5, 195568) There cannot, therefore, be overcarefulness.
('71', 96, 1, 6, 195613) But to stop private tuition of girls is to admit moral bankruptcy.
('71', 96, 1, 7, 195680) There is no warrant for panic.
('71', 96, 1, 8, 195711) So far as I know, the Hindi teachers in general have done their work without blemish in the matter of personal purity.
('71', 96, 1, 9, 195830) I have not suppressed from the public any proved lapses.
('71', 96, 1, 10, 195887) We may not invite temptations nor may we shut ourselves in iron cages in order to avoid them altogether.
('71', 96, 1, 11, 195992) We must be prepared to face them when they come uninvited.
('71', 96, 1, 12, 196051) Sharma fell because he invited temptation.
('71', 96, 1, 13, 196094) He trusted himself too much.
('71', 96, 1, 14, 196123) Let the public that is interested in Hindi prachar work not be curious about the future of Pandit Sharma or about the details of his error.
('71', 96, 1, 15, 196263) He will be with me whilst he is reforming himself.
('71', 96, 1, 16, 196314) His disappearance from the organization does not mean the close of a career of service.
('71', 96, 1, 17, 196402) Indeed if this fall has taught him the lesson of his life, he will have lost nothing nor Hindi prachar a worker of his calibre.
('71', 96, 1, 18, 196530) To err is human, to own up one’s error and to so act as to be proof against it is manly.
('71', 96, 1, 19, 196619) Let us hope that he has the manly quality necessary for the task and pray that he may become a better servant for the fall.
('71', 96, 1, 20, 196743) Some of the saints of the world had been notorious sinners.
('71', 96, 1, 21, 196803) Harijan, 3 4 1937
('71', 96, 2, 22, 196821) 104. AN UNFORTUNATE DOCUMENT
('71', 96, 3, 23, 196850) Fourteen highly educated Indian Christians occupying impor tant social positions have issued a joint manifesto setting forth their views on the missionary work among Harijans.
('71', 96, 3, 24, 197026) The document has been published in the Indian Press.
('71', 96, 3, 25, 197079) I was disinclined to publish it in Harijan, as after having read it more than once I could not bring myself to say anything in its favour and I felt that a critical review of it might serve no useful purpose.
('71', 96, 3, 26, 197288) But I understand that my criticism is expected and will be welcomed no matter how candid and strong it may be.
('71', 96, 3, 27, 197399) The reader will find the manifesto published in full in this issue.
('71', 96, 3, 28, 197467) The heading 1 is also the authors’.They seem to have fallen between
('71', 96, 4, 29, 197535) 1 “Our Duty to the Depressed and Backward Classes”.
('71', 96, 4, 30, 197587) The signatories were: K. K. Chandy, S. Gnanaprakasam, S. Gurubatham, S. Jesudasen, M. P. Job, G. V. Job, G. Joseph, K. I. Matthai, A. A. Paul, S. E. Ranganadham, A. N. Sudarsanam, O. F. E. Zacharia, D. M. Devasahayam, G. V. Martyn.
('71', 97, 0, 1, 197819) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 97, 1, 2, 197860) two stools in their attempt to sit on both.
('71', 97, 1, 3, 197904) They have tried to reconcile the irreconcilable.
('71', 97, 1, 4, 197953) If one section of Christians has been aggressively open and militant, the other represented by the authors of the manifesto is courteously patronizing.
('71', 97, 1, 5, 198105) They would not be aggressive for the sake of expedience.
('71', 97, 1, 6, 198162) The purpose of the manifesto is not to condemn unequivocally the method of converting the illiterate and the ignorant but to assert the right of preaching the Gospel to the millions of Harijans.
('71', 97, 1, 7, 198357) The key to the manifesto is contained in paragraphs 7 and 8. This is what one reads in paragraph 7:
('71', 97, 2, 8, 198457) Men and women individually and in family or village groups will continue to seek the fellowship of the Christian Chruch.
('71', 97, 2, 9, 198578) That is the real movement of the Spirit of God.
('71', 97, 2, 10, 198626) And no power on earth can stem that tide.
('71', 97, 2, 11, 198668) It will be the duty of the Christian Church in India to receive such seekers after the truth as it is in Jesus Christ and provide for them instruction and spiritual nurture.
('71', 97, 2, 12, 198842) The Church will cling to its right to receive such people into itself from whatever religious group they may come.
('71', 97, 2, 13, 198957) It will cling to the further right to go about in these days of irreligion and materialism to awaken spiritual hunger in all.
('71', 97, 2, 14, 199083) These few sentences are striking instance of how the wish becomes father to the thought.
('71', 97, 2, 15, 199172) It is an unconscious process but not on that account less open to criticism.
('71', 97, 2, 16, 199249) Men and women do not seek the fellowship of the Christian Church.
('71', 97, 2, 17, 199315) Poor Harijans are no better than the others.
('71', 97, 2, 18, 199360) I wish they had real spiritual hunger.
('71', 97, 2, 19, 199399) Such as it is, they satisfy by visits to the temples, however crude they may be.
('71', 97, 2, 20, 199480) When the missionary of another religion goes to them, he goes like any vendor of goods.
('71', 97, 2, 21, 199568) He has no special spiritual merit that will distinguish him from those to whom he goes.
('71', 97, 2, 22, 199656) He does, however, possess material goods which he promises to those who will come to his fold.
('71', 97, 2, 23, 199751) Then mark, the duty of the Christian Church in India turns into a right.
('71', 97, 2, 24, 199824) Now when duty becomes a right it ceases to be a duty.
('71', 97, 2, 25, 199878) Performance of a duty requires one quality–that of suffering and introspection.
('71', 97, 2, 26, 199958) Exercise of a right requires a quality that gives the power to impose one’s will upon the resister through sanctions devised by the claimant or the law whose aid he invokes in the exercise of his right.
('71', 97, 2, 27, 200161) I have the duty of paying my debt, but I have no right to thrust the owed coppers (say) into the pocket of an unwilling creditor.
('71', 97, 2, 28, 200291) The duty of taking spiritual message is performed by the messenger becoming a fit vehicle by prayer and fasting.
('71', 97, 2, 29, 200404) Conceived as a right, it may easily become an imposition on unwilling parties.
('71', 97, 2, 30, 200483) Thus the manifesto, undoubtedly designed to allay suspicion and soothe the ruffled feelings of Hindus, in my opinion, fails to accomplish its purpose.
('71', 97, 2, 31, 200634) On the contrary, it leaves a bad taste in the
('71', 98, 0, 1, 200680) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 99
('71', 98, 1, 2, 200722) I venture to suggest to the authors that they need to re examine their position in the light of my remarks.
('71', 98, 1, 3, 200830) Let them recognize the fundamental difference between rights and duties.
('71', 98, 1, 4, 200903) In the spiritual sphere, there is no such thing as a right.
('71', 98, 1, 5, 200963) Harijan, 3 4 1937
('71', 98, 2, 6, 200981) 105. OBSTACLES IN THE WAY OF A GOSEVAK
('71', 98, 3, 7, 201020) The secretary of a goshala writes: 1
('71', 98, 4, 8, 201057) It is my firm belief that by making good use of the hide of a dead animal religion is not violated, nor should sanatanist Hindus feel offended over this.
('71', 98, 4, 9, 201211) Yes, it is certainly a lapse of religion if full use of the hide of a dead animal is not made because it increases cow slaughter.
('71', 98, 4, 10, 201341) The price of a cow decreases day by day and so cows are easily sold and taken straight to slaughter houses.
('71', 98, 4, 11, 201449) If we consider goseva as an inseparable part of Hindu religion, we can neither look down upon the tanners’ profession nor consider them untouchable.
('71', 98, 4, 12, 201598) The cow dies solely from our ignorance.
('71', 98, 4, 13, 201638) Dharma cannot be protected by merely talking about it; that can be done only by understanding the meaning of the Shastras and by practising it.
('71', 98, 4, 14, 201782) I have written several times that if the goshalas in India know their duty and adhere to it faithfully, then cow slaughter can be done away with and cow’s milk will be easily available to everyone.
('71', 98, 4, 15, 201980) There is no exaggeration of any kind in this statement.
('71', 98, 4, 16, 202036) Almost all cows are owned by Hindus.
('71', 98, 4, 17, 202073) If they adhere to their dharma and refrain from selling cows which is the cause of cow slaughter, there can be no cow slaughter.
('71', 98, 4, 18, 202202) Let every goshala become an ideal dairy, that is, self reliant, and let experts on dairying and animal husbandry work in it.
('71', 98, 4, 19, 202327) A self reliant goshala must prosper from day to day.
('71', 98, 4, 20, 202380) It can also make proper use of the hides of the dead cattle.
('71', 98, 4, 21, 202441) This amounts to saying that with the increase in cattle wealth, our knowledge will also grow; and this will be a great help to us in reducing unemployment in the country.
('71', 98, 4, 22, 202612) Even if one goshala will accomplish this task, other goshalas will follow it.
('71', 98, 4, 23, 202690) [From Hindi] Harijan Sevak, 3 4 1937
('71', 98, 5, 24, 202727) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('71', 98, 5, 25, 202764) The correspondent had said that till then the practice of the goshala was to give away dead cattle without any charge.
('71', 98, 5, 26, 202883) However, in that year they had had the hides removed and sold, which had resulted in great dissatisfaction among orthodox Hindus.

('71', 116, 1, 2, 232248) 137. WONDERFUL IF TRUE
('71', 116, 2, 3, 232271) During our morning and evening walks, Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan and I often talk on matters of common interest.
('71', 116, 2, 4, 232387) Having travelled in the Frontier territories as far as Kabul and beyond and knowing the Frontier tribes well, he often describes to me the habits and customs of these simple folk.
('71', 116, 2, 5, 232567) He tells me that these tribesmen who are untouched by the so called civilization live principally on maize and barley, bread and lentils supplemented at times by buttermilk.
('71', 116, 2, 6, 232741) They get meat but rarely.
('71', 116, 2, 7, 232767) The only way I could account for their well known hardiness was their open air life and invigorating climate.
('71', 116, 2, 8, 232877) Khan Saheb promptly added:
('71', 116, 3, 9, 232904) That is not enough.
('71', 116, 3, 10, 232924) The secret of their strength lies in their chaste lives.
('71', 116, 3, 11, 232981) They marry, both men and women, after full maturity.
('71', 116, 3, 12, 233034) Unfaithfulness, adultery or unmarried love are practically unknown.
('71', 116, 3, 13, 233102) Union out of wedlock is punishable by death.
('71', 116, 3, 14, 233147) The injured party has the right to take the life of the wrongdoer.
('71', 116, 3, 15, 233214) If this chastity is so universal as Khan Saheb describes it, it furnishes us in India a lesson that we should take to heart.
('71', 116, 3, 16, 233339) I suggested to Khan Saheb that if the fine physique of the tribesmen was largely due to their continence, there must be perfect co operation between the mind and the body.
('71', 116, 3, 17, 233511) For, if the mind hankered after satisfaction of the flesh and the body resisted, there must be tremendous waste of vital energy, leaving the body thoroughly exhausted.
('71', 116, 3, 18, 233679) Khan Saheb agreed that that was a fair deduction and that, so far as he was able to judge, he felt that the tribesmen were so habituated to continence outside marriage that young men and women never seemed to desire sexual satisfaction outside marriage.
('71', 116, 3, 19, 233933) Khan Saheb also told me that the women in the tribal areas never observed the purdah, there was no false prudery there, the women were fearless, roamed about anywhere freely, were well able to take care of themselves and defend their honour without seeking or needing male protection.
('71', 116, 3, 20, 234218) Khan Saheb, however, admits that this continence not being based on reason or enlightened faith breaks down when these men and women of the hills come in contact with civilized or soft life where departure from the custom carries no punishment and publicopinion looks upon unfaithfulness and adultery with more or less indifference.
('71', 116, 3, 21, 234551) This opens up reflections which I must not discuss just now.
('71', 116, 3, 22, 234612) My purpose in writing this just now is to seek corroboration and further light from those who know these tribesmen, as Khan Saheb does, and to suggest to young men and women of the plains that observance of continence, if it is really natural to the tribesmen, as Khan Saheb thinks it is, should be equally natural to us, if only we
('71', 117, 0, 1, 234945) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 117, 1, 2, 234987) would inhabit our thought world with the right kind of thoughts and deal summarily with the intruders.
('71', 117, 1, 3, 235090) Indeed, if the right kind settle down in sufficiently large numbers, the intruders will be crowded out no doubt.
('71', 117, 1, 4, 235203) The process requires courage.
('71', 117, 1, 5, 235233) But self restraint never accrues to the faint hearted.
('71', 117, 1, 6, 235288) It is the beautiful fruit of watchfulness and ceaseless effort in the form of prayer and fasting.
('71', 117, 1, 7, 235386) The prayer is not vain repetition nor fasting mere starvation of the body.
('71', 117, 1, 8, 235461) Prayer has to come from the heart which knows God by faith, and fasting is abstinence from evil or injurious thought, activity or food.
('71', 117, 1, 9, 235597) Starvation of the body when the mind thinks of a multiplicity of dishes is worse than useless.
('71', 117, 1, 10, 235692) Harijan, 10 4 1937
('71', 117, 2, 11, 235711) 138. KHADI IN SWADESHI EXHIBITIONS
('71', 117, 3, 12, 235746) In all other parts of India where swadeshi exhibitions permitting mill cloth are held the A. I. S. A. has as a rule refused to exhibit khadi.
('71', 117, 3, 13, 235888) And the rule has answered the purpose for which it was framed.
('71', 117, 3, 14, 235951) From U.P., however, the pressure has come to relax the rule.
('71', 117, 3, 15, 236012) But I have hitherto resisted the temptation.
('71', 117, 3, 16, 236057) U.P. khadi workers made a special reference for their guidance.
('71', 117, 3, 17, 236121) They are almost all Congressmen no less ardent than the others, but they have dedicated themselves to the Congress service through its constructive and the most difficult programme, khadi.
('71', 117, 3, 18, 236310) Appreciating their difficulty I referred the question to Shri Jawaharlal Nehru for his opinion.
('71', 117, 3, 19, 236406) I have received the following reply 1 from him:
('71', 117, 4, 20, 236454) I have your letter of the 5th March enquiring about khadi at exhibitions.
('71', 117, 4, 21, 236528) This matter has been repeatedly discussed by us in the course of the past year ever since my return from Europe.
('71', 117, 5, 22, 236641) The question you have put is not easy to answer.
('71', 117, 5, 23, 236690) The average khadi worker seems to be of opinion that khadi should not be exhibited if mill cloth is allowed there.
('71', 117, 5, 24, 236805) Other Congress workers are usually of a contrary opinion on the ground that at such exhibitions there is usually a good sale of khadi.
('71', 117, 5, 25, 236940) Obviously the opinion of the khadi worker, who is presumed to be an expert at his job and who is anxious to push khadi, should be almost final.
('71', 117, 5, 26, 237084) I would therefore hesitate to give my decision against him unless I succeed in convincing him.
('71', 117, 5, 27, 237179) I imagine that from a certain long distance view it is better even to incur some loss now so as to avoid producing any confusion in the public mind as to what khadi is and what it is not.
('71', 117, 5, 28, 237367) This can only be done by
('71', 117, 6, 29, 237392) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('71', 118, 0, 1, 237429) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 119
('71', 118, 1, 2, 237472) adherence to the present policy of banning certified khadi sales in such exhibitions.
('71', 118, 1, 3, 237558) At the same time, I find that uncertified khadi is sold at such exhibitions and plenty of people patronize it.
('71', 118, 1, 4, 237669) There are quite large numbers of people as you know who are not particularly keen on buying certified khadi, but who are prepared to do so if it comes their way.
('71', 118, 1, 5, 237831) The point is: are we to cater for the people in any especial measure, or are we to concentrate on holding fast to those who desire to use pure khadi only?
('71', 118, 1, 6, 237986) This question has not only its business side but its psychological side.
('71', 118, 1, 7, 238059) Khadi has on the one hand built up a firm foundation for itself, and there is a body of men in the country who must have pure khadi whatever the cost or the trouble.
('71', 118, 1, 8, 238225) At the same time khadi does not spread as rapidly as it might among other classes who only occasionally patronize it.
('71', 118, 1, 9, 238343) For khadi workers the object should be to develop the khadi habit in the latter.
('71', 118, 1, 10, 238424) That habit comes largely from appeals, to the mind or heart and partly from sheer habit.
('71', 118, 1, 11, 238513) Ordinarily speaking, it would be a good thing to have as many casual purchasers as possible so that they may get used to buying and wearing khadi and thus develop the real habit.
('71', 118, 1, 12, 238692) The present policy to some extent keeps away this casual purchaser and thus reduces the field from which regular khadi buyers might be drawn.
('71', 118, 1, 13, 238834) Therefore, if you want my final opinion, I cannot give it very definitely, and because of my not being definite I must respect the opinions of others who are working for khadi.
('71', 118, 1, 14, 239011) I am, however, inclined to think that it might be preferable to allow khadi to be exhibited and sold in these exhibitions under certain conditions which would prevent as far as possible (1) something else being mistaken for khadi and the distinction between khadi and mill cloth being clearly preserved (2) the exclusion of partly foreign stuffs from the exhibition.
('71', 118, 1, 15, 239378) In the absence of final opinion which he is unable to give, he would respect the opinions of others who are working for khadi.
('71', 118, 1, 16, 239505) He is, however, “inclined to think that it might be preferable to allow khadi to be exhibited and sold in these exhibitions.” My own experience, however, tells me that it is dangerous to befog the mass mind by putting khadi in juxtaposition with the gaudy mill made cloth.
('71', 118, 1, 17, 239778) It is very like putting human beings side by side with robots.
('71', 118, 1, 18, 239841) Human beings may be worsted in the competition if they allow themselves to be compared to robots.
('71', 118, 1, 19, 239939) Even so will khadi fare, in comparision with mill made cloth.
('71', 118, 1, 20, 240001) The planes of the two are different.
('71', 118, 1, 21, 240038) The aims are opposite.
('71', 118, 1, 22, 240061) Khadi gives work to all, mill cloth gives work to some and deprives many of honest labour.
('71', 118, 1, 23, 240152) Khadi serves the masses, mill cloth is intended to serve the classes.
('71', 118, 1, 24, 240222) Khadi serves labour, mill cloth exploits it.
('71', 118, 1, 25, 240267) My experience is backed by that of the khadi workers throughout
('71', 119, 0, 1, 240331) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 119, 1, 2, 240373) I hope therefore that with Shri Jawaharlal Nehru the Congressmen of U.P. will respect the experience and the policy of the A. I. S. A. in preference to their own opinion, if it be against that of the A. I. S. A. Harijan, 10 4 1937
('71', 119, 2, 3, 240604) 139. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('71', 119, 3, 4, 240632) WARDHA, April 10, 1937 I have read Lord Lothian’s appeal 1 to me with the respect it deserves.
('71', 119, 3, 5, 240727) I have a vivid recollection of the talks with him among other friends.
('71', 119, 3, 6, 240798) The provincial autonomy then pictured was a real stuff unlike what the present Constitution is supposed to give.
('71', 119, 3, 7, 240911) Lord Zetland’s elaborate statement 2 confirms my view and hardens the universal suspicion of the British statement’s intentions.
('71', 119, 3, 8, 241040) So long as they wish to bolster up imperialistic designs, India, which the Congress represents, will never reconcile itself to them.
('71', 119, 3, 9, 241173) I believe in friendship with Britain, not with imperialistic exploitation.
('71', 119, 3, 10, 241248) I am free to confess ignorance of the Government of India Act and a greater ignorance of the Select Committee’s Report.
('71', 119, 3, 11, 241368) My advice to the Congress to adopt my resolution on a conditional acceptance of office was based on an assurance of lawyers amongCongressmen that the Governors could give the required assurance without an infringement of the Act.
('71', 119, 3, 12, 241598) 3 I do not, therefore, need even Sir Samuel Hoare’s past declarations to support me.
('71', 119, 3, 13, 241683) If, therefore, he disclaims having ever made the statement which I aver having heard him make, I accept his disclaimer without argument.
('71', 119, 3, 14, 241820) The dismal fact stares India in the face that British statement imposed an Act on India against her declared wishes and then instead of leaving its interpretation to impartial tribunals impose their own upon her and call this transaction autonomy.
('71', 119, 3, 15, 242068) Lawyers, Mussalman, Parsi and Hindu, whom the Government have hitherto honoured with their partronage, declared that the Governors can without an infringement give the required assurance.
('71', 119, 3, 16, 242256) I regard the British statesmen’s interpretation as non judicial, arbitrary and interested.
('71', 119, 4, 17, 242347) 1 The references is to Lord Lothian’s letter to The Times; vide Appendix “Lord Lothian’s Letter to The Times”, after 16 3 1937. 2 Vide footnote 1, “Letter to Agatha Harrison”,9 4 1937 3 Vide also the following item.
('71', 120, 0, 1, 242563) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 121
('71', 120, 1, 2, 242606) At the same time I recognize that other lawyers give an interpretation favourable to the British Government.
('71', 120, 1, 3, 242715) Therefore I invite them to appoint an arbitration tribunal of three judges of whom one will be appointed by the Congress, another by the British Government with power to the two to appoint a third to decide whether it is competent for the Governors to give the required assurance described by me.
('71', 120, 1, 4, 243012) And since the legality of the present Ministries has been questioned, I would refer that question also to the proposed tribunal.
('71', 120, 1, 5, 243141) There is precedent for such a course.
('71', 120, 1, 6, 243179) If they would accept my proposal I would advise the Congress to do likewise.
('71', 120, 1, 7, 243256) I mean every word of my previous statement 1. I want right to prevail.
('71', 120, 1, 8, 243327) There is here no question of diplomacy with India.
('71', 120, 1, 9, 243378) It is a question of life and death.
('71', 120, 1, 10, 243414) Office will be accepted if only progress towards her goal is accepted, not otherwise.
('71', 120, 1, 11, 243500) It, therefore, pains me to find Lord Zetland playing upon the old familiar tune of divide and rule.
('71', 120, 1, 12, 243600) The Congress cannot exist for two days if it disregards the interests of minorities.
('71', 120, 1, 13, 243685) It cannot bring about mass rule by dividing India into factions.
('71', 120, 1, 14, 243750) The Congress Ministries, if they ever come into existence, will dig their own graves without the Governors’ safeguards the moment they trample upon the rights of the minorities or resort to injustice otherwise.
('71', 120, 1, 15, 243961) I regret to have to say it but, to be true, I must say that Lord Zetland’s speech is that of one who is conscious of his sword rather than of his right.
('71', 120, 1, 16, 244114) His Lordship is again misleading when he says that the Congress wants to be treated as a privileged body.
('71', 120, 1, 17, 244220) It does not.
('71', 120, 1, 18, 244233) Anyone representing a most decisive majority like the Congress.
('71', 120, 1, 19, 244297) would want the gentlemanly assurance that the Congress has asked for.

('71', 121, 7, 10, 244988) 141. INTELLECTUAL DEVELOPMENT OR DISSIPATION?
('71', 121, 8, 11, 245034) During my recent wanderings in Travancore and Madras I found that most of the students and ‘intellectuals’ who came into touch with me were an instance of intellectual dissipation rather than intellectual development.
('71', 121, 8, 12, 245252) The fault lies in the modern system of education which encourages this vicious tendency, misdirects the mind, and thereby hinders its development instead of helping it.
('71', 121, 8, 13, 245421) My experiments in Segaon have only confirmed this impression.
('71', 121, 8, 14, 245483) But they are as yet too incomplete to be cited as evidence.
('71', 121, 8, 15, 245543) The views on education that I am now going to set forth have been held by me right from the time of the founding of the Phoenix settlement in South Africa in the year 1904.
('71', 121, 9, 16, 245716) I hold that true education of intellect can only come through a proper exercise and training of the bodily organs, e.g., hands, feet, eyes, ears, nose, etc.
('71', 121, 9, 17, 245873) In other words, an intelligent use of the bodily organs in a child provides the best and quickest way of developing his intellect.
('71', 121, 9, 18, 246004) But unless the development of the mind and body goes hand in hand with a corresponding awakening of the soul, the former alone would prove to be a poor lop sided affair.
('71', 121, 9, 19, 246174) By spiritual training I mean education of the heart.
('71', 121, 9, 20, 246227) A proper and all round development of the mind, therefore, can take place only when it proceeds pari passu with the education of the physical and spiritual faculties of the child.
('71', 121, 9, 21, 246407) They constitute an indivisible whole.
('71', 121, 9, 22, 246445) According to this theory, therefore, it would be a gross fallacy to suppose that they can be developed piecemeal or independently of one another.
('71', 121, 10, 23, 246591) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 11 4 1937. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('71', 122, 0, 1, 246696) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 123
('71', 122, 1, 2, 246739) The baneful effects of absence of proper co ordination and harmony among the various faculties of body, mind and soul respectively are obvious.
('71', 122, 1, 3, 246883) They are all around us; only we have lost perception of them owing to our present perverse associations.
('71', 122, 1, 4, 246988) Take the case of our village folk.
('71', 122, 1, 5, 247023) From their childhood upward they toil and labour in their fields from morning till night like their cattle in the midst of whom they live.
('71', 122, 1, 6, 247162) Their existence is a weary, endless round of mechanical drudgery unrelieved by a spark of intelligence or higher graces of life.
('71', 122, 1, 7, 247291) Deprived of all scope for developing their mind and soul, they have sunk to the level of the beast.
('71', 122, 1, 8, 247391) Life to them is a sorry bungle which they muddle through anyhow.
('71', 122, 1, 9, 247456) On the other hand what goes by the name of education in our schools and colleges in the cities today is in reality only intellectual dissipation.
('71', 122, 1, 10, 247602) Intellectual training is there looked upon as something altogether unrelated to manual or physical work.
('71', 122, 1, 11, 247707) But since the body must have some sort of physical exercise to keep it in health, they vainly try to attain that end by means of an artificial and otherwise barren system of physical culture which would be ridiculous beyond words if the result was not so tragic.
('71', 122, 1, 12, 247970) The young man who emerges from this system can in no way compete in physical endurance with an ordinary labourer.
('71', 122, 1, 13, 248084) The slightest physical exertion gives him headache; a mild exposure to the sun is enough to cause him giddiness.
('71', 122, 1, 14, 248197) And what is more, all this is looked upon as quite natural.
('71', 122, 1, 15, 248257) As for the faculties of the heart, they are simply allowed to run to seed or to grow anyhow in a wild undisciplined manner.
('71', 122, 1, 16, 248381) The result is moral and spiritual anarchy.
('71', 122, 1, 17, 248424) And it is regarded as something laudable!
('71', 122, 1, 18, 248466) As against this, take the case of a child in whom the education of the heart is attended to from the very beginning.
('71', 122, 1, 19, 248583) Supposing he is set to some useful occupation like spinning, carpentry, agriculture, etc., for his education and in that connection is given a thorough, comprehensive knowledge relating to the theory of the various operations that he is to perform and the use and construction of the tools that he would be wielding.
('71', 122, 1, 20, 248900) He would not only develop a fine, healthy body but also a sound, vigorous intellect that is not merely academic but is firmly rooted in and is tested from day to day by experience.
('71', 122, 1, 21, 249081) His intellectual education would include a knowledge of mathematics and the various sciences that are useful for an intelligent
('71', 123, 0, 1, 249209) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 123, 1, 2, 249251) and efficient exercise of his avocation.
('71', 123, 1, 3, 249292) If to this is added literature by way of recreation, it would give him a perfect, well balanced, all round education in which the intellect, the body and the spirit have all full play and develop together into a natural, harmonious whole.
('71', 123, 1, 4, 249531) Man is neither mere intellect nor the gross animal body, nor the heart or soul alone.
('71', 123, 1, 5, 249617) A proper and harmonious combination of all the three is required for the making of the whole man and constitutes the true economics of education.
('71', 123, 1, 6, 249763) To say that this kind of education can only be given after we have attained our independence would, I am afraid, be like putting the cart before the horse.
('71', 123, 1, 7, 249919) The advent of independence would be incredibly hastened if we could educate millions of our people through an intelligent exercise of their respective vocations like this and teach them that they live for the common good of all.
('71', 123, 2, 8, 250148) Harijan, 8 5 1937
('71', 123, 3, 9, 250166) 142. MESSAGE TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF AMERICA
('71', 123, 4, 10, 250210) WARDHA, April 12, 1937
('71', 123, 5, 11, 250233) You ask me to give you a special message for the readers of your 1,300 American newspapers, whom you serve.
('71', 123, 5, 12, 250341) I would like Americans first of all to know my limitations and our internal politics.
('71', 123, 5, 13, 250427) They should know that I am not even a primary member of the Congress.
('71', 123, 5, 14, 250497) Whatever influence I possess is purely moral.
('71', 123, 5, 15, 250543) Congressmen recognize in me the author of purely non violent action and its technique and, therefore, so long as the Congress retains its creed of truth and non violence, Congressmen are likely to be guided by my advice whenever it has anything to do, directly or indirectly, with non violent action, but those who can speak with authority are the President of the Congress i.e., Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, and the Working Committee, i.e., the Congress Cabinet.
('71', 123, 5, 16, 251003) I function purely as a humble adviser.
('71', 123, 6, 17, 251042) For me the present issue is not political, but moral, It is a fight between truth and untruth; non violence and violence and right and
('71', 124, 0, 1, 251177) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 125
('71', 124, 1, 2, 251220) might; for I hold that Lord Zetland could not have uttered the speech 1

('71', 124, 2, 5, 251468) If they were not, they ought to have bowed to the will of the majority as represented by their elected leaders.

('71', 124, 2, 16, 252254) I must repeat that the latest gesture is one of the sword not of goodwill; certainly not of democratic obedience to the will of a democratic majority.

('71', 127, 6, 25, 256329) 148. LETTER TO HARIBHAU UPADHYAYA
('71', 127, 7, 26, 256363) April 13, 1937
('71', 127, 8, 27, 256378) HARIBHAU, I have your letter.
('71', 127, 8, 28, 256408) You have made a big change as regards hip bath.
('71', 127, 8, 29, 256456) Really useful changes can be made by the patient himself, with the help of Kuhne’s and Just’s books.
('71', 127, 8, 30, 256557) Nature cure remedies are not like ordinary drugs.
('71', 127, 8, 31, 256607) A patient can say that a particular drug does not suit him, but only the vaidya who is treating him can say which one is likely to suit.
('71', 127, 8, 32, 256744) In nature cure, on the other hand, the patient himself knows which remedies benefit him and, after he has submitted himself to several restrictions, can himself decide as to what kind of remedies to employ and in what measures.
('71', 127, 8, 33, 256972) The reason is that the guide can never know as well as the patient can, the changes that take place in the latter’s body.
('71', 127, 8, 34, 257094) Do make whatever changes seem necessary.
('71', 127, 8, 35, 257135) But keep me informed, as you did this time.
('71', 127, 8, 36, 257179) I certainly wish that if no definite change is clearly visible this month, then you may spend a day in Delhi.
('71', 127, 8, 37, 257289) Saraswati Gadodia owes her job to this remedy.
('71', 127, 8, 38, 257336) Her guru is a kind maulvi.
('71', 127, 8, 39, 257363) The only attraction for going to Delhi is that you can have the benefit of the advice of both.
('71', 127, 8, 40, 257458) I carefully went
('71', 128, 0, 1, 257475) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 129
('71', 128, 1, 2, 257518) through Bhandari’s book for five minutes.

('71', 128, 1, 4, 257587) What I want is Indian equivalents for technical terms, not definitions.
('71', 128, 1, 5, 257659) A definition of a motor car can be given, but I heard it described as air car only in Champaran.
('71', 128, 1, 6, 257756) I cannot, therefore, give my opinion all at once.
('71', 128, 1, 7, 257806) If you or somebody else tells me its special merits, then only can I express an opinion.

('71', 128, 4, 13, 258193) 149. DISCUSSION WITH MISSIONARY 1
('71', 128, 5, 14, 258227) [Before April 14, 1937] 2
('71', 128, 6, 15, 258253) MISSIONARY: I have been following your comments on the statement regarding mass movement made by the Indian Christians.
('71', 128, 6, 16, 258373) I wonder if those who made the statement were thinking of anything in the nature of a legal right.
('71', 128, 6, 17, 258472) It is, I think, a moral right they claim here rather than a legal one.
('71', 128, 6, 18, 258543) GANDHIJI: My criticism would apply even if they had used the word ‘moral right’.
('71', 128, 6, 19, 258624) But it is clear that they mean a legal right, because for one thing there is no such thing as a moral right, and secondly because in the very next para of the manifesto, in which they have referred to the Karachi Resolution 3 on Fundamental Rights, they make it clear that they mean by ‘right’ legal right.
('71', 128, 6, 20, 258931) A moral right, if there is any such thing, does not need any asserting and defending.
('71', 128, 7, 21, 259017) The main purpose of the manifesto was to check the agitation that is going on in certain quarters.
('71', 128, 7, 22, 259116) I admit that if it was meant to be a protest, it was not properly drafted.
('71', 128, 7, 23, 259191) That is why I have called it “an unfortunate document” And is there anything like a moral right?
('71', 128, 7, 24, 259288) Give me an illustration.
('71', 128, 8, 25, 259313) Have I not a moral right to speak?
('71', 128, 9, 26, 259348) 1 This is extracted from “Weekly Letter” by Mahadev Desai, who had reported: “An Indian Christian missionary had a long talk with Gandhiji the other day during which he put to Gandhiji questions arising from Gandhiji’s recent criticism of a joint manifesto issued by several influential Indian Christians.” Vide “An Unfortunate Document”, 3 4 1937 2 Gandhiji left Wardha for Hudli on April 14, 1937. 3Vide “Resolution on Fundamental Rights and Economic Changes”, 31 3 1931
('71', 129, 0, 1, 259821) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 129, 1, 2, 259863) It is not a moral right, but a legal right.
('71', 129, 1, 3, 259907) There is no right but is legal.
('71', 129, 1, 4, 259939) Divorced from legality moral right is a misnomer.
('71', 129, 1, 5, 259989) And therefore you either enforce a right or fight for it.
('71', 129, 1, 6, 260047) Whereas nobody asserts one’s duty.
('71', 129, 1, 7, 260082) He humbly performs it.
('71', 129, 1, 8, 260105) I shall take an illustration.
('71', 129, 1, 9, 260135) You are here.
('71', 129, 1, 10, 260149) You feel like preaching to me the Gospel.
('71', 129, 1, 11, 260191) I deny the right and ask you to go away.
('71', 129, 1, 12, 260232) If you regard praying for me a duty,you will quietly go away and pray for me.
('71', 129, 1, 13, 260310) But if you claim the right to preach to me, you will call the police and appeal to them for preventing my obstructing you.
('71', 129, 1, 14, 260433) That leads to a clash.
('71', 129, 1, 15, 260456) But your duty no one dare question.
('71', 129, 1, 16, 260492) You perform it here or elsewhere, and if your prayers to God to change my heart are genuine, God will change my heart.
('71', 129, 1, 17, 260611) What Christianity, according to my interpretation of it, expects you to do is to pray to God to change my heart.
('71', 129, 1, 18, 260724) Duty is a debt.
('71', 129, 1, 19, 260740) Right belongs to a creditor, and it would be a funny thing indeed if a devout Christian claimed to be a creditor!
('71', 129, 2, 20, 260854) You have objected to Christian propaganda on the ground that Harijans are illiterate and ignorant.
('71', 129, 2, 21, 260953) What would you say of propaganda amongst non Harijans?
('71', 129, 2, 22, 261008) I have the same objection, because the vast mass of people of India would not understand the pros and cons of Christianity better than a cow.
('71', 129, 2, 23, 261150) I repeat this simile in spite of the fact that it has been objected to.
('71', 129, 2, 24, 261222) When I say I do not understand logarithms any better than my cow, I do not mean any insult to my intelligence.
('71', 129, 2, 25, 261333) In matters of theology the non Harijan masses can understand no better than Harijans.
('71', 129, 2, 26, 261419) I would take you to Segaon and show you that there is no distinction, so far as capacity to understand such things is concerned, between Harijans and non harijans.
('71', 129, 2, 27, 261583) Try to preach the principles of Christianity to my wife.
('71', 129, 2, 28, 261640) She can understand them no better than my cow.
('71', 129, 2, 29, 261687) I can, because of the training that I have had.
('71', 129, 3, 30, 261735) But we do not preach any theology.
('71', 129, 3, 31, 261770) We simply talk of the life of Christ and tell them what a comfort His life and teaching have been to us.
('71', 129, 3, 32, 261875) He has been our guide, we say, and ask others also to accept Him as their guide.
('71', 129, 3, 33, 261956) Oh yes, you do say that.
('71', 129, 3, 34, 261981) But when you say I must accept Jesus in preference to Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, you will have to go into deep waters.
('71', 129, 3, 35, 262098) That is why I say, let your life speak to us, even as the rose needs no speech but simply spreads its perfume.
('71', 129, 3, 36, 262209) Even the blind who do not see the rose perceive its fragrance.
('71', 129, 3, 37, 262272) That is the secret of the Gospel of the rose.
('71', 129, 3, 38, 262318) But the Gospel that Jesus preached is more subtle and fragrant than the Gospel of the rose.
('71', 129, 3, 39, 262410) If the rose needs no agent, much less does the Gospel of Christ need any agent.
('71', 129, 4, 40, 262490) But then your objection is to the commercial aspect of the Christian propaganda.
('71', 129, 4, 41, 262571) Every true Christian will agree that no baits should be offered.
('71', 130, 0, 1, 262636) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 131
('71', 130, 1, 2, 262679) But what else is Christianity as it is preached nowadays?
('71', 130, 1, 3, 262737) Not unless you isolate the proselytizing aspect from your educational andmedical institutions are they any worth.
('71', 130, 1, 4, 262851) Why should students attending Mission schools and colleges be compelled or even expected to attend Bible classes?

('71', 130, 4, 17, 263929) Why should not your service be its own reward?
('71', 130, 5, 18, 263976) But leave alone these.
('71', 130, 5, 19, 263999) I think I can cite instances of exceptionally fine people who attract people to them by the example of their lives.
('71', 130, 5, 20, 264115) I too can cite such instances.
('71', 130, 5, 21, 264146) Andrews is one such.

('71', 130, 7, 31, 264879) Then, I should be obliged to hear from you your attitude to the personality of Jesus.

('71', 131, 1, 2, 265007) I have often made it clear.
('71', 131, 1, 3, 265035) I regard Jesus as a great teacher of humanity, but I do not regard him as the only begotten son of God.
('71', 131, 1, 4, 265139) That epithet in its material interpretation is quite unacceptable.
('71', 131, 1, 5, 265206) Metaphorically we are all begotten sons of God, but for each of us there may be different begotten son of God in a special sense.
('71', 131, 1, 6, 265336) Thus for me Chaitanya may be the only begotten son of God.
('71', 131, 2, 7, 265395) But don’t you believe in the perfection of human nature, and don’t you believe that Jesus had attained perfection?
('71', 131, 2, 8, 265510) I believe in the perfectability of human nature.
('71', 131, 2, 9, 265559) Jesus came as near to perfection as possible.
('71', 131, 2, 10, 265605) To say that he was perfect is to deny God’s superiority to man.
('71', 131, 2, 11, 265669) And then in this mater I have a theory of my own.
('71', 131, 2, 12, 265719) Being necessarily limited by the bonds of flesh, we can attain perfection only after dissolution of the body.
('71', 131, 2, 13, 265829) Therefore God alone is absolutely perfect.
('71', 131, 2, 14, 265872) When he descends to earth, He of His own accord limits Himself.
('71', 131, 2, 15, 265936) Jesus died on the Cross because he was limited by the flesh.
('71', 131, 2, 16, 265997) I do not need either the prophecies or the miracles to establish Jesus’s greatness as a teacher.
('71', 131, 2, 17, 266094) Nothing can be more miraculous than the three years of his ministry.
('71', 131, 2, 18, 266163) There is no miracle in the story of the multitude being fed on a handful of loaves.
('71', 131, 2, 19, 266247) A magician can create that illusion.
('71', 131, 2, 20, 266284) But woe worth the day on which a magician would be hailed as the Saviour of humanity.
('71', 131, 2, 21, 266370) As for Jesus raising the dead to life, well, I doubt if the men he raised were really dead.
('71', 131, 2, 22, 266462) I raised a relative’s child from supposed death to life, but that was because the child was not dead, and but for my presence there she might have been cremated.
('71', 131, 2, 23, 266624) But I saw that life was not extinct.
('71', 131, 2, 24, 266661) I gave her an enema and she was restored to life.
('71', 131, 2, 25, 266711) There was no miracle about it.
('71', 131, 2, 26, 266742) I do not deny that Jesus had certain psychic powers and he was undoubtedly filled with the love of humanity.
('71', 131, 2, 27, 266851) But he brought to life not people who were dead but who were believed to be dead.
('71', 131, 2, 28, 266933) The laws of Nature are changeless, unchangeable, and there are no miracles in the sense of infringement or interruption of Nature’s laws.
('71', 131, 2, 29, 267071) But we limited beings fancy all kind of things and impute our limitations to God.
('71', 131, 2, 30, 267153) We may copy God, but not He us.
('71', 131, 2, 31, 267185) We may not divide Time for Him, Time for Him is eternity.
('71', 131, 2, 32, 267243) For us there is past, present and future.
('71', 131, 2, 33, 267285) And what is human life of a hundred years but less than a mere speck in the eternity of Time?

('71', 136, 4, 7, 275437) April 16, 1937
('71', 136, 5, 8, 275452) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Please speak up if my voice does not reach you.
('71', 136, 5, 9, 275522) I shall speak a little louder.
('71', 136, 5, 10, 275553) I have agreed to say a few words before the President starts the discussion.
('71', 136, 5, 11, 275630) During the next six days I shall try to participate in the meetings as much as I can.
('71', 136, 5, 12, 275716) One thing I wish to mention right at the outset.
('71', 136, 5, 13, 275765) When I arrived in the morning, someone remarked that if the Faizpur Congress was Jawaharlal’s, the Hudli Congress was going to be Gandhi’s.
('71', 136, 5, 14, 275905) It was conveyed to me by the President or someone else.
('71', 136, 5, 15, 275961) I know it was said in jest.
('71', 136, 5, 16, 275989) But it pained me that such a thing should be said even in jest.
('71', 136, 5, 17, 276053) It is a sin to imagine even in jest that there can be any rivalry between Jawaharlal and me, or the Congress and the Gandhi Seva Sangh.
('71', 136, 5, 18, 276189) The Gandhi Seva Sangh is not opposed to the Congress.
('71', 136, 5, 19, 276243) It is meant to serve the Congress.
('71', 136, 5, 20, 276278) How could the Sangh be opposed to the Congress when it was conceived in order to carry out the constructive programme of the Congress?
('71', 136, 5, 21, 276413) But I would go even further.
('71', 136, 5, 22, 276442) The Congress represents the millions.
('71', 136, 5, 23, 276480) The Sangh represents us.
('71', 136, 5, 24, 276505) The members of the Sangh are either their own representatives or the representatives of truth and non violence.
('71', 136, 5, 25, 276617) You can say that the whole world should be the representative of truth and non violence.
('71', 136, 5, 26, 276706) But that is a different matter.
('71', 136, 5, 27, 276738) The members of the Sangh would, under the present situation, represent only themselves.
('71', 136, 5, 28, 276826) But do we not want to be the representatives of the millions as well?
('71', 136, 5, 29, 276896) And it is the Congress which is pledged to be the voice of the suffering millions.
('71', 136, 5, 30, 276979) How, then, can there be any opposition between us and the Congress?
('71', 136, 5, 31, 277047) I would go to the extent of saying that the Sangh can have rivalry with none at all.
('71', 136, 5, 32, 277132) Let no one suggest even in jest that there can possibly be any rivalry between the Sangh and the Congress.
('71', 136, 5, 33, 277239) For, it would be an untruth.
('71', 136, 5, 34, 277268) And it is forbidden to speak an untruth even in jest.
('71', 136, 5, 35, 277322) Anyone who hears it must promptly stop it.
('71', 136, 5, 36, 277365) I wish to give you a warning.
('71', 136, 5, 37, 277395) Surely, we do not

('71', 137, 0, 1, 277476) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 137, 1, 2, 277518) intend to indulge in a fight with anyone.
('71', 137, 1, 3, 277560) We cannot even talk in such terms.
('71', 137, 1, 4, 277595) Another thing which I wish to suggest is whether it would not be better to change the name of the Gandhi Seva Sangh.
('71', 137, 1, 5, 277712) You have asso ciated my name with the Sangh.

('71', 137, 1, 18, 278503) And only what independently belongs to you can be really yours.
('71', 137, 1, 19, 278567) Like food, only what you have assimlated would serve you any purpose.
('71', 137, 1, 20, 278637) When we accept someone’s ideas but do not digest them, absorb them intellectually but not emotionally anddo not translate them into practice, it is a kind of indigestion.
('71', 137, 1, 21, 278808) It is an intellectual luxury.
('71', 137, 1, 22, 278838) Ill digested ideas are much worse than ill digested food.
('71', 137, 1, 23, 278896) There is a cure for ill digested food; but ill digested ideas harm the spirit and there is no cure for it.
('71', 137, 1, 24, 279003) It is right that I should help you.
('71', 137, 1, 25, 279039) You have right to pick up a quarrel with me if I say anything which is contrary to what I said in 1920. You must consider independently whether I have improved upon those ideas or allowed them to degenerate.
('71', 137, 1, 26, 279247) Let me tell you that day by day I am marching ahead in the direction of progress and the application of my principles covers a wider field.
('71', 137, 1, 27, 279387) You will have to judge if I am progressing in the right direction.
('71', 137, 1, 28, 279454) You cannot do so if you do not exercise your power of independent judgment.
('71', 137, 1, 29, 279530) The world will ridicule you if you keep on sticking to my name.
('71', 137, 1, 30, 279594) But there is another and graver danger.
('71', 137, 1, 31, 279634) I have a fear that the Sangh may degenerate into a sect.
('71', 137, 1, 32, 279691) If such a thing is possible while I am still alive, what may not happen when I am gone?
('71', 137, 1, 33, 279779) Whenever a difficult situation arises, you would refer to my writings in Young India and Harijan and swear by them to support your own argument.
('71', 137, 1, 34, 279924) It would be proper to cremate all my writings with my body.
('71', 137, 1, 35, 279984) I am not saying this out of any sense of modesty.
('71', 137, 1, 36, 280034) Have I not already said that the world is not going to lose anything even if all our Vedas are destroyed and only the first mantra of Ishopanishad survives?
('71', 137, 1, 37, 280191) And what purpose would be served even by that mantra if we do not understand it and follow it in our actions?
('71', 138, 0, 1, 280301) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 139
('71', 138, 1, 2, 280344) Whatever I have said or written is useful only to the extent that it can help you in understanding and digesting the principles of truth and non violence.
('71', 138, 1, 3, 280499) Hence you must give a serious thought to what I am saying today.
('71', 138, 1, 4, 280564) My faith in truth and non violence becomes stronger every day.
('71', 138, 1, 5, 280627) And as I go on applying these principles to my life, I go on making progress, and with that my ideas acquire a fresh quality.
('71', 138, 1, 6, 280753) This does not mean that I am disorganized and my mind is not steady, or that my intellect is becoming shaky.
('71', 138, 1, 7, 280862) I claim that my intellect has not lost its sharpness even though I have aged.
('71', 138, 1, 8, 280940) It is not as if I was making thoughtless statements.
('71', 138, 1, 9, 280993) My intellect continues to grow and in the matter of truth and non violence it comes face to face with new things every day.
('71', 138, 1, 10, 281117) And I find new light in them.
('71', 138, 1, 11, 281147) I find new meanings in them every day.
('71', 138, 1, 12, 281186) Hence, I continue to give new suggestions to the organizations like the Spinners’ Association, Harijan Sevak Sangh, Village Industries Association etc.
('71', 138, 1, 13, 281338) This means that these organizationsand their organizers are very much alive.
('71', 138, 1, 14, 281415) And like a tree they will go on acquiring a changing quality assuming ever new forms.
('71', 138, 1, 15, 281501) Their merit is that they should grow and progress.
('71', 138, 1, 16, 281552) They would meet their downfall if they do not do so.
('71', 138, 1, 17, 281605) I for one do not feel at all that I am going down.
('71', 138, 1, 18, 281656) I want you to march with me in the direction of progress.
('71', 138, 1, 19, 281714) I am not keen to know what would happen when I am dead.
('71', 138, 1, 20, 281770) My only desire is that the Sangh should always grow like a tree.
('71', 138, 1, 21, 281835) If you worship the ideals–not me–you should remove my name from the name of the Sangh.
('71', 138, 1, 22, 281922) You should not be so much attached to my name.
('71', 138, 1, 23, 281969) You must measure each action of yours with the yardstick of truth and non violence.
('71', 138, 1, 24, 282053) If you make this your yardstick, you will be able to deliberate on all problems without any fear even after I am gone.
('71', 138, 1, 25, 282172) All of you who have come here should always be fully awake.
('71', 138, 1, 26, 282232) You are going to face problems which will demand from you a fresh outlook.
('71', 138, 1, 27, 282307) I hope that with the light of truth you will be able to do so.

('71', 138, 3, 30, 282464) 157. SPINNERS’ WAGES The Council of the A. I. S. A. passed the following important resolutions at its meeting at Wardha on the 23rd and 24th ultimo: 1
('71', 138, 4, 31, 282615) 1 The resolutions are not reproduced here.
('71', 139, 0, 1, 282658) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 139, 1, 2, 282700) When the scheme was inaugurated many workers had grave doubts about its success.
('71', 139, 1, 3, 282781) They had thought that the consequent rise in the price of khadi will adversely affect the sales.
('71', 139, 1, 4, 282878) Experience has dispelled the fears and the Council is anxious to take a further step forward, if it can at all be taken, at an early date.
('71', 139, 1, 5, 283017) Whilst, therefore, there need be no haste about taking the further step, workers may not be lazy about it either.
('71', 139, 1, 6, 283131) They should know that the goal is eight annas per day of eight hours.
('71', 139, 1, 7, 283201) We have only nominally reached three annas which are evenly distributed between increase and efficiency.
('71', 139, 1, 8, 283306) The efficiency earnings do not directly affect the sale price.
('71', 139, 1, 9, 283369) If anything, the efficiency of spinners improves the quality of khadi.
('71', 139, 1, 10, 283440) The direct increase in the wages undoubtedly raises the prices, but its burden is broken by the improvement in quality.
('71', 139, 1, 11, 283560) Then the increase is sojudiciously regulated as to affect the poorest buyer not at all or very slightly.
('71', 139, 1, 12, 283665) I have no manner of doubt that if only the workers will themselves be more efficient, more vigilant and more faithful, they will hasten the day when spinners can easily earn eight annas per day of eight hours’ work without involving a phenomenal rise in the sale price.
('71', 139, 1, 13, 283935) More scientific knowledge must improve the capacity of hand gins, carding bows and spinning wheels.
('71', 139, 1, 14, 284035) Greater observation of spinners’ work must result in their being more skilled and more efficient.
('71', 139, 1, 15, 284133) Greater grasp of administrative detail and greater faithfulness must mean a substantial decrease in overhead charges.
('71', 139, 1, 16, 284251) In other words, our ignorance of the science of khadi is at the bottom of our present inability to reach the goal of eight annas per day.
('71', 139, 1, 17, 284389) The resolution is intended as a spur to effort.
('71', 139, 1, 18, 284437) God helps only the ever watchful.
('71', 139, 1, 19, 284471) Harijan, 17 4 1937
('71', 139, 2, 20, 284490) 158. BAD IF TRUE
('71', 139, 3, 21, 284507) Shri P. O. Philip of the National Christian Council has received the following complaint from Travancore:
('71', 139, 4, 22, 284613) Many thanks for your letter.
('71', 139, 4, 23, 284642) I am consoled by the fact that the Mahatma will use his influence in removing the ill feeling of the caste Hindus in Travancore towards Christians and the Depressed Class converts.
('71', 139, 4, 24, 284823) Last week, while my evangelist Jacob was returning from a Church in North Travancore after the baptism of eight Pariahs, he was stopped by a Hindu Excise (Government) peon and was seriously assulted.
('71', 139, 4, 25, 285023) One of his eyes is injured by the blows.
('71', 139, 4, 26, 285064) The peon said the evangelist had no business to teach and prepare people for baptism after the Temple entry Proclamation.
('71', 139, 4, 27, 285186) I have written about this to the The Madras Mail and the Manorama, but my note has not appeared
('71', 140, 0, 1, 285282) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 141
('71', 140, 1, 2, 285325) in the papers.
('71', 140, 1, 3, 285340) Will you please give publicity to the hideous act?
('71', 140, 1, 4, 285391) Such acts are not isolated ones, but are perpetrated with the knowledge of influential caste Hindus who want to suppress if possible the progress of Christianity.
('71', 140, 1, 5, 285554) You may forward a copy of this note to Mr. Gandhi.
('71', 140, 1, 6, 285605) Communal hatred is on the increase after the Temple entry Proclamation!
('71', 140, 1, 7, 285677) A similar complaint was received by me a few weeks ago through the same source.
('71', 140, 1, 8, 285757) I have forwarded the papers to the Travancore Harijan Sevak Sangh for investigation.
('71', 140, 1, 9, 285842) Meantime I have the foregoing.
('71', 140, 1, 10, 285873) The brief postcard contains most serious allegations.
('71', 140, 1, 11, 285927) The writer claims that 1. the acts are not isolated; 2. they are perpetrated with the knowledge of influential caste Hindus; 3. caste Hindus want to suppress if possible the progress of Christianity; 4. communal hatred is on the increase after the Temple entry Proclamation.
('71', 140, 1, 12, 286202) Now these statements ought not to be lightly made.
('71', 140, 1, 13, 286253) I advise the writer to furnish proofs to the Harijan Sevak Sangh who, I promise, will thoroughly investigate the whole complaint.
('71', 140, 1, 14, 286383) The Sangh has a retired High Court judge as its President and a most conscientious and cultured man as its Secretary.
('71', 140, 1, 15, 286501) I myself will have no hesitation in denouncing the slightest departure by caste Hindus from the strictest non violence.
('71', 140, 1, 16, 286621) It is difficult for me to see why communal hatred should be on the increase because of the Temple entry Proclamation.
('71', 140, 1, 17, 286739) Certainly I observed none during my recent tour in Travancore.

('71', 140, 1, 22, 287304) They could only be dealt with publicly and by a public investigation.

('71', 140, 2, 24, 287393) 159. A. I. V. I. A. TRAINING SCHOOL
('71', 140, 3, 25, 287429) This school has gone through several vicissitudes because of the inexperience of the management.
('71', 140, 3, 26, 287526) The A. I. V. I. A. has to cut its way as it proceeds through an unbeaten track.
('71', 140, 3, 27, 287606) A year’s experience and
('71', 141, 0, 1, 287630) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 141, 1, 2, 287672) experimenting have made the management less ambitious.
('71', 141, 1, 3, 287727) The teachers themselves are training themselves through experimenting.
('71', 141, 1, 4, 287798) And when the next terms commences, there will be greater preparedness than hitherto.
('71', 141, 1, 5, 287883) Here is the unambitious but more realistic prospectus of the school: 1
('71', 141, 2, 6, 287954) The academic year of the All India Village Industries Association Training School for Village Workers will begin from Ist July 1937. .
('71', 141, 3, 7, 288089) 1. Hindi will be the medium of instruction.
('71', 141, 4, 8, 288133) 2. The course will be as far as may be for a period of 12 months, of which two months will have to be spent in village uplift centres for practical study.
('71', 141, 4, 9, 288288) In the first 10 months training in the following industries, together with some theoretical knowledge for village work, will be given:
('71', 141, 5, 10, 288423) 1. Paddy husking and grinding
('71', 141, 6, 11, 288453) 2. Paper making
('71', 141, 7, 12, 288469) 3. Oil pressing by ghani
('71', 141, 8, 13, 288494) 4. Date palm gur making
('71', 141, 9, 14, 288518) 5. Bee keeping
('71', 141, 10, 15, 288533) Students will have to select one of the above industries and devote six hours every day to it.
('71', 141, 11, 16, 288628) 3. Students will be examined at the end of the year and, if found necessary, the course may be prolonged.
('71', 141, 12, 17, 288734) 4. Applicants for admission should not be less than 18 years of age and should possess a healthy body.
('71', 141, 12, 18, 288837) On arrival, such of those as the School Committee requires will undergo preliminary examination and will be expected to pass a test equal to what is known as the Vernacular Middle Course, and may be rejected if they do not possess adequate knowledge.
('71', 141, 12, 19, 289088) They should have a working knowledge of Hindi, should be habitual wearers of khadi and should be prepared to do manual work such as sanitary service, kitchen work and spinning, and such other work as may be required under the discipline of the School.
('71', 141, 12, 20, 289340) Let the applicants study the prospectus carefully.
('71', 141, 12, 21, 289391) Those who are disinclined to do manual labour and apply themselves to the practical learning of the industry of their choice will be disappointed.
('71', 141, 12, 22, 289538) Those who appreciated the necessity of mastering the industries mentioned will find ample scope for their talents.
('71', 141, 12, 23, 289653) Harijan, 17 4 1937

('71', 142, 1, 2, 289752) 160. FOR STUDENTS
('71', 142, 2, 3, 289770) Though this letter 1 was received about the end of February last, I am able to deal with it only now.
('71', 142, 2, 4, 289872) It raises issues of great importance, each demanding large enough space for two columns of Harijan.
('71', 142, 2, 5, 289972) But I must be brief.
('71', 142, 2, 6, 289993) The very difficulties the student raises, though serious in their setting, are of his own making.
('71', 142, 2, 7, 290091) The very mention of them must show the falsity of his position and of the educational system in our country.
('71', 142, 2, 8, 290200) It turns education into a purely commercial product to be converted into money.
('71', 142, 2, 9, 290280) For me education has a much nobler purpose.
('71', 142, 2, 10, 290324) Let the student count himself as one among millions and he will discover that millions of young men and women of his age cannot fulfil the conditions which he will have his degree to do.
('71', 142, 2, 11, 290511) Why should he make himself responsible for the maintenance of all the relatives he mentions?
('71', 142, 2, 12, 290604) Why should the grown up ones, if of sound body, not labour for their maintenance?
('71', 142, 2, 13, 290686) It is wrong to have many drones to one busy bee—though a male.
('71', 142, 2, 14, 290749) The remedy lies in his unlearning many things.
('71', 142, 2, 15, 290796) He must revise his ideas of education.
('71', 142, 2, 16, 290835) His sisters ought not to repeat the expensive education that he had.
('71', 142, 2, 17, 290904) They can develop their intelligence through learning some handicraft in a scientific manner.
('71', 142, 2, 18, 290997) The moment they do so, they have development of the mind side by side with that of the body.
('71', 142, 2, 19, 291090) And if they will learn to regard themselves as servants of humanity rather than its exploiters, they will have development of the heart, i.e., the soul as well.
('71', 142, 2, 20, 291251) And they will become equal earners of bread with their brother.
('71', 142, 2, 21, 291315) I might as well discuss here his sister’s marriage to which reference has been made in the letter.
('71', 142, 2, 22, 291414) I do not know what is meant by marriage taking place ‘sooner rather than later’.
('71', 142, 2, 23, 291495) In no case need it take place before they are 20 years old.
('71', 142, 2, 24, 291555) It is no use thinking so many years in advance.
('71', 142, 2, 25, 291603) And if he will revise the whole scheme of life, he willhave the sisters to choose their partners and the ceremony need never cost more than five rupees each, if that.
('71', 142, 2, 26, 291770) I have been present at several such ceremonies.
('71', 142, 2, 27, 291818) And the husbands or their elders have been graduates in fair circumstances.
('71', 142, 3, 28, 291894) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('71', 142, 3, 29, 291931) The correspondent said that Gandhiji had not done justice to “a student” in his reply; vide “Notes”, sub title “A Student’s Difficulty”, 9 1 1937 He also asked for a “detailed, practical and comprehensive solution” to some of his personal problems.
('71', 143, 0, 1, 292180) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 143, 1, 2, 292222) It is pathetic to find the student so helpless as not to know how and where to have spinning lessons.
('71', 143, 1, 3, 292324) Let him make a diligent search in Lucknow and he will find that there are young men enough to teach him.
('71', 143, 1, 4, 292429) But he need not confine himself to spinning, though it too is fast becoming a full time occupation able to give a village minded man or woman his or her livelihood.
('71', 143, 1, 5, 292594) I hope I have said here sufficient to enable him to dot the i’s and cross the t’s.

('71', 143, 1, 7, 292705) Even here, the difficulty is imaginary.

('71', 143, 1, 15, 293428) The millions are in no dread of having to breed their children though the latter may not all be wanted.

('71', 144, 0, 1, 294598) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 145
('71', 144, 1, 2, 294641) I have been meaning to write to you ever since I read in Harijan your fine letter to Mr. Gandhi.
('71', 144, 1, 3, 294738) I want to tell you how very much I feel with you about what you said with regard to missionary work and to thank you for saying it in your own way to a man like Mahatmaji.
('71', 144, 1, 4, 294910) When I was in India, first as a very undeveloped girl thrust into a C. M. S. atmosphere, very many years ago, I felt that the approach of the missionaries to the people of India was all wrong and I had lonely times of being up against the whole system and yet not exactly being able to formulate my idea or talk to others with any chance of being understood.
('71', 144, 1, 5, 295269) I was also set wondering if we as British people had any right to be ruling India, and I remember expressing this in those early days and being firmly dealt with!
('71', 144, 1, 6, 295432) But ever since those days as my thought life has developed I have been getting to feel that fundamentally the whole position of the British in India was wrong and that the missionaries as a whole were sharing in the superiority complex of those who ruled.
('71', 144, 1, 7, 295688) I am regarded, I know, as a real black sheep in missionary circles.
('71', 144, 1, 8, 295756) So I can thoroughly sympathize with criticism that I am sure you have met with from those quarters!
('71', 144, 1, 9, 295856) But what you said needed saying by someone who was a Christian and who yet saw a different way of sharing her faith with others.
('71', 144, 1, 10, 295985) And it makes all the difference when someone like you who is known and has a position in the country says these things.
('71', 144, 2, 11, 296105) We sing in our Churches in England that grand hymn, whose words I expect you know, written by that inspired blind poet George Matheson:
('71', 144, 3, 12, 296241) Gather us in; we worship only thee
('71', 144, 4, 13, 296276) In varied names we stretch a common hand;
('71', 144, 5, 14, 296318) In diverse forms a common soul we see;
('71', 144, 6, 15, 296357) In many ships we seek one spirit land;
('71', 144, 7, 16, 296396) Gather us in.
('71', 144, 8, 17, 296410) Each sees one colour in Thy rainbow light,
('71', 144, 9, 18, 296453) Each looks upon one tint and calls it heaven,
('71', 144, 10, 19, 296499) Thou art the fulness of OUR partial sight;
('71', 144, 11, 20, 296542) We are not perfect till we find the seven;
('71', 144, 12, 21, 296585) Gather us in.
('71', 144, 13, 22, 296599) Anyway it is a step beyond ‘From Green Land’s lcy Mountains’!
('71', 144, 13, 23, 296661) But I sometimes wonder if the people here who sing this realize its implications.

('71', 146, 1, 2, 298244) 164. LETTER TO HASANALI SHAMJI
('71', 146, 2, 3, 298275) April 17, 1937 I received your letter.
('71', 146, 2, 4, 298314) The questions you have asked 1 can be raised more or less about all [religions].
('71', 146, 2, 5, 298395) I am just telling you my impression after reading the whole biography of the Prophet.
('71', 146, 2, 6, 298481) If I start looking for imperfections and faults, I can find many but while doing so a man begins to despair and there is no reason to despair.
('71', 146, 2, 7, 298624) I left out about the hearing of the inner voice because while replying I did not have your letter before me.

('71', 160, 1, 20, 335657) The sacred thread is useful from this standpoint.
('71', 160, 1, 21, 335707) Otherwise, there is no need to believe that dwija means a Brahmin.
('71', 160, 1, 22, 335774) A Brahmin is one who has awareness of Brahman.
('71', 160, 1, 23, 335821) If, after receiving the sacred thread, we do not take a new birth, if we do not begin a life in accordance with dharma, it makes little difference whether we wear it or not.
('71', 160, 1, 24, 335995) I do not ask anyone to wear the sacred thread, as it has become a mere outward ceremony.
('71', 160, 1, 25, 336084) But those who wish to imbibe consciousness of dharma from the ceremony may well wear the sacred thread.

('71', 163, 7, 11, 339474) For today you may consider me the President.

('71', 180, 4, 17, 386756) The proposal is: Since it is the aim of the Sangh to look upon the constructive programme of the Indian National Congress as a dharma and make it a success, in a programme like the removal of untouchability it is the duty of the members of the Sangh to come into direct contact with sweepers and other Harijan brethren and convince them as well as others that they make no distinctions in their treatment of the Harijans.

('71', 189, 1, 11, 408103) But I would like to remind this sister, and through her all the women of India, that at the time of the Dandi march the women of India did listen to my advice and made the fight against drink and the plying of the wheel their speciality.
