('71', 190, 2, 10, 411195) 183. THE CAUSE OF IT
('71', 190, 3, 11, 411216) A Bangalore correspondent asks:
('71', 190, 4, 12, 411248) You say that a married couple may have sexual union only when there is a mutual desire for a child and on no other account.
('71', 190, 4, 13, 411372) Please let me know why one should wish for a child at all.
('71', 190, 4, 14, 411431) Many people wish for children without fully realizing the responsibilities of parenthood, and many more wish for children fully knowing that they are incapable of discharging the responsibilities of a parent.
('71', 190, 4, 15, 411640) Many persons who are physically and mentally unfit for parenthood wish for children.
('71', 190, 4, 16, 411725) Don’t you think that it is wrong for these persons to procreate?
('71', 190, 5, 17, 411790) I would like to know the motive behind the desire for children.
('71', 190, 5, 18, 411854) Many people wish for children to bequeath their possesions and to break the monotony of their life.
('71', 190, 5, 19, 411954) A few people wish for a male child lest the gates of Heaven would not be opened for them.
('71', 190, 5, 20, 412044) Are not these prople wrong in wishing for a child?
('71', 190, 5, 21, 412095) It is good to seek causes for things.
('71', 190, 5, 22, 412133) But it is not always possible to discover them.
('71', 190, 5, 23, 412181) The desire for children is universal.
('71', 190, 5, 24, 412219) But I do not know any convincing cause, if to see oneself perpetuated through one’s descendants is not a sufficient and convincing cause.
('71', 190, 5, 25, 412357) My proposition, however, is not vitiated if the cause I give for the desire is not found sufficiently convincing.
('71', 190, 5, 26, 412471) The desire is there.
('71', 190, 5, 27, 412492) It seems to be natural.
('71', 190, 5, 28, 412516) I am not sorry for having been born.
('71', 190, 5, 29, 412553) It cannot be unlawful for me to see the best in me reproduced.
('71', 190, 5, 30, 412616) Anyway till I see evil in procreation itself and till I see that the sexual act for mere pleasure is justifiable, I must hold that the sexual act is justified only where there is desire for children.
('71', 190, 5, 31, 412816) I understand that this was so clear to the makers of Smritis that Manu described only the first born as children born of
('71', 191, 0, 1, 412937) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 191, 1, 2, 412979) dharma and the rest of kama—lust.
('71', 191, 1, 3, 413013) The more throught I give to the subject as dispassionately as is possible, the more convinced I feel about the correctness of the position I have taken and am enforcing.
('71', 191, 1, 4, 413183) It is becoming clearer to me that the difficulty lies in our ignorance of the subject with which needless secrecy is being associated.
('71', 191, 1, 5, 413318) Our thought is clouded.
('71', 191, 1, 6, 413342) We dread to face consequences.
('71', 191, 1, 7, 413373) We resort to half measures as if they were perfect or final and thus render them most difficult of execution.
('71', 191, 1, 8, 413483) If our thoughts were clear, if we became sure of our ground, our speech and action would be firm.
('71', 191, 1, 9, 413581) Thus if I am sure that every morsel of food I take is for building and sustaining the body, I shall never desire to take food for the pleasure of the palate.
('71', 191, 1, 10, 413739) I shall further realize that if I have any desire to eat things because they are tasty, and apart from hunger or the thought of sustaining the body, it is a token of disease and I should seek to cure myself of it and not satisfy it as if it was lawful or healthy.
('71', 191, 1, 11, 414003) Even so if I am quite clear that the sexual act, apart from the unquestioned desire for progeny, is unlawful and detrimental to the body, mind and soul, surely resistance to the desire will become easy– far easier than when I am not clear whether the gratification of mere desire is or is not lawful and beneficial.
('71', 191, 1, 12, 414319) If I am quite clear about the unlawfulness of the desire, I shall treat it as if it were a disease and repel its attacks with all my vigour.
('71', 191, 1, 13, 414460) I shall feel the stronger for the resistance.
('71', 191, 1, 14, 414506) They are wrong, even untruthful, who claim that they do not like the act but are helpless and therefore resistance leaves them weak and defeated.
('71', 191, 1, 15, 414652) If all such people were to examine themselves, they would discover that their thoughts deceive them.
('71', 191, 1, 16, 414753) Their thoughts cherish the desire and their speech is a false interpreter of their thoughts.
('71', 191, 1, 17, 414846) If on the other hand the speech is a true interpreter of the thoughts there can be no such thing as weakness.
('71', 191, 1, 18, 414956) Defeat there may be.
('71', 191, 1, 19, 414977) Weakness never.
('71', 191, 2, 20, 414993) The correspondent’s objection to procreation by unhealthy parents is perfectly valid.
('71', 191, 2, 21, 415079) They can have or should have no desire for progeny.
('71', 191, 2, 22, 415131) They are deceiving themselves and the world if they say that they perform the sexual act for progeny.
('71', 191, 2, 23, 415233) In an examination of any subject truthfulness is always assumed.
('71', 191, 2, 24, 415298) Desire for progeny must not be feigned in order to cover the pleasure of sexual union.

('71', 198, 1, 2, 426015) 194. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS1
('71', 198, 2, 3, 426044) NAGPUR, [ April 25, 1937] 2
('71', 198, 3, 4, 426072) Q. Would you be satisfied with the assurance from the Governors on the lines given by Sir Samuel Hoare and quoted 3 by you?
('71', 198, 3, 5, 426196) A. I would be satisfied with the assurance with a definition of the word ‘ordinarily’ which everybody can understand.
('71', 198, 4, 6, 426314) Will you kindly give me your own definition of the work ‘ordinarily’?
('71', 198, 4, 7, 426384) A. definition has really to come from those who want to introduce the adverb.
('71', 198, 4, 8, 426462) I have not introduced the word ‘ordinarily’ in the Congress resolution 4 .
('71', 198, 4, 9, 426537) Congress meaning is quite clear.
('71', 198, 4, 10, 426570) For, it asked for an assurance in connection with a definite programme.
('71', 198, 4, 11, 426642) If that programme and everything similar to that programme is pursued by the Congress there should be no interference on the part of the Governor.
('71', 198, 4, 12, 426789) If in the opinion of the Governors the worst happens as Lord Lothian has suggested, the Governors can dismiss the Cabinet, dissolve the Assemblies and appeal to the electorate to find out whom the electorate will support.
('71', 198, 4, 13, 427011) If the Congress aim is to create deadlocks, what point is there is asking for any assurance from the Governors?
('71', 198, 4, 14, 427123) As I have already said and as I have read the Congress resolution, the aim of the Congress is not to create deadlocks,, but its aim undoubtedly is to make Congress position so irresistible as to replace the present Act, which nobody likes, by an Act which will represent the will of the masses.
('71', 198, 4, 15, 427418) This will be brought about by constitutional means permissible under the Act itself.
('71', 198, 4, 16, 427503) And if the Congress by force of its majority and by skill of Congress Ministers advances its own constitutional position to such a pitch that the British Ministers cannot possibly resist it except by force of arms, surely there can be nothing to grumble at.
('71', 198, 5, 17, 427761) You have said 4 that the Congress wanted non interference not non dismissal.
('71', 198, 5, 18, 427838) Will you please explain the difference between the two?
('71', 198, 5, 19, 427894) As a gentleman I cannot possibly ask for a promise that the Cabinet may never be dismissed.
('71', 198, 5, 20, 427986) But I can ask that there should be no
('71', 198, 6, 21, 428024) 1 Gandhiji gave the answers to questions sulrmitted to him by the correspondents of The Times of India, Bomay, and News Chronicle, London.
('71', 198, 6, 22, 428163) 2 On his way to Allahabad Gandhiji passed through Nagpur on this date.
('71', 198, 6, 23, 428234) 3 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 30 3 1937 4 Vide “ Extract From A.I.C.C. Resolution”, 16 3 1937; also “Interview to The Bombay Chronicle”.

('71', 199, 0, 1, 428384) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 199, 1, 2, 428426) interference in the day to day administration.
('71', 199, 1, 3, 428473) I do not want the Cabinet to be in a position of having to resign on the slightest pretext; for honourable resignation there must be honourable cause that anybody could see.
('71', 199, 1, 4, 428647) If I have no assurance of non interference the Governor may submit his Ministers to pinpricks which they would feel but which may not give them understandable cause to take to the public in justifying resignation.
('71', 199, 1, 5, 428861) I would never put the Congress Cabinet in such embarrassing and humiliating position.
('71', 199, 1, 6, 428947) The same thing would apply to the Governors.
('71', 199, 1, 7, 428992) They would look incredibly foolish if on the slightest pretext they dismissed the Cabinet.
('71', 199, 1, 8, 429083) Therefore, if Governors are gentlemen and want to preserve the honour of the nation whom they represent they will think fifty times before dismissing the Cabinet.
('71', 199, 1, 9, 429246) I want to put them in that position so that there shall be no pinpricks from the Governors as all Ministers who worked under the Montford reforms have testified.
('71', 199, 1, 10, 429408) Their position was made unbearable and humiliating and yet they were unable to resign, perhaps they would not.
('71', 199, 1, 11, 429519) I do not know which was the case.

('71', 199, 2, 13, 429577) 195. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('71', 199, 3, 14, 429603) ALLAHABAD, April 26, 1937
('71', 199, 4, 15, 429629) MY DEAR REBEL, Your note awaited me as I reached Allahabad.
('71', 199, 4, 16, 429689) Jawaharlal looks very much pulled down, looks almost an old man.
('71', 199, 4, 17, 429754) His voice is feeble.
('71', 199, 4, 18, 429775) Enough to make one weep to see him so pale.
('71', 199, 4, 19, 429819) Indu is quite nice though she looks the same fragile thing she was before.
('71', 199, 4, 20, 429894) Old Mrs. Nehru is bed ridden though better than she was a fewdays ago.
('71', 199, 4, 21, 429965) Subhas has arrived but I have not yet seen him.
('71', 199, 4, 22, 430013) It is presently to strike 12 when I break silence.
('71', 199, 4, 23, 430064) Subhas sees me at 1 p.m.
('71', 199, 4, 24, 430089) The Working Committee sits at 2.30 p.m.
('71', 199, 4, 25, 430129) I leave here on 28th and reach Wardha 29th.
('71', 199, 4, 26, 430173) The weather seems to have been abnormal everywhere.
('71', 199, 4, 27, 430225) It is very hot here.
('71', 199, 4, 28, 430246) Mahadev, Pyarelal and Radhakrishna are with me.
('71', 199, 5, 29, 430294) From the original: C.W. 3778. Courtesy: Amrit Kaur.

('71', 200, 7, 15, 431356) It is to be hoped therefore that representative papers like The Times and The Manchester Guardian will influence the British Government rather than seek to influence me or the Working Committee.
('71', 200, 7, 16, 431551) The latter will take care of itself and speak for itself.
('71', 200, 7, 17, 431609) I have made my position absolutely clear.

('71', 201, 1, 3, 432047) But to the man in the street who knows nothing of legal quibbles or even of the Consititution that is the only question.
('71', 201, 2, 4, 432168) With reference to Press report 1 from Nagpur stating that to a question whether
('71', 201, 3, 5, 432248) he thought, if the Congress did not accept office, the minority Ministries would win over the electorate by their ameliorative measures, Mr. Gandhi was reported to have said, “I should not be surprised,” Mr. Gandhi says: Whoever is the party concerned for the Nagpur telegram, he has reported just the contrary of what I meant or at least what I intended to mean.
('71', 201, 3, 6, 432612) My answer was that I should be surprised if minority Ministries would win over the electorate by their ameliorative measures in case Congress did not accept office.
('71', 201, 3, 7, 432777) A slip of paper containing questions was handed to me through the crowd into the railway compartment which was none too empty.
('71', 201, 3, 8, 432904) I hurriedly wrote out the answer in pencil.
('71', 201, 3, 9, 432948) If the reporter maintains that I wrote the word ‘not’, I would very much like to see the original.

('71', 202, 11, 24, 434461) 201. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”3
('71', 202, 12, 25, 434503) April 30, 1937
('71', 202, 13, 26, 434518) Questioned whether he still adhered to the view that if Governors gave assurance to the effect that “ordinarily” they would not interfere with constitutional activities of the Congress Ministers, the Congress would accept office, Gandhiji said,
('71', 202, 14, 27, 434763) 1 Laxmi, daughter of Janakidevi Bajaj’s brother, Purushottamdas Jajodiya.
('71', 202, 14, 28, 434837) 2 Shriram, son of Rameshwardas Poddar of Dhulia.
('71', 202, 14, 29, 434886) 3 Gandhiji gave the interview in the train en route to Wardha.
('71', 203, 0, 1, 434949) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 203, 1, 2, 434991) in this matter his position should be properly understood.
('71', 203, 1, 3, 435050) Gandhiji did not think that mere addition of the word ‘ordinarily’ to the formula would satisfy him or the Congress.
('71', 203, 1, 4, 435167) Such assurance would be acceptable to him only if the qualifying word was “properly interpreted to our satisfaction”.
('71', 203, 1, 5, 435285) Gandhiji further declared: We should know the meaning of ‘ordinarily’ beforehand.
('71', 203, 2, 6, 435367) Our correspondent then drew Gandhiji’s attention to Prof.
('71', 203, 2, 7, 435425) Keith’s 2 latest constitutional pronouncement published in today’s Leader and asked him about the Congress position vis a vis Governor’s special powers.
('71', 203, 3, 8, 435578) Gandhiji smiled and said it was stale news and he had read it already in some paper yesterday.
('71', 203, 3, 9, 435673) As I read Professor Keith’s statement I saw that he entirely endorsed the Congress position that the Congress does not seek any abrogation of the Act.
('71', 203, 4, 10, 435824) Asked whether it would not be unconstitutional for the Congress Ministry to attempt to trample over the legitimate rights of the minorities, Gandhiji declared that it would not only be unconstitutional but “suicidal”.
('71', 203, 4, 11, 436042) The Bombay Chronicle, 1 5 1937
('71', 203, 5, 12, 436073) 202. HARIJANS ON BEGAR
('71', 203, 6, 13, 436096) The newspapers have given publicity to the threat of certain Harijans in certain villages to transfer their allegiance to the Christian Missions seeking to wean them from Hinduism under promise of better treatment, and especially freedom from begar 3 to which they are subjected by savarna Hindus.
('71', 203, 6, 14, 436394) It seems that representatives of the Hindu Mission and of the Harijan Sevak Sangh visited the aggrieved Harijans and got the savarna Hindus to promise better treatment.
('71', 203, 6, 15, 436563) The storm has abated for the time being.
('71', 203, 6, 16, 436604) I do not know what would have been the gain to the Missions concerned if the Harijans had gone over to their fold and how far the Harijans could have been claimed as bona fide converts.
('71', 203, 6, 17, 436790) This I know that such proselytizing efforts demoralize society, create suspicions and bitterness and retard the all round progress of society.
('71', 203, 6, 18, 436933) If, instead of wanting the so called conversion as the price of better treatment, Christian Missions co operated with Harijan sevaks in their effort to ease the burderns of Harijans, their help would be welcomed and the evolution of society would be hastened.
('71', 203, 6, 19, 437193) But I write this more to awaken savarna conscience than to
('71', 203, 7, 20, 437252) 1 Vide also “Interview to the Press”,25 4 1937 2 A. B. Keith, a constitutional lawyer of England.
('71', 203, 7, 21, 437350) 3 Forced labour without any wages.
('71', 204, 0, 1, 437385) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 205
('71', 204, 1, 2, 437428) criticize the Mission methods brought to light.
('71', 204, 1, 3, 437476) The system of forced labour exacted by petty land owners from Harijans and other classes called backward is almost universal in India.
('71', 204, 1, 4, 437611) The petty landlords are mostly Hindus.
('71', 204, 1, 5, 437650) Harijans and others can legally resist forced labour.
('71', 204, 1, 6, 437704) They are slowly but surely being awakened to a sense of their rights.
('71', 204, 1, 7, 437774) They are numerous enough to enforce them.
('71', 204, 1, 8, 437816) But all grace will be gone when savarna Hindus impotently resign themselves to their merited fate.
('71', 204, 1, 9, 437915) Better surely by far if they will recognize their duty of regarding Harijans as blood brothers, entitled to the respect that belongs to man and to receive due payment for services voluntarily performed.
('71', 204, 1, 10, 438118) It is the privilege of Harijan savaks, no matter to what organization they belong, to befriend Harijans to study their condition in detail, to approach savarna Hindus and show them as gently as possible what their duty is towards those whom they have treated as outcastes of society and deprived even of legal rights.
('71', 204, 1, 11, 438436) From the papers before me I further find that in Ode and some other villages in Gujarat the savarna Hindus take from Harijans who dispose of their dead cattle half the hide.
('71', 204, 1, 12, 438610) This is unlike the usual practice of allowing the Harijans to own the dead cattle they remove.
('71', 204, 1, 13, 438705) In some cases Harijans not only retain the dead cattle they remove, but receive a payment for the labour of removing carcasses.
('71', 204, 1, 14, 438833) The matter demands more investigation and fair adjustment.
('71', 204, 1, 15, 438892) If Harijans were better treated and if savarna Hindus had no horror of dead cattle and had no superstitious laws of pollution, they would learn the art of flaying the dead cattle and turning every part of the carcasses into wealth, both to the benefit of themselves and the Harijans whom they may invite to help them in the process of disposing of their dead cattle.
('71', 204, 1, 16, 439259) Harijan, 1 5 1937
('71', 204, 2, 17, 439277) 203. ESSAYS ON BARTER SYSTEM Reader will remember that a prize of Rs. 500 was announced for the best essay recommending a barter system.
('71', 204, 2, 18, 439414) The terms were also given.
('71', 204, 2, 19, 439441) The time for sending the essays having elapsed, the Board of Examiners entered upon their task and have reported that none of the essays fulfil the conditions laid down.
('71', 204, 2, 20, 439611) The following is their report 1 .
('71', 204, 2, 21, 439645) The prize has not been withdrawn by the donor.
('71', 204, 2, 22, 439692) The examiners, Prof.
('71', 204, 2, 23, 439713) K.T. Shah, Shri Vaikunth Mehta and Prof.
('71', 204, 3, 24, 439754) 1 This is not reproduced here; vide also “Letter to J. C. Kumarappa”, 3 4 1937
('71', 205, 0, 1, 439833) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 205, 1, 2, 439875) Kumarappa, have kindly signified their readiness to examine any further essays that may be sent.
('71', 205, 1, 3, 439972) I would, however, advise competitors, if any are willing, to strictly conform to the requirements laid down by the examiners.
('71', 205, 1, 4, 440098) It is clear from their note and it is but natural that no essay will pass muster unless it reaches the level expected by them, and none will reach that level unless writers are industrious enough to study the necessary literature on the subject and build on their study an original thesis.
('71', 205, 1, 5, 440388) It may be that the prize is not sufficiently tempting for such an effort.
('71', 205, 1, 6, 440462) If that is so, I can only say that those who write for the mere monetary value of prizes hardly ever realize the expectations of donors.
('71', 205, 1, 7, 440599) Without love of subject itself, high merit is not to be expected in difficult competitions like the one about the system of barter.

('71', 205, 2, 12, 440999) 204. A MORAL DILEMMA1
('71', 205, 3, 13, 441021) A friend writes: 2
('71', 205, 4, 14, 441040) About two and a half years ago this city was convulesd by a social tragedy.
('71', 205, 4, 15, 441116) A Vaishya gentleman had a sixteen year old daughter.
('71', 205, 4, 16, 441169) She had a maternal uncle aged twenty one years studying in college in the same city.
('71', 205, 4, 17, 441254) The two fell secretly in love with each other.
('71', 205, 4, 18, 441301) The girl is said to have become pregnant.
('71', 205, 4, 19, 441343) When the true state of affairs at last became known, the lovers committed suicide by taking poison.
('71', 205, 4, 20, 441443) The girl died immediately but the boy died a couple of days afterwards in the hospital .
('71', 205, 4, 21, 441532) At the time when the storm was at its height and nobody had a kind word to say about the deceased unfortunate lovers, I shocked everybody by expressing my opinion that under the afore mentioned circumstances the young lovers ought to have been allowed to have their way.
('71', 205, 4, 22, 441803) But mine remained a voice in the wilderness.
('71', 205, 4, 23, 441848) What is your opinion in the matter?
('71', 205, 4, 24, 441884) I have deliberately kept back the name of the correspondent and the place at the request of the writer as he did not want old sores to be reoponded by a revival of an old controversy.
('71', 205, 4, 25, 442068) All the same I feel that a public discussion of this delicate topic is necessary.
('71', 205, 4, 26, 442150) In my opinion such marriages as are interdicted in a particulars society cannot be recongnized all at once or at the will of an individual.
('71', 205, 4, 27, 442290) Nor has society
('71', 205, 5, 28, 442306) 1 The Hindi original of this was published in Harijan Sevak, 1 5 1937. This appeared as “abridged by Pyarelal”.
('71', 205, 5, 29, 442418) 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('71', 206, 0, 1, 442455) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 207
('71', 206, 1, 2, 442498) or relatives of parties concerned any right to impose their will upon and forcibly curtail the liberty of action of the young people who may want to contract such marriages.
('71', 206, 1, 3, 442672) In the instance cited by the correspondent both the parties had fully attained maturity.
('71', 206, 1, 4, 442761) They could well think for themselves.
('71', 206, 1, 5, 442799) No one had a right forcibly to prevent them from marrying each other if they wanted to.
('71', 206, 1, 6, 442887) Society could at the most refuse to recognize the marriage, but it was the height of tyranny to drive them to suicide.
('71', 206, 1, 7, 443006) Marriage taboos are not universal and are largely based on social usage.
('71', 206, 2, 8, 443079) These alliances are not taboo in every society.
('71', 206, 2, 9, 443127) The Christian, Muslim, Parsi and other communities do not observe this taboo.
('71', 206, 2, 10, 443205) It is not even taboo in all Hindu varnas.
('71', 206, 2, 11, 443247) The same varna has different customs in different Provinces.
('71', 206, 2, 12, 443308) Among the so called high caste Brahmins of the South, such alliances are not only not tabooed, but on the contrary are considered commendable.
('71', 206, 3, 13, 443451) The usage varies from Province to Province and as between different divisions.
('71', 206, 3, 14, 443530) This does not mean that the youth may ride roughshod over all established social customs and inhibitions.
('71', 206, 3, 15, 443636) Before they decide to do so, they must convert public opinion to their side.
('71', 206, 3, 16, 443713) In the meantime, the individuals concerned ought patiently to bide their time, or, if they cannot do that calmly and quietly, to face the consequences of social ostracism.
('71', 206, 3, 17, 443885) At the same time it is equally the duty of society not to take up a heartless, step motherly attitude towards those who might disregard or break the established conventions.
('71', 206, 3, 18, 444059) In the instance described by my correspondent the guilt of driving the young couple to suicide certainly rests on the shoulders of society if the version that is before me in correct.
('71', 206, 3, 19, 444243) Harijan, 29 5 1937

('71', 207, 5, 13, 445292) 206. KATHIAWAR COWS.
('71', 207, 6, 14, 445313) Shri Narahari Parikh, Secretary of the Goseva Sangh, has sent me a brief description of his tour in some Kathiawar States which he undertook for examining the cattle wealth there.
('71', 207, 6, 15, 445493) I hope to publish it in Harijanbandhu, in two instalments.
('71', 207, 6, 16, 445552) The following [item in this issue] is the first of these.
('71', 207, 6, 17, 445610) 1 There was a time when Kathiawar cows were highly praised.
('71', 207, 6, 18, 445670) That variety still exists but it is gradually disappearing.

('71', 214, 8, 17, 457557) For, the right person to interview the Viceroy is naturally Jawaharlal Nehru.

('71', 217, 5, 7, 461194) 222. LETTER TO M. SATYANARAYANA1
('71', 217, 6, 8, 461227) May 6, 1937
('71', 217, 7, 9, 461239) BHAI SATYANARAYANA, I have shown your scheme to Anna also.
('71', 217, 7, 10, 461298) His views are enclosed.
('71', 217, 7, 11, 461322) What you have written about Punjabi in the first paragraph does not seem to be correct.
('71', 217, 7, 12, 461410) For, if Punjabi is quite similar to Hindi, are not Bengali, Oriya, Assamese and Sindhi also very much like Hindi?
('71', 217, 7, 13, 461524) But at the same time it can be said that Hindustani and Urdu are also as much in use as Punjabi in the Punjab.
('71', 217, 7, 14, 461635) So whatever work is to be done there should be carried on only through local people.
('71', 217, 7, 15, 461720) It is for this reason that just as no activity is carried on by the Hindi Prachar Samiti in the United Provinces, there should be none in the Punjab also.
('71', 217, 7, 16, 461875) You must keep in mind that we do not propagate Hindi where Urdu is spoken.
('71', 217, 7, 17, 461950) We consider Urdu speaking people as Hindi speaking ones.
('71', 217, 7, 18, 462007) As for the rest of the scheme my view is that all the activities should be self sufficient.
('71', 217, 7, 19, 462099) Let me give you one more idea.
('71', 217, 7, 20, 462130) I am of the opinion that we have attempted nothing original in our method of teaching, i.e., we have hardly made any efforts for making the learning of Hindi easy and interesting as has been done in the case of English.
('71', 217, 7, 21, 462350) Who amongst us can tell how many days it takes to teach Hindi, or in how many days the script may be taught?
('71', 217, 7, 22, 462459) We have not evolved a model self teaching primer in any of the Indian languages.
('71', 217, 7, 23, 462540) Some little effort has been made in Tamil, etc., but I see nothing original, nothing extraordinary in it.
('71', 217, 7, 24, 462646) If we can do something on these lines the spread
('71', 217, 8, 25, 462695) 1 Of the Dakshin Bharat Hindi Prachar Sabha
('71', 218, 0, 1, 462739) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 219
('71', 218, 1, 2, 462782) of Hindi will be greatly expedited and lakhs of rupees saved.
('71', 218, 1, 3, 462844) We do have a good many teachers in the South because of the Dakshin Bharat [Hindi] Prachar [Sabha] but do we have someone who can take up this kind of task?
('71', 218, 1, 4, 463001) I think that such an experiment must find a place in one of our schemes.
('71', 218, 2, 5, 463074) Blessings from
('71', 218, 3, 6, 463089) From the Hindi original: Rashtrabhasha Prachar Samiti Papers.

('71', 218, 4, 9, 463212) 223. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('71', 218, 5, 10, 463256) WARDHA, May 6, 1937
('71', 218, 6, 11, 463276) Q. I take it that you had much to do with the latest resolution 1 of the Working
('71', 218, 7, 12, 463357) Committee on office acceptance.
('71', 218, 7, 13, 463389) If so, is there any truth in the suggestion that you
('71', 218, 8, 14, 463442) have yielded to the left wingers?
('71', 218, 8, 15, 463476) A. As a matter of fact there were no left wingers and right wingers this time.
('71', 218, 8, 16, 463555) The only question discussed was about the form the resolution had to take.
('71', 218, 9, 17, 463630) Do you not see that there is very little difference between Mr. Butler’s 2
('71', 218, 10, 18, 463705) statement and the Working Committee’s resolution?
('71', 218, 10, 19, 463755) If that is so, why is there the slightest difficulty about Mr. Butler’s instructing the Governors to offer office to the Congress leaders in terms of the Congress Resolution?
('71', 218, 11, 20, 463930) 1 Passed at Allahabad on April 28, which read: :”The past record of the British Government as well as its present attitude show that without the specific assurances as required by the Congress, popular Ministers will be unable to function properly and without irritating interference.
('71', 218, 11, 21, 464215) The assurances do not contemplate abrogation of the right of the Governor to dismiss the Ministry or dissolve the provincial Assembly when serious differences of opinion arise between the Governor and his Ministers.
('71', 218, 11, 22, 464431) But this Committee has grave objection to Ministers having to submit to interference by the Governor with the alternative of themselves having to resign their office instead of the Governors taking the responsibility of dismissing them.” 2 Under Secretary of State for India; addressing the House of Commons on April 26, he said: “His Majesty’s Government have no intention of countenancing the use of special powers for purposes other than those for which Parliament intended them.
('71', 218, 11, 23, 464914) It is certainly not their intention that the Governors, by a narrow or legalistic interpretation of their own responsibilities should trench upon the wide powers which it was the purpose of Parliament to place in the hands of Ministers and which it is desired they should use in furtherance of the programmes they have advocated.”
('71', 219, 0, 1, 465245) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 219, 1, 2, 465287) Leaving Lord Zetland’s speech 1 aside for the moment, what is the discourtesy you detect in Mr. Butler’s statement?
('71', 219, 1, 3, 465403) I have never known a great party, commanding a majority that the Congress does, having such a thing as office thrown at it, and its leaders treated as if they were petitioners.
('71', 219, 1, 4, 465580) If they were Ministers would they have to send applications to the Governors for interviews and run the risk of their applications being summarily rejected?
('71', 219, 1, 5, 465737) I had thought that in autonomy the Ministers got the audience of their Governors for the asking and often the Governors had to give in to the Ministers where the latter had felt displeased or offended.
('71', 219, 1, 6, 465939) The British Government know that the Congress is out for complete independence.
('71', 219, 1, 7, 466019) It seems to me that the British Cabinet resent this attitude of Congress.
('71', 219, 1, 8, 466093) If so, they should plainly tell the Congress and the world that they will not tolerate complete independence and should cease to play with the word ‘autonomy’.
('71', 219, 1, 9, 466253) If on the other hand they do not mind natural evolution of India to its destiny, whatever it may be, they must treat the Congress with the consideration its position demands and disarm suspicion that, owing to their speech and action, is deepening.
('71', 219, 1, 10, 466502) The Hitavada, 7 5 1937

('71', 219, 4, 15, 466758) The last resolution of the Working Committee is the clearest possible annotation of the All India Congress Committee’s resolution, in accordance with which assurances were asked for.
('71', 219, 4, 16, 466941) Now the world knows what was meant.

('71', 220, 2, 6, 468564) 225. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI SEGAON, WARDHA May 7, 1937 CHI.
('71', 220, 2, 7, 468627) NARANDAS, Give the accompanying letter to Kamu.
('71', 220, 2, 8, 468675) The letter to which it is a reply is also enclosed.
('71', 220, 2, 9, 468727) If you take from her all the work she can do what would be your assessment of its value at the market rate?
('71', 220, 2, 10, 468835) You need not consider whether your school can bear the burden.
('71', 220, 2, 11, 468898) You have read in Harijan 1 about Anna.
('71', 220, 2, 12, 468937) Kamalabai, the person with whom he fell, is here at present.
('71', 220, 2, 13, 468998) She says that she is repenting now.
('71', 220, 2, 14, 469034) I have myself brought Anna here.
('71', 220, 2, 15, 469067) I think he is repenting.
('71', 220, 2, 16, 469092) I am not sure about Kamalabai.
('71', 220, 2, 17, 469123) She says that she has felt so deeply that she is not likely to commit a similar mistake again.
('71', 220, 2, 18, 469218) It does not seem desirable to keep both of them at Segaon.
('71', 220, 2, 19, 469277) I think it will be for Anna’s good to keep him with me.
('71', 220, 2, 20, 469333) I, therefore, feel inclined to put Kamalabai under your care.
('71', 220, 2, 21, 469395) I will bear the expenses on her account.
('71', 220, 2, 22, 469436) You may give her any work you like.
('71', 220, 2, 23, 469472) She has some ability.
('71', 220, 2, 24, 469494) Her mother tongue is Kannada and she is a Hindi teacher.
('71', 220, 2, 25, 469551) She is ready to learn whatever other work we may teach her.
('71', 220, 2, 26, 469611) She can teach sewing, etc.
('71', 220, 2, 27, 469638) If you feel hesitant, please let me know.
('71', 220, 2, 28, 469680) Send me a wire if you are ready to take her under your care.
('71', 220, 2, 29, 469741) We start from here on the 9th.
('71', 220, 2, 30, 469772) 10, 11 and 12 at Bardoli, and after the 12th in Tithal, near Bulsar, Send the wire to Bardoli.

('71', 221, 0, 1, 470210) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 221, 1, 2, 470252) 226. COCHIN TRAVANCORE
('71', 221, 2, 3, 470275) My worst fears have come true and Cochin and Travancore are at war with each other.
('71', 221, 2, 4, 470359) The pity of it is that the war is over a matter of vital interest to Hinduism and therefore to the whole of India.
('71', 221, 2, 5, 470474) It is a war between light and darkness.
('71', 221, 2, 6, 470514) I am loath to think that the population of Cochin is behind the Cochin Maharaja’s action.
('71', 221, 2, 7, 470604) He may regulate worship in the Cochin temples under his jurisdiction in any manner he likes.
('71', 221, 2, 8, 470697) But even the most orthodox Hinduism would hardly permit him to regulate the private conduct of the visitors to the Cochin temples.
('71', 221, 2, 9, 470828) In no temple in India where Harijans are not permitted to worship are trustees authorized to scrutinize the actions of savarna Hindus who are entitled as a matter of right to visit the temples.
('71', 221, 2, 10, 471022) In Cochin the Maharaja has interfered in respect of a temple 1
('71', 221, 3, 11, 471085) over which he has no exclusive control.
('71', 221, 3, 12, 471125) The Maharaja of Travancore, too, possesses substantial right over the temples in question.
('71', 221, 3, 13, 471216) The Cochin order is clearly an interference with that right.
('71', 221, 3, 14, 471277) If Travancore has sinned, it is no concern of Cochin.
('71', 221, 3, 15, 471331) The Cochin order is an interference with the right of private judgment.
('71', 221, 3, 16, 471403) In this crisis the duty of the public seems to me to be clear.
('71', 221, 3, 17, 471466) Meetings should be held all over the country condemning the Cochin orders and asking for their withdrawal.
('71', 221, 3, 18, 471573) The most orthodox Hindus can surely join such protest meetings even though they may not be in favour of throwing open all temples to Harijans.
('71', 221, 3, 19, 471716) Seeing that the Cochin public is directly interested in the action of its Maharaja, they may lead the agitation.
('71', 221, 3, 20, 471829) The pundits of India should dispassionately examine the orders and express their unbiased opinion.
('71', 221, 3, 21, 471928) I am inclined to think that the Travancore Durbar may well invite the opinion of pundits on the single question of the religious propriety of the Cochin order and undertake to abide by their opinion.
('71', 221, 3, 22, 472128) In other words, Travancore may well offer to abide by the verdict of an arbitration tribunal consisting of unbiased pundits who will be universally accepted as such.
('71', 221, 3, 23, 472294) The opinion of an assembly of such pundits would be the nearest approach to an arbitration tribunal.
('71', 221, 3, 24, 472395) For, whilst the
('71', 221, 4, 25, 472411) 1 Koodalmanikkam Temple; for details of the controversy, vide Appendix “Koodalmanikkam Temple Controversy”, 22 5 1937; vide also the following item and “Cochin untouchability”, 5 6 1937.
('71', 222, 0, 1, 472598) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 223
('71', 222, 1, 2, 472641) Travancore Durbar had a perfect right to open to Harijans the temples within their sole jurisdiction and ownership and without reference to the opinion of pundits, it would hardly be right to propound a new Smriti in respect of temples where there is joint jurisdiction.
('71', 222, 1, 3, 472912) The Harijan cause must be always and everywhere above suspicion.
('71', 222, 1, 4, 472977) Travancore’s glorious action is capable of standing meticulous scrutiny on the ground of moral correctness.
('71', 222, 1, 5, 473085) Harijan, 8 5 1937
('71', 222, 2, 6, 473103) 227. THE COCHIN TEMPLE ENTRY BAN
('71', 222, 3, 7, 473136) Since the foregoing 1 was written the following was received from Shri C.K. Parameswaran Pillai, President, Kerala Harijan Sevak Sangh...
('71', 222, 4, 8, 473274) In a letter to The Madras Mail from somebody from Ernakulam, dated the 20th April, 1937, it is stated that considerable resentment is felt here at the criticisms in Travancore of the Cochin Government’s order regarding the Koodalmanikkam Temple at Irinjalakuda, and the vast majority of the Hindus in the State support the Government’s action....
('71', 222, 4, 9, 473621) Again on the 23rd April The Madras Mail’s own correspondent wrote to that paper that “leading citizens of Irinjalakuda support the Cochin Government’s declaration that the temple was defiled by the participation in its ceremonies of tantris who had officiated in temples to which avarnas were admitted....
('71', 222, 5, 10, 473927) The Cochin Legislative Council has been passing resolutions year after year recommending to Government the abolition of untouchability.
('71', 222, 5, 11, 474063) Resoutions were also passed at public meetings on several occasions in support of temple entry for Harijans.
('71', 222, 5, 12, 474172) Having reasons, therefore, to doubt therefore, to doubt the correctness of the statement in The Madras Mail, I went
('71', 222, 6, 13, 474288) to Ernakulam on the 25th April accompanied by Sjt.
('71', 222, 6, 14, 474339) M. Govindan, B.A.,B.L., retired Judge and the President of the Trivandrum District Committee of the Harijan Sevak Sangh, to study the real situation of affairs in Cochin.
('71', 222, 6, 15, 474510) I interviewed several important persons including the Thachudaya Kaimal, the administrator of the Koodalmanikkam Temple, and the Prisendent of the S.N.D.P. Yogam.
('71', 222, 6, 16, 474673) I am now in a position, to say difinitely that there is no foundation for the statement in The Madras Mail that the majority of the
('71', 222, 7, 17, 474805) people of Cochin support the action of the Cochin Government in excommunicating the tantris.
('71', 222, 7, 18, 474898) The Hindu of the 23rd April has published two
('71', 222, 8, 19, 474944) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('71', 222, 9, 20, 474971) 2 Only extracts from Parameswaran Pillai’s letter, reporting his interview to the Associated Press of India after a study tour of Cochin, are reproduced here.
('71', 223, 0, 1, 475130) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 223, 1, 2, 475172) statements...
('71', 223, 1, 3, 475186) denouncing in unmistakable terms the action taken by the Cochin Government against the Nedumpally Nambudiri the tantri
('71', 223, 2, 4, 475305) concerned...
('71', 223, 2, 5, 475318) From the social and moral standpoint the action of the Cochin Government is unjustifiable and inconsistent.
('71', 223, 2, 6, 475426) The dharmashastras clearly lay down that anybody who takes a sea voyage—even a person who remains in the sea for three consecutive days—becomes a patita.
('71', 223, 2, 7, 475580) It was for this reason that Professor (now Sir) Ramunny Menon was ostracized by the Cochin Government and prohibited from entering into Cochin temples.
('71', 223, 2, 8, 475732) A few years later when the Cochin Maharaja’s son returned from England after his education, the rule was abrogated and admission was given to all England returned men to temples.
('71', 223, 2, 9, 475911) The Cochin temples became polluted then, and the Travancore Government might have taken such steps against the Nedumpally Nambudiripad at that time which the Cochin Government have now taken.
('71', 223, 2, 10, 476103) If in fact we apply strictly the rules of the dharmashastras to the present day, the savarna Hindus will all have to be treated as patitas and they cannot enter the temples there.
('71', 223, 2, 11, 476283) But in these progressive days no reasonable Government will think of doing such an unreasonable thing.
('71', 223, 2, 12, 476386) I hope, therefore, that the Cochin Government will reconsider their order and withdraw the same.
('71', 223, 2, 13, 476483) The Dewan, Sir R. K. Shanmukham Chetty, is a cultured man of modern views and a supporter of the Justice Party.
('71', 223, 2, 14, 476595) I have no doubt that he will do what is proper and restore public confidence in his administration.
('71', 223, 3, 15, 476695) Harijan, 8 5 1937

('71', 224, 1, 2, 477278) 229. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('71', 224, 2, 3, 477304) SEGAON, WARDHA, MAY 8, 1937
('71', 224, 3, 4, 477332) MY DEAR REBEL, This is being written on paper prepared by Prabhu Dayal.
('71', 224, 3, 5, 477404) He has brought a fair lot of paper and has been showing it to me with great pride.
('71', 224, 3, 6, 477487) I thought therefore that I should let you see his handiwork.
('71', 224, 3, 7, 477548) This is not the best specimen but it was a convenient size for me to cut.
('71', 224, 3, 8, 477622) Well, normal men are just as good and as bad as normal women.
('71', 224, 3, 9, 477684) You have been known to have behaved just as badly as if not worse than Lionel.
('71', 224, 3, 10, 477763) And I see from your letter to Mira that you do not give me any news about your health thus leaving me to infer that you are keeping quite well.
('71', 224, 3, 11, 477907) But now I understand you are not keeping extra well.
('71', 224, 3, 12, 477960) Why should I not know all this?
('71', 224, 3, 13, 477992) And you have been taking medicines too!
('71', 224, 3, 14, 478032) You must let me know accurately what the matter is with you.
('71', 224, 3, 15, 478093) Balkrishna 1 is just as you left him.
('71', 224, 3, 16, 478131) I thought I had told you as much.
('71', 224, 3, 17, 478165) I am glad you are giving so much time to Sanskrit.
('71', 224, 3, 18, 478216) Your Hindi writing is a trifle too large but you are erring on the safe side; when the hand has settled you will soon begin to write the natural size.
('71', 224, 3, 19, 478367) I have not had a bill from Mehta.
('71', 224, 3, 20, 478401) He was given the full address.
('71', 224, 3, 21, 478432) But an evil fate hangs about your address which no one but I would write correctly.
('71', 224, 3, 22, 478516) I hope you had to pay nothing extra.
('71', 224, 3, 23, 478553) I hope it will be of use.
('71', 224, 3, 24, 478579) You should write to Dinsha Mehta to send you the bill for the kettle.

('71', 225, 8, 20, 479808) 232. DUTIES OF GANDHI SEVA SANGH
('71', 225, 9, 21, 479841) Kumri is a small village, about seventeen miles from Belgaum.
('71', 225, 9, 22, 479903) Shri Gangadharrao has built an ashram there.
('71', 225, 9, 23, 479948) The annual meeting of the Gandhi Seva Sangh was to have been held in Hudli but the rain god intervened and the members of the Sangh ran from the pandal and took shelter under the roof of the weaving school of the Kumri
('71', 225, 10, 24, 480167) 1 The source has “13th”, a slip,
('71', 226, 0, 1, 480200) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 227
('71', 226, 1, 2, 480243) Ashram.
('71', 226, 1, 3, 480251) After a great deal of discussion, some important resolutions were passed there, of which the following are the most noteworthy.
('71', 226, 1, 4, 480379) I give these 1 in the original Hindi language.
('71', 226, 1, 5, 480426) The Hindi is so simple that no reader will need a translation.
('71', 226, 1, 6, 480489) Despite this, if anyone fails to understand them, he should get them translated by someone who knows Hindi.
('71', 226, 1, 7, 480597) As regards the first [three] resoultions, it would be sufficient to say that the changes made have been introduced with a view to the expansion of constructive work.
('71', 226, 1, 8, 480763) These are not made as alternatives or additions to constructive work.
('71', 226, 1, 9, 480833) The object of the permission 2 is merely to assist it.
('71', 226, 1, 10, 480888) If this objective is not clearly understood, the fears of Shri Kishorelal may perhaps prove true.
('71', 226, 1, 11, 480986) The Sangh exists for the very purpose of keeping constructive work alive, for making it interesting and for spreading it from Kashmir to Cape Comorin and from Karachi to Dibrugarh.
('71', 226, 1, 12, 481167) This is because constructive work has been regarded as the mark of truth and non violence.
('71', 226, 1, 13, 481258) For its success contact has to be established with three crores of voters.
('71', 226, 1, 14, 481333) In order to make this contact effective, if some members of the Gandhi Seva Sangh have to enter Legislatures, it becomes a clear duty of the Sangh to make provision for it.
('71', 226, 1, 15, 481506) The fourth resolution is almost self evident.
('71', 226, 1, 16, 481552) No matter how many wells and ponds are added, they will prove useful.
('71', 226, 1, 17, 481622) They increase the country’s wealth and, moreover, wells, ponds and such otherwater reservouirs constructed by the Sangh, will of course be open to all Harijans.
('71', 226, 1, 18, 481783) Hence if these are built at appropriate sites, they will provide water to innumerable thirsty Harijans and the donors as well as the Sangh will earn the blessings of the beneficiaries.
('71', 226, 1, 19, 481968) Hence, those who wish to do so should send contributions, without a second thought, to the Sangh for the purpose of digging wells for Harijans.
('71', 226, 1, 20, 482112) The fifth resolution is an all embracing one.
('71', 226, 1, 21, 482158) The assumption behind it is that village welfare work begins with the service of Bhangis, i.e., with village sanitation.
('71', 226, 1, 22, 482279) How this can be done is explained in the resolution.
('71', 226, 1, 23, 482332) It is worth noting that the task of providing medicines and running schools has not been considered essential.
('71', 226, 1, 24, 482443) There is no mention in the resolution of spinning and such other crafts.
('71', 226, 1, 25, 482516) The implication is that these things will have to be done, but the
('71', 226, 2, 26, 482583) 1 Not translated here.
('71', 226, 2, 27, 482606) The resolution dealt with the constructive programme through charkha, wells for drinking water, use and propagation of Hindi, eradication of untouchability, and cow protection.
('71', 226, 2, 28, 482783) 2 For Sangh members to stand for election to the Legislative Assembly with the approval of the Working Committee; vide also “Speech at Gandhi Seva Sangh Meeting, Hudli III”,20 4 1937
('71', 227, 0, 1, 482966) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 227, 1, 2, 483008) stress is laid on what one has to start with.
('71', 227, 1, 3, 483054) This is because the aim of the resolution is to remove the fear entertained by some members of being boycotted while doing the work of sanitation.
('71', 227, 1, 4, 483201) In the sixth resolution the propagation of Hindi has been advocated and the methods indicated.
('71', 227, 1, 5, 483296) As long as leaders feel it infra dig to appear for an examination in Hindi, others will not be very enthusiastic about it.
('71', 227, 1, 6, 483419) So long as public institutions do not carry on their business in Hindi or so long as Hindi translations are not made available where the use of English is found indispensable, Hindi cannot be propagated on a large scale.
('71', 227, 1, 7, 483640) Here Hindi includes Hindustani.
('71', 227, 1, 8, 483672) There is no distinction between the two from the point of view of the Sangh.
('71', 227, 1, 9, 483749) The Sangh has through the seventh resolution demonstrated its zeal for national education, but the national Vidyapiths have been entrusted with the task, and that is as it should be.
('71', 227, 1, 10, 483932) By the eighth resolution, the meaning of the abolition of untouchability from the standpoint of the Sangh has been clarified.
('71', 227, 1, 11, 484058) The limits which have been accepted by the Harijan Sevak Sangh for crores of persons so far as the abolition of untouchability is concerned, are in no way sufficient for members of the Sangh who regard truth and non violence from my standpoint.
('71', 227, 1, 12, 484303) So long as there are restrictions as regards inter dining and intermarriage, untouchability is bound to survive to some extent.
('71', 227, 1, 13, 484431) It is necessary for members of the Sangh to give up these restrictions.
('71', 227, 1, 14, 484503) Anyone who sincerely serves Harijans cannot possibly observe such restrictions.
('71', 227, 1, 15, 484583) Although the ninth resolution is not related to the constructive work of the Congress, it is closely connected with the economic condition of India.
('71', 227, 1, 16, 484732) Crores of rupees are lost because of our indifference towards our cattle wealth.
('71', 227, 1, 17, 484813) The struggle between the cow and the buffalo on the one hand and between cattle and man on the other can continue only to the detriment of all the three.
('71', 227, 1, 18, 484967) This is because if cows are allowed to perish, buffaloes are bound to follow suit and drag human beings behind.
('71', 227, 1, 19, 485079) The latter will survive if cows do, but buffaloes have either to return to their original wild state or continue to survive in a very small number.
('71', 227, 1, 20, 485227) The Sangh has pointed out the easy, straight and consequently inexpensive way of escaping such an untimely death; and that is to insist upon using cow’s milk and nothing but cow’s milk and its products.
('71', 227, 1, 21, 485430) This objective will probably be achieved without much difficulty if an all out effort is

('71', 234, 4, 14, 496165) 244. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('71', 234, 5, 15, 496193) TITHAL (BULSAR), MAY 12, 1937
('71', 234, 6, 16, 496223) I am surprised at my remarks 1 being misunderstood.
('71', 234, 6, 17, 496275) I still maintain that whilst Lord Zetland's statement is agreeably worded, it does not remove the deadlock in the sense that it gives no specific answer to the specific Congress demand, namely, that the method in which the Governors will use their powers of interference whenever they fear an emergency would be that of dismissal of the Ministry rather than expecting the Ministry to resign or submit to the Governor's wishes.
('71', 234, 6, 18, 496702) I hold that this is perfectly consitutional and equally honourable for both parties.
('71', 234, 6, 19, 496787) The Governors will reason with their Ministers.
('71', 234, 6, 20, 496835) The Ministers would be bound courteously to listen to what they say.But if reason fails to carry conviction the only proper course for both parties would be for the Governors to dismiss such Ministers and dissolve the Assembly or take whatever measures may be open to them constitutionally.
('71', 234, 7, 21, 497126) The Hindu, 13 5 1937

('71', 235, 1, 2, 497568) 245. LETTER TO VIJAYA N. PATEL
('71', 235, 2, 3, 497599) TITHAL, BULSAR, MAY 12, 1937
('71', 235, 3, 4, 497628) VIJAYA, I met Naranbhai 1 .
('71', 235, 3, 5, 497656) Sardar also was present.
('71', 235, 3, 6, 497681) We had a long talk.
('71', 235, 3, 7, 497701) His love for you is boundless.
('71', 235, 3, 8, 497732) When I talked about Manubhai 2 he started crying.
('71', 235, 3, 9, 497782) He said: "If she wants to marry only with our consent, why does she bring up Manubhai's name every time?
('71', 235, 3, 10, 497887) We will never be pleased with that marriage.
('71', 235, 3, 11, 497932) She has taken a pledge to remain unmarried.
('71', 235, 3, 12, 497976) Let her keep it.
('71', 235, 3, 13, 497993) But if at all she wants to marry, then there are two or three good young men in our community; she may select one of them." This is the substance of what he said.
('71', 235, 3, 14, 498156) I pacified him.
('71', 235, 3, 15, 498172) I told him that you were not bent upon marrying him.
('71', 235, 3, 16, 498225) If you at all marry, I said, you would marry Manubhai, but that if your parents would not gladly give you their blessings you would be prepared to remain unmarried.
('71', 235, 3, 17, 498390) I also told him that you certainly wished that they should not press you to marry anybody else.
('71', 235, 3, 18, 498486) Sardar also spoke in favour of Manubhai.
('71', 235, 3, 19, 498527) He said that now in this age girls should be given some freedom; after having educated them we should not expect that they should always obey our wishes.
('71', 235, 3, 20, 498681) But all this had no effect on Naranbhai.

('71', 242, 1, 2, 509993) 254. LETTER TO G.D. BIRLA MAY 14, 1937 MY DEAR GHANSHYAMDASJI, I have your full letter of the 10th with the enclosure.

('71', 242, 1, 5, 510548) If the bare assurance 3 that Bapu has now reduced the Congress demand to is granted, there will be no questions of interpretation and no fear of breach of faith.
('71', 242, 1, 6, 510710) I am surprised that you do not see this.
('71', 242, 1, 7, 510751) You seem to have read more meaning in my sentence than I had meant.
('71', 242, 1, 8, 510819) 4 I meant to say that if the speech had been made two months ago it would have gone a long way in bringing about an understanding.
('71', 242, 1, 9, 510950) That is to say, from that statement to the assurance asked for by Bapu would have been a very easy step.
('71', 242, 1, 10, 511055) He has publicly recognized the conciliatory tone in which the speech was couched, but it leaves him enough loop hole to say that he meant nothing more than is laid down in the Government of India Act.
('71', 242, 1, 11, 511256) They must be prepared to face the fact that a new convention is being asked for by the party commanding the biggest majority in the country and it must be given.

('71', 243, 6, 16, 513216) 256. THE CONSTRUCTIVE PROGRAMME The Working Committee has emphasized the necessity of the members of the Legislatures and other workers taking the constructive programme of 1920 to the three crore villagers between whom and their representatives a direct contact has been established.
('71', 243, 6, 17, 513501) The representatives may if they choose neglect them, or give them some paltry or even substantial relief from financial burdens; but they cannot give them self confidence, dignity and the power of continuously bettering their own position unless they will interest them in the fourfold constructive programme i.e., universal production and use of khadi through universal hand spinning, Hindu Muslim or rather communal unity, promotion of total prohibition by propaganda among those who are addicted to the drink habit, and removal by Hindus of untouchability root and branch.
('71', 243, 6, 18, 514077) It was announced in 1920 and 1921 from a thousand platforms that attainment of swaraj by the non violent method was impossible without these four things.
('71', 243, 6, 19, 514231) I hold that it is not less true today.
('71', 243, 6, 20, 514270) It is one thing to improve the economic condition of the masses by State regulation of taxation, and wholly another for them to feel that they have bettered their condition by their own sole personal effort.
('71', 243, 6, 21, 514478) Now this they can only do through hand spinning and other village handicrafts.
('71', 243, 6, 22, 514557) Similarly it is one thing to regulate communal conduct by
('71', 243, 7, 23, 514615) 1 The original is damaged at several places.
('71', 244, 0, 1, 514660) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 245
('71', 244, 1, 2, 514703) means of pacts between leaders, voluntary or imposed by the State; it is wholly different for the masses to respect one another's religious and outward observances.
('71', 244, 1, 3, 514868) This cannot be done unless the legislators and workers would go out among the villagers and teach them mutual toleration.
('71', 244, 1, 4, 514990) Again it is one thing to impose, as we must, prohibition by law, and another to sustain it by willing obedience to it.
('71', 244, 1, 5, 515109) It is a defeatist, arm chair mentality which says that it cannot work without an expensive and elaborate system of espionage.
('71', 244, 1, 6, 515235) Surely if the workers went out to the villagers and demonstrated the evil of drink wherever it is prevalent, and if research scholars found out the causes of alcoholism and proper knowledge was imparted to the people, prohibition should not only prove inexpensive but profitable.
('71', 244, 1, 7, 515515) This is a work essentially for women to handle.
('71', 244, 1, 8, 515563) Lastly, we may banish by statute, as we must, the evil consequences of untouchability.
('71', 244, 1, 9, 515650) But we cannot have real independence unless people banish the touch me not spirit from their hearts.
('71', 244, 1, 10, 515751) The masses cannot act as one man or with one mind unless they eradicate untouchability from their hearts.
('71', 244, 1, 11, 515857) Thus this and the three other items are a matter of true mass education.
('71', 244, 1, 12, 515930) And it has become imperatively necessary now that three crores of men and women have rightly or wrongly power put into their hands.
('71', 244, 1, 13, 516062) However hedged in it is, Congressmen and others who want the suffrages of these voters have it in their hands either to educate the three crores of mankind along the right lines or the wrong.
('71', 244, 1, 14, 516254) It would be the wrong line to neglect them altogether in matters which most vitally concern them.
('71', 244, 1, 15, 516352) Harijan, 15 5 1937
('71', 244, 2, 16, 516371) 257. WHOSE IS THE BLAME?
('71', 244, 3, 17, 516396) With reference to my note 1 in Harijan of 17th April, 1937, about the alleged ill treatment of Christians by Hindus, I have received two letters.
('71', 244, 3, 18, 516542) One is from Shri C.K. Parameswaran Pillai, President of the Kerala Harijan Sevak Sangh, and the other from Dr. M.E. Naidoo of Nagercoil.
('71', 244, 3, 19, 516679) Shri Pillai writes:

('71', 245, 2, 13, 517980) 258. THE MARRIAGE IDEAL 2
('71', 245, 3, 14, 518006) A FRIEND WRITES: 3
('71', 245, 4, 15, 518025) In the current issue of Harijan Sevak in your article entitled “A Moral Dilemma” 4 you have observed, “Many marriage taboos appear to have grown out of social customs.
('71', 245, 4, 16, 518193) 5 They are nowhere seen to rest on any vital, moral or religious principle.” My own instinct based upon my experience tells me that probably these taboos were promulgated out of eugenic considerations.
('71', 245, 4, 17, 518395) It is a well known principle of the science of eugenics that the issue resulting from the crossing of exogamous elements is eugenically fitter than the product of endogamous unions.
('71', 245, 4, 18, 518577) That is the reason why in Hinduism sagotra ( ) and sapinda ( ) marriage are interdicted.
('71', 245, 4, 19, 518666) On the other hand if we admit social custom with all its kaleidoscopic variety and change to be sole reason for these taboos, we are left with no strong reason why marriages between paternal uncle and niece, or for the matter of that between brother and sister, should absolutely be tabooed.
('71', 245, 4, 20, 518958) If, as you say, the begetting of progeny be the only legitimate object of marriage then the choice of partners would become purely a question of eugenic harmony.
('71', 245, 4, 21, 519120) Are all other considerations to be ruled
('71', 245, 5, 22, 519161) 1 Not reproduced here 2 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 15 5 1937, of which this is a “slightly abridged” translation by Pyarelal.
('71', 245, 5, 23, 519314) 3 Only extracts from the letter written by Haribhau Upadhyaya are reproduced here.
('71', 245, 5, 24, 519397) 4 Vide “A Moral Dilemma”, 29 5 1937 5 In Pyarelal’s translation, however, this reads: “Marriage taboos are not universal and are largely based on social usage.”
('71', 246, 0, 1, 519558) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 247
('71', 246, 1, 2, 519601) out of court as relatively unimportant?
('71', 246, 1, 3, 519641) If not, what should be their order of precedence?
('71', 246, 1, 4, 519691) I would set it down as follows; 1. mutual attraction or love; 2. eugenic fitness; 3. approval and consent of the respective families concerned; and consideration for the interest of the social order to which one belongs; 4. spiritual development.
('71', 246, 1, 5, 519938) What do you say to it?
('71', 246, 2, 6, 519961) I entirely agree with you that a married person who confines the sex act strictly to the purpose of procreation should be regarded as a brahmachari.
('71', 246, 2, 7, 520110) I also hold with you that in the case of a married couple who have practised the rule of purity and self control before and after marriage a single act of union must lead to conception.
('71', 246, 2, 8, 520296) In support of your first point there is in our Shastras the celebrated story of Vishwamitra and Arundhati, the wife of Vasishtha who in spite of her one hundred sons was greeted by Vishwamitra as a perfect brahmacharini, whose command even the elements were bound to obey because her connubial relations with her husband were purely directed to the attainment and discharge of the function of motherhood.
('71', 246, 2, 9, 520701) But I doubt whether even the Hindu Shastras would support your ideal of having only one offspring irrespective of whether it is male or female.
('71', 246, 2, 10, 520845) It seems to me, therefore, that if you liberalize your ideal of married life so as to include the begetting of one male offspring in addition to the possible female ones, it would go a long way towards satisfying many married couples.
('71', 246, 2, 11, 521080) I do not know what the scientific basis for the various taboos in respect of marriage relationships is.
('71', 246, 2, 12, 521184) But it seems to me clear that a social custom or usage that helps the practice of virtue and self control should have the sanctity of a moral law.
('71', 246, 2, 13, 521331) If it is eugenic considerations that are at the root of interdiction of marriages between brother and sister, then they ought to apply equally to cousin marriages.
('71', 246, 2, 14, 521495) A safe rule of conduct, therefore, would be as a rule to respect such taboos where they exist in a marriage enumerated by my correspondent.
('71', 246, 2, 15, 521635) But I would change their order of importance and put 'love' last in the list.
('71', 246, 2, 16, 521713) By giving it the first place, the other conditions are liable to be overshadowed by it altogether and rendered more or less nugatory.
('71', 246, 2, 17, 521847) Therefore, spiritual development ought to be given the first place in the choice for marriage.
('71', 246, 2, 18, 521942) Service should come next, family considerations and the interest of the social order should have the third place, and mutual attraction or 'love' the fourth and the last place.
('71', 246, 2, 19, 522119) This means that 'love' alone, where the other four conditions are not fulfilled, should not be held as a valid reason for marriage.
('71', 246, 2, 20, 522251) At the same time, marriage where there is no love should equally be ruled out even though all the other conditions are fully complied with.
('71', 246, 2, 21, 522391) I should score out the condition of eugenic fitness, because the begetting of offspring being the central purpose of marriage, eugenic
('71', 247, 0, 1, 522526) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 247, 1, 2, 522568) fitness cannot be treated merely as a condition, it is the sine qua non of marriage.
('71', 247, 1, 3, 522653) Hindu Shastras certainly show a marked bias in favour of the male offspring.
('71', 247, 1, 4, 522730) But this orginated at a time when physical warfare was the order of the day and adequate man power was a sine qua non of success in the struggle for existence.
('71', 247, 1, 5, 522890) The number of sons that a man had was therefore then looked upon as a mark of virility and strength and to facilitate the begetting of numerous offspring even polygamy was sanctioned and encouraged.
('71', 247, 1, 6, 523089) But if we regard marriage as a sacrament, there is room in it only for one offspring, and that is why in our Shastras the first offspring, described as [dharmaja], i.e., 'duty born', all subsequent issues being referred to as [kamaja], i.e., lust born'.
('71', 247, 1, 7, 523343) I make no distinction between son and daughter.
('71', 247, 1, 8, 523391) Such distinction is in my opinion invidious and wrong.
('71', 247, 1, 9, 523446) The birth of a son or a daughter should be welcome alike.
('71', 247, 1, 10, 523504) The story of Vishwamitra and Vasishtha is good as an illustration of the principle that the sexual act performed solely for the purpose of begetting offspring is not inconsistent with the highest ideal of brahmacharya.
('71', 247, 1, 11, 523723) But the whole of that story need not be taken literally.
('71', 247, 1, 12, 523780) Sexual intercourse for the purpose of carnal satisfaction is reversion to animality, and it should therefore be man's endeavour to rise above it.
('71', 247, 1, 13, 523926) But failure to do so as between husband and wife cannot be regarded as a sin or a matter of obloquy.
('71', 247, 1, 14, 524027) Millions in this world eat for the satisfaction of their palate; similarly millions of the husbands and wives indulge in the sex act for their carnal satisfaction and will continue to do so and also pay the inexorable penalty in the shape of numberless ills with which nature visits all violations of its order.
('71', 247, 1, 15, 524339) The ideal of absolute brahmacharya or of married brahmacharya is for those who aspire to a spiritual or higher life; it is the sine qua non of such life.
('71', 247, 1, 16, 524493) Harijan, 5 6 1937

('71', 254, 6, 15, 534898) 270. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('71', 254, 7, 16, 534942) MAY 15, 1937 It is unfortunate that His Excellency has walked round instead of walking straight to the resolution of the Working Committee.
('71', 254, 7, 17, 535082) If he has only to repeat what he said to Mr. Kher, leader of the Congress Parliamentary Party of the Presidency, there is evidently no advance upon the old position and if the Belgaum speec 2 is a paraphrase of Lord Zetland’s recent speech 3 the situation is certianly no better and it is possibly worse.
('71', 254, 7, 18, 535387) The Hindu, 15 5 1937
('71', 254, 8, 19, 535408) 1 Addressee's mother 2 On May 14, in his speech at Belgaum, Lord Brabourne, Governor of Bombay, had said: “The special responsibilities placed on the Governor by Parliament deal with matters on which it was hoped that no conflict would arise between a Governor and his Ministers .
('71', 254, 8, 20, 535689) The taking of office means hard work and the assumption of responsibility, but without these no country can govern itself; an attitude of mere negation leads nowhere and avails nothing.
('71', 254, 8, 21, 535875) My Ministers, whatever their political outlook, can rely not only on this understanding and sympathy but also on my doing everything in my power to avoid a situation occuring in which conflict of opinion would arise between us in the sphere of responsibilities." 3 Of May 6, 1937; vide Appendix IV.
('71', 255, 0, 1, 536174) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 255, 1, 2, 536216) 271. THE REED V. THE FOUNTAIN PEN 1
('71', 255, 2, 3, 536252) I am tempted to share with the reader the following letter 2 received by Mahadev Desai:
('71', 255, 3, 4, 536340) Some time back in an article entitled “Wanted Rural mindedness”, you recommended, as a step in that direction, the adoption of the reedpen in the place of the fountain pen.
('71', 255, 3, 5, 536513) I was struck by your argument, and after reading Bapu's interpretation of the A. I. V. I. A. membership pledge 3 , I laid aside my fountain pen and took to the reed, nine months back.
('71', 255, 3, 6, 536697) I was not altogether unused to the reed pen.
('71', 255, 3, 7, 536742) .After a month of baffling experience, however, I was again forced to return to the fountain pen a sadder and a wiser man.
('71', 255, 3, 8, 536865) The reasons which compelled the change were as follows:
('71', 255, 4, 9, 536921) 1. It took three hours to copy out matter, using a reed pen, that could be done with the fountain pen in one hour and a half.
('71', 255, 5, 10, 537047) 2. It took at least from a quarter of an hour to three quarters of an hour to mend one reed pen by means of an indigenous village knife.
('71', 255, 6, 11, 537184) 3. The fountain pen enables you to make short jottings and entries, so indispensable in the course of village work, while standing, or while you are on the move.
('71', 255, 6, 12, 537346) When I reverted to the use of the reed pen, I invariably found that my diary writing and maintanance of other daily records and registers fell heavily into arrears.
('71', 255, 7, 13, 537511) Surely, it is no part of the policy of the A.I.V.I.A. to slave drive its workers to the very limit of their capacity .
('71', 255, 8, 14, 537630) At the same time it would be unconscionable to go on using the fountain pen in the teeth of the clear injunction of the A.I.V.I.A. .
('71', 255, 9, 15, 537763) As I write this another argument occurs to me.
('71', 255, 9, 16, 537810) Perhaps you will find it to be specious as the preceding ones.
('71', 255, 9, 17, 537873) Bapu welcomes the Singer machine as an aid to the tailer's needle; why should he not extend the same welcome to other domestic tools and appliances that are no less helpful to the individual householder .
('71', 255, 9, 18, 538078) .The A.I.V.I.A. does not oppose the use of the plough, the spinning wheel and the fly shuttle loom in the place respectively of the hoe, the takli and the old fashioned simple pit loom by the cultivator if he feels so inclined.
('71', 255, 9, 19, 538306) Why stop at that and interdict the use, further, of more advanced and efficient appliances of a like nature?
('71', 255, 9, 20, 538415) Is not your insistence on the use of the inefficient and fragile reed pen in the place of a metal nib of a piece with asking people in this age of iron and electricity to discard
('71', 255, 10, 21, 538594) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 16 5 1937. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('71', 255, 10, 22, 538699) 2 Only excepts from the letter written by Prabhudas Gandhi are reproduced here.
('71', 255, 10, 23, 538779) 3 Vide “London”, 23 7 1909 and “Letter to Lord’ Ampthill”, 5 8 1909
('71', 256, 0, 1, 538847) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 257
('71', 256, 1, 2, 538890) all iron instruments and revert to primitive stone ones instead?
('71', 256, 1, 3, 538955) You have applied yourself to the task of improving village tools.
('71', 256, 1, 4, 539021) I would like you to suggest the nature and extent of the improvements which you would like to see effected.
('71', 256, 1, 5, 539129) The above letter is written partly in jest, partly in earnest and partly as a dialectical exercise for its own sake in which the writer obviously luxuriates.
('71', 256, 1, 6, 539287) His whole argument boils down to this that modern appliances are capable of more speed then their earlier prototypes.
('71', 256, 1, 7, 539405) If the consideration of speed were ruled out, there would hardly be left anything from his argument for me to answer.
('71', 256, 1, 8, 539523) But the village movement, as I conceive it, does not discount speed or efficiency of production.
('71', 256, 1, 9, 539620) Our village folk need all the efficiency that we can give them and more.
('71', 256, 1, 10, 539693) The A.I.V.I.A. is doing its level best to increase the speed of production consistently with its ideal and self imposed limits.
('71', 256, 1, 11, 539821) Already the speed of the takli has been increased beyond the wildest expectations of its protagonists.
('71', 256, 1, 12, 539924) But this was achieved without the slightest sacrifice of the principle of ruralmindedness.
('71', 256, 1, 13, 540015) More, I claim that the marvellous ingenuity and skill which rendered this possible could only spring from a village brain.
('71', 256, 1, 14, 540138) The limiting principle that was kept in view in effecting improvement in the speed of the takli , the spinning wheel and other domestic tools should hold good in respect of the writing pen too.
('71', 256, 1, 15, 540332) The rush and hurry of the town have no place in the village.
('71', 256, 1, 16, 540393) The village dweller has not to work under high pressure or to speed about from place to place in motor cars and trams like the city dwellers.
('71', 256, 1, 17, 540535) All this work is done by the easier and more natural modes of locomotion.
('71', 256, 1, 18, 540609) Similarly the fountain pen can have no place in his economy.
('71', 256, 1, 19, 540670) I might, perhaps, reluctantly go so far as to admit the steel nib as a compromise, but that is all.
('71', 256, 1, 20, 540770) The steel nib in my opinion has spelt the death of the calligraphist's art the mending of a reed pen was itself an art.
('71', 256, 1, 21, 540890) It called into play the artistic skill and the personality of the scribe that was reflected in the characters which he traced.
('71', 256, 1, 22, 541017) All that has gone with the advent of the steel pen.
('71', 256, 1, 23, 541069) But the steel pen has not done even half the mischief that the fountain pen is doing.
('71', 256, 1, 24, 541155) The introduction of the fountain pen in the village, to me, marks the beginning of the end of the existence of the village as such and its slow metamorphosis into the city.
('71', 256, 1, 25, 541328) The analogy of the Singer machine v.
('71', 256, 1, 26, 541365) the tailor's needle adduced by the writer is misleading.
('71', 256, 1, 27, 541422) The Singer machine was intended to supplement the work of the needle.
('71', 256, 1, 28, 541492) It was never intended to be introduced into every hut and home.
('71', 256, 1, 29, 541556) The purpose which it was calculated to serve and which it has actually served is to increase the speed of the individual needle to such an extent as to make hand stitching a profitable whole time avocation for the needy, unemployed
('71', 257, 0, 1, 541788) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 257, 1, 2, 541830) of the cities.
('71', 257, 1, 3, 541845) The fountain pen has rendered an analogous service to the art of stenography, and as such it can certainly claim a place as a useful adjunct of city life.
('71', 257, 1, 4, 542000) The argument that I have used in connection with the fountain pen applies mutatis mutandis to the other points raised by the correspondent in question.
('71', 257, 1, 5, 542152) Clearly it is not possible to lay down hard and fast rules in all such cases.
('71', 257, 1, 6, 542230) Let everybody strive to cultivate and practise the principle of rural mindedness as best as he or she can.
('71', 257, 1, 7, 542337) Only let the worker from the city who goes out to work in the villages take care that he does not turn the heads and confuse the intelligence of the simple minded village folk, whom ostensibly he is anxious to serve but whose requirements and standards of values and utility are altogether different from that of the city dweller.
('71', 257, 1, 8, 542668) Harijan, 5 6 1937

('71', 259, 1, 2, 544978) creation of family spirit.
('71', 259, 1, 3, 545005) However, I am sorry that the inmates at Segaon do not regard the world as one family.
('71', 259, 1, 4, 545091) For a devoted servant of the people such a feeling is essential.
('71', 259, 1, 5, 545156) Those in whom it is born are seen bahaving with a family spirit wherever they go, although the other people might be utter strangers to them and all of them might have different spheres of activity.
('71', 259, 1, 6, 545355) Moreover, family spirit does not require mutual co operation.
('71', 259, 1, 7, 545417) Among members of the same family, some may be so straightforward by nature that they live in harmony with other members of the family who are curt.

('71', 259, 1, 9, 545636) But what can I do?

('71', 260, 1, 2, 547053) 277. LETTER TO AGATHA HARRISON
('71', 260, 2, 3, 547084) MAY 17, 1937
('71', 260, 3, 4, 547097) MY DEAR AGATHA, Your letter has just come.
('71', 260, 3, 5, 547140) And I hasten to answer.
('71', 260, 3, 6, 547164) Could I be more definite than when I said if Mr. Butler and Lord Zetland meant what the papers made out they did, why not straightway give the assurances in terms of the (Congress) resolution?
('71', 260, 3, 7, 547357) I have now gone a step further and said in so many words that when there is an emergency dismiss the Ministers.
('71', 260, 3, 8, 547469) The Bombay Governor's speech 1 , as I read it, is a denial of what Lord Zetland is supposed to have yielded in his recent speech 2 .
('71', 260, 3, 9, 547602) You must have seen the text.
('71', 260, 3, 10, 547631) And why is my remark on complete independence a knotty point?
('71', 260, 3, 11, 547693) Is it not in the Congress creed?
('71', 260, 3, 12, 547726) Is it not in the very resolution which was shown to the Governors and to which they raised no objection?
('71', 260, 3, 13, 547831) Perhaps you do not know the difficulties we have to combat here.
('71', 260, 3, 14, 547896) It is impossible to have mental reservations when you have millions of mankind to deal with, especially when you are training them not for an armed rebellion but for a peaceful revolution as yet unknown to history.
('71', 260, 3, 15, 548111) I want you therefore not to be agitated over what the diplomats say there or here.
('71', 260, 3, 16, 548194) Your and my first and last care is to hold on to the anchor at all costs but say nothing in anger, nothing equivocal, nothing short of the whole truth and then leave the result to the unseen and uncanny Power that over rules all our pet decisions at Its own sweet will.
('71', 260, 3, 17, 548464) No more, for the postal time is up.
('71', 260, 4, 18, 548500) From a photostat: G.N. 1499
