('71', 267, 2, 3, 559146) TITHAL, BULSAR, MAY 20, 1937
('71', 267, 3, 4, 559175) DEAR DR.
('71', 267, 3, 5, 559184) GODBOLE, I have now gone through your book carefully.
('71', 267, 3, 6, 559238) It is good so far as it goes.
('71', 267, 3, 7, 559268) Its price is prohibitive.
('71', 267, 3, 8, 559294) You have gone beyond the scope of the book which its title suggests but the chapters are scrappy.
('71', 267, 3, 9, 559392) Thus your examination of vegetarian and non vegetarian foods reproduces authorities quoted in vegetarian literature and contains nothing original.
('71', 267, 3, 10, 559539) I should expect an original contribution from an Indian scholar.
('71', 267, 3, 11, 559604) Then the chapter on breeding and feeding is very superficial.
('71', 267, 3, 12, 559666) Dairy experts tell me that breeding is the only thing.
('71', 267, 3, 13, 559721) Feeding is said to produce little impression on the milk yield.
('71', 267, 3, 14, 559785) I miss a chapter on comparison between buffalo and cow.
('71', 267, 3, 15, 559841) Can both be supported?
('71', 267, 3, 16, 559864) Which is the more economical animal?
('71', 267, 3, 17, 559901) As you may be aware, separated milk is being widely recommended by Dr. Aykroyd 1 .
('71', 267, 3, 18, 559984) But I do not find in your book enough instruction as to the ways in which it can be used.
('71', 267, 3, 19, 560074) I am myself making experiments within the limits of a villager and had hoped to find assistance in your book.
('71', 267, 3, 20, 560184) Nor have you examined the indigenous methods of using milk.
('71', 267, 3, 21, 560244) Your sincerely,

('71', 272, 6, 18, 567721) This is the only great lesson that is to be learnt from me.

('71', 273, 1, 2, 568350) 303. TRAVANCORE V. COCHIN
('71', 273, 2, 3, 568376) The reader will find elsewhere an authentic and exhaustive note 1
('71', 273, 3, 4, 568442) on the Koodalmanikkam controversy prepared by Shri G. Ramachandran, Secretary of the Kerala Harijan Sevak Sangh.
('71', 273, 3, 5, 568555) The note is authentic in the sense that it is based purely on official records.
('71', 273, 3, 6, 568635) Add to this note the following from the Kerala Harijan Sevak Sangh's office in Trivandrum:
('71', 273, 4, 7, 568726) In the issue of Harijan of 8th May in the article, "Cochin Travancore" 2 by Mahatmaji, in paragraph three, the following sentences are found: "The pundits of India should dispassionately examine the orders and express their unbiased opinion.
('71', 273, 4, 8, 568968) I am inclined to think that the Travancore Durbar may well invite the opinion of pundits on the single question of the religious propriety of the Cochin order and undertake to abide by their opinion.
('71', 273, 4, 9, 569168) In other words, Travancore may well offer to abide by the verdict of an arbitration tribunal consisting of unbiased pundits who will be universally accepted as such.
('71', 273, 4, 10, 569334) The opinion of an assembly of such pundits would be the nearest approach to an arbitration tribunal.
('71', 273, 4, 11, 569435) For, whilst the Travancore Durbar had a perfect right to open to Harijans the temples within their sole jurisdiction and ownership and without reference to the opinion of pundits, it would hardly be right to propound a new Smriti in respect of temples where there is joint jurisdiction." I am herewith forwarding a true copy of a judgment of the Chief Court of Cochin which discusses the Kaimal's position with regard to the Koodalmanikkam Temple.
('71', 273, 4, 12, 569883) This judgment shows the Kaimal to be the supreme spiritual authority in all matters connected with that Temple, and therefore the opinion of the pundits in this instance seems to be unnecessary.
('71', 273, 4, 13, 570078) These enable the reader to form his own judgment as to the propriety or otherwise of the action of the Cochin Durbar.
('71', 273, 4, 14, 570196) If the note and the Cochin Court judgment are to be trusted, evidently the Cochin Durbar's action was wholly wrong.
('71', 273, 4, 15, 570312) This is not to say that the Kaimal's action was right in the religious sense.
('71', 273, 4, 16, 570390) But if it was not, the only course open to the Cochin Durbar was to reason with the Kaimal, notKaimal, not to force his hands as was done.
('71', 273, 4, 17, 570529) The Kaimal evidently becomes the supreme and final authority on spiritual matters after his appointment by the Travancore Durbar.
('71', 273, 4, 18, 570659) Like the king he can do no wrong.
('71', 273, 4, 19, 570693) But even he may not long resist the opinion of his peers.
('71', 273, 4, 20, 570751) And the only way the Cochin Durbar or anyone else can influence the
('71', 273, 5, 21, 570819) 1 Vide Appendix “Koodalmanikkam Temple Controversy”, 22 5 1937. 2 Vide “Cochin Travancore”, 8 5 1937
('71', 274, 0, 1, 570920) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 275
('71', 274, 1, 2, 570963) Kaimal’s judgment is, I presume, by evoking the opinion of pundits learned in spiritual matters.
('71', 274, 1, 3, 571060) And legally speaking even their opinion has no binding effect on the Kaimal.
('71', 274, 1, 4, 571137) Harijan, 22 5 1937
('71', 274, 2, 5, 571156) 304. RELIGIOUS OATH AND NON RELIGIOUS
('71', 274, 3, 6, 571194) Shri Shivaprasad Gupta, the great philanthropist of Benares, writes:
('71', 274, 4, 7, 571263) After hearing the Harijan of May 1st read to me, I have been pondering over the note “Gandhi Seva Sangh and Legislatures”.
('71', 274, 4, 8, 571386) I reread it today, I also read the Weekly Letter, but I could not give rest to the surging thought rising in my mind.
('71', 274, 5, 9, 571504) The last paragraph 1 of the note reads: “It is not a religious oath, so far as I understand the Constitution, and it is wholly consistent with the demand for immediate and concrete independence." The following are the questions that arise in my mind:
('71', 274, 6, 10, 571755) 1. Are oaths of several and different kinds?
('71', 274, 6, 11, 571800) 2. Can an oath taken in the name of God, or in the alternative form where one has to affirm solemnly, be classed in two categories, “religious oath and non religious oath”?
('71', 274, 6, 12, 571973) 3. What is the governing idea behind a non religious oath?
('71', 274, 6, 13, 572032) 4. How can an oath of allegiance to the person of a king be consistent with “the demand for immediate and concrete independence”?
('71', 274, 6, 14, 572162) This demand, at least to me, means depriving the same sovereign of his sovereignty.
('71', 274, 7, 15, 572246) I would very much like your answer to these pertinent questions.
('71', 274, 7, 16, 572311) My answer to the first and the second questions is ‘Yes’.
('71', 274, 7, 17, 572369) The answer to the other two questions may be gathered from what follows.
('71', 274, 7, 18, 572442) An oath may be taken in the name of God and yet may not be styled religious.
('71', 274, 7, 19, 572519) An oath that a witness takes in a court of law is a legal not a religious oath, breach of which would carry legal consequences.
('71', 274, 7, 20, 572647) An oath taken by Members of Parliament may be called a constitutional not a religious oath, breach of which may involve mundane consequences.
('71', 274, 7, 21, 572789) Breach of a religious oath carries no legal consequences, but in the opinion of the taker does carry divine punishment.
('71', 274, 7, 22, 572909) This does not mean that any of the three varieties of oaths is less binding than the others on a conscientious man.
('71', 274, 7, 23, 573025) A conscientious witness will tell the truth, not for fear of the legal consequence, but he will do so in every case.
('71', 274, 7, 24, 573142) The legislator's oath has
('71', 274, 8, 25, 573168) 1 Vide “Sacrifice of Ras”, 18 4 1937
('71', 275, 0, 1, 573205) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 275, 1, 2, 573247) an interpretation in terms of the Constitution which prescribes the oath.
('71', 275, 1, 3, 573321) The interpretation may be given in the Constitution itself or may grow up by usage.
('71', 275, 1, 4, 573405) So far as I understand the British Constitution, the oath of allegiance simply means that the legislator will in pushing forward his policy or point conform to the Constitution.
('71', 275, 1, 5, 573583) I hold that it is open to the legislator consistently with his oath under the British Constitution to adopt measures in the Legislature for complete independence.
('71', 275, 1, 6, 573746) That to my mind is the saving grace of the British Constitution.
('71', 275, 1, 7, 573811) I fancy that the members of the Union Parliament of South Africa take substantially the same oath as the members in India, but it is open to that Parliament today to declare complete independence without any violation of the oath of allegiance.
('71', 275, 1, 8, 574056) It is because I have a profound conviction that the British Constitution in theory permits of the fulfilment of the highest ambition of an individual or the nation of which he is a member that I advised the Workiing Committee to accept my formula for office acceptance.
('71', 275, 1, 9, 574326) And it is in the same conviction that I am struggling to get the British Government to respond to it.
('71', 275, 1, 10, 574428) I am painfully conscious that they would prolong the agony to the breaking point.
('71', 275, 1, 11, 574510) But I know that if we have faith and grit we shall win at every point and reach our goal without shedding a drop of blood.
('71', 275, 1, 12, 574633) The British people apply the same laws to the game of politics that they apply to the game of football which I believe is their invention.
('71', 275, 1, 13, 574772) They give no quarter to the opponent and ask for none.
('71', 275, 1, 14, 574827) The fundamental difference in our case is that we have abjured the use of arms.
('71', 275, 1, 15, 574907) This has confounded them.
('71', 275, 1, 16, 574933) They do not believe our protestations.
('71', 275, 1, 17, 574972) They do not mind our agitation for complete independence so long as we keep it within the constitutional limit.
('71', 275, 1, 18, 575084) What else can the legislators do or are they to do inside their Assemblies?
('71', 275, 1, 19, 575160) They may not take there pistols in their pockets.
('71', 275, 1, 20, 575210) That would be a flagrant breach of the oath and also the law.
('71', 275, 1, 21, 575272) Shri Shivaprasad Gupta need not worry himself over the propriety of the oath by Congressmen.
('71', 275, 1, 22, 575365) If the agitation for complete independence was inconsistent with the oath, surely the British Government themselves would have raised that preliminary objection even to the candidature of Congressmen.
('71', 275, 1, 23, 575566) Harijan, 22 5 1937
('71', 276, 0, 1, 575585) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 277

('71', 278, 6, 13, 579811) 309. SPEECH AT TITHAL 1
('71', 278, 7, 14, 579835) MAY 22, 1937 If we want to impart education best suited to the needs of villagers, we should take the Vidyapith to the villages.
('71', 278, 7, 15, 579964) We should convert it into a training school in order that we might be able to give practical training to teachers in terms of the needs of villagers.
('71', 278, 7, 16, 580114) You cannot instruct the teachers in the needs of villagers through a training school in a city.
('71', 278, 7, 17, 580210) Nor can you so interest them in the condition of villages.
('71', 278, 7, 18, 580269) To interest city dwellers in villages and make them live in them is no easy task.
('71', 278, 7, 19, 580351) I am finding daily confirmation of this in Segaon.
('71', 278, 7, 20, 580402) I cannot give the assurance that our year's stay in Segaon has
('71', 278, 8, 21, 580465) 1 This is extracted from "Weekly Letter" By Mahadev Desai, who had reported: "The convener of the small conference of the teachers in Gujarat national schools which met at Tithal on the 22nd May had sent to the invitees a questionnaire which speaks for itself: 1. What is the education best suited to the needs of our villages and most beneficial to them?
('71', 278, 8, 22, 580821) 2. How to combat mass illiteracy and ignorance?
('71', 278, 8, 23, 580869) 3. Is literacy indispensable for intellectual growth?
('71', 278, 8, 24, 580923) Is the system of starting instruction with teaching the alphabet and reading and writing prejudicial to intellectual growth?
('71', 278, 8, 25, 581048) 4. The need of making vocational training the pivot of all instruction.
('71', 278, 8, 26, 581120) 5. The future of the present national schools.
('71', 278, 8, 27, 581167) 6. The possibility of imparting all education through the mother tongue of the children.
('71', 278, 8, 28, 581256) 7. In what essentials of national education are existing schools lacking?
('71', 278, 8, 29, 581330) 8. The necessity of making Hindi Hindustani compulsory in the early years of primary and secondary education.' On Gandhiji being invited to give his views on these points, he made observations giving individual examples.
('71', 278, 8, 30, 581551) I epitomize them below leaving out the latter, which while they were interesting to the few friends to whom he spoke are of little use to the general reader."
('71', 279, 0, 1, 581710) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 279, 1, 2, 581752) made of us villagers or that we have become one with them for common good.
('71', 279, 1, 3, 581827) Then as to primary education my confirmed opinion is that the commencement of training by teaching the alphabet and reading and writing hampers their intellectual growth.
('71', 279, 1, 4, 581998) I would not teach them the alphabet till they have had an elementary knowledge of history, geography, mental arithmetic and the art (say) of spinning.
('71', 279, 1, 5, 582149) Through these three I should develop their intelligence.
('71', 279, 1, 6, 582206) Question may be asked how intelligence can be developed through the takli or the spinning wheel.
('71', 279, 1, 7, 582303) It can be, to a marvellous degree, if it is not taught merely mechanically.
('71', 279, 1, 8, 582379) When you tell a child the reason for each process, when you explain the mechanism of the takli or the wheel, when you give him the history of cotton and its connection with civilization itself and take him to the village field where it is grown, and teach him to count the rounds he spins and the method of finding the evenness and strength of his yarn, you hold his interest and simultaneously train his hands, his eyes and his mind.
('71', 279, 1, 9, 582814) I should give six months to this preliminary training.
('71', 279, 1, 10, 582869) The child is probably now ready for learning how to read the alphabet, and when he is able to do so rapidly, he is ready to learn simple drawing, and when he has leant to draw geometrical figures and the figures of birds, etc., he will draw, not scrawl, the figures of the alphabet.
('71', 279, 1, 11, 583152) I can recall the days of my childhood when I was being taught the alphabet.
('71', 279, 1, 12, 583228) I know what a drag it was.
('71', 279, 1, 13, 583255) Nobody cared why my intellect was rusting.
('71', 279, 1, 14, 583298) I consider writing as a fine art.
('71', 279, 1, 15, 583332) We kill it by imposing the alphabet on little children and making it the beginning of learning.
('71', 279, 1, 16, 583428) Thus we do violence to the art of writing and stunt the growth of the child when we seek to teach him the alphabet before its time.
('71', 279, 1, 17, 583560) Indeed in my opinion what we have reason to deplore and be ashamed of is not so much illiteracy as ignorance.
('71', 279, 1, 18, 583670) Therefore adult education, too, should have an intensive programme of driving out ignorance through carefully selected teachers with an equally carefully selected syllabus according to which they would educate the adult villager's mind.
('71', 279, 1, 19, 583907) This is not to say that I would not give them a knowledge of the alphabet.
('71', 279, 1, 20, 583982) I value it too much to despise or even belittle its merit as a vehicle of education.
('71', 279, 1, 21, 584067) I appreciate Prof.
('71', 279, 1, 22, 584086) Laubach's immense labours in the way of making the alphabet easy and Prof.
('71', 279, 1, 23, 584161) Bhagwat's great and practical contribution in the same direction.
('71', 279, 1, 24, 584227) Indeed I have invited the latter to come to Segaon whenever he chooses and try his art on the men, women and even children of Segaon.
('71', 279, 1, 25, 584361) As to the necessity and value of regarding the teaching of village handicrafts as the pivot and centre of education I have no
('71', 280, 0, 1, 584487) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1935 281
('71', 280, 1, 2, 584530) manner of doubt.
('71', 280, 1, 3, 584547) The method adopted in the institutions in India, I do not call education, i.e., drawing out the best in man, but a debauchery of the mind.
('71', 280, 1, 4, 584686) It informs the mind anyhow, whereas the method of training the mind through village handicrafts from the very beginning as the central fact would promote the real, disciplined development of the mind resulting in conservation of the intellectual energy and indirectly also the spiritual.
('71', 280, 1, 5, 584974) Here, too, I must not be understood to belittle fine arts.
('71', 280, 1, 6, 585033) But I would not misplace them.
('71', 280, 1, 7, 585064) Matter misplaced has been rightly described as dirt.
('71', 280, 1, 8, 585117) In proof of what I am saying, I can only cite the tons of worthless and even indecent literature that is pouring in upon us with the result which he who runs may see.
('71', 280, 1, 9, 585284) Harijan, 5 4 1937
('71', 280, 2, 10, 585302) 310. REGISTER OF CUSTOMERS
('71', 280, 3, 11, 585329) Shri Jerajani writes to say: 1
('71', 280, 4, 12, 585360) This suggestion is worth considering, and if a register of customers is maintained at each centre, it is likely to prove useful.
('71', 280, 4, 13, 585489) The only doubt may be regarding its feasibility.
('71', 280, 4, 14, 585538) I would regard it as practical if a complete list could be compiled speedily and at little additional cost.
('71', 280, 4, 15, 585646) A list of workmen poses no difficulties.
('71', 280, 4, 16, 585687) And, ordinarily it may be said that those workmen who are once registered continue to work for good.
('71', 280, 4, 17, 585788) But customers keep changing every day.
('71', 280, 4, 18, 585827) It cannot be said with certainty that the individual who purchases khadi worth one anna today is bound to come back for more.
('71', 280, 4, 19, 585953) However, if the list is to be complete, even such a customer's name must be recorded.
('71', 280, 4, 20, 586039) What is its utility?
('71', 280, 4, 21, 586060) If a list is to be compiled, should it consist only of customers of a certain kind?
('71', 280, 4, 22, 586144) In order that such a list should prove useful, it should be maintained in alphabetical order.
('71', 280, 4, 23, 586238) If this is attempted, it will necessarily entail some expenses.
('71', 280, 4, 24, 586302) Should a list then be made of those who give a certain yearly subscription?
('71', 280, 4, 25, 586378) If this be the case, what benefit do they get out of it?
('71', 280, 4, 26, 586435) As I have no experience in this matter, I can only frame such questions.
('71', 280, 4, 27, 586508) Shri Jerajani's suggestion has been published here in order to invite discussion.
('71', 280, 4, 28, 586590) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 23 5 1937
('71', 280, 5, 29, 586631) 1 The correspondent, whose letter is not translated here, had said that a register of customers with their full names and addresses would prove useful.
('71', 281, 0, 1, 586783) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 281, 1, 2, 586825) 311. VERY OLD QUESTIONS
('71', 281, 2, 3, 586849) I have received a letter.
('71', 281, 2, 4, 586875) Its substance is as follows: Our country does not manufacture any dyes.
('71', 281, 2, 5, 586947) But the khadi sold in our country comes in many coloured prints.
('71', 281, 2, 6, 587012) Obviously the dyes used could only be foreign.
('71', 281, 2, 7, 587059) I cannot understand how we can tolerate it.
('71', 281, 2, 8, 587103) India can certainly manufacture its own dyes.
('71', 281, 2, 9, 587149) Why then foreign chemical dyes on a sacred thing like khadi?
('71', 281, 2, 10, 587210) For patriotic reasons khadi is of course best for wearing for Indians but why shouldn't it be as fine as muslin?
('71', 281, 2, 11, 587323) There was a time when India used to produce muslin for the entire world.
('71', 281, 2, 12, 587396) All these three questions were discussed at length when Navajivan was first started.
('71', 281, 2, 13, 587481) Ordinarily such questions are not raised these days.
('71', 281, 2, 14, 587534) As the correspondent desires that replies should be given only through the columns of the Harijanbandhu, I give these here.
('71', 281, 2, 15, 587658) Ever since I accepted khadi as the focal point of swadeshi in the year 1918, I have been repeatedly saying that we should keep the pledge of swadeshi not because we hate what is foreign but because the welfare of the country is rooted in swadeshi.
('71', 281, 2, 16, 587906) Hence we should certianly accept those foreign products which we cannot produce immediately, which are needed by the country and the introduction of which would not harm the country in any way.
('71', 281, 2, 17, 588100) Everyone can think of examples of such foreign goods.
('71', 281, 2, 18, 588154) Regarding the propagation of khadi, the question of using [foreign] dyes arose at the very outset.
('71', 281, 2, 19, 588253) The Spinners' Association did not exist at that time.
('71', 281, 2, 20, 588307) I had given the opinion that wherever indigenous dyes were not available, there should be no bar to using foreign ones.
('71', 281, 2, 21, 588427) But the utmost effort should be made for producing the best possible indigenous dyes.
('71', 281, 2, 22, 588513) The same policy continues even now.
('71', 281, 2, 23, 588549) Experiments with indigenous dyes are being made and they are being used whenever it is convenient to do so.
('71', 281, 2, 24, 588657) The needs of those who would not use foreign dyes are met by white khadi.
('71', 281, 2, 25, 588731) The propaganda for khadi is not for its own sake, nor is it unthinking.
('71', 281, 2, 26, 588803) The following is the trend of thought behind the khadi shastra.
('71', 281, 2, 27, 588867) If Indians use nothing but khadi, crores of women spinners, carders, washermen, dyers and such other persons could get a livelihood; and crores of rupees will remain in the country and go into the pockets of half starved and wholly or partially unemployed
('71', 282, 0, 1, 589123) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 283
('71', 282, 1, 2, 589166) villagers.
('71', 282, 1, 3, 589177) The Spinners’ Association by investing a negligible amount of capital has to date put almost three and a half crores of rupees into the pockets of such artisans.
('71', 282, 1, 4, 589339) Had these earnings gone to a hundred or two or even ten or twenty thousand persons in cities, it would have been announced by the beating of drums.
('71', 282, 1, 5, 589487) But no one is surprised because this amount has found its way without any fanfare, into the homes of hundreds of thousands of starving villagers.
('71', 282, 1, 6, 589633) But I regard it as a minor miracle.
('71', 282, 1, 7, 589669) No one is deprived of his livelihood by the use of foreign dyes, no new industry is prevented from coming up because of this and khadi has been given an impetus.
('71', 282, 1, 8, 589831) I do believe that chemical dyes can be made in India but that is a distinct and independent industry.
('71', 282, 1, 9, 589933) However, it is the dharma of the wealthy to take up that venture.
('71', 282, 1, 10, 589999) Such risks are beyond the scope of a khadi worker.
('71', 282, 1, 11, 590050) Even today mill like khadi is produced in sufficient quantity to meet the demand.
('71', 282, 1, 12, 590132) Even the patolas 1 of Patan are available today if anyone wished to wear them.
('71', 282, 1, 13, 590211) But there are few such generous persons who would pay the price.
('71', 282, 1, 14, 590276) If anyone expects that the same quality of khadi should be available at a price comparable to mill made mull, I would tell him that it is impossible, and it should be impossible, to have hand made mull without the use of force against the workmen.
('71', 282, 1, 15, 590524) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 23 5 1937

('71', 292, 2, 3, 604905) [After May 26, 1937] 1
('71', 292, 3, 4, 604928) Revered Bapuji’s instructions are that if the thread snaps while spinning it should be joined rather than thrown away.
('71', 292, 3, 5, 605047) It will lessen the wastage.
('71', 292, 3, 6, 605075) The best thing would be to spin in such a way that there would be no occasion for joining.
('71', 292, 3, 7, 605166) Usually the thread snaps only because of its unevenness.
('71', 292, 3, 8, 605223) There will not be any wastage if as soon as the thread becomes thinner than usual, the sliver is broken off and put along with the thin thread and spun again.
('71', 292, 3, 9, 605382) Professional spinners follow this method.

('71', 297, 6, 17, 614372) 340. LATHI’S EXAMPLE
('71', 297, 7, 18, 614393) The reader will find a fair notice in Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter” of the opening to Harijans of its important temple by the ruler of Lathi State.
('71', 297, 7, 19, 614543) The event is of great value to Kathiawar.
('71', 297, 7, 20, 614585) And Thakoresaheb Prahladsinghiji deserves the congratulations of all lovers of Hinduism and humanity.
('71', 297, 7, 21, 614687) Published reports show that there was not a murmur against the act and that the savarna Hindus partook in the proceedings without any reserve.
('71', 297, 7, 22, 614830) I draw from this the same inference I drew from the Travancore Proclamation.
('71', 297, 7, 23, 614907) For the people religious proclamations of a ruler have the sanction of Smritis.
('71', 297, 7, 24, 614987) I am unable on any other basis to account for the unanimous welcome extended to the generous action of the Thakoresaheb of Lathi.
('71', 297, 7, 25, 615117) I have bitter experiences of the obstinacy of the savarnas of Lathi.
('71', 297, 7, 26, 615186) They would not come to the Harijan quarters.
('71', 297, 7, 27, 615231) There was difficulty in getting medical attendance for a Harijan woman who was dying of
('71', 297, 8, 28, 615319) 1 The name has been omitted.
('71', 297, 8, 29, 615348) 2 Daughter of Vrajlal Gandhi
('71', 298, 0, 1, 615377) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 299
('71', 298, 1, 2, 615420) pneumonia.
('71', 298, 1, 3, 615431) There were distinctions observed at the State dispensary.
('71', 298, 1, 4, 615489) It must be said in passing that these disabilities were not peculiar to Lathi, they were common to all parts of Kathiawar and outside it in Gujarat.
('71', 298, 1, 5, 615638) Indeed in some vital matters untouchability is worse in Gujarat than elsewhere and worst in Kathiawar.
('71', 298, 1, 6, 615741) Nor do I imagine that with the opening of the temple in Lathi all the disabilities have disappeared in practice.
('71', 298, 1, 7, 615854) Nevertheless in the ready co operation of the savarna Hindus in the worthy action of the Thakoresaheb of Lathi, as in Travancore, one finds a quick solution of the untouchability problem.
('71', 298, 1, 8, 616042) For if my reasoning is sound, the other Indian chiefs have but to copy the examples of Travancore and Lathi and untouchability will lose its sharp edge, even though it may not die out altogether inthe States of India.
('71', 298, 1, 9, 616260) And if it does on that large scale, British India cannot but be affected by the phenomenon.
('71', 298, 1, 10, 616352) One fails to see, why the princes move so slowly in this matter which is one of life and death to a large portion of Hindu humanity.
('71', 298, 1, 11, 616485) Would that the princes recognized their obvious duty of purging Hinduism of the virus of untouchability and took timely action.
('71', 298, 1, 12, 616613) The Thakoresaheb of Lathi is reported to have said in his address that as soon as he gets suitable priests and teachers he would like to open more temples and cover them with schools for all classes of children.
('71', 298, 1, 13, 616825) I would suggest to him the same remedy I put before the authorities in Travancore.
('71', 298, 1, 14, 616908) A small training schoold should be opened in Lathi for giving practical training in conducting services and schools in temples.
('71', 298, 1, 15, 617036) There is no reason why both the offices should not be combined in one person.
('71', 298, 1, 16, 617114) A school master has as much need to be pure in heart as a priest and vice versa.
('71', 298, 1, 17, 617195) Nor need a priest be ignorant of the art of teaching.
('71', 298, 1, 18, 617249) At the present moment the most deplorable thing is that the temple priests are as a rule ignorant men often devoid of character.
('71', 298, 1, 19, 617378) The training course need not be long–not beyond six months.
('71', 298, 1, 20, 617438) If the salaray offered is attractive, the school should draw well read youths of character beyond reproach.
('71', 298, 1, 21, 617546) My suggestion no doubt implies that the reform of Lathi has its root in spirituality.
('71', 298, 1, 22, 617632) Harijan, 29 5 1937

('71', 299, 3, 4, 617748) MY DEAR IDIOT, I have already told you I leave here 10th June, reach Segaon 12th June, not to leave it (D.V.) till the meeting of the Haripura Congress.
('71', 299, 3, 5, 617901) So I expect you in July and thereafter you will take your seconds, minutes or hours whatever you can get and have advice, guidance, and orders at your wish!
('71', 299, 3, 6, 618058) Yes, Kumarappa does feel that his interpretation was right and mine wholly wrong and misleading and when he told me that Bahadurji had agreed with him, I told him I must have his opinion in writing.
('71', 299, 3, 7, 618257) He said he would get it.
('71', 299, 3, 8, 618282) I do not know what happened after.
('71', 299, 3, 9, 618317) I still maintain that he has no legal sense.
('71', 299, 3, 10, 618362) But what does that matter?
('71', 299, 3, 11, 618389) He has good sense, he is a faithful worker.
('71', 299, 3, 12, 618433) I would therefore be pleased if he proves to be right in his interpretation.
('71', 299, 3, 13, 618510) I shall then have to blow out my legal brain which people thought I had.
('71', 299, 3, 14, 618583) Your pin head is an eternal pin prick for me.
('71', 299, 3, 15, 618629) You must not neglect it.
('71', 299, 3, 16, 618654) You must worry Shummy’s life out of him and get it right, your preocupations notwithstanding.
('71', 299, 3, 17, 618748) Your dal is also a pin head.
('71', 299, 3, 18, 618777) I speak not from prejudice but experience.
('71', 299, 3, 19, 618820) You cannont judge results from what ordinarily healthy men can eat seemingly without harm.
('71', 299, 3, 20, 618911) I tell you a tea spoonful of dal has been known to upset delicate stomachs and yours is extra delicate.

('71', 299, 3, 28, 619368) Although he has become a big architect and his firm has four branches employing 35 architects, he remains in his personal life just as simple as when I left him in 1914. I hope you have the lace from Bombay.

('71', 300, 1, 2, 619763) 342. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('71', 300, 2, 3, 619795) May 29, 1937
('71', 300, 3, 4, 619808) PREMA, I shall not probably be able to reply to the whole of your letter.

('71', 304, 5, 19, 627707) 350. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('71', 304, 6, 20, 627746) TITHAL, June 1, 1937 I am very anxious that Congressmen should take office— but only if Government show their willingness to conciliate the Congress.
('71', 304, 6, 21, 627896) If, as has been said, Lord Zetland has conceded all but the question of dismissal, the Congress asks Government to come a little way to meet it.
('71', 304, 6, 22, 628041) The conciliatory moves so far have come from the
('71', 304, 7, 23, 628090) 1 Vijaya Gandhi, addressee’s daughter in law
('71', 305, 0, 1, 628135) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 305, 1, 2, 628177) Congress.
('71', 305, 1, 3, 628187) It would have been easy at Allahabad to close the door by putting a narrow interpretation on the Delhi resolution.
('71', 305, 1, 4, 628302) Instead it was kept open.
('71', 305, 1, 5, 628328) The only obstacle, so far as can at present be seen, is the Congress demand that in the event of serious disagreement between a Governor and his Congress Ministers, the Governor should dismiss them.
('71', 305, 1, 6, 628527) I personally would be satisfied, however, if the Governor gave an undertaking that in such a case he would demand his Ministers’ resignation.
('71', 305, 2, 7, 628669) Mr. Gandhi refused to agree that it was a small matter for the Congress, because his idea was to make the Governor think fifty times before he took the responsibility of dismissing his Ministers.
('71', 305, 2, 8, 628865) In other words, Mr. Gandhi wished to “take advantage of the ordinary human virtue—it may be weakness—of not wishing to look a fool”.
('71', 305, 2, 9, 628998) Congress critics had said that this demand was merely a trifle.
('71', 305, 2, 10, 629062) [Mr. Gandhi asked:] If it is so, why not give the Congress the trifle?
('71', 305, 3, 11, 629133) In any case, Mr. Gandhi affirmed, the object of the Congress demand was to test the sincerity of British Government.
('71', 305, 3, 12, 629250) Did they want the Congress in office, or did they not?
('71', 305, 3, 13, 629305) In South Africa, Britain meticulously conciliated the Boer.
('71', 305, 3, 14, 629365) In India, however, such a gesture was lacking.
('71', 305, 3, 15, 629412) Indeed all the moves towards solving the impasse had come from the Congress.
('71', 305, 3, 16, 629489) Now the Congress did not demand any legal change.
('71', 305, 3, 17, 629539) But it was being talked at instead of being talked to.
('71', 305, 3, 18, 629594) It would appear that British statesmen and the provincial Governors were addressing the world and not the Congress.
('71', 305, 3, 19, 629710) In fact, they might be accused of attempting as ever to discredit and isolate the Congress.
('71', 305, 4, 20, 629802) If Congressmen took office, they would be doing so with a full sense of their responsibility.
('71', 305, 4, 21, 629896) Therefore, unless the Government recognized its policy of wrecking the Act and achieving independence by constitutional means as perfectly legitimate, they would not welcome the rule of the Congress majority.
('71', 305, 4, 22, 630105) Mr. Gandhi did not see any constitutional obstacle or impropriety in the Viceroy taking steps in an attempt to end the deadlock.
('71', 305, 4, 23, 630234) It was known that the Viceroy had conferred with provincial Governors before they summoned the Congress leaders.
('71', 305, 4, 24, 630347) Surely, then, there was no obstacle to his asking the Congress President to meet him.
('71', 305, 4, 25, 630433) [Mr. Gandhi said:] I do not say that this is necessary.
('71', 305, 4, 26, 630489) It is enough if the Congress demand in accordance with the Allahabad resolution 1 is complied with.
('71', 305, 5, 27, 630589) If Government would not make a gesture, the deadlock must continue.
('71', 305, 5, 28, 630657) The result might in the end be the application of Section 93, that is, the suspension of the
('71', 305, 6, 29, 630750) 1 Vide footnote 1, “Interview to Associated Press of India”, 6 5 1937
('71', 306, 0, 1, 630820) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 307
('71', 306, 1, 2, 630863) democratic portion of of the new Constitution.
('71', 306, 1, 3, 630910) Mr. Gandhi was prepared for that and its possible consequences.
('71', 306, 1, 4, 630974) He preferred open oppression under a state of autocracy to veiled oppression of, and interference with, Congress Ministers.
('71', 306, 1, 5, 631098) Though he was ready to face it, oppression was the last thing he desired.
('71', 306, 1, 6, 631172) It would increase the existing bitterness and hatred between Britain and India.
('71', 306, 1, 7, 631252) He himself would die in an effort to prevent the tragedy, but there must come a time when his effort would be fruitless.
('71', 306, 1, 8, 631373) Mr. Gandhi concluded: Nobody has yet said that the present Congress condition for accepting office is unconstitutional.
('71', 306, 1, 9, 631493) The Congress had gone as far as it could, consistent with self esteem and with its avowed object.
('71', 306, 1, 10, 631591) The next move must come from the Government, if they really want the Congress to take office.
('71', 306, 1, 11, 631685) The Times of india, 2 6 1937

('71', 309, 1, 2, 635563) 356. LETTER TO MUNNALAL G. SHAH
('71', 309, 2, 3, 635595) TITHAL, [June] 1 2, 1937
('71', 309, 3, 4, 635620) MUNNALAL, Indu has given me your letters.
('71', 309, 3, 5, 635662) After reading them, I wonder whether to laugh, weep or be angry and I was inclined to do these things in that order and I finally decided not to do any of them.
('71', 309, 3, 6, 635823) I could not follow what Indu told me orally, nor have I been able to judge whose fault it must have been.
('71', 309, 3, 7, 635929) I hope to reach there on the 11th instead of the 12th.
('71', 309, 3, 8, 635984) I shall listen to the story when I come there.
('71', 309, 3, 9, 636031) Or perhaps by that time the cloud might have cleared.
('71', 309, 3, 10, 636085) Therefore I wish to say nothing about the discord.
('71', 309, 3, 11, 636136) Do what you can to settle it among yourselves.
('71', 309, 3, 12, 636183) You have written to me saying that I have thrust on you the burden of winning over Lilavati, Balvantsinha and others.
('71', 309, 3, 13, 636301) If I had put on you the burden of village service for which you and others are in Segaon, you would have been able to carry it.
('71', 309, 3, 14, 636429) But this very distinction that you have made is not proper.
('71', 309, 3, 15, 636489) We have resolved that village service is not different from overcoming anger, etc.The equation would be: To win over Lilavati and others is to overcoming anger and that is equal to serving the villages.
('71', 309, 3, 16, 636692) But so long as you regard them as two separate things, they will remain so from your point of view.
('71', 309, 3, 17, 636792) I have, however, solved this problem, too.
('71', 309, 3, 18, 636835) As I have already told you and Balvantsinha, you can have separate arrangements for your meals, etc.
('71', 309, 3, 19, 636936) You will have to deal only with me.
('71', 309, 3, 20, 636972) You should spend all your time in the service chosen by you.
('71', 309, 3, 21, 637033) After careful thinking, you rejected the suggestion.

('71', 312, 11, 24, 641899) June 3, 1937
('71', 312, 12, 25, 641912) MUNNALAL, Today I am trying to answer several letters of yours.
('71', 312, 12, 26, 641976) Try to analyse and understand the reasons why you worry about Kanchan.
('71', 312, 12, 27, 642047) She is now well settled and studies as much as she can.
('71', 312, 12, 28, 642103) She couldn’t be in a better place than where she is at present.
('71', 312, 12, 29, 642167) What then is the point
('71', 312, 13, 30, 642190) 1 1890 1975; educationist, author and social worker; member of Servants of India Society from 1927 to 1958
('71', 313, 0, 1, 642297) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 313, 1, 2, 642339) in worrying about her?
('71', 313, 1, 3, 642362) Is it that you wish to live with her?
('71', 313, 1, 4, 642400) If that is so, there is no real cause for your worry.
('71', 313, 1, 5, 642454) It is simply a question of your desire.
('71', 313, 1, 6, 642494) If you are trying to curb that desire, we should consider whether you ought to do so.
('71', 313, 1, 7, 642580) The villagers live on jowar and besan 1. You will never be able to copy them in that.
('71', 313, 1, 8, 642666) One should know one’s limitations.
('71', 313, 1, 9, 642701) Hence, the reasoning behind your decision to resume solid food is wrong.
('71', 313, 1, 10, 642774) Whether from the economic or the moral point of view, which is economical in the long run for you—to eat solid food and fall ill or live on milk which is costlier and work regularly?
('71', 313, 1, 11, 642957) There is only one golden key in being able to live a true life.
('71', 313, 1, 12, 643021) One should plunge into whatever work of service comes to one unsought, surrendering everything to Shri Krishna, and being wholly engrossed in the work.
('71', 313, 1, 13, 643173) Even the thoughts in one’s mind should be about how to complete the task and not whether the work is proper or not.
('71', 313, 1, 14, 643289) That we have employed a Bhangi and are building a road is certainly a form of service.
('71', 313, 1, 15, 643376) We are in a position to make people spend money in this way.
('71', 313, 1, 16, 643437) If we don’t use our advantage we would prove ourselves fools.
('71', 313, 1, 17, 643499) And, besides, the money is given by the zamindar.
('71', 313, 1, 18, 643549) That we thus make him take interest in the village, though it be indirectly, is no small thing.
('71', 313, 1, 19, 643645) We need not postpone the cleaning of a village and wait for the village people themselves to start doing something.
('71', 313, 1, 20, 643761) If we can melt the heart of the zamindar in every village, our task would be made very much easier.
('71', 313, 1, 21, 643861) However, we have to keep in view all the limbs of society and the limits of each would be the limits of our strength.
('71', 313, 1, 22, 643979) My wish to live alone in Segaon did not mean that it was not possible to enlarge the field of service so long as other people lived there.
('71', 313, 1, 23, 644118) I only wanted to see what one man could do, to see for my own sake whether I could carry on the work by myself.
('71', 313, 1, 24, 644230) The plan could not be carried out and others joined me.
('71', 313, 1, 25, 644286) I must then use their services and they should give them.
('71', 313, 1, 26, 644344) The relations with Jamnalalji should not be allowed to become an obstacle.
('71', 313, 1, 27, 644419) If they make us soft and comfort loving, we would fall off like dried leaves, and that deservedly.
('71', 313, 1, 28, 644518) If we think of nothing but service every hour of the day and strive to remain pure, people will understand us even though a multi millionaire may be living with us.
('71', 313, 2, 29, 644683) 1 Gram flour
('71', 314, 0, 1, 644696) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 315
('71', 314, 1, 2, 644739) I see from your letters that you spend most of your time in dreaming, and that prevents your work from shining out.
('71', 314, 1, 3, 644855) Your motive is pure, but you start running before you have learnt to walk and even while running you dream of flying.
('71', 314, 1, 4, 644973) The result is that you not only do not run or fly but cannot even walk.
('71', 314, 1, 5, 645045) During your illness you could somehow carry on your work, but can you be satisfied with that?

('71', 318, 7, 11, 651348) 371. COCHIN UNTOUCHABILITY A Cochin correspondent writes:
('71', 318, 8, 12, 651406) I have just gone through your article 2 “Cochin Travancore” in the Harijan, dated May 8, 1937. I find that you have, perhaps unwittingly, done a
('71', 318, 9, 13, 651551) distinct disservice to the cause of truth.
('71', 318, 10, 14, 651594) The controversy about the Koodalmanikkam Temple can in no sense be
('71', 318, 11, 15, 651661) regarded as a war between light and darkness; at any rate, there is not the
('71', 318, 12, 16, 651737) slightest intention among the people of Cochin to hug darkness as a virtue in
('71', 318, 13, 17, 651815) itself, worth putting up a fight for.
('71', 318, 14, 18, 651853) You seem to be labouring under a misapprehension when you say that “even the most orthodox Hinduism would hardly permit him (the Cochin Maharaja) to regulate the private conduct of the visitors to the Cochin temples.
('71', 318, 14, 19, 652070) In no temple in India where Harijans are not permitted to worship are trustees authorized to scrutinize the actions of savarna Hindus who are
('71', 318, 15, 20, 652212) entitled, as a matter of right, to visit the temples.” So far as the Cochin Government are concerned, they have not sought to regulate the “private conduct” of visitors to Cochin temples.
('71', 318, 15, 21, 652400) They have also not sought to exercise any scrutiny into the actions of savarna Hindus who are entitled, as a matter
('71', 318, 16, 22, 652516) of right, to visit the temples.
('71', 318, 17, 23, 652548) What they have done is simply to declare as polluted, so far as Cochin temples are concerned, the tantris who have performed religious worship in
('71', 318, 18, 24, 652694) the temples of Travancore thrown open to avarnas.
('71', 318, 18, 25, 652744) There is no sort of ban
('71', 318, 19, 26, 652768) 1 In Nepal 2 Vide “Cochin Travancore”, 8 5 1937
('71', 319, 0, 1, 652816) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 319, 1, 2, 652858) imposed on entry into Cochin temples of savarna Hindus who have
('71', 319, 2, 3, 652922) worshipped in Travancore temples.
('71', 319, 3, 4, 652956) Even this ban on tantris was imposed by Cochin not because of any spite or malice against a sister State, but solely at the instance of the vaideekans and vadhyars who, from time immemorial, have been recognized and acknowledged as spiritual directors in such matters.
('71', 319, 4, 5, 653225) You observe that “in Cochin the Maharaja has interfered in respect of a temple over which he has no exclusive control.
('71', 319, 4, 6, 653344) The Maharaja of Travancore, too, possesses substantial rights over the temple in question.
('71', 319, 4, 7, 653435) The Cochin order is clearly an interference with that right.” History, tradition, usage, custom—all these point to the fact that, while the right of the Maharaja of Travancore in respect of the Koodalmanikkam Temple begins and ends with the nomination of a Thachudaya Kaimal, the Maharaja of Cochin has always exercised, as President of the Yogakkars, enormous powers with regard to its affairs, both spiritual and secular.
('71', 319, 4, 8, 653859) The very fact that the present Kaimal, when the recent troubles arose, solicited advice and guidance from the Maharaja of Cochin shows conclusively enough that the “substantial rights” alleged to be possessed by Travancore do not include, at any rate, the right to have a voice in the adjudication of spiritual affairs relating to the temple.
('71', 319, 5, 9, 654202) It may interest you, in this connection, to know that in a recent speech at Thiruvalla, Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar, the Dewan of Travancore, admitted that the Travancore Government had no complaint whatever to make in regard to what has happened in the Koodalmanikkam Temple.
('71', 319, 5, 10, 654477) Is this not a proof that Travancore itself does not find any fault with the attitude of Cochin?
('71', 319, 6, 11, 654573) Your suggestion that the opinion of pundits might be invited on the issues involved is certainly one that ought to commend itself to all.
('71', 319, 6, 12, 654711) But how do you justify, I wonder, your appeal in the same breath to the people of Cochin to hold protest meetings against the order of the Maharaja and lead an agitation for throwing open all temples to Harijans?
('71', 319, 6, 13, 654924) Why not wait till the pundits give their opinion at least?
('71', 319, 6, 14, 654983) “Whilst the Travancore Durbar had a perfect right to open to Harijans the temples within their sole jurisdiction and ownership and without reference to the opinion of pundits, it would hardly be right to propound a new Smritiin respect of temples where there is joint jurisdiction.
('71', 319, 6, 15, 655265) The Harijan cause must be always and everywhere above suspicion.” This is a perfectly sensible position to take up, and we in Cochin would certainly be glad if no attempt is made in Travancore “to propound a new Smriti in respect of temples where there is joint jurisdiction”.
('71', 319, 6, 16, 655542) I gladly publish this letter.
('71', 319, 6, 17, 655572) The order reffered to of the Mahar aja of Cochin reads as follows: The Maharaja of Cochin is of opinion that proper purificatory ceremonies should be performed in the Koodalmanikkam Temple without any
('71', 320, 0, 1, 655773) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 321
('71', 320, 1, 2, 655816) His Highness considers that the temples has been polluted by entry into and participating in ceremonies by persons who have officiated in other temples where the entry of avarnas has been allowed.
('71', 320, 1, 3, 656013) The Maharaja of Cochin has now definitely ordered that any person who has taken part in the conduct of ceremonies in temples which have been polluted by the entry of avarnas thereby becomes polluted and loses the right to enter temples in Cochin until proper prayashchittams are performed.
('71', 320, 1, 4, 656303) Such persons are prohibited from entering temples, touching tanks and wells until they perform the required purificatory ceremonies.
('71', 320, 1, 5, 656436) My note was based upon a summary of the order above quoted.
('71', 320, 1, 6, 656496) There is no mention in it of tantris.
('71', 320, 1, 7, 656534) And are not tantris savarna Hindus?
('71', 320, 1, 8, 656570) My contention was and is that savarna Hindus because they visit or officiate in temples visited by Harijans do not become Harijans.
('71', 320, 1, 9, 656702) But I did err in thinking that the order applied to all savarna Hindus who had visited Travancore temples, whereas it is restricted to those who officiated at Travancore temples.
('71', 320, 1, 10, 656881) Whilst, therefore, I gladly admit the error as to quantity, my argument remains unaffected.
('71', 320, 1, 11, 656973) The Maharaja has surely extended the doctrine of untouchability by regarding savarnas as untouchables because they did not believe in untouchability.
('71', 320, 1, 12, 657123) But the authentic and exhaustive note 1 since published in Harijan disposes of most of the contentions of my correspondent.
('71', 320, 1, 13, 657247) For, according to that note neither the Maharaja of Cochin nor of Travancore has any jurisdiction over the administration of the Koodalmanikkam Temple.
('71', 320, 1, 14, 657399) When, therefore, Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar said that Travancore had no complaint, he merely stated the legal position.
('71', 320, 1, 15, 657518) The only party who has the right and whose duty it is to complain is the Thachudaya Kaimal.
('71', 320, 1, 16, 657610) And one may hope that he will not rest content till he has secured complete freedom from interference with his exclusive right to regulate the admission of worshippers and officiating tantris.
('71', 320, 1, 17, 657803) The correspondent has surely confused the issue by suggesting that my advice to the Hindus of Cochin to agitate for the throwing open of temples to Harijans is inconsistent with my proposal to refer to pundits the question of the legality of declaring, as the Cochin Maharaja’s order does, savarna Hindus as untouchables.
('71', 320, 1, 18, 658125) And now that it is known that the Maharaja had no right to issue the order he did, the proposed reference becomes unnecessary except as an academic proposition.
('71', 320, 1, 19, 658286) Harijan, 5 6 1937
('71', 320, 2, 20, 658304) 1 Vide Appendix “Koodalnanikkam Temple Controversy”, 22 5 1937.

('71', 321, 1, 2, 658410) 372. SHAMEFUL IF TRUE
('71', 321, 2, 3, 658432) Thakkar Bapa sends me the following statement which he received during his recent tour in the Nizam’s Dominions:
('71', 321, 3, 4, 658545) About six months ago an event which took place at Karepally, Warangal District, Nizam’s Dominions, describes the methods adopted by the Christian missionaries to make conversions of Hindus and especially Harijans.
('71', 321, 3, 5, 658759) Some days previous to the appointed date, the village teachers sent out news of the coming event into all the surrounding villages and made sure that the people of all castes of Hindus and especially Harijans were present on the occasion in large numbers.
('71', 321, 3, 6, 659015) Then the pastor arrived at the place bringing with him a girl, about 12 years old, who he said would cure all that were presented to her of all sorts of diseases and also show them the real path of realization of God.
('71', 321, 4, 7, 659233) The pastor then stood and said addressing those present: “You believe in
('71', 321, 5, 8, 659306) gods who are dead and gone.
('71', 321, 5, 9, 659334) Your Rama was born, behaved and acted like an
('71', 321, 6, 10, 659380) ordinary mortal and then died.
('71', 321, 6, 11, 659411) So was the case with Krishna also, who had
('71', 321, 7, 12, 659454) many more vices to his credit.
('71', 321, 7, 13, 659485) Here is before you a person who is the very
('71', 321, 8, 14, 659529) incarnation of Christ.
('71', 321, 8, 15, 659552) Christ is in her now, which fact you can verify yourself
('71', 321, 9, 16, 659609) by being cured of your diseases at the mere touch of her hands.
('71', 321, 9, 17, 659673) Why believe in
('71', 321, 10, 18, 659688) gods who are past and no more effective?
('71', 321, 10, 19, 659729) You should all believe in and follow
('71', 321, 11, 20, 659766) the path of Jesus Christ who was born to Virgin Mary, preached the Gospel
('71', 321, 12, 21, 659840) which leads to salvation, died outwardly but rose again on the third day to
('71', 321, 13, 22, 659916) redeem the sinning millions of the world.”
('71', 321, 14, 23, 659959) A subscription of one anna per head and two annas for a metal cross were
('71', 321, 15, 24, 660032) charged.
('71', 321, 15, 25, 660041) They were told that unless they wore the cross at all times and
('71', 321, 16, 26, 660105) believed in the truth and efficacy of Christianity, there would not be any good
('71', 321, 17, 27, 660185) effect in the case of diseased patients.
('71', 321, 18, 28, 660226) This happened on two occasions.
('71', 321, 18, 29, 660258) On the third occasion, the Secretary of
('71', 321, 19, 30, 660298) the District Committee and friends visited them and told them that theycould
('71', 321, 20, 31, 660375) preach their religion as they wanted to, but they should not wound the feelings
('71', 321, 21, 32, 660455) of the people by repeating unpleasant things which were not true.
('71', 321, 21, 33, 660521) The local
('71', 321, 22, 34, 660531) police then stopped the proceedings fearing there might be breach of peace in
('71', 321, 23, 35, 660609) the place.
('71', 321, 23, 36, 660620) If it is true, it stands self condemned.
('71', 321, 23, 37, 660661) I would like the Mission concerned to investigate the complaint and throw light on it.

('71', 322, 1, 2, 660809) 373. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI
('71', 322, 2, 3, 660851) TITHAL, BULSAR, June 3[5] 1 1937
('71', 322, 3, 4, 660884) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, I have liked your letter.
('71', 322, 3, 5, 660931) It is indeed true that my statements contain several implications.
('71', 322, 3, 6, 660998) Therefore, the meaning that you have read is possible.
('71', 322, 3, 7, 661053) But the statement also implies the other meaning that you have suggested.
('71', 322, 3, 8, 661127) Truth need not be made bitter.
('71', 322, 3, 9, 661158) Nor need it be embellished.
('71', 322, 3, 10, 661186) If one person wounds another with a sword and a witness describes the incident, such description by itself is not bitter, though the consequences of the testimony may be bitter for the assailant.
('71', 322, 3, 11, 661382) But that doesn’t make truth itself bitter.
('71', 322, 3, 12, 661425) If, however, the description of the assault was full of exaggerations, we might say that truth had been made bitter.
('71', 322, 3, 13, 661542) After saying this, I may add that if I had to make a choice, I would certainly prefer bitter truth to untruth agreeably.
('71', 322, 3, 14, 661663) If, in trying to change bitter into agreeable language, you are likely to kill truth, you had better stick to bitter language.
('71', 322, 3, 15, 661790) You have always been unlucky in the matter of helpers.
('71', 322, 3, 16, 661845) You have never had a really good man.
('71', 322, 3, 17, 661883) But you have got a good helper in Sushila.
('71', 322, 3, 18, 661926) I wonder how you could have managed to pull on if you didn’t have her.
('71', 322, 3, 19, 661997) Even from the point of view of self interest, therefore, Sushila must improve her health with good food, exercise and water treatment.
('71', 322, 3, 20, 662132) Mr. Kallenbach has at last arrived.
('71', 322, 3, 21, 662168) He is fine.
('71', 322, 3, 22, 662180) For the present he is here.
('71', 322, 3, 23, 662208) Tithal may be described as a small village about six or seven furlongs from the sea coast.
('71', 322, 3, 24, 662299) We are staying in that village.
('71', 322, 3, 25, 662331) We are leaving on the 10th and shall reach Segaon on the 11th.
('71', 322, 3, 26, 662394) I have just got a letter from Harilal.
('71', 322, 3, 27, 662433) I am enclosing it as a sample.
('71', 322, 3, 28, 662464) I have gone through the Phoenix Trust.
('71', 322, 3, 29, 662503) There is no need to make any changes in it.
('71', 322, 3, 30, 662547) But if you have any suggestion to make, it can perhaps be carried out.
('71', 322, 3, 31, 662618) So it is you who should draft something and send it to me, instead of my drafting anything.

('71', 325, 3, 21, 667273) 378. MY MISTAKE
('71', 325, 4, 22, 667289) In the issue of Harijanbandhu dated 16th May, I have said in an article entitled “A Moral Dilemma” 2, that amongst South Indian Brahmins the marriage of a maternal uncle to his niece is permissible, and so, too amongst Parsis and Muslims.
('71', 325, 4, 23, 667528) Professor Balvantrai Thakore 3 has, in an interesting letter, corrected this error of mine.
('71', 325, 4, 24, 667620) He points out that amongst the Brahmins of the South the children of a brother and sister are permitted to marry, but not a girl and her maternal uncle.
('71', 325, 4, 25, 667773) Poet Chaman informs us that such an alliance is prohibited amongst Muslims.
('71', 325, 4, 26, 667849) I am grateful to both these gentlemen for the correction.
('71', 325, 4, 27, 667907) I was actually aware of such an alliance between the
('71', 325, 5, 28, 667960) 1 Feminine of Kanabi, name of a community of peasant farmers 2 Vide “A Moral Dilemma”, 29 5 1937
('71', 325, 6, 29, 668057) 3 Balvantrai Kalyanrai Thakore, Gujarati Poet and man of letters
('71', 326, 0, 1, 668122) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 327
('71', 326, 1, 2, 668165) children of a brother and sister.
('71', 326, 1, 3, 668199) And I regard it as unpardonable on my part to have come to the conclusion and to have made a categorical statement that an alliance would be permissible between a girl and her maternal uncle.
('71', 326, 1, 4, 668391) I should have realized that in these matters presumptions such as mine have no place.
('71', 326, 1, 5, 668477) If I presumed, I should have indicated the uncertainly.
('71', 326, 1, 6, 668533) However, I categorically asserted something for which I had no actual evidence as if I had it.
('71', 326, 1, 7, 668628) And, as a result, my fidelity to truth has been blemished.
('71', 326, 1, 8, 668687) For this lapse I must beg forgiveness from readers.
('71', 326, 1, 9, 668739) They will be generous and forgive me, but my conscience will not forgive me so easily.
('71', 326, 1, 10, 668826) From this mistake I learnt the lesson that one has to exercise great care before coming to certain conclusions.
('71', 326, 1, 11, 668938) I shall henceforth try to be more careful to avoid such mistakes.
('71', 326, 2, 12, 669004) [From Gujarati] Harijanbandhu, 6 6 1937

('71', 333, 8, 9, 680484) 391. SPEECH ON COW PROTECTION, TITHAL 2
('71', 333, 9, 10, 680524) [Before June 10, 1937] 3
('71', 333, 10, 11, 680549) The pity is that most of our cow protection associations will keep cows and buffaloes both and try to run them and make them paying concerns by selling buffalo’s milk.
('71', 333, 10, 12, 680717) The cow, they think, is uneconomic, not knowing that if the cow was exclusively taken care of, and all attention concentrated on increasing her yield of milk, in making her a good breeder, and on making use of every bit of her carcass after she is dead, she would be more than an economic proposition.
('71', 333, 10, 13, 681019) If someone could convince me that both the cow and the buffalo could be protected, without our having to feed on them or slaughtering them, I should be only too willing to include both in my scheme.
('71', 333, 10, 14, 681218) The fact, however, is that the buffalo, apart from her milk, is an uneconomic animal.
('71', 333, 10, 15, 681304) Except in a few wet regions of India the buffalo is useless for agricultural purposes, and so we either starve or kill the male progeny.
('71', 333, 10, 16, 681441) Some of the best known dairies priding themselves on the wonderful milk yield of their cows have been found to be doing away with the male calves.
('71', 333, 10, 17, 681588) We have to make them good milkers and good mothers of fine plough bullocks.
('71', 333, 10, 18, 681664) It is no use saying that there is no demand for cow’s milk.
('71', 333, 10, 19, 681724) If we refused to supply any other milk, and if we ensured a supply of the richest and purest and safest milk, everyone would enlist himself as our regular customer.
('71', 333, 11, 20, 681889) 1 Vide “Letter to Brijkrishna Chandiwala”, 2 6 1937
('71', 333, 12, 21, 681941) 2 This is extracted from Mahadev Desai’s “Weekly Letter”.
('71', 333, 12, 22, 681999) 3 Gandhiji left Tithal for Wardha on June 10; vide the two preceding items, also “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 7 6 1937
('71', 334, 0, 1, 682113) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 335
('71', 334, 1, 2, 682156) But the first thing is to eliminate the buffalo.
('71', 334, 1, 3, 682205) It is like the exclusive emphasis on khadi.
('71', 334, 1, 4, 682249) You cannot promote khadi by dividing your attention between khadi and mill cloth.
('71', 334, 1, 5, 682331) But we have not given the necessary attention to her feed and her upkeep.
('71', 334, 1, 6, 682405) Show the best results and I tell you you will not have to complain of lack of patronage.
('71', 334, 1, 7, 682494) Why is there such a mad run on a certain company’s shares?
('71', 334, 1, 8, 682553) Because people know that it is going to be a highly paying concern.
('71', 334, 1, 9, 682621) If you could make people believe that yours also would be a payingconcern, they would rush to offer their patronage to you.
('71', 334, 1, 10, 682745) Concentrate on one.
('71', 334, 1, 11, 682765) Take a city like Bombay, take a census of the children, enlist the names of people who will buy only cow’s milk for their children, and make your dairy an exclusive cow’s milk supplier for children.
('71', 334, 1, 12, 682964) Don’t you know how they popularize an article like tea?
('71', 334, 1, 13, 683020) They distribute free packets of tea, they run free tea houses.
('71', 334, 1, 14, 683083) You can do likewise and popularize cow’s milk.
('71', 334, 1, 15, 683130) Your ambition should be to cater to the needs of the whole of Bombay.
('71', 334, 1, 16, 683200) There is a demand for cow’s milk in a city like Calcutta.
('71', 334, 1, 17, 683258) The best Haryana breed are imported to Calcutta, but as soon as the cows go dry they go to the butcher.
('71', 334, 1, 18, 683362) The result is that the Haryana cow is getting scarce in the Punjab.
('71', 334, 1, 19, 683430) No, the cow need not go to the butcher at all.
('71', 334, 1, 20, 683477) She will have more than paid for her upkeep for her dry years by her rich yield of milk and progeny, and after death, she would fetch the same value as she did when alive.
('71', 334, 1, 21, 683649) The cow can either be protected by the State or by those who are really religiously inclined.
('71', 334, 1, 22, 683743) The State we may leave aside for the moment, it is the religiously inclined who should rise to the occasion and bring to bear knowledge and industry to the task.
('71', 334, 1, 23, 683905) Humanitarianism without knowledge is futile and may even be harmful.
('71', 334, 1, 24, 683974) Harijan, 19 6 1937

('71', 337, 6, 16, 687534) NOT A POLITICAL ORGANIZATION
('71', 337, 7, 17, 687563) As lovers of Hindi know the next session of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan is to take place in Simla.
('71', 337, 7, 18, 687661) A correspondent who is working in Simla writes to say that there is a suspicion that the Sammelan is a political organization with anti Muslim tendencies.
('71', 337, 7, 19, 687816) Having been twice its President, I can unhesitatingly say that it is a purely non political organization.
('71', 337, 7, 20, 687922) It has Rajas and Maharajas as its patrons.
('71', 337, 7, 21, 687965) It has numerous non Congressmen who are identified with it.
('71', 337, 7, 22, 688025) Rajas and Maharajas often attend the sessions.
('71', 337, 7, 23, 688072) His Highness the Maharaja of Baroda has been one of its Presidents.
('71', 337, 7, 24, 688140) So far as I know it has no anti Muslim tendencies.
('71', 337, 7, 25, 688191) I could not have presided if I had suspected any.
('71', 337, 7, 26, 688241) I hope by anti Muslim is not meant anti Urdu.
('71', 337, 7, 27, 688287) Many use anti Urdu and anti Muslim as synonymous terms.
('71', 337, 7, 28, 688343) But that is a superstition.
('71', 337, 7, 29, 688371) Urdu is the common language of many Hindus and Mussalmans in the Punjab, Delhi and Kashmir.
('71', 337, 7, 30, 688463) It is also significant that at the session of the Sammelan held in Indore in 1935 it defined Hindi to mean that
('71', 337, 8, 31, 688575) 1 The original is damaged and the date is illegible.
('71', 337, 8, 32, 688628) Gandhiji arrived in Segaon on June 11. 2 Vide “Letter to S. Ambujammal”, 7 6 1937
('71', 338, 0, 1, 688710) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 339
('71', 338, 1, 2, 688753) language which Hindus and Muslims of the North spoke and wrote either in Devanagari or Persian script.
('71', 338, 1, 3, 688856) I hope, therefore, that even if anti Muslim has been used in the sense of anti Urdu, the suspicion to which my correspondent refers will be dispelled and that the work of preparations for the session of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan to be held in Simla will proceed without any suspicion about its object or attitude.
('71', 338, 2, 4, 689171) THE SOCIAL BAIT A friend who has had occasion to study the work of the Salvation Army sends me the following interesting note:
('71', 338, 3, 5, 689298) The Salvation Army is essentially a religious body with ‘aggressive evangelism’ as its main characteristic.
('71', 338, 3, 6, 689406) The social work the Army does ‘has from the first been regarded by the Army leaders as an organized warfare against social evils in order to clear the way for evangelization.’ This is from the Encyclopaedia Britannica (14th edition).
('71', 338, 3, 7, 689640) It further says that ‘It was realized that the physical and the environmental condition of many of the people, especially in great cities, made it extremely difficult for them to apprehend the spiritual message which the Army had to deliver.
('71', 338, 3, 8, 689882) Therefore various social activities arose, diverse in character but all actuated by the same purpose’, and General Booth himself in one of his letters to his son has said that ‘the social works is the bait, but it is salvation that is the hook that lands the fish.’
('71', 338, 4, 9, 690148) The object and the work of this Mission according to its Founder is ‘to seek the conversion of the neglected crowds of people who are living without God and without hope, and to gather those so converted into Christian Fellowship.’ It is also stated in the Salvation Army Year Book for 1937 that ‘upon Salvationists everywhere was urged the importance of personal evangelism—that each one was responsible before God for the salvation of others.
('71', 338, 4, 10, 690593) Personal touch, personal conversation, personal effort, it was pointed out, was of paramount importance nay, was the duty of every wearer of our uniform.’ Thus ‘Every Soldier a Soul winner’ became and remains an inspiring slogan.
('71', 338, 4, 11, 690823) Of course what is true of the Army is more or less true of all Christian Missions.
('71', 338, 4, 12, 690906) Their social work is undertaken not for its own sake but as an aid to the salvation of those who receive social service.
('71', 338, 4, 13, 691027) The history of India would have been written differently if the Christians had come to India to live their lives in our midst and permeate ours with their aroma if there was any.
('71', 338, 4, 14, 691206) There would then have been mutual goodwill and utter absence of suspicion.
('71', 338, 4, 15, 691281) But say some of them, “If what you say had held good with Jesus there wouldhave been no Christians.” To answer this would land me in a controversy in which I have no desire to engage.
('71', 338, 4, 16, 691465) But I may be
('71', 339, 0, 1, 691478) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 339, 1, 2, 691520) permitted to say that Jesus preached not a new religion but a new life.
('71', 339, 1, 3, 691592) He called men to repentance.
('71', 339, 1, 4, 691621) It was he who said, “Not everyone that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven.” 1
('71', 339, 2, 5, 691790) Harijan, 12 6 1937
('71', 339, 3, 6, 691809) 398. HARIJANS
('71', 339, 4, 7, 691823) But as for Harijans themselves, I certainly do not agree that they are stupid, or unintelligent, or lacking in religious sense.
('71', 339, 4, 8, 691951) They are not even unsophisticated.
('71', 339, 4, 9, 691986) If we tried to use the high pressure methods of which you accuse us, I assure you, we would get no results among them.
('71', 339, 4, 10, 692105) To me they are just nice people very much like myself and my brothers and sisters and friends.
('71', 339, 4, 11, 692200) To be sure, they are oppressed and illiterate, even unkempt, but they are thoughtful, spiritual minded, generous, kindly; in character they seem to me above, rather than below, the average of mankind.
('71', 339, 4, 12, 692401) I like them better than savarnas—but that is my bad taste, perhaps.
('71', 339, 5, 13, 692469) Still, I cannot figure out how you can live among them and hold such a superficial attitude towards them.
('71', 339, 5, 14, 692575) The only explanation that comes to my mind is that you either do not know them or you are insincere.
('71', 339, 5, 15, 692676) The latter is unworthy of attention.
('71', 339, 5, 16, 692713) But the former might be true—for we sometimes know least those who live in the same house with us.
('71', 339, 5, 17, 692812) Harijans do have strong self protective complex that is hard to get past.
('71', 339, 5, 18, 692886) A reserve past which they will not readily let an outsider come.
('71', 339, 5, 19, 692951) They may be in awe of your ‘Mahatmaship’ (as we all are, a little) or it may be because they think you are a reincarnation of Rama (as they do think).
('71', 339, 5, 20, 693102) Maybe you begin by trying to ‘uplift’ them—it seems to be against human nature to appreciate being ‘uplifted’.
('71', 339, 5, 21, 693213) Maybe you still unconsciously have a little ‘high caste’ attitude–savarna Christians have that
('71', 339, 6, 22, 693308) trouble sometimes.
('71', 339, 6, 23, 693327) It may be your city outlook.
('71', 339, 6, 24, 693356) Whatever it is, you are not seeing them as I see them.
('71', 339, 7, 25, 693411) I admit I have certain advantages.
('71', 339, 7, 26, 693446) I myself am a villager, so can enter into their life of farming, gardening, raising chickens, pigs, goats, cows.
('71', 339, 7, 27, 693559) As a nurse I could help them in sickness and teach them how to have better health.
('71', 339, 7, 28, 693642) I was an ‘untouchable’ to savarna Hindus, as they were, and was glad to be
('71', 339, 8, 29, 693717) allowed to get water out of a decent cattle trough rather than the tanks the pigs and buffaloes wallowed in, when I toured in the villages.
('71', 339, 8, 30, 693857) So I wasn’t an outsider to their life—not even a ‘visitor’.
('71', 339, 8, 31, 693917) I was, as they said, a ‘relative’, one of themselves.
('71', 339, 8, 32, 693971) It naturally followed that we would love and respect each other
('71', 339, 9, 33, 694035) 1 St. Matthew, VII.
('71', 340, 0, 1, 694055) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 341
('71', 340, 1, 2, 694098) and that we would trust each other spiritually.
('71', 340, 1, 3, 694146) Our spiritual communion was always on terms of equality.
('71', 340, 1, 4, 694203) I received as much from them as I gave—maybe more.
('71', 340, 1, 5, 694254) At least I can testify that some of the deepest spiritual thinking, the most exquisite spiritual attainment, that I have ever known, I have seen in the souls of Depressed Class Hindus—and I don’t mean exceptional, educated ones, I mean illiterate villagers.
('71', 340, 1, 6, 694512) But would I have seen it if I had been haggling them to become Christians?
('71', 340, 1, 7, 694587) I assure you I would not!
('71', 340, 2, 8, 694613) Occasionally for information I asked one who was thorougly familiar with Christian doctrine, what he thought of it, pro and con, and he answered me as readily and frankly as if I had asked whether to feed an ox oil cake or jowari and why.
('71', 340, 3, 9, 694852) To be sure they talk politics and economics, but it is only the spiritual interest that holds them till midnight, brings them back at dawn, and in the hot noonday with the plea, ‘If you knew how we want to hear that God loves us, you wouldn’t want to rest.’
('71', 340, 4, 10, 695110) If you cannot meet that need, you cannot hold the Depressed Classes—if you can meet it you will hold them.
('71', 340, 4, 11, 695217) For that is what they are asking—yes, and Shudras, too, and even some merchants and Brahmins.
('71', 340, 4, 12, 695311) This is an extract from a long letter 1 received from an American sister who has lived for years in India as a Missionary.
('71', 340, 4, 13, 695434) I heartily endorse the last statement in the extract.
('71', 340, 4, 14, 695488) Of course, if I cannot meet their spiritual needs, I cannot hold the Harijans.
('71', 340, 4, 15, 695567) But I am not so stupid as to think that I or any single person can supply the spiritual needs of his neighbour.
('71', 340, 4, 16, 695679) Spiritual needs cannot be supplied through the intellect or through the stomach even as the needs of the body cannot be supplied through the spirit.
('71', 340, 4, 17, 695828) One can paraphrase the famous saying of Jesus and say “Render unto the body that which is its, and unto the spirit that which is its.’ And the only way I can supply my neighbour’s spiritual needs is by living the life of the spirit without even exchanging a word with him.
('71', 340, 4, 18, 696101) The life of the spirit will translate itself into acts of love for my neighbour.
('71', 340, 4, 19, 696182) Therefore I have not a shadow of doubt that Hinduism will (and rightly) lose Harijans if the so called caste Hindus will not love Harijans—the outcaste Hindus—even as themselves.
('71', 340, 4, 20, 696361) If they will just do that and nothing else, Hinduism is safe and so are Harijans and they.
('71', 340, 4, 21, 696452) If they will not, they and Hinduism will surely perish.
('71', 340, 4, 22, 696508) The so called high caste Hindus may spend millions for Harijans, but if they do not do the one thing needful, i.e., regard the Harijans as their spiritual equals, the material
('71', 340, 5, 23, 696684) 1 In reply to Gandhiji’s article “The Cow”; vide “The Cow”, 13 3 1937
('71', 341, 0, 1, 696754) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 341, 1, 2, 696796) aid will stink in their nostrils and will be and deserve to be thrown away as so much waste.
('71', 341, 1, 3, 696889) But to admit that Harijans have the same spiritual need as the rest of us, is not to say that they would understand the intellectual presentation of Christianity as much as I would, for instance.
('71', 341, 1, 4, 697085) I put them on the same level as my own wife.
('71', 341, 1, 5, 697130) Her spiritual needs are no less than mine, but she would no more understand the presentation of Christianity than any ordinary Harijan would.
('71', 341, 1, 6, 697272) The reason is obvious.
('71', 341, 1, 7, 697295) We came together practically as children.
('71', 341, 1, 8, 697337) My studies went on in spite of marriage.
('71', 341, 1, 9, 697378) She never attended a school before marriage.
('71', 341, 1, 10, 697423) I neglected her educational training.
('71', 341, 1, 11, 697461) Presentation, with a view to conversion, of a faith other than one’s own, can only necessarily be through an appeal to the intellect or the stomach or both.
('71', 341, 1, 12, 697618) I do maintain in spite of the extract I have quoted that the vast mass of Harijans, and for that matter Indian humanity, cannot understand the presentation of Christianity, and that generally speaking their conversion wherever it has taken place has not been a spiritual act in any sense of the term.
('71', 341, 1, 13, 697919) They are conversions for convenience.
('71', 341, 1, 14, 697957) And I have had overwhelming corroboration of the truth during my frequent and extensive wanderings.
('71', 341, 1, 15, 698057) The writer has no warrant for suggesting that I do not know or love Harijans sufficiently because I attribute to Harijans inability to receive Christian teachings.
('71', 341, 1, 16, 698221) My attitude is not ‘superficial’ as she will have it to be.
('71', 341, 1, 17, 698281) Whatever it is, it is based on deep experience and observation dependent not on day’s or even a year’s contact, but on close contact for years with tens of thousands of India’s masses, not as a superior being but feeling as one of them.
('71', 341, 1, 18, 698518) But she is wholly right when she says, ‘whatever it is, you are not seeing them as I see them.’ They are my kith and kin, breathing the same air, living the same life, having the same faith, the same aspirations, and the same earth sustaining us in life as it will in death!
('71', 341, 1, 19, 698793) And for her?
('71', 341, 1, 20, 698806) Harijan, 12 6 1937
