('71', 343, 2, 3, 700851) June 12, 1937 You must know that this work is for your own benefit, and not for the benefit of the malguzar.
('71', 343, 2, 4, 700960) He had never even thought of this.
('71', 343, 2, 5, 700995) But you will not keep your promise and I have come to express my pain to you.
('71', 343, 2, 6, 701073) You must remember that this is a recurring task.
('71', 343, 2, 7, 701122) Every year the road will have to be renewed and stone will have to be supplied by you.
('71', 343, 2, 8, 701209) If you do not co operate with me, all the labour that we have put in this year will be wasted.
('71', 343, 2, 9, 701304) This year the profits from the village have not been equal to the tasks we have undertaken, and it was never my purpose to draw upon Jamnalalji’s other income for the purposes of this village.
('71', 343, 2, 10, 701497) I shall therefore have to find the expense from the donations I receive for Segaon work.
('71', 343, 2, 11, 701586) You will therefore understand the gravity of the breach of promise.
('71', 343, 2, 12, 701654) I therefore appeal to those of you who have not kept their promises to cart the stones to the other road.
('71', 343, 2, 13, 701760) I shall ask Jamnalalji to pay for the stones and use the proceeds for the welfare of Segaon.
('71', 343, 2, 14, 701853) But I am told that you are indifferent to all that is happening, that you do not care whether you have the road here or not.
('71', 343, 2, 15, 701978) I ask you to put your heads together and decide whether you should co operate with us or not.
('71', 343, 2, 16, 702072) I do not refer to untouchability.
('71', 343, 2, 17, 702106) There is no untouchability involved in this work, nor in the revival of your handicrafts.
('71', 343, 2, 18, 702196) If you co operate, I can assure you that your income will easily be doubled.
('71', 343, 2, 19, 702273) Then there is the question of sanitation.
('71', 343, 2, 20, 702315) I cannot make your village neat and clean and sweet smelling without your co operation.
('71', 343, 2, 21, 702403) We have engaged a scavenger here.
('71', 343, 2, 22, 702437) We pay for his service, but it is for you to keep your streets and lanes clean.

('71', 346, 6, 8, 707438) 407. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('71', 346, 7, 9, 707464) June 14, 1937
('71', 346, 8, 10, 707478) MY DEAR REBEL, Having just got your letter, this is just to tell you I understand and appreciate your 'No' 1. I had expected it.
('71', 346, 8, 11, 707607) Mira went yesterday to Dalhousie, having got Subhas's wire.
('71', 346, 8, 12, 707667) Why should you worry about explaining the 'No' to me?
('71', 346, 8, 13, 707721) Must every 'yes' and every 'no' need explaining?
('71', 346, 8, 14, 707770) Love that demands such explanations must be sorry stuff.
('71', 346, 8, 15, 707827) Mine never is.
('71', 346, 8, 16, 707842) It can stand many "no’s” so long as there is a ‘yes' interspersed.
('71', 346, 8, 17, 707909) No nonsense now.
('71', 346, 8, 18, 707926) Time flies.
('71', 346, 10, 19, 707938) From the original: C.W. 3609. Courtesy: Amrit Kaur.

('71', 347, 1, 2, 708116) 408. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('71', 347, 2, 3, 708142) SEGAON, WARDHA, June 14, 1937
('71', 347, 3, 4, 708172) MY DEAR REBEL, Herewith Andrews's letter.
('71', 347, 3, 5, 708214) Can't cheer those who won't be cheered.
('71', 347, 3, 6, 708254) I am positive that you have no cause to feel depressed.
('71', 347, 3, 7, 708310) You will feel depressed even when you do the right thing, if so doing you are likely to wound somebody's susceptibility.
('71', 347, 3, 8, 708431) How are you to cheer such stupid people?
('71', 347, 3, 9, 708472) Are they to be told to do the wrong thing in order to escape depression?
('71', 347, 3, 10, 708545) Read Chapter 6 of the Gita or Japji.
('71', 347, 3, 11, 708582) You will find in the latter many passages to dispel your depression which is a form of ignorance.
('71', 347, 3, 12, 708680) I suppose Jawaharlal wrote to me at the same time that he wrote to you.
('71', 347, 3, 13, 708752) For in his letter to me also he alludes to his sore throat, etc.
('71', 347, 3, 14, 708817) He is likely to be with me during the last week of the month.

('71', 351, 2, 3, 713010) June 15, 1937 CHI.
('71', 351, 2, 4, 713029) KANTI, I got your letter just now.
('71', 351, 2, 5, 713064) The description of the lady is interesting.
('71', 351, 2, 6, 713108) Amtul Salaam is sitting beside me, fan in hand, while I am writing this.
('71', 351, 2, 7, 713181) Mirabehn has gone to Dalhousie Hill in the Punjab.
('71', 351, 2, 8, 713232) She couldn't get rid of her fever.
('71', 351, 2, 9, 713267) Your asking for exemption from fees does not seem proper.
('71', 351, 2, 10, 713325) It was not proper either, that the lawyer should have been fined.
('71', 351, 2, 11, 713391) If you can carry on without staying in a hostel, it would be worth while to save that expense.
('71', 351, 2, 12, 713486) I had understood from what you said that you would stay with Ramji and thus save boarding and lodging expenses.
('71', 351, 2, 13, 713598) If, however, you think that staying in a hostel will be of great benefit to you, never mind the expense.
('71', 351, 2, 14, 713703) You did well in giving Devdas all the details.
('71', 351, 2, 15, 713750) You cannot by any means be but in the category of the poor.
('71', 351, 2, 16, 713810) Only those who have none to support them can be called poor.
('71', 351, 2, 17, 713871) How much was the lawyer fined?
('71', 351, 2, 18, 713902) Take care of your health.
('71', 351, 2, 19, 713928) Even when you don't get time to write, you should drop a postcard at least once in a week.
('71', 351, 2, 20, 714019) But if you can write a letter as long as 50 postcards every week, then that is what you should do.
('71', 351, 2, 21, 714118) Because of the rains the sultriness persists.
('71', 351, 2, 22, 714164) Blessings from BAPU From a photosat of the Gujarati: C.W. 7322. Courtesy: Kantilal Gandhi

('71', 352, 1, 2, 714857) 418. LETTER TO NATHUBHAI N. PAREKH
('71', 352, 2, 3, 714892) June 15, 1937
('71', 352, 3, 4, 714906) BHAI NATHUBHAI, The period of vanapravesh will last up to 58. 1 In these many years you can do a lot.
('71', 352, 3, 5, 715008) When a man enters the forest he is bound to make friends with trees, leaves, birds and animals.
('71', 352, 3, 6, 715104) He would attain fearlessness, be acquainted with Nature, would live in the midst of men and animals and know what man's place in the world is and, by the time he emerges from the forest, would have gathered such knowledge which would be helpful to himself and which would enable him to guide his neighbours.
('71', 352, 3, 7, 715412) We have to create such a forest in our heart.
('71', 352, 3, 8, 715458) If physical desires lose their keenness and we become inward looking, we shall have gained much.
('71', 352, 3, 9, 715555) You have done a bit of research to discover my mistake.
('71', 352, 3, 10, 715611) I have also had letters from four or five other Gujarati friends from the South in that regard.
('71', 352, 3, 11, 715707) Indu stayed for quite some time with me and we talked at length on many things.
('71', 352, 3, 12, 715787) He is still a child.
('71', 352, 3, 13, 715808) He is not yet aware of his responsibilities.
('71', 352, 3, 14, 715853) But he does have some good qualities.
('71', 352, 3, 15, 715891) He has great regard for Kanti.
('71', 352, 3, 16, 715922) He wishes to share in lightening the burden that has fallen on you.
('71', 352, 3, 17, 715990) Hence I hope that he will do something.
('71', 352, 3, 18, 716030) Now he will be staying under the direct care of Kanti.
('71', 352, 3, 19, 716085) Everything, therefore, will be well.
('71', 352, 4, 20, 716122) Blessings from

('71', 353, 0, 1, 716629) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 353, 1, 2, 716671) my going to Gujarat.
('71', 353, 1, 3, 716692) Of course, I was expected to go there for two or three days to inspect the site for the Congress.
('71', 353, 1, 4, 716790) But then I also have no reason for not going either.
('71', 353, 1, 5, 716843) I may say that Sardar's keen insistence dragged me.
('71', 353, 1, 6, 716895) But this is not real defence.
('71', 353, 1, 7, 716925) If sardar's insistence can persuade me to do something wrong, his other importunities may persuade me to commit greater wrongs.
('71', 353, 1, 8, 717053) In spite of knowing all this I could not withstand his insistence.
('71', 353, 1, 9, 717120) Now about cow's ghee.
('71', 353, 1, 10, 717142) I charge Rs. 3 per seer or even two and a half.
('71', 353, 1, 11, 717190) I charge according to the cost.
('71', 353, 1, 12, 717222) I am able to get this much because there are people like Jamnalalji and I am able to insist on their using cow's ghee prepared in Wardha.
('71', 353, 1, 13, 717360) But I shall not be able to carry on this Rs. 3 per seer business for long.
('71', 353, 1, 14, 717435) Your ghee of course cannot be sold even free of cost because we cannot accept an agency for buffalo's ghee.
('71', 353, 1, 15, 717543) Moreover your ghee is adulterated.
('71', 353, 1, 16, 717578) It is my firm belief that this business of yours is wrong.
('71', 353, 1, 17, 717637) As you do not abide by the regulations of the Goseva Sangh, you do not get any help from them and therefore make adulterated ghee at home.
('71', 353, 1, 18, 717776) Naturally it fetches lower price in the market.
('71', 353, 1, 19, 717824) Nowadays ghee made out of pure buffalo's milk fetches a good price in the market.
('71', 353, 1, 20, 717906) Ghee made from from pure cow's milk fetches a lower price.
('71', 353, 1, 21, 717965) So if at the moment you make no distinction between the cow and the buffalo, you should engage yourself in making ghee only out of buffalo's milk.
('71', 353, 1, 22, 718112) You will surely succeed in it.
('71', 353, 1, 23, 718143) I can understand that it will not give you mental satisfaction.
('71', 353, 1, 24, 718207) But if you derive any mental satisfaction from mixing cow's milk with buffalo's, it is a false satisfaction.
('71', 353, 1, 25, 718316) Hence it is my sincere advice that you should either make ghee out of pure cow's milk and sell it at the normal rate or, failing that, find some other occupation which would be beneficial to the villages.
('71', 353, 1, 26, 718521) Obtain from the public whatever cannot be met by the income from the business.
('71', 353, 1, 27, 718600) But this after all is my opinion.
('71', 353, 1, 28, 718634) There is no absolute rule that you have to follow my advice in such matters.
('71', 353, 1, 29, 718711) Of course I would never insist.
('71', 353, 1, 30, 718743) So think over my argument and do only what you think proper.
('71', 353, 1, 31, 718804) Kishorelalbhai will of course read this, and, if possible, Vinoba, too.
('71', 353, 1, 32, 718876) I shall try to send their opinions along with this.
('71', 353, 2, 33, 718928) Blessings from
('71', 353, 4, 34, 718943) From the Gujarati original: C.W. 9862. Courtesy: Narayan J. Sampat

('71', 354, 8, 24, 719916) But the recollection does not affect what I said 2 at Hudli.

('71', 354, 8, 27, 720167) But Gangadharrao whom I knew very well bore down my opposition and assured me that Mr. Chikodi and others would whole heartedly work out the scheme.
('71', 354, 8, 28, 720316) Gangadharrao himself admits that he failed.
('71', 354, 8, 29, 720360) He could not even personally confine himself to cow's milk, nor Mr. Chikodi who was to be active worker in the movement.

('71', 355, 0, 1, 720621) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 355, 1, 2, 720663) resolution of the big body was tragic, through no fault of anybody.
('71', 355, 1, 3, 720731) But my fault was in not sufficiently realizing that my method of working out the cow protection programme would not be popular and that I would have to show results by experimenting.
('71', 355, 1, 4, 720914) That experiment is still going on.
('71', 355, 1, 5, 720949) Tanning at Ahmedabad did not succeed, because the so called experts were not really experts.
('71', 355, 1, 6, 721042) But as it always existed in my imagination it has taken shape in Wardha and Bengal.
('71', 355, 1, 7, 721126) In Wardha the experiment is being conducted under my direct supervision and in Bengal under the supervision of one of my colleagues.
('71', 355, 1, 8, 721259) I can still show no striking results because the experiment is novel and difficult.
('71', 355, 1, 9, 721343) This programme is not any part of the village movement, although it can be.
('71', 355, 1, 10, 721419) It is being worked out independently as part of the scheme not of village improvement but of cow protection.
('71', 355, 1, 11, 721528) My point remains that those who invited me in Belgaum to take up the cow protection work were previously in that field and should not have given it up because I failed or seemed to fail.

('71', 357, 12, 18, 724185) We creatures are not all dharmaja progeny, but kamaja.
('71', 357, 12, 19, 724240) Let us suppose that a man in full control of his passion desires progeny and a suitable mate, too, who desires progeny only from him and is not moved by passion.
('71', 357, 12, 20, 724402) Their son would be dharmaja.
('71', 357, 12, 21, 724431) But this does not imply that none among their ancestors were kamaja.
('71', 357, 12, 22, 724500) 4 Thus what I mean is that

('71', 358, 1, 2, 724973) though we are full of imperfections we should make an effort at any rate to rid ourselves of them.
('71', 358, 1, 3, 725072) I cannot say from personal experience whether it is possible or not to procreate dharmaja offspring but I do hold that the remark in the Adiparva of Mahabharta regarding Vyasji stems from experience.
('71', 358, 1, 4, 725272) 1 It is possible that it is only a poetic fancy and not an actual experience.
('71', 358, 1, 5, 725350) But this takes away nothing from my argument because if a couple come together not moved by passion but only for the sake of progeny, their brahmacharya is in no was lessened.
('71', 358, 1, 6, 725526) But there can be only one single offspring of this kind.
('71', 358, 1, 7, 725583) This is a description of the ideal state.
('71', 358, 1, 8, 725625) And we must try to reach it to the extent we can.
('71', 358, 1, 9, 725675) Procreation is no obligatory duty, but the desire for it is no sin either.
('71', 358, 1, 10, 725750) Thus marriage is impermissible for one who has no wish for progeny, i.e., satisfaction of passion should never be the ground for marriage.

('71', 358, 5, 17, 726313) 428. HOW THEY CONVERT
('71', 358, 6, 18, 726335) Thakkar Bapa had his attention drawn to the so called conversion to Christianity in Shahabad District.
('71', 358, 6, 19, 726438) He thereupon called for a report on the statements made to him.
('71', 358, 6, 20, 726502) The following is the report 2 made by the local Harijan Sevak Sangh:
('71', 358, 7, 21, 726571) In the district of Shahbad, about 40 years ago, a Methodist Episcopal Christian Mission was established at Arrah.
('71', 358, 7, 22, 726685) Through its efforts a large number of Harijans, numbering about three thousand, were converted to Christianity up to the year 1931. .
('71', 358, 7, 23, 726819) Last year a Roman Catholic Mission appeared on the scene.
('71', 358, 7, 24, 726877) Since then, the activities of both the Missions have increased .
('71', 358, 7, 25, 726942) .Enquiry has revealed that they have been successful in getting
('71', 358, 8, 26, 727006) 1 Vide “Advice to Newly Married Couples”, 18 4 1937 2 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('71', 359, 0, 1, 727095) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 359, 1, 2, 727137) some new Christian converts from the Rabidas (Chamar) community amongst whom their activities are mainly confined.
('71', 359, 1, 3, 727252) Roughly their method of work may be described as follows: After having visited the village and created familiarity with the Harijans they at once start a school and put it in charge of a Harijan teacher who either himself is an influential man or related to such a one.
('71', 359, 1, 4, 727522) Whenever they come to learn that some tension or actual litigation is going on between the Harijans and other villagers they at once seize the opportunity to take up the side of the poor Harijans and help them with money and advice.
('71', 359, 1, 5, 727755) They are thus hailed as saviours and conversion follows as if to repay the obligation.
('71', 359, 2, 6, 727842) As their work is scattered throughhout the thana in the remotest
('71', 359, 3, 7, 727907) villages, the present enquiry could not be exhaustive .
('71', 359, 3, 8, 727963) The one remarkable feature of these recent conversions is that they take place en masse.
('71', 359, 3, 9, 728052) Whenever a village Harijan leader accepts the new faith almost all
('71', 359, 4, 10, 728119) belonging to his clan follow him .
('71', 359, 4, 11, 728154) In all cases of conversions new or old, not a single instance can be found in which the acceptance of the new faith was due to any religious conviction .
('71', 359, 4, 12, 728308) The reasons, therefore, of conversions may be roughly described as economic or socioeconomic.
('71', 359, 4, 13, 728402) Generally, the Harijans have to submit to a number of unjust exactions and to suffer from humiliating treatment which are now resented by them .
('71', 359, 4, 14, 728547) Those of the new and the old who are still continuing as nominal Christians are willing to return to Hinduism if their grievances are removed.
('71', 359, 4, 15, 728690) Their grievances as disclosed during the enquiry are briefly indicated below: 1. They are forced to labour for their maliks and other caste Hindus of their villages at about half or even less wages then they would get for the same kind of labour in other villages.
('71', 359, 4, 16, 728955) 2. They are forced to labour for their maliks and other caste Hindu villgers on occasions of marriages and deaths in their families on almost no wages.
('71', 359, 5, 17, 729107) 3. They are charged six annas per year per family as mutharfa (house
('71', 359, 7, 18, 729176) 4. They have to pay Re.
('71', 359, 7, 19, 729200) 1, Rs. 2 and Rs. 3 or Rs. 4 for the hide of every dead cow, bullock or buffalo respectively to their owners if they fail to deliver a corresponding number of pairs of shoes to them.
('71', 359, 8, 20, 729382) 5. Their wives are paid only four annas for a male or two annas for a female child born in the house of the caste Hindu villagers where they have to work as midwives during confinement, and even these payments are not regularly made.
('71', 359, 9, 21, 729616) 6. They are forced to work for their maliks and caste Hindu villgers even
('71', 359, 10, 22, 729690) at the sacrifice of their own agricultural needs or when they are ill or engaged in their social or religious functions.
('71', 360, 0, 1, 729811) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 361
('71', 360, 1, 2, 729855) 7. The levy of the Chowkidari tax on them is generally excessive.
('71', 360, 2, 3, 729921) 8. They are not allowed to draw water from wells used by caste Hindus.
('71', 360, 3, 4, 729992) 9. They are not allowed to enter temples nor are Brahmin priests available to recite religious kathas at their houses.
('71', 360, 3, 5, 730111) If what is said in the report about the conversions be true, it is from my standpoint reprehensible.
('71', 360, 3, 6, 730212) Such superficial conversions can only give rise to suspicion and strife.
('71', 360, 3, 7, 730285) But if a missionary body or individuals choose to follow the methods described in the report, nothing can be done to prevent them.
('71', 360, 3, 8, 730416) It is therefore much more profitable to turn the searchlight inward and to discover our own defects.
('71', 360, 3, 9, 730517) Fortunately the report enables us to do so.
('71', 360, 3, 10, 730561) Nine causes are enumerated to show why Harijans are induced to leave the Hindu fold.
('71', 360, 3, 11, 730646) Seven are purely economic, one is social, and one is purely religious.
('71', 360, 3, 12, 730717) Thus they are reduced economically, degraded socially and boycotted from religious participation.
('71', 360, 3, 13, 730815) The wonder is not that they leave Hinduism; the wonder is that they have not done so for so long and that so few leave their ancestral faith even when they do.
('71', 360, 3, 14, 730975) The moral is obvious.
('71', 360, 3, 15, 730997) Let us make every discovery, such as the one made in Shahabad, an occasion for greater self purification, greater dedication to the harijan cause, greater identification with the Harijans.
('71', 360, 3, 16, 731186) It should result in the local Sangh collecting more workers than it has for doing on the one hand service among the Harijans and on the other propaganda among the so called caste Hindus, not in the shape of reviling them but showing them that religion does not warrant the treatment that is meted out to Harijans by them.
('71', 360, 3, 17, 731508) Harijan, 19 6 1937
('71', 360, 4, 18, 731527) 429. KHADI AT HARIPURA
('71', 360, 5, 19, 731550) Dastane is anxious that something striking should happen at Haripura so as to make khadi much more popular than it is.
('71', 360, 5, 20, 731669) There are other workers who no doubt anticipate great things from Haripura about khadi.
('71', 360, 5, 21, 731757) Bardoli's promise to be wholly self sustained about khadi made in 1921 still remains unredeemed.
('71', 360, 5, 22, 731854) Painful to tell, Bardoli like other places falls back on Wardha for its cheap and well coloured khadi.
('71', 360, 5, 23, 731957) The khadi method excludes concentration.
('71', 360, 5, 24, 731998) Wardha is in no need of outside patronage.
('71', 360, 5, 25, 732041) And if it began to rely on it, it would harm itself and khadi in the long run.
('71', 360, 5, 26, 732120) The secret of success in khadi is for each taluk or at least district to produce and use its own khadi.
('71', 361, 0, 1, 732224) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 361, 1, 2, 732266) But Sjt.
('71', 361, 1, 3, 732275) Dastane says, though the Working Committee has re emphasized the fourfold programme of 1920, there is hardly an M.L.A. who talks about it to his constituency.
('71', 361, 1, 4, 732434) And if the khadi lovers, too, do not show application or orginality, khadi has a poor chance of becoming universal.
('71', 361, 1, 5, 732550) There is force in what Sjt.
('71', 361, 1, 6, 732578) Dastane says.
('71', 361, 1, 7, 732592) But things are not quite as bad as he perhaps imagines.
('71', 361, 1, 8, 732648) In Nalwadi, Vinoba is practically concentntrating the whole of his attention on khadi.
('71', 361, 1, 9, 732735) He is making experiments to see whether the minimum of three annas per day of eight hours for spinners is an easily realizable proposition.
('71', 361, 1, 10, 732875) It bids fair to succeed.
('71', 361, 1, 11, 732900) There is a boy 16 year old who is a villager of quite the ordinary type.
('71', 361, 1, 12, 732973) He is earning four annas per day.
('71', 361, 1, 13, 733007) If the average villager has a sufficient ocular demonstration of the possibility of earning three annas per day, and if he or she knows that there is an organization that will take in all the standard yarn that can be produced, there will be a spontaneous response.
('71', 361, 1, 14, 733273) Now this kind of very solid work does not admit of haste or a spectacular display.
('71', 361, 1, 15, 733356) Then there is one great difficulty in the way.
('71', 361, 1, 16, 733403) The spinners, weavers and other artisans engaged in khadi production are expected to use khadi for their own wear.
('71', 361, 1, 17, 733518) This means popular education in the economics of khadi, a change in the mentality of the poor artisans who do not know anything of why they are so helpless and poor and still less of how they can help themselves to get rid of their ignorance and poverty.
('71', 361, 1, 18, 733773) The spread of such education means again a large number of workers possessing love of khadi and an adequate knowledge of the economics and the technique of khadi.
('71', 361, 1, 19, 733936) Thus there are very natural difficulties to be overcome in the attempt to make khadi universal.
('71', 361, 1, 20, 734032) Let Sjt.
('71', 361, 1, 21, 734041) Dastane and others who feel like him about khadi make a deep study of the science and make their own experiments if they have any original contribution to make or pursue the beaten track and give to the work their exclusive attention.
('71', 361, 1, 22, 734276) Harijan, 19 6 1937
('71', 361, 2, 23, 734295) 430. MAN’S INHUMANITY
('71', 361, 3, 24, 734317) Not many people know what is phooka.
('71', 361, 3, 25, 734354) Still fewer know that there is an association in Calcutta called the Anti phooka Association.
('71', 361, 3, 26, 734448) Its patrons are Maharajadhiraja Sir Bijoy Chand Mahatab Bahadur and Justice Sir L. W. J. Costello.
('71', 361, 3, 27, 734547) Its president is Shri Ramkumar
('71', 362, 0, 1, 734578) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 363
('71', 362, 1, 2, 734622) Bangar.
('71', 362, 1, 3, 734630) The office is at 65 Pathuriaghata Street.
('71', 362, 1, 4, 734672) The Secretary thus describes the process of phooka:
('71', 362, 2, 5, 734724) I have to inform you that the atrocities of phooka are perpetrated on
('71', 362, 3, 6, 734794) each milch animal twice daily.
('71', 362, 3, 7, 734825) The four legs of the animal are tied to four
('71', 362, 4, 8, 734870) strong posts and two men hold the animal so tightly that she cannot make
('71', 362, 5, 9, 734943) any movement of her limbs whatsoever.
('71', 362, 5, 10, 734981) A bamboo rod or pipe, 22 inches
('71', 362, 6, 11, 735013) long and 8 inches in circumference, is then forcibly pushed into the
('71', 362, 7, 12, 735082) generative organ of the animal, and then one man begins to blow air into
('71', 362, 8, 13, 735155) the uterus, causing it to be fully distended thereby.
('71', 362, 8, 14, 735209) This inflammation
('71', 362, 9, 15, 735227) causes extra pressure on the glands which helps the milkman to extract the
('71', 362, 10, 16, 735302) last drop of milk.
('71', 362, 10, 17, 735321) The milking also is indescribably cruel, and it is
('71', 362, 11, 18, 735372) continued to the great pain of the animal till blood comes out of the udder.
('71', 362, 12, 19, 735449) Sometimes a few drops of the blood get mixed up with the milk.
('71', 362, 12, 20, 735512) Unable to
('71', 362, 13, 21, 735522) make any movements, the animal silently bears this inhuman torture and
('71', 362, 14, 22, 735593) her great pain is manifested only by the copious perspiration and tears that
('71', 362, 15, 23, 735670) flow down her body and cheeks.
('71', 362, 15, 24, 735701) This is repeated twice daily and the animal
('71', 362, 16, 25, 735745) invaribly swoons after each operation.
('71', 362, 16, 26, 735784) It is difficult to conceive anything more torturing or revolting than the process described by the Secretary.
('71', 362, 16, 27, 735894) From the proceedings of a meeting of the Association it appears that the practice results in the sterility of the cows and she buffaloes subjected to the torture.
('71', 362, 16, 28, 736057) They are therefore transferred to butchers after they cease to yield milk even in spite of phooka.
('71', 362, 16, 29, 736156) The Association undertakes the prosecution of the torturers.
('71', 362, 16, 30, 736217) It engages plain clothes detectives to discover the culprits.
('71', 362, 16, 31, 736279) The activity of the Association is good as far as it goes.
('71', 362, 16, 32, 736338) But it does not appear to me to go far enough.
('71', 362, 16, 33, 736385) Punishment of a few criminals won't stop the inhumanity.
('71', 362, 16, 34, 736442) It is necessary to carry on propaganda among the offenders and educate them to understand the evils of the system.
('71', 362, 16, 35, 736557) Of course the surest way of dealing with the evil is for the Corporation to take charge of the whole of the milk supply of Calcutta and change the gwalas into its paid servants.
('71', 362, 16, 36, 736735) They would then not be open to temptation as they are now.
('71', 362, 16, 37, 736794) They will be under sanitary supervision.
('71', 362, 16, 38, 736835) Milking will be done under proper control.
('71', 362, 16, 39, 736878) The citizens will have a guarantee of having pure milk for their money.
('71', 362, 16, 40, 736950) And there is not the slightest reason why the milk supply department should not be self supporting.
('71', 362, 16, 41, 737050) The citizens will gladly pay an extra pie, if an increase in the selling price becomes necessary.
('71', 362, 16, 42, 737148) Of course the milk supply has to
('71', 363, 0, 1, 737181) 364 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 363, 1, 2, 737223) become a monopoly of a municipality undertaking the enterprise, even as the postal stamp is a monopoly of the State.

('71', 371, 16, 22, 749896) sent to him earlier by the correspondent and asked him to read it aloud for the benefit
('71', 371, 17, 23, 749984) of himself and others present.

('71', 372, 3, 8, 751129) 448. LETTER TO ATULANAND CHAKRABARTY
('71', 372, 4, 9, 751166) SEGAON (WARDHA) June 23, 1937
('71', 372, 5, 10, 751196) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('71', 372, 5, 11, 751229) It is unfortunate but it is true that I have not been able to appreciate the utility of your method as a contribution to the communal tangle.
('71', 372, 5, 12, 751371) That does not mean that there is no value in cultural contact.
('71', 372, 5, 13, 751434) I think it has great value.
('71', 372, 5, 14, 751462) But I am more than doubtful as to the possibility of organizing such contact.
('71', 372, 5, 15, 751540) I do not know if I have expressed myself clearly.
('71', 372, 5, 16, 751590) Rabindranath has, of all the men of the world, perhaps, made the largest contribution in that direction.
('71', 372, 5, 17, 751695) But it has not been through any organization.
('71', 372, 5, 18, 751741) His writings have compelled attention.
('71', 372, 5, 19, 751780) I should be delighted if your writings serve the same purpose.
('71', 372, 5, 20, 751843) But then you do not need my certificate or anybody else's, even as the Poet does not.
('71', 372, 5, 21, 751929) I wonder if I have made my position clear.
('71', 372, 5, 22, 751972) I, somehow or other, feel that yours is a different position.
('71', 372, 5, 23, 752034) Maybe that I have not understood it and, therefore, I have been indifferent to it.
('71', 372, 5, 24, 752117) I would be satisfied if I can make you believe that my indifference is not due to cussedness or even to want of study of your thought expressed by you.
('71', 372, 5, 25, 752269) The moment I begin to appreciate your method you will find me advertising it in my own humble way.
('71', 372, 5, 26, 752368) But you seem to be paralysed without my advertisement and this hurts me.
('71', 372, 5, 27, 752441) Why should you need my advertisement?
('71', 372, 5, 28, 752479) Surely the names you have gathered round yourself are far better judges of your work than I ever can be.
('71', 372, 5, 29, 752584) It is easy enough now to answer your questions.
('71', 372, 5, 30, 752632) The solid work for villages that I have in mind is the work such as the Spinners' Association is doing among thousand of artisans irrespective of their caste or creed.
('71', 372, 5, 31, 752800) I hope to publish statistics showing
('71', 373, 0, 1, 752837) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 373, 1, 2, 752879) the number of artisans with whom the Spinners' Association has established contact–not political but purely economic.
('71', 373, 1, 3, 752997) Of course, anyone who has faith in such kind of contact can work for it if he has the desire to learn the technique.
('71', 373, 1, 4, 753114) This work is necessarily confined to the villages because the bulk of these artisans are to be found in the villages and these are the people who are in need of the assistance of the kind we are offering.
('71', 373, 1, 5, 753319) The third and the fourth question are answered in the foregoing paragraphs.
('71', 373, 1, 6, 753395) The fifth question is answered in the preliminary paragraph.
('71', 373, 1, 7, 753456) You do not seem to have kept a copy of your letter.
('71', 373, 1, 8, 753508) I am, therefore, returning your letter in order to enable you to see if I have covered all your questions.
('71', 373, 1, 9, 753615) If I have not, you should tell me and I shall make another endeavour to answer your questions.

('71', 374, 1, 2, 754983) 450. LETTER TO LORD LOTHIAN
('71', 374, 2, 3, 755011) SEGAON, WARDHA, June 24, 1937
('71', 374, 3, 4, 755041) DEAR LORD LOTHIAN, My deepest thanks for your long letter 1. I appreciate the patient effort you are making to convince me of the correctness of your advice.
('71', 374, 3, 5, 755199) With much of what you say I wholly agree.
('71', 374, 3, 6, 755241) The question of office acceptance will now be finally decided at the forthcoming meeting of the Working Committee of the Congress.
('71', 374, 3, 7, 755372) The Viceroy has just said 2 the last word about the Government's attitude.
('71', 374, 3, 8, 755447) I admit that it is an improvement upon the first speech 3 on the situation by Lord Zetland.
('71', 374, 3, 9, 755539) Whatever the decision of the Working Committee may be–and you will have known it before this reaches you–what I would like to write upon is the fundamental difference between the colonies and India.
('71', 374, 3, 10, 755738) So far as I know, the colonists were armed and knew the use of arms.
('71', 374, 3, 11, 755807) The vast majority of thirty millions of voters here are unarmed, do not know the use of arms and perhaps would not like to be armed even if they were left absolutely free to do so–such is Indian culture.
('71', 374, 3, 12, 756011) Though, therefore, I have pinned my faith to working along constitutional lines, I have, as every Indian has, either to think out a programme whereby every adult can be trained in the use of arms or find a substitute.
('71', 374, 3, 13, 756229) At my instance, the Congress has for the last eighteen years attempted to experiment with the substitute called non violent non co operation, civil resistance, etc.
('71', 374, 3, 14, 756394) For myself I have rejected the idea of achieving freedom by the use of arms in the last resort and I have accepted as its final substitute the use of non violence in every shape and form.
('71', 374, 3, 15, 756582) The use of arms is not an unexplored field, that of non violence has possibilities of infinite exploration.
('71', 374, 3, 16, 756690) Hence my eagerness to discover a formula whereby, consistently with the Congress creed of complete independence, office acceptance may be possible.
('71', 374, 3, 17, 756838) But I must confess that I have not the faith that you have in the possibility of the existing Act to expand into an instrument of complete freedom.
('71', 374, 3, 18, 756986) On the contrary, I believe in common with the vast majority of educated Indians that it is incapable of giving India what it wants and the sooner it is replaced by something of Indian design the better.
('71', 374, 4, 19, 757189) 1 Vide footnote on “Letter to Manilal and Sushila Gandhi”, 21 6 1937 2 Vide Appendix “Viceroy’s Speech”, 21 6 1937. 3 Vide Apendix “Lord Zetland’s Speech”, 6 5 1937.
('71', 375, 0, 1, 757355) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 375, 1, 2, 757397) Of course, the Act does contemplate militarization of India at a snail's pace and therefore it is not so repugnant to those overwhelming numbers of Indians who want India to develop military power as it is to me who would if I could take India along a wholly different route.
('71', 375, 1, 3, 757673) Now, if you think that my reasoning is erroneous and that it is possible for India to attain her full height without the back ground of either military training or of non violent training, you should come to India during next autumn if only to teach me.
('71', 375, 1, 4, 757927) In any case, if the Congress decides upon office acceptance it will be the beginning of real difficulty in one way and your coming is likely to be helpful.
('71', 375, 1, 5, 758083) If the Congress decides otherwise, you will perhaps yourself feel impelled to come here in order that you might not leave a single stone unturned to avert a calamity which it would be if the rule of the sword replaces the rule of the electorate, that is, democracy, however, incipient it might be.
('71', 375, 2, 6, 758381) Yours sincerely,
('71', 375, 3, 7, 758398) From a copy: C.W. 6386 a.

('71', 375, 4, 10, 758459) 451. LETTER TO KANTILAL GANDHI
('71', 375, 5, 11, 758490) June 24, 1937
('71', 375, 6, 12, 758504) KANTI, I got your letter.
('71', 375, 6, 13, 758530) I read also your letter to Mahadev.
('71', 375, 6, 14, 758566) The latter I consider an excellent letter.
('71', 375, 6, 15, 758609) You have been able to describe very vividly the struggle going on in your heart.
('71', 375, 6, 16, 758690) Your decision is of course good.
('71', 375, 6, 17, 758723) If you have determination, and indeed you have it, any college will be good for you.
('71', 375, 6, 18, 758808) But compared to Bombay, Bangalore is superior because there you will have more freedom.
('71', 375, 6, 19, 758896) The fact that the Principal has sent his son to Bombay counts little with me, for in doing so he has merely put a higher value on Bombay degrees.
('71', 375, 6, 20, 759042) For you such value has, and I think should have, secondary importance.
('71', 375, 6, 21, 759113) It is not the university that brings credit to a brilliant student but the latter that brings credit to a university.
('71', 375, 6, 22, 759231) There is a small village in England named Louth.
('71', 375, 6, 23, 759280) Tennyson was a pupil in that school and because of that even today the teachers of that school take great pride in it.
('71', 375, 6, 24, 759399) In the same way you should bring glory to the college in Bangalore.
('71', 375, 6, 25, 759467) What pains me particularly when I see people going to England or the West is that those who seek prestige for themselves by going to the West gain none, but, of course, they certainly raise the value of Western degrees.
('71', 375, 6, 26, 759687) One can understand that those who seek prestige do not gain any, for many who hold Western degrees remain
('71', 376, 0, 1, 759793) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 377
('71', 376, 1, 2, 759837) unemployed.
('71', 376, 1, 3, 759849) But anyone who has ability, whether he holds a degree from the East or from the West, does acquire prestige.
('71', 376, 1, 4, 759958) The late Dr. Tribhovandas was only an L.M.&S. He used to charge Rs. 1,000 a day as fee.
('71', 376, 1, 5, 760046) He was unrivalled both as physician and surgeon.
('71', 376, 1, 6, 760095) And in the art of restoring a nose that had been cut off, he has had no equal anywhere in the world.
('71', 376, 1, 7, 760196) The chief reason was that at that time dacoits had made it a custom to cut the noses of high officials.
('71', 376, 1, 8, 760300) Had Tribhovandas been diffident he would have called in some English doctor in such cases.
('71', 376, 1, 9, 760391) But being courageous he held the knife and the needle in his own hands and restored the noses in all or almost all cases.
('71', 376, 1, 10, 760513) If a man is honest, he is sure to become proficient through experience.
('71', 376, 1, 11, 760585) I have written all this to strengthen you in your decision, for people will continue to put before you all sorts of arguments that might persuade you to revise your decision.
('71', 376, 1, 12, 760760) Your aim is to acquire knowledge.
('71', 376, 1, 13, 760794) It is not as if after getting a degree one need gain no further knowledge.
('71', 376, 1, 14, 760869) It is possible that real knowledge is acquired only after getting a degree because that has been the experience of most people.
('71', 376, 1, 15, 760997) Regarding your lodging and boarding make whatever arrangement you think will suit you from the point of view of health and studies.

('71', 377, 1, 2, 761723) 452. LETTER TO KANU GANDHI
('71', 377, 2, 3, 761750) June 24, 1937
('71', 377, 3, 4, 761764) KANAIYO,
('71', 377, 4, 5, 761773) I got your letter.

('71', 377, 5, 9, 761965) Her name is Soundaram.
('71', 377, 5, 10, 761988) She had also brought her vina, which was worth Rs. 150. The chief reason of its high value was its decoration.
('71', 377, 5, 11, 762099) Without the decoration it would be worth only Rs. 80. But what I like most was her mastery in playing on the vina.
('71', 377, 5, 12, 762214) She sang, too, to the accompaniment of the vina.
('71', 377, 5, 13, 762263) Her voice is sweet.
('71', 377, 5, 14, 762283) During all that time I remembered you.
('71', 377, 5, 15, 762322) She said she would come again some other time.
('71', 377, 5, 16, 762369) You have not followed my questions about book keeping.
('71', 377, 5, 17, 762424) That only means that you have not understood the technical terms of book keeping.
('71', 377, 5, 18, 762506) So to that extent you probably do not know book keeping.
('71', 377, 5, 19, 762563) Show that letter to Narandas.
('71', 377, 5, 20, 762593) If he does not understand my terms, then I will have to admit that I do not know the technical language of book keeping and, therefore, could not use it correctly.
('71', 377, 5, 21, 762757) Narandas knows book keeping throughly well.
('71', 377, 5, 22, 762801) I learnt just enough of it for my legal practice, with my own effort, and it is possible, therefore, that I do not know the technical terms as well as an expert in book keeping.
('71', 377, 5, 23, 762979) In short, what I had asked from you was a summary, or 'abstract' as it is called in English, of the different accounts in the ledger.
('71', 377, 5, 24, 763113) If neither the register nor the abstracts are available here, we cannot know what the credit or debit balances are in the different accounts.
('71', 377, 5, 25, 763255) And such occasions are bound to arise when it becomes necessary to know the figures.
('71', 377, 5, 26, 763340) Do complete the accounts.
('71', 377, 5, 27, 763366) While you are there, try to perfect your knowledge of book keeping.
('71', 377, 5, 28, 763434) Similarly you may increase your knowledge of music as much as you wish to.
('71', 377, 5, 29, 763509) You are doing well in planning to go to Chorwad a little earlier.
('71', 377, 5, 30, 763575) Amtul Salaam's amount has been received.
('71', 377, 5, 31, 763616) I see that you go to bed at 11. I consider it too late.
('71', 377, 5, 32, 763672) Everybody should form the habit of going to bed by 10. But you should of course follow the convenience of others there.

('71', 383, 4, 18, 772144) 464. UNFORTUNATE BUT INDISPENSABLE
('71', 383, 5, 19, 772179) The Secretary of the local Harijan Sevak Sangh of Jamshedpur applied to a lady among others for a subscription and he received the following reply:
('71', 383, 6, 20, 772327) It is some time since your letter of 5th February appealing for funds was
('71', 383, 7, 21, 772401) received by me.
('71', 383, 8, 22, 772417) I appreciate the good work your Association is doing at Jamshedpur, but, on principle, I cannot bring myself to send any subscription to any Association that calls itself 'Harijan' just because of the interpretation put upon that word in this country.
('71', 383, 9, 23, 772669) I am convinced that as long as any member of a society is classified by a
('71', 383, 10, 24, 772743) name that savours of inferiority, that section of society will never be raised.
('71', 383, 11, 25, 772823) would abolish from our vocabulary the words 'Harijan', 'Depressed Class', and
('71', 383, 12, 26, 772901) all such other appellations of the same meaning, which are used to distinguish
('71', 383, 13, 27, 772980) people who should never be separately described from their fellow beings.
('71', 383, 13, 28, 773054) The objection raised by the lady is not new.
('71', 383, 13, 29, 773099) The adoption of the name 'Harijan' was not a matter of choice, it was one of compulsion.
('71', 384, 0, 1, 773188) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 385
('71', 384, 1, 2, 773232) So long as the suppressed classes exist, it will be necessary to have some designation for them.
('71', 384, 1, 3, 773329) Thus Indians in South Africa were popularly distinguished from the rest as 'coolies' or 'sammies'.
('71', 384, 1, 4, 773428) This was resented by them.
('71', 384, 1, 5, 773455) Protests were made with more or less effect not against a distinguished name but against a name which in itself carried reproach and signified inferiority.
('71', 384, 1, 6, 773611) So ultimately they came to be classified as Indians as they should have been from the beginning.
('71', 384, 1, 7, 773708) Even thus were untouchables called by various names denoting reproach and inferiority.
('71', 384, 1, 8, 773795) The Government officers have devised names such as 'depressed', 'backward'.
('71', 384, 1, 9, 773871) Now they are known as 'scheduled classes'.
('71', 384, 1, 10, 773914) For the reformers, the name 'Harijan' was suggested by someone who belonged to the suppressed classes.
('71', 384, 1, 11, 774017) And that name has been adopted by the Harijan Sevak Sangh, being in its meaning absolutely free from reproach and even fitting in the sense that the despised of man are the dear ones of God, which is what 'Harijan means.
('71', 384, 1, 12, 774238) What, therefore, is possible and is being done is to remove the last trace of inferiority, but it is not possible to do away with a special name for those whose inferiority is abolished even from the hearts of caste Hindus, so long as the necessity for knowing the liberated ones from the rest exists.
('71', 384, 1, 13, 774540) I hope, therefore, that the objecting lady will recognize the inevitability of a separate designation for the suppressed class, but appreciate the fact that the word chosen by the Sangh has absolutely no reproach about it, and therefore give her subscription and become an active helper in a cause than which none can be found worthier.
('71', 384, 1, 14, 774877) Harijan, 26 6 1937
('71', 384, 2, 15, 774896) 465. ARE THERE DIFFERENT OATHS?
('71', 384, 3, 16, 774928) On reading my article 1 on 'Religious Oath and Non religious', a Quaker friend wrote to a common friend who has passed on the letter to me.
('71', 384, 3, 17, 775068) I copy the letter 2 below:
('71', 384, 4, 18, 775095) It appears to me that Mr. Gandhi is dealing with two quite distinct questions in this article.
('71', 384, 4, 19, 775190) I wholly agree with his answer to one of them as, with due respect, I wholly disagree with the other .
('71', 384, 4, 20, 775293) I agree wholly with him that a Congressman need not worry over the propriety of the oath.
('71', 384, 4, 21, 775383) 2. But the Mahatma's subtle mind is too much for me when he draws distinctions between religious and non religious oaths.
('71', 384, 4, 22, 775505) At any rate we simple
('71', 384, 5, 23, 775527) 1 Vide “Religious Oath and Non Religious”,22 5 1937 2 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('71', 385, 0, 1, 775616) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 385, 1, 2, 775658) Quakers look at it thus: Religion is man's search for God, and his reference of all life to the life of God.
('71', 385, 1, 3, 775767) An affirmation, or promise, to tell the truth and do the truth, is a reference of the self back to the life of God, for Truth is a part of God’s essential nature.
('71', 385, 1, 4, 775930) Therefore all such promises are religious acts.
('71', 385, 1, 5, 775978) The Quakers object to oaths, because they claim to be religious people, that is, people who fear God, and intend to observe the truth without swearing in the name of God.
('71', 385, 1, 6, 776149) As you know, after a long struggle and much suffering they obtained the right to affirm instead of swearing.
('71', 385, 1, 7, 776258) But affirmation or oath, both are for us religious acts; unless by religion one means something apart from the most part of life.
('71', 385, 1, 8, 776388) I should not agree that a Court of Law or a Parliament was something apart from religion for a religious man.
('71', 385, 1, 9, 776498) We, Quakers, are clear that all life is religious for the religious man, and have no particular use for a segregated 'religion' .
('71', 385, 2, 10, 776628) Cuttings from two Indian newspapers criticizing the article have also been sent to me.
('71', 385, 3, 11, 776715) What I find after reading the letter and the cuttings is that it is very difficult for me to make myself fully intelligible especially when I write on anything out of the way.
('71', 385, 3, 12, 776891) The only thing for me is to endeavour to elucidate my point so long as there is anything to elucidate.
('71', 385, 4, 13, 776994) I can see no subtlety about my argument.
('71', 385, 4, 14, 777035) But I see the clearest possible distinction between the oath or affirmation that a person takes before a court of law, a legislature and before his God perhaps daily at the time of rising and retiring.
('71', 385, 4, 15, 777237) They have different functions, different incidences.
('71', 385, 4, 16, 777290) The Quaker friend in my opinion surrenders the whole position when he agrees with me in my interpretation of the legislative or constitutional oath.
('71', 385, 4, 17, 777439) His quarrel is purely over my designation of oaths.
('71', 385, 4, 18, 777491) If my designation is faulty, I would accept any other which succinctly shows the distinction I have pointed out and which the friend accepts by implication.
('71', 385, 4, 19, 777648) The mere linguistic meaning of the legislative oath is wholly different from the meaning that the law and tradition have given to it.
('71', 385, 4, 20, 777782) One not knowing the law and the tradition will certainly have the objection that Shri Shivprasad Gupta has raised.
('71', 385, 4, 21, 777897) Mere grammatical or linguistic meaning of a sentence divorced from its context and history has often been found erroneous and sometimes positively mischiev ous.
('71', 385, 4, 22, 778058) Therefore, knowing the context of the legislative oath, I had no hesitation in saying that there was not the slightest strain on or violation of truth when I suggested that a Congressman could, consis 
('71', 386, 0, 1, 778260) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 387
('71', 386, 1, 2, 778304) tently with his creed of complete independence and his resolution of wrecking the Constitution Act, take the oath required by law shortly described by me as legislative.
('71', 386, 1, 3, 778474) And here again my statement must be interpreted in its context and historical perspective.
('71', 386, 1, 4, 778565) A Congressman entering the Legislature will strive for gaining complete independence working within the law, and so will he try to wreck the Act working within the law.
('71', 386, 1, 5, 778734) If he can work for its amendment, he can quite properly work for its repeal, i.e., wrecking.
('71', 386, 1, 6, 778827) Indeed his deadlocks also will be within the law.
('71', 386, 1, 7, 778877) And he won't be frightened or hang his head low if his opponent twits him by saying that he is after all working the Constitution.
('71', 386, 1, 8, 779008) He will not, must not, care so long as he knows his mind, hides nothing and is downright honest in all his dealings.
('71', 386, 1, 9, 779125) Of course I agree with the Quaker friend that for a religiously or spiritually minded man religion or rather religious attitude pervades all his thoughts, words and acts.
('71', 386, 1, 10, 779296) But having said this I must adhere to my statement that for the multitudinous purposes of life we find it necessary to distinguish our activities as social, political, mercantile, religious, etc.
('71', 386, 1, 11, 779492) These divisions can be extended almost to infinity.
('71', 386, 1, 12, 779544) But the seeker of God will apply his godly attitude even to his sports if he finds time for them.
('71', 386, 1, 13, 779642) Harijan, 26 6 1937

('71', 386, 3, 29, 780455) Thus did nature help me.

('71', 389, 4, 10, 784560) 472. A GREAT EXPERIMENT 1
('71', 389, 5, 11, 784586) The Ahmedabad Labour Union has of late started a great experiment which is likely to prove of great interest and importance to all labour organizations.
('71', 389, 5, 12, 784739) The essence of the experiment consists in training its members to a supplementary occupation in addition to their principal occupation in the mills so that in the event of a lock out, strike or loss of employment otherwise, they would always have something to fall back upon instead of being faced with the prospect of starvation.
('71', 389, 5, 13, 785070) A mill hand’s life is ever full of vicisssitudes.
('71', 389, 5, 14, 785120) Thrift and economy no doubt provide a sort of remedy and it would be criminal to neglect them.
('71', 389, 5, 15, 785215) But the savings thus made cannot carry one far, seeing that the vast bulk of our mill labourers are always struggling on the margin of bare subsistence.
('71', 389, 5, 16, 785368) Moreover it would never do for a working man during strike or unemployment to rest idly at home.
('71', 389, 5, 17, 785465) There is nothing more injurious to his morale and self respect than enforced idleness.
('71', 389, 5, 18, 785552) The working class will never feel secure or develop a sense of self assurance and strength unless its members are armed with an unfailing subsidiary means of subsistence to serve as a second string to their bow in a crisis.
('71', 389, 5, 19, 785776) The idea of a subsidiary occupation for the mill hands was first conceived by me during the eventful twenty three days’ strike of the Ahmedabad mill hands in the year 1918. It occurred to me then that if the strike was to be successful the mill hands must have an occupation that would maintain them wholly or partly.
('71', 389, 5, 20, 786094) They must not
('71', 389, 6, 21, 786108) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 27 6 1937. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('71', 390, 0, 1, 786213) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 391
('71', 390, 1, 2, 786257) rely upon doles.
('71', 390, 1, 3, 786274) During the strike many of them were employed on unskilled labour.
('71', 390, 1, 4, 786340) It was then that I mooted my suggestion to teach mill hands a subsidiary occupation.
('71', 390, 1, 5, 786425) But my suggestion remained a dead letter till the next strike came.
('71', 390, 1, 6, 786493) A sort of a beginning was made then.
('71', 390, 1, 7, 786530) But it was difficult to bring into being all of a sudden an effective organization for teaching subsidiary occupations.
('71', 390, 1, 8, 786650) With the end of the second strike died also the effort to find and teach suitable occupations.
('71', 390, 1, 9, 786745) An organized and systematic effort is now being made by the Labour Union in that direction.
('71', 390, 1, 10, 786837) Mill hands are being taught to select occupations which they can practise in their leisure hours at home and which would give them substantial relief in times of unemployment.
('71', 390, 1, 11, 787013) These are ginning, cleaning, carding and spinning of cotton, weaving, tailoring, soap and paper making, type setting, etc.
('71', 390, 1, 12, 787136) I hold that a working knowledge of a variety of occupations is to the working class what metal is to the capitalist.
('71', 390, 1, 13, 787253) A lobourer’s skill is his capital.
('71', 390, 1, 14, 787288) Just as the capitalist cannot make his capital fructify without the co operation of labour, even so the working man cannot make his labour fructify without the co operation of capital.
('71', 390, 1, 15, 787473) And if both labour and capital have the gift of intelligence equally developed in them and have confidence in their capacity to secure a fair deal, each at the hands of the other, they would get to respect and appreciate each other as equal partners in a common enterprise.
('71', 390, 1, 16, 787747) They need not regard each other as inherently irreconcilable antagonists.
('71', 390, 1, 17, 787821) But the difficulty is that whilst today capital is organized and seems to be securely entrenched, labour is not.
('71', 390, 1, 18, 787934) The intelligence of the working man is cramped by this soulless, mechanical occupation which leaves him little scope or chance to develop his mind.
('71', 390, 1, 19, 788082) It has prevented him from realizing the power and full dignity of his status.
('71', 390, 1, 20, 788160) He has been taught to believe that his wages have to be dictated by capitalists instead of his demanding his own terms.
('71', 390, 1, 21, 788280) Let him only be organized along right lines and have his intelligence quickened, let him learn a variety of occupations, and he will be able to go about with his head erect and never be afraid of being without means of sustenance.
('71', 390, 1, 22, 788511) It is the grossest of superstitions for the working man to believe that he is helpless before the employers.
('71', 390, 1, 23, 788620) The effort of the Labour Union in Ahmedabad is to dispel this superstition in a concrete manner.
('71', 390, 1, 24, 788717) Its experiment, therefore, ought to be welcomed by all concerned.
('71', 390, 1, 25, 788783) Success will depend on an inflexible determination on the part of the Labour Union to follow up the good beginning that has
('71', 391, 0, 1, 788907) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 391, 1, 2, 788949) been made, with unflagging perseverance.
('71', 391, 1, 3, 788990) It must have the right sort of instructors who can arouse among the workers an intelligent interest in their work.
('71', 391, 1, 4, 789105) A handicraft plied merely mechanically can be as cramping to the mind and soul as any other pursuit taken up mechanically.
('71', 391, 1, 5, 789228) An unintelligent effort is like a corpse from which the sprit has departed.
('71', 391, 1, 6, 789304) Harijan, 3 7 1937
('71', 391, 2, 7, 789322) 473. MY NOTES
('71', 391, 3, 8, 789336) IS IT THEN NO MISTAKE?
('71', 391, 3, 9, 789359) Many people seem to have been hurt on reading my note entitled “My Mistake” 1 .
('71', 391, 3, 10, 789439) Of course readers of Harijanbandhu are all Gujaratis.
('71', 391, 3, 11, 789493) But Gujaratis are scattered in all Provinces and among them those who are alert know the customs and practices of the people in whose midst they live.
('71', 391, 3, 12, 789644) I have received letters from such persons residing in places as far off as Malabar, Tamilnadu, Andhradesh and Karnataka.
('71', 391, 3, 13, 789765) All of them write that my presumption was correct.
('71', 391, 3, 14, 789816) In all these Provinces, amongst Hindus both high and low so called, not only do marriages take place between a maternal uncle and his niece (sister’s daughter) but these marriages are highly estemed in most cases.
('71', 391, 3, 15, 790030) One correspondent asked for a lawyer’s opinion.
('71', 391, 3, 16, 790078) The lawyer wrote back that not only are such marriages customary in the South, but that they are also clearly sanctioned by law.
('71', 391, 3, 17, 790207) Thus, although the correction made by Professor Thakore does not to a certain extent hold good, the manner in which I drew my conclusion was nevertheless faulty.
('71', 391, 3, 18, 790369) The fact that what I had presumed happens to be true with regard to Hindu society, may be regarded as an accident.
('71', 391, 3, 19, 790484) From the fact that the children of a brother and sister are permitted to marry, I had no right to conclude that a girl could marry her maternal uncle.
('71', 391, 3, 20, 790635) Hence Professor Thakore has indeed done me a sevice.
('71', 391, 3, 21, 790688) I can understand the love of the gentlemen who have written to me having regard for my prestige.
('71', 391, 3, 22, 790785) I thank them for having informed me and I also compliment them for ascertaining the customs and practices of the Provinces in which they happen to reside.
('71', 391, 3, 23, 790940) Because such marriages are acceptable in the South, no one should conclude that the attempt to make them acceptable in places where they are prohibited, will be welcomed.
('71', 391, 3, 24, 791111) The field for marriages is so wide that where it is prohibited among relatives, there is hardly
('71', 391, 4, 25, 791207) 1 Vide “My Mistake”, 6 6 1937
('71', 392, 0, 1, 791237) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 393
('71', 392, 1, 2, 791281) any need for going against the prohibition.
('71', 392, 1, 3, 791325) The reforms which Hindu society needs are those concerning the breaking of inter caste barriers.
('71', 392, 1, 4, 791422) These restrictions are truly detrimental to social progress.
('71', 392, 1, 5, 791483) Hence it would be a real reform to permit inter provincial and inter caste marriages.
('71', 392, 1, 6, 791569) [From Gujarati]
('71', 392, 2, 7, 791585) Harijanbandhu, 27 6 1937
('71', 392, 3, 8, 791610) 474. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('71', 392, 4, 9, 791634) SEGAON, WARDHA, June 27, 1937
('71', 392, 6, 10, 791664) It is a mere sluit which collects and discharges rain water.
('71', 392, 6, 11, 791725) It therefore fills as rapidly as it discharges.
('71', 392, 6, 12, 791773) there was hardly 1/2 inch rain, not violent either.
('71', 392, 6, 13, 791825) But it was enough to fill the sluit rapidly.
('71', 392, 6, 14, 791870) You know the sluit.
('71', 392, 6, 15, 791890) It is like a belt round Segaon village.
('71', 392, 6, 16, 791930) The idea was to bridge it.
('71', 392, 6, 17, 791957) The bridge was made but the rushing water destroyed the earth work in front of and behind the bridge.
('71', 392, 6, 18, 792059) The water might easily have destroyed Khandu’s and Prahlad’s houses if the rain had continued 1. Therefore at considerable expense the sluit is reduced to its original state.
('71', 392, 6, 19, 792234) But there is no rain worth speaking about.
('71', 392, 6, 20, 792277) And Bombay had already 30 inches!
('71', 392, 6, 21, 792311) Ba returns tomorrow.
('71', 392, 6, 22, 792332) Spinning by the women has restarted.
('71', 392, 6, 23, 792369) Govind has gone to Kakasaheb at his own instance.

('71', 401, 7, 10, 804004) 491. LETTER TO KRISHNACHANDRA
('71', 401, 8, 11, 804034) SEGAON, July 2, 1937
('71', 401, 9, 12, 804055) KRISHNACHANDRA, The doubt you have raised is extermely pertinent.
('71', 401, 9, 13, 804121) I cannot say now how I could dicate such a meaningless sentence.
('71', 401, 9, 14, 804186) 2 Read it as follows: "But it should never be taken that the ancestors of an adharmaja were all dharmaja themselves or that his future progeny will all be dharmaja." There is no harm in learning and practising hatha yoga for the sake of physical health, but all the instructors are not fully well versed in it.
('71', 401, 9, 15, 804497) It has also been my experience that those who do not know the science and techniques of hatha yoga can even cause harm.
('71', 401, 9, 16, 804617) Moreover, everyone is not capable of performing each and every asana.

('71', 402, 0, 1, 805089) VOL.71 : 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 403
('71', 402, 1, 2, 805133) 492. DISCUSSION WITH AN AMERICAN 1
('71', 402, 2, 3, 805168) SEGAON, [Before July 3, 1937]
('71', 402, 3, 4, 805198) GANDHIJI: It involved intensive education, not in the three Rs, but in changed ways of thinking and changed ways of life.
('71', 402, 3, 5, 805320) To bring about that change in the people's mentality is a Herculean task.
('71', 402, 3, 6, 805394) But it is such because the way is the non violent way, the way of persuasion.
('71', 402, 3, 7, 805472) This method is any day slower than the method of compulsion, but it is also surer and stabler.
('71', 402, 4, 8, 805567) AMERICAN: But would it in any way help if the British were to retire?
('71', 402, 4, 9, 805637) Would you have been better if the British had retired 150 years ago?
('71', 402, 4, 10, 805706) I have no doubt.
('71', 402, 4, 11, 805723) We should begin anew and without at least the political handicap.
('71', 402, 4, 12, 805789) You talk of the pax Britannica.
('71', 402, 4, 13, 805821) I do not deny that they have introduced education of a sort, have built schools and colleges, and built an unrivalled railway system, But our difficulty is this, that whereas elsewhere all these things have made the countries prosperous, they have brought about an opposite result here.
('71', 402, 4, 14, 806108) Not only the wealth of the land but even our intelligence has been drained away.
('71', 402, 4, 15, 806189) The very life hope is gone.
('71', 402, 4, 16, 806217) I will not say that a miracle would happen the moment the British retire.
('71', 402, 4, 17, 806291) Only we shall begin our history anew.
('71', 402, 4, 18, 806329) India will then have her destiny in her own hands.
('71', 402, 4, 19, 806380) And mind you we do not want the British to go, if they will stay as friends and voluntary co operators.
('71', 402, 5, 20, 806484) But why, if they don't want this rule, do they tolerate it?
('71', 402, 5, 21, 806544) Why is a united will lacking?
('71', 402, 5, 22, 806574) There are numerous causes which I cannot go into now.
('71', 402, 5, 23, 806628) All have their share in it, but the root cause is perhaps indefinable.

('71', 403, 4, 12, 808216) But we will not die killing, though we might be killed.
('71', 403, 4, 13, 808272) It is a novel experiment, I know.
('71', 403, 4, 14, 808306) Herr Hitler, I know, does not accept the position of human dignity being maintained without the use of force.

('71', 403, 4, 19, 808849) I have reasoned out the doctrine of the sword, I have worked out its possibilities and come to the conclusion that man's destiny is to replace the law of the jungle with the law of conscious love.

('71', 404, 1, 2, 809779) G. I have said that we cannot accept Western models holusbolus.

('71', 404, 4, 10, 810417) surgery.

('71', 404, 4, 26, 811591) Until the man's last moment on earth you go on drugging him even by injecting.

('71', 405, 11, 33, 814009) 494. HINDI V. URDU
('71', 405, 12, 34, 814028) A correspondent says a great deal is being written against me in the Urdu Press in regard to my attitude towards Urdu.
('71', 405, 12, 35, 814147) They even go so far to suggest that though I speak about Hindu Muslim unity I am the most communally minded of all the Hindus.
('71', 406, 0, 1, 814274) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 407
('71', 406, 1, 2, 814317) I have no desire to defend myself against the suggestion referred to by my correspondent.
('71', 406, 1, 3, 814407) My life must be my credentials on my attitude regarding the Hindu Muslim question.
('71', 406, 1, 4, 814490) But the Hindi Urdu question is an evergreen.
('71', 406, 1, 5, 814535) Though I have expressed my views often enough on this question, they will bear repetition.
('71', 406, 1, 6, 814626) I shall simply enunciate my belief without advancing any argument in support.
('71', 406, 1, 7, 814704) I believe that 1. Hindi, Hindustani and Urdu are words denoting the same language spoken in the North by Hindus and Mussalmans and written in either Devanagari or Perisian script; repetition.
('71', 406, 1, 8, 814896) I shall simply enunciate my belief without advancing any argument in support.
('71', 406, 1, 9, 814974) I believe that 1. Hindi, Hindustani and Urdu are words denoting the same language spoken in the North by Hindus and Mussalmans and written in either Devanagari or Persian script; 2. Hindi was the name for this language used both by Hindus and Mussalmans before the word Urdu came to be used; 3. the word Hindustani also came to be used later (the date unknown to me) to denote the same speech; 4. both Hindus and Mussalmans should try to speak the language as understood by the vast mass of the people in the North; 5. at the same time many Hindus and many Mussalmans will persist in using Sanskrit words and persian or Arabic words respectively and exclusively.
('71', 406, 1, 10, 815637) This we shall have to bear so long as mutual distrust and aloofness continue.
('71', 406, 1, 11, 815715) Those Hindus who care to know a certain class of Mussalman thought will study Urdu written in Persian script, and similarly those Mussalmans who care to know a certain class of Hindu thought will study Hindi written in Devanagari script; 6. ultimately when our hearts have become one and we all are proud of India as our country, rather than our Provinces, and shall know and practise different religions as derived from one common source, as we know and relish different fruits of the same tree, we shall reach a common language with a common script whilst we shall retain provincial languages for provincial use; 7. the attempt to force one script or one form of Hindi on any Province or district or people is detrimental to the best interest of the country; 8. the common language question should be viewed apart from the religious differences;
('71', 407, 0, 1, 816563) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('71', 407, 1, 2, 816605) 9. Roman script cannot and should not be the common script of India.
('71', 407, 1, 3, 816674) The rivalry can only be berween Persian and Devanagari.
('71', 407, 1, 4, 816730) Apart from its intrinsic merit the latter should be the common script for all India because most of the provincial scripts have their origin in Devanagari and it is for them by far the easiest to learn.
('71', 407, 1, 5, 816933) At the same time no attempt whatsoever should be made to foist it upon Mussalmans and for that matter on those others who do not know it.
('71', 407, 1, 6, 817071) 10. I served the cause of Urdu, if it may be distinguished from Hindi, when at Indore 1 the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan at my instance accepted the definition given in Clause I, and when at Nagpur 2 at my instance the Bharatiya Sahitya Parishad accepted the definition and called the common langugage of inter provincial intercourse Hindi or Hindustani, thus giving fullest scope to both Mussalmans and Hindus to identify themselves with the effort to enrich the common language and to interpret the best provincial thought in that language.
('71', 407, 1, 7, 817608) Harijan, 3 7 1937
('71', 407, 2, 8, 817626) 495. A PLEA FOR THE VILLAGE CART
('71', 407, 3, 9, 817659) Shri Ishverbhai S. Amin of Baroda sends me a long note on animal power v.
('71', 407, 3, 10, 817733) machine power.
('71', 407, 3, 11, 817748) From it I copy the following relevant portion 3 .
('71', 407, 4, 12, 817798) Animal power is not costlier than machine power in fields or short distance work and hence can compete with the latter in most cases.
('71', 407, 4, 13, 817932) The present day tendency is towards discarding animal power in preference to machine power.
('71', 407, 5, 14, 818024) Take for example a bullock driven cart, costing Rs. 100 and Rs. 200 for the bullocks.
('71', 407, 5, 15, 818110) The bullocks can drive the cart at least 15 miles per day with a load of 16 Bengal maunds on rough sandy village roads.
('71', 407, 5, 16, 818230) This service will cost....
('71', 407, 5, 17, 818257) in total Rs. 1/6 per day., A one ton motor lorry will cost for 15 mles ....
('71', 407, 5, 18, 818333) Rs. 2/12, i.
('71', 407, 5, 19, 818346) e., Rs 1/6 per cartload of 16 Bengal maunds ....
('71', 407, 5, 20, 818395) A moror lorry may compete when it has to carry loads at a stretch for a long distance on a good metal road, where bullock carts seem too slow and uneconomical....
('71', 407, 5, 21, 818558) It is the slowness only which goes againjst the bulocks cart....
('71', 407, 5, 22, 818623) If a farmer has his own cart and travels in it, he has not to spend anything in the form of ready money but uses the produce of his own field in producing power by feeding bullocks.
('71', 407, 5, 23, 818805) Really grass and grain should be looked upon by the farmer as his petrol, and the cart the motor lorry, and bullocks the engine converting grass into power.
('71', 407, 5, 24, 818962) The machine will neither consume grass nor will it yield manure,
('71', 407, 6, 25, 819027) 1 In April 1935. 2 In April 1936. 3 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('71', 408, 0, 1, 819098) VOL.71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 409
('71', 408, 1, 2, 819141) an article of vast importance.
('71', 408, 1, 3, 819172) Then the villager has to have his bullocks; in any case he has his grass.
('71', 408, 1, 4, 819246) And if he has a cart, he is maintaining the village carpenter and the blacksmith; and if he is keeping a cow, he is maintaining a hydrogenation plant converting vagetabele oil into solid butter or ghee and also at the same time a bullock manufacturing machine thus serving a twofold purpose.
('71', 408, 1, 5, 819538) The invasion of the motor lorry may or may not succeed.
('71', 408, 1, 6, 819594) It would be wisdom if intelligent workers will study the pros and cons and definitely guide the villagers.
('71', 408, 1, 7, 819701) Shri Ishverbhai’s note should pro voke the thought of all village workers in the direction indicated in it.

('71', 408, 2, 9, 819827) 496. WHAT SHOULD BE DONE?
('71', 408, 2, 10, 819853) The letter, notice and application quoted below 1 are well worth reading.
('71', 408, 2, 11, 819927) I have omitted names and addresses.
('71', 408, 2, 12, 819963) The correspondent who has written this letter is devoted to ahimsa.
('71', 408, 2, 13, 820031) This question is pertinent.
('71', 408, 2, 14, 820059) One who resists the oppressor is, to some extent, saved; but one who has no strength to resist gets beaten.
('71', 408, 2, 15, 820167) What should a devotee of ahimsa do in such circumstances?
('71', 408, 2, 16, 820225) Should the oppressed be advised to hit back or at least take the matter to the court?
('71', 408, 2, 17, 820311) Both these proceedings are lawful.
('71', 408, 2, 18, 820346) The law allows a person to defend himself if he is illegally assaulted.
('71', 408, 2, 19, 820418) He of course has the right to go to the court.
('71', 408, 2, 20, 820465) But a devotee of ahimsa will not give such advice.
('71', 408, 2, 21, 820516) He believes that tit for tat is not the true way of ending oppression in the world.
('71', 408, 2, 22, 820600) The world has hitherto followed this path; but it has not reduced oppression only its forms may have changed.
('71', 408, 2, 23, 820710) As devotee of ahimsa will advise the oppressed to resort to non co operation.
('71', 408, 2, 24, 820788) No one can be compelled to slave for another.
('71', 408, 2, 25, 820834) Hence those Harijans who are oppressed should learn to quit the oppressors’ lands.
('71', 408, 2, 26, 820917) The questions naturally arises: Where should they go after quitting these lands?
('71', 408, 2, 27, 820998) It is the duty of a Harijan sevak to find some work or other for such helpless Harijans.
('71', 408, 2, 28, 821087) This should not be difficult.
('71', 408, 2, 29, 821117) The path of ahimsa is no doubt difficult, but its ultimate result is permanent and beneficial to both.
('71', 408, 2, 30, 821220) The world has been returning blow for a blow, but it has neither enhanced happiness not removed injustice and oppression.
('71', 408, 2, 31, 821342) My experience tells me that the only way to remove these is ahimsa.
('71', 408, 3, 32, 821410) 1 Not reproduced here.
('71', 408, 3, 33, 821433) They described the harassment of Harijan labourrers by landlords in villages.
('71', 408, 3, 34, 821511) The correspondent had asked whether the labourers should be advised to retaliate.

('71', 409, 1, 2, 821635) What I have said is the ultimate remedy.
('71', 409, 1, 3, 821676) But after deciding that blow is no answer for blow and before advising non co operation, the non violent worker will approach the landlords and endeavour to explain to them their duty.
('71', 409, 1, 4, 821861) It may well be that the landlords may melt a little.

('71', 415, 3, 4, 830885) RESOLUTION PASSED AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, DELHI 1
('71', 415, 4, 5, 830932) March 16, 1937
('71', 415, 5, 6, 830947) The All India Congress Committee records its high appreciation of the magnificent response of the country to the call of the Congress during the recent elections and the approval by the electorate of the Congress policy and programme.
('71', 415, 5, 7, 831182) The Congress entered these elections with its objective of independence and its total rejection of the new Constitution; and the demand for a Constituent Assembly to frame India’s Constitution.
('71', 415, 5, 8, 831376) The declared Congress policy was to combat the new Act and end it.
('71', 415, 5, 9, 831443) The electorate has, in an overwhelming majority, set its seal of approval on this policy and programme, and the new Act, therefore, stands condemned and utterly rejected by the people through the self same democratic process which has been invoked by the British Government, and the people have further declared that they desire to frame their own constitution, based on national independence, through the medium of a Constituent Assembly elected by adult franchise.
('71', 415, 5, 10, 831910) This Committee, therefore, demands on behalf of the people of India that the new Constitution be withdrawn.
('71', 415, 5, 11, 832018) In the event of the British Government still persisting with the new Constitution in defiance of the declared will of the people, the All India Congress Committee desire to impress upon all Congress members of the Legislatures that their work inside and outside the Legislatures must be based on the fundamental Congress policy of combating the new Constitution and seeking to end it, a policy on the basis of which they sought the suffrage of the electorate and won their overwhelming victory in elections.
('71', 415, 5, 12, 832526) That policy must inevitably lead to deadlocks with the British Government and bring out still further the inherent antagonism between British Imperialism and Indian Nationalism and expose the autocratic nature of the new Consititution.
('71', 415, 6, 13, 832762) THE BACKGROUND
('71', 415, 7, 14, 832777) While the British Governments’ reform as proposed in the Government of India Act (1935) had been totally rejected by the Bombay Congress session, at the Working Committee meeting held at Allahabad in April, 1936, the members differed widely in their views on the subject of office acceptance.
('71', 415, 7, 15, 833070) In the absence of a consensus, it was decided to review the matter after the elections in February, 1937. When the results of the elections were announced, the Congress had the majority of seats in five Provinces, namely, Madras, the United Provinces, the Central Provinces, Bihar and Orissa.
('71', 415, 7, 16, 833363) It was the biggest single Party in four Provinces,
('71', 415, 8, 17, 833414) 1Vide “Letter to Amritlal T. Nanavati”, 15 3 1937 and “Interview to the Press”, 19 3 1937 2 This was followed by the clause on office acceptance.
('71', 416, 0, 1, 833560) VOL. 71: 25 FEBRUARY, 1937 5 JULY, 1937 417
('71', 416, 1, 2, 833604) namely, Bombay, Bengal, Assam and North West Frontier Province.
('71', 416, 1, 3, 833668) In the Legislative Assmeblies of Sind and the Punjab, the Congress was in a minority.
('71', 416, 1, 4, 833754) The following extract from the The History of the Indian National Congress, shows the Party position in various Assemblies:
